headline: U.S. SAYS PRETORIA WAS TOLD OF A BLACK NOMINEE
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States had notified South Africa of the possibility that it might nominate a black North Carolina businessman as its next ambassador.   The officials said the South Africans had no immediate reaction to the potential appointment of Robert J. Brown, a move described by officials as part of the Administration's effort to suggest a change in the tone of its policy toward Pretoria.   Administration officials had no comment on disclosures that shortly after leaving the Nixon White House, where he was a special assistant, Mr. Brown became a partner in a company that received a Government contract without bidding through a program designed to aid disadvantaged minorities. Mr. Brown, who is now is a public relations executive in North Carolina, could not be reached for comment today.   At a 1977 hearing, Senator Lawton Chiles used the case of Mr. Brown as one of several examples of what he termed abuses in the Small Business Administration's 8(a) program for encouraging minority businesses. The program provided no bid Federal contracts to minority businesses.

headline: HOW TAX REFORM IS RESHAPING DIVORCE
abstract: ALTHOUGH the tax bill that is being hammered out by the House-Senate conference committee does not deal directly with divorce settlements, tax experts say it will reshape the agreements many couples make.   The most dramatic change expected in the bill -and the one likely to have the most effect on divorce settlements - is the sharp drop in the top tax bracket. But other parts of the tax bill, including the new personal exemptions and the changed treatment of capital gains, will also affect divorce settlements.   Tax experts and matrimonial lawyers say the new bill will make husbands less willing to pay their ex-wives alimony and more inclined to agree to larger property settlements instead - a development that may not be in the wives' best interest.

headline: ARMS SHIP LEAVES WAKE OF MYSTERY IN PERU
abstract: A small cargo ship flying the Danish flag radioed the nearby port of Callao on June 6 to say it would be docking shortly. Hours later, it turned around, sped north and left in its wake a mystery of conspiracy and corruption that has kept Peruvians entertained ever since.   Officials here said that Peru's President, Alan Garcia, had been tipped off by the Central Intelligence Agency that the ship, the Pia Vesta, was carrying contraband Soviet-bloc weapons for possible delivery to terrorist groups, and that when the vessel arrived at the port of Balboa on June 14, President Garcia asked Panamanian authorities to seize it.   But while inspection confirmed that its cargo had indeed been loaded in East Germany and comprised 32 trucks, 1,500 AK-47 automatic rifles and 1,500 antitank rockets of Soviet design, its owner seemed to be a Miami-based American arms dealer and its buyers anything but leftist guerrillas.

headline: Preparing A 'Pop-Up' For Time
abstract: THE Transamerica Corporation's nine-inch high, full-color ''pop-up'' advertisement that appeared in last week's Time magazine was the culmination of more than 10 months of preparations, technical problems and hand assembly in Latin America requiring 420,000 worker-hours. It also involved suspense up to the last moment as to whether the magazine might be harmed in mailboxes or crumpled in readers' pockets.   The ad, the centerfold in a five-page insert, cost $3 million, or 35 percent of the entire 1986 advertising budget of Transamerica, an insurance and financial-service company based in San Francisco. This compares with an ordinary double-page, four-color ad's costing about $229,000 plus $10,000 for color separation.

headline: HPECIAL TASKS IN CAPITAL FOR CITICORP EXECUTIVE
abstract: Citicorp's man in Washington is Thomas C. Gaspard, whose job is to take a once-failing savings and loan institution there and turn it into a slick Citicorp consumer operation.   Mr. Gaspard, 42, is chief executive of Citicorp Savings of Washington, formerly known as the National Permanent Bank. Citicorp bought the thrift institution for an undisclosed price from Federal regulators, and the Federal Reserve Board approved the transaction on Aug. 1.

headline: Ex-Im Bank Bill Passed
abstract: The House of Representatives today passed a two-year extension of the United States Export-Import Bank's authority to make loans to finance American exports. The bill, passed by voice vote, authorizes $1.8 billion in loans through Sept. 30, 1988. The bill now goes before the Senate.

headline: REBUFF TO REAGAN
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in a rebuff to President Reagan, said today that an American journalist restricted to Moscow was ''a spy caught red-handed.''   Mr. Gorbachev's remark, made on a provincial tour, was his first public comment on the case of Nicholas S. Daniloff of the magazine U.S. News & World Report, who has been restricted to Moscow on espionage charges.   The Soviet leader said the affair was being used by the United States to ''reap a harvest of hatred'' against the Soviet Union.  [ In Rome, an Italian official said that Mr. Gorbachev had put off an expected visit to Italy, and that it was believed the postponement reflected deteriorating prospects for a United States-Soviet summit meeting. Page A6. ]  Reagan Gave Assurances President Reagan has said that Mr. Daniloff, seized in Moscow and accused of espionage, was a ''hostage'' for the release of Gennadi F. Zakharov, a Soviet employee of the United Nations, who had previously been arrested in New York on spying charges.

headline: MARCOS TIE TO HOTEL TAKEOVER IS SEEN
abstract: Notes taken by a telephone operator during the takeover of the Manila Hotel last month appear to show both prior knowledge and direct involvement by former President Ferdinand E. Marcos from his exile in Honolulu.   A transcript of the notes, provided today by a Malacanang Palace source, quoted Mr. Marcos, in a series of telephone calls to the hotel, as giving instructions to two of the leaders of the takeover and urging them to call for his return to the Philippines.   ''Tell Turing to draft a resolution and send to Reagan at the White House stating you want me back there,'' the transcript quotes Mr. Marcos as having told one of his allies in the hotel.   Turing is the nickname of Arturo M. Tolentino, Mr. Marcos's running mate in the Feb. 7 election, who declared himself acting president at the start of the July 6 incident.

headline: Voest-Alpine Unit Sale in Jeopardy
abstract: A deal by Austria's state-owned giant Voest-Alpine to sell its deficit-ridden American subsidiary, Bayou Steel, has run into trouble just two weeks after Voest said the sale was a formality. A Voest spokesman, Fritz Orasch, said that negotiations over the deal had reached a stalemate after the buyer, the RSR Corporation of Dallas, had sharply cut its offer price at the last moment, citing troubles in the United States steel industry.

headline: PATENTS; A Meter Examines Intestinal Worms
abstract: Intestinal worms, known as helminths, can be examined by a meter patented this week by James L. Bennett and Ralph A. Pax of Michigan State University's department of pharmacology in East Lansing. The instrument is used to test the effectiveness of drugs against the parasites.  Patent No. 4,603,977 has been assigned to the Research Corporation, a foundation with offices in Tucson, Ariz., and Port Washington, L.I., which is offering licenses to industry.

headline: ICAHN FORECASTS PROFIT FOR T.W.A. IN 3D PERIOD
abstract: Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines, said yesterday that the airline would have a profit of about $70 million in the third quarter and that it would have a substantial profit in the fourth quarter.   Mr. Icahn also spoke of the need for further consolidation in the airline industry and said that T.W.A. was considering joining in the trend and linking up with another airline or company outside the airline industry.   However, Mark A. Buckstein, senior vice president of external affairs and general counsel at T.W.A., said that the airline was not currently talking with another company about joining forces.

headline: After Four Years, the Gavel Falls on Columbus
abstract: A longtime source of debate has finally been removed from the General Assembly's agenda: the issue of how the United Nations should observe the quincentenary of the 1492 discovery of America.   The item has aroused passions since it was first proposed to the Assembly four years ago by Spain's delegation after what was described by those present as a ''well-wined luncheon.''   Iceland's chief delegate at the time, Hordur Helgason, objected to the resolution because it ignored Leif Ericsson's visit to North America. African countries said the resolution glorified colonialism. And Ireland's delegates claimed Irish saints had visited the New World as well.

headline: INSTRUCTOR AT L.I. COLLEGE AMONG HIJACK VICTIMS
abstract: Syed Nesar Ahmad, who was killed by Arab terrorists in the hijacking of a Pan American World Airways jet in Pakistan Friday, was depicted by a colleague at a Long Island campus where he taught as an ''extremely loving, very compassionate'' person and scholar ''continually searching for a rational means to resolve conflict.''   Dr. Lawrence Weiss, president of Friends World College, with headquarters in Lloyd Harbor, L.I., where Mr. Ahmad, 44 years old, had taught and advised since 1982, said his specialty had been political science and political sociology.   Mr. Ahmad, the holder of two master's degrees, was a Ph.D. candidate at the State University of New York in Binghamton where he was scheduled to defend his dissertation in sociology next week, Dr. Weiss said.

headline: Will 'Son of Cube' Bring Another Bout of Rubikmania?
abstract: THERE might be someone, somewhere who is still agonizing over Rubik's Cube. But for the most part that frustrating artifact of the early 1980's has been retired to the attic, the garbage heap, and, with a bow to its elegance and ingeniousness, to the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art.   But Erno Rubik, the soft-spoken Hungarian architecture professor whose name it bears, is not one to fade from sight. He is about to mark his return with a puzzle that, if anything, is more difficult to solve than the once-ubiquitous cube, which during a three-year run generated sales that have been estimated at 100 million authorized copies, 50 million unauthorized ''knockoffs,'' and at least 10 million books explaining how it could be solved. The enterprise also netted millions of dollars for the Hungarian economy and its entrepreneurial son, Mr. Rubik.   The cube contained 26 smaller cubes in six bright colors that rotated on horizontal and verticle axes. The trick, as thousands of purchasers remember with despair, was to unscramble the smaller cubes so that they gave the larger cube six walls of solid colors. Mathemeticians figured that the cube could be arranged in 43 quintillion positions, or, more precisely, 43,252,003,274,489,856,000.

headline: Oil Prices Rise a Bit; Traders Are Watchful
abstract: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products rose moderately in the world oil markets yesterday. Analysts said traders had adopted a wait-and-see attitude about whether the production-limiting agreement reached by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries could send prices higher.   The near-month futures contract for West Texas Intermediate crude closed at $15.32 a barrel, up 35 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. On the London-based spot market, this American benchmark grade was $15.30, up 70 cents. The British Brent North Sea crude was $13.60 a barrel, up 60 cents, on the London market.

headline: Jet America Option Used
abstract: Alaska Air Group, in the midst of a bidding war for ownership of Long Beach-based Jet America Airlines Inc., said today it had exercised an option to buy 18 percent of the California carrier.   Alaska Air, based in Seattle, started a tender offer of $3.25 a share, or $14.3 million, for Jet America two weeks ago after getting the backing of its management and directors.

headline: Revlon Sues Ex-Employee
abstract: Revlon Inc. has filed suit against a former employee accusing him and other defendants of swindling $1.1 million by falsely billing the company over a four-year period.   In the complaint, filed yesterday in the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York, Revlon alleged that Roger Shelley, the concern's former vice president of corporate affairs and investor relations, authorized payments to two businesses from early 1983 to June 1986 for services that were never performed.

headline: TEXT OF CHINA'S STATEMENT
abstract: Following is the text of a Chinese statement on the case of John F. Burns, the Peking bureau chief of The New York Times, who was expelled yesterday. The statement was read in Peking by Xu Hui, an official of the State Security Bureau, to A. M. Rosenthal, executive editor of The Times, and Warren Hoge, the newspaper's foreign editor.   The Burns-McNally case is a grave one. They disregarded the laws of China, deliberately violating the law governing aliens entering into and exiting from the People's Republic of China. They broke into a military restricted zone of our country and took numerous photographs of classified objects.

headline: High Yen Cuts Toyota's Profit
abstract: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that its earnings fell 14.9 percent in the latest year as a result of the yen's surge in value.

headline: Key Rates
Syria Backs Talks to End Lebanese Civil War
abstract: Syria, the main power broker in Lebanon, voiced support today for proposed talks between Moslems and Christians on ending the 11-year-old Lebanese civil war.   Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad, gave his support when he met in Damascus with Moslem members of the Lebanese Cabinet, led by Prime Minister Rashid Karami.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Aluminum Company of America, Pittsburgh, said it had agreed in principle to acquire H-C Industries, a maker of plastic closures, steel crowns and packaging machinery for bottlers. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: BOLIVIA IMPOSES STATE OF SIEGE, ARRESTING HUNDREDS
abstract: The Government imposed a nationwide state of siege today in response to labor unrest and hundreds of arrests were reported. Troops surrounded 7,000 miners who were marching on La Paz to protest layoffs.   Low world prices for tin have been disastrous for Bolivia, throwing the economy into chaos, and the Government decided Monday to close most of the mines that provide the bulk of its export income.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JULY 3, 1986
abstract: The Economy    The U.S. and Western Europe agreed to a six-month truce in their most serious trade dispute in decades, and officials said a permanent settlement looked promising. Under the accord, Spain would keep its higher tariffs on American crops, but if those tariffs lead to a drop in the imports from recent levels, other members of the European Community would make up the difference. Officials said the move, involving $1 billion in American farm exports and U.S. retaliation against $1 billion in European goods, appeared to clear away most of the trade discord between the two sides. ''Both sides now have running room to negotiate the final settlement,'' said Commerce Secretary Baldrige.  [ Page D1. ]    World Bank officials are exploring ways to recycle Japan's global trade surpluses, projected this year at nearly $60 billion, to provide more growth capital for debtor countries, according to the bank's new president, Barber B. Conable Jr.  [ D7. ]

headline: Kaiser Cement Considers Sale
abstract: The Kaiser Cement Corporation said today that it was considering the sale of all or parts of the company and that it had retained the First Boston Corporation as an adviser.   The move comes a day after the Los Angeles investor David Murdock said he had raised his stake in Kaiser Cement to 22.1 percent, from 7.7 percent, and indicated that he intends to acquire up to 30 percent.

headline: Oil Stocks Continue to Strengthen
abstract: Oil stocks continued to dominate the market yesterday. The prices of all major oils were up and they accounted for nine of the 10 most actively traded issues. But, analysts nevertheless found yesterday's market weak and suggested that recent lows may have to be tested before any significant advance could be supported.

headline: Fed, in May, Decided To Stick With Policy
abstract: Federal Reserve Board policy makers voted, 11 to 1, at their meeting in May to leave basic monetary policy unchanged, according to minutes of the meeting released today.   But at its meeting on Tuesday and Wednesday, the Fed's Open Market Committee apparently made the decision to cut its benchmark discount lending rate to stimulate the economy. And on Thursday, the Fed announced a reduction to 6 percent, from 6 1/2 percent, in the discount rate, the fee it charges banks and other financial institutions for loans.

headline: Magazine Rebuffs Pergamon Offer
abstract: Scientific American Inc. has rejected a $61 million offer from Robert Maxwell, the chairman of Pergamon Press Ltd. in Britain, saying that Mr. Maxwell did not abide by the terms of the initial bidding. Scientific American, publisher of the scholarly monthly magazine, last week accepted a $52.6 million offer from a German publishing concern, Verlagsgruppe Georg von Holtzbrinck of Stuttgart.

headline: REPORTER'S CASE TERMED SERIOUS BY WHITE HOUSE
abstract: The Reagan Administration, stepping up its warnings to the Soviet Union, said today that the filing of espionage charges against an American reporter in Moscow was ''a matter of utmost seriousness'' for the United States.   Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said the United States had received ''no official notification'' that the Russians had charged Nicholas S. Daniloff, Moscow correspondent of U.S. News & World Report, with espionage. But Mr. Speakes said Mr. Reagan was ''concerned'' about the case and asserted that the continuing detention of Mr. Daniloff could have ''serious implications'' for United States-Soviet relations. Immediate Release Demanded    ''Daniloff is innocent,'' Mr. Speakes said. ''We want his immediate release and we do regard it as very, very serious.'' The White House spokesman declined to specify how United States-Soviet relations would be affected by the reporter's detention and the charges against him.

headline: Bond Prices Continue to Fall
abstract: Stronger-than-expected economic data sent bond prices tumbling yesterday for the second day. Credit markets were also discouraged by comments from Paul A. Volcker, Federal Reserve Board chairman, about the limited impact of a cut in the discount rate.   The price for the key 30-year Treasury bond fell by a point and a half in early trading, but recouped some of the loss later in the day to finish at 98 27/32, down a point from Tuesday, to yield 7.34 percent. Declines for shorter-term Treasury issues were less steep, ranging from 5/32 to 10/ 32.

headline: PINOCHET'S OPPONENTS: POLARIZED BY VIOLENCE AND LACKING A STRONG LEADER
abstract: The two-day general strike in Chile last week pointed out two major difficulties confronting Chileans who want Gen. Augusto Pinochet to give up power in favor of a democratically elected government.   One is the problem faced by the democratic opposition over its relations with the Communist Party and the militant left, which, along with the military and the police, are blamed for turning what was supposed to be a peaceful protest into a nightmare for many Chileans.   The other problem is what is widely perceived as the absence of a strong leader within the opposition forces, coupled with a more precise statement of the basis for a future government and the steps in a transition.   General Pinochet touched an opposition nerve on the point about violence when he asserted Friday, the day after the 48-hour strike ended, that the protest and other protests against him had united ''those who call themselves democrats with the anti-democrats and the terrorists.''

headline: A Bargain Price and a Personal Touch
abstract: DATING services do not stop at advertising in their pursuit of new names for their files. Some offer complimentary memberships; others even guarantee a certain number of dates.   Last year, when M. Elizabeth Dearheart bought Options, which matches single and married people, the club was dying. She had some luck drumming up new male members, and soon the men outnumbered the women.

headline: Chesebrough Sells Division
abstract: The American Home Products Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the hospital products division of Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. for $260 million.   The division supplies hospitals with products used for special feeding, cardiopulmonary care, incontinence, wound treatment and personal care.

headline: Divining the Dow
abstract: Is the stock market's sharp decline nearing a bottom? A check with three technicians yielded a bounty of answers - but no consensus. John A. Mendelson, the Dean Witter Reynolds analyst who turned bearish just before stocks began their slide, does not think the slump is over.

headline: Hunts' Plea Against Judge
abstract: Companies owned by the Hunt brothers asked a Federal appeals court today to remove District Judge Barefoot Sanders of Dallas from all proceedings involved with their bankruptcy case.   The Placid Oil Company, a subsidiary, and the William Herbert Hunt Trust Estate contended to the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit that Judge Sanders had possible business ties to banks involved in the case.

headline: People
abstract: * Terron Schaefer will join Bloomingdale's as vice president, marketing.    * Roy Herbert, Kathleen Kiley, Karen Larson and John Peebles were all promoted to senior vice president of HBM/Creamer, New York.    * Ransdall L. Thompson was elected senior vice president of Creswell, Munsell, Fultz & Zirbel    * Jay Burzon, executive vice president of American Health, was named group publisher of American Health, Mother Earth News and Sponsorship Marketing.

headline: GREEK PREMIER MAY DEMAND REMOVAL OF A-ARMS
abstract: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has told his Socialist Party's central committee that he has ''personally informed'' the United States that Greece may at some unspecified time demand the removal of nuclear weapons stored here.   Western officials said they were unaware of such an approach to the United States.   Mr. Papandreou also said that the threat against which Greece's armed forces were on guard came from Turkey, Greece's ally in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and not the country's Communist neighbors.

headline: The U.N. Today: Aug. 12, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on Decolonization - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Preparatory Commission for the International Sea-Bed Authority and the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea - 3:30 P.M.

headline: Employee Unions Sue Safeway
abstract: Safeway Stores Inc. said that unions representing its employees had filed suit in California Superior Court in Alameda County against the company; Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, and others, including Safeway shareholders and the banks providing financing for the pending leveraged buyout of the supermarket chain.   The suit does not seek a preliminary injunction to block the buyout, but asks the court to declare the transaction a fraud, restrain Safeway's assets and appoint a receiver so that the union's and employees' claims as creditors can be answered. Officials of Safeway and Kohlberg, Kravis said they believed the suit to be without merit and that they expected the buyout to proceed as planned.

headline: Fed Inactive On Dollar
abstract: Foreign central banks intervened to slow the decline of the dollar by making sizable purchases of the currency between May and the end of July, but the Federal Reserve Bank stayed out of the currency markets, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday. The dollar fell 9 percent against the yen and the Swiss franc and 5 percent against the mark and other currencies in the European Monetary System during those months, according to the bank's quarterly report. It remained stable against the Canadian dollar and rose 3 percent against the pound.

headline: 3 South Africans Hurt In Nightclub Attack
abstract: A hand grenade was hurled at a nightclub open to all races today, and the blast wounded three people and caused extensive damage, the Bureau for Information said.   The bureau is the official source of information on unrest under press restrictions that prohibit journalists from reporting unauthorized information on actions of the security forces, statements deemed to be subversive and information that could be construed as endangering public safety.

headline: First Oklahoma Halts Paying Debt
abstract: The First Oklahoma Bancorporation said it was temporarily suspending payment of the principal and interest on more than $130 million of debt and that further payments would await a management review. The company's major subsidiary and only banking unit, the First National Bank and Trust Company of Oklahoma City, was declared insolvent earlier this month and sold to First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles.   First Oklahoma said its assets now include the First National Center and other real estate in Oklahoma City, a state trust company and a ''significant portfolio of loans.''

headline: C.D.'s Off; Funds Rise
abstract: Yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts continued to drift gently downward for the week ended yesterday, while interest rates on money market mutual funds rose slightly.   According to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index, the average yield for six-month certificates of deposit dropped three basis points, from 6.79 percent to 6.76 percent, and the average yield of bank money market accounts, which compete directly with money market mutual funds, declined four basis points, to 6.20 percent from 6.24 percent.   The drop in yields extended to certificates of deposit with longer maturities, with one-year certificates off three basis points, to 7.06 percent; two-and-half-year certificates down two basis points, to 7.41 percent, and five-year certificates of deposit off by five basis points, to 7.85 percent.

headline: FOR CONTRAS, PROSPECT OF AID STIRS PREPARATION FOR COMBAT
abstract: Among Nicaraguan guerrillas, in their border bases and hidden bunkers, there is a prickly sense of preparing for war. With American aid coming, the battles that lie ahead seem to be approaching with a rush.   The signs that fighting will come soon are all around. Two top guerrilla leaders, Adolfo Calero and Arturo Cruz, flew into Honduras this week to discuss with other rebel officials how to use the millions of dollars in American weapons and training that the House of Representatives has approved. There were also celebrations of having finally won the crucial vote in the House for renewed American assistance.   At a rebel camp, pallets stacked with ammunition cases, food and boots lay neatly arranged in row after row, rigged with parachutes and ready to be loaded onto cargo planes that are to drop the supplies to rebel patrols deep inside Nicaragua.

headline: FOR CIVIL WAR VETERANS, NEITHER SPAIN WILL DIE
abstract: Here in this tiny village on the Jarama River, the scene of some of the bloodiest battles of the Spanish Civil War, four grizzled veterans sat playing cards in a senior citizens' center one day recently.   Outside, a few people braved the pounding Castilian sun to buy jugs of red wine from a passing truck. Several youths splashed in the swimming pool.   ''I was a blue,'' said two of the card-players matter-of-factly, referring to the color of the Nationalists. ''I was a red,'' said the two others.  ''Now we are merely equal,'' said one of the blues.

headline: Pact Set on Polish Debt
abstract: Polish authorities and Western bankers have signed an agreement for rescheduling more than $2 billion in debts due this year and next year.

headline: Silver Trader Gets Big Fine
abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said yesterday that Naji Robert Nahas, a Brazilian investor, had agreed to pay a $250,000 fine to settle charges that he and a group of others, including Nelson Bunker Hunt, illegally manipulated silver prices during the speculative debacle of the late 1970's.   The civil penalty was the largest ever assessed against an individual by the C.F.T.C. In addition to paying the fine, Mr. Nahas was suspended from trading on any futures markets for five years.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
Tunis Opens Inquiry On Ex-Prime Minister
abstract: Authorities have opened an inquiry into the disappearance of the former Prime Minister, Mohammed Mzali, official sources said today.

headline: LETHAL GAS FROM NATURE
abstract: In heavy concentrations, hydrogen sulfide gas is extremely poisonous. It is sometimes a hazard in mines that have deposits rich in sulfide ores.

A transcript of the notes, provided today by a Malacanang Palace source, quoted Mr. Marcos, in a series of telephone calls to the hotel, as giving instructions to two of the leaders of the takeover and urging them to call for his return to the Philippines.   ''Tell Turing to draft a resolution and send to Reagan at the White House stating you want me back there,'' the transcript quotes Mr. Marcos as having told one of his allies in the hotel.   Turing is the nickname of Arturo M. Tolentino, Mr. Marcos's running mate in the Feb. 7 election, who declared himself acting president at the start of the July 6 incident.

headline: Voest-Alpine Unit Sale in Jeopardy
abstract: A deal by Austria's state-owned giant Voest-Alpine to sell its deficit-ridden American subsidiary, Bayou Steel, has run into trouble just two weeks after Voest said the sale was a formality. A Voest spokesman, Fritz Orasch, said that negotiations over the deal had reached a stalemate after the buyer, the RSR Corporation of Dallas, had sharply cut its offer price at the last moment, citing troubles in the United States steel industry.

headline: PATENTS; A Meter Examines Intestinal Worms
abstract: Intestinal worms, known as helminths, can be examined by a meter patented this week by James L. Bennett and Ralph A. Pax of Michigan State University's department of pharmacology in East Lansing. The instrument is used to test the effectiveness of drugs against the parasites.  Patent No. 4,603,977 has been assigned to the Research Corporation, a foundation with offices in Tucson, Ariz., and Port Washington, L.I., which is offering licenses to industry.

headline: A.T.&T. Plan For Layoffs
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it planned to reduce the number of lower- and middle-level managers by offering them money to quit.   A.T.&T. did not set a goal for the reduced work force levels, but industry analysts estimated that between 10,000 and 25,000 managers might be asked to leave.

headline: 45,000 HOMES ARE DAMAGED
abstract: About 4,900 apartment buildings and 45,000 private homes were damaged in Moldavia by an earthquake and a strong aftershock this week, the Government newspaper Izvestia said today.   The article was the most detailed report of damage from the quake, which rocked the Balkans and part of the Soviet Union early Sunday.   It was the first mention of an aftershock Tuesday in Moldavia, which Izvestia said registered 5 on the Soviet scale.

headline: Dynamics, U.S. Set Deal on Jets
abstract: The Air Force and the General Dynamics Corporation, after months of negotiation, have agreed on a second multiyear contract for F-16 jet fighters totaling $4.3 billion. The contract, announced late   Monday in a brief listing of awards, calls for General Dynamics' Fort Worth division to provide 720 F-16's by May 1991.

headline: Eastern Loss Of $44 Million
abstract: Eastern Air Lines Inc., reeling from an industrywide fare war, reported yesterday a second-quarter loss of $44 million, compared with a profit of $25.5 million, or 37 cents a share, for the corresponding period a year ago.   Eastern's revenues declined 15.4 percent, to $1.1 billion, from $1.3 billion.

headline: Montreal Releases Sikh Accused of Conspiracy
abstract: One of five Sikhs arrested here last month on explosives-related conspiracy charges was freed today for lack of evidence. A preliminary hearing for the others was set for Wednesday.

headline: Texas Air
abstract: The Texas Air Corporation and Continental Airlines Inc. said that they had revised the terms of Texas Air's bid to acquire the shares of Continental that Texas Air does not already own. Under the proposed agreement, Continental common stock would be exchanged for $15.20 a share. The prior agreement called for each share to be exchanged for Texas air senior notes with a face value of $14.75.

headline: German G.N.P. In Rebound
abstract: West Germany's economy, the strongest in Western Europe, has rebounded after a slow start this year, the Federal Statistics Office said Friday.   The gross national product was up 2 percent in the second quarter, compared with the first three months of the year, and was up 3.3 percent compared with the second quarter of 1985.

headline: Louisiana Land Option Signed
abstract: The Dallas investor Harold Simmons disclosed that he had an option to buy 800,000 shares, or 2.9 percent of the outstanding stock, of the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company. An agreement on the option was signed June 26 between the Amalgamated Sugar Company, a concern controlled by Mr. Simmons, and Jefferies & Company, a Los Angeles securities dealer, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

headline: Israel Starts Deporting Black Hebrew Members
abstract: Israel has started deporting members of the United States-based Black Hebrew sect, a police spokesman said today.

headline: JOHN PAUL MOURNS THE WALL'S VICTIMS
abstract: Pope John Paul II today joined in the commemoration of those who died trying to cross the Berlin wall and called for the reconciliation of all peoples.   Addressing a group of West Germans at his regular general audience, the Pope said Roman Catholics in West Berlin were marking the 25th anniversary of the wall's construction today with a liturgical service for reconciliation.   ''Let us pray together with these our brothers and sisters, above all for the victims, and also for all the persons and families that have directly suffered from it,'' he said to a crowd of several thousand people in the Pope Paul VI Audience Hall at the Vatican.

headline: HUSSEIN FACES DOMESTIC PROBLEMS AS HE ORDERS ARAFAT OFFICES SHUT
abstract: Military policemen, heavily armed and backed by pickup trucks bristling with .50-caliber machine guns, went about the business of shutting Palestinian guerrilla offices here today, sealing the doors with red wax.   But for King Hussein of Jordan, the mounting struggle with Yasir Arafat is only one of a host of problems.   In the four months since the King split with the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, blaming him for the failure of their joint peace initiative, Jordan appears to have entered a period of uncertainty and drift, according to Jordanian, Palestinian and diplomatic sources here.   The break appears to be a turning point. The King has told visitors that he has come to the ''end of the line'' with Mr. Arafat.

headline: I.M.F. FILLING A KEY POST
abstract: Jacob A. Frenkel, a leading international economist who has taught for the last 13 years at the University of Chicago, will become research chief at the International Monetary Fund, succeeding William C. Hood, a former deputy finance minister of Canada, who is retiring.   An announcement has yet to be made, but people at the I.M.F. and in international monetary circles confirmed the appointment of the 43-year-old, Israel-born academic to the key post at the 151-nation lending agency. Mr. Frenkel himself could not be reached.

headline: Norton Head Says Concern Is 'Leaner'
abstract: John M. Nelson, who has spent his entire career at the Norton Company, a maker of abrasives, engineering materials and petroleum and drilling products, was named the concern's president and chief operating officer yesterday. The post was last held in 1980 by Donald R. Melville, now the chairman and chief executive officer.   Mr. Nelson, 54 years old, started as a sales trainee fresh out of the Harvard Business School in 1959, selling grinding wheels in Chicago. He worked his way up to vice president and general manager of the grinding wheel division in 1967 and in 1978 became a group vice president and chief executive of Norton-Christensen, manufacturers of drilling products and systems in Salt Lake City.

headline: ULSTER'S PROTESTANTS MARCH TO TRADITIONAL TUNE OF 'NO!'
abstract: The Rev. Ian Paisley, carrying on a ''no surrender'' tradition that goes back three centuries, paraded past crowds of cheering Protestant loyalists today. His appearance was plainly designed to scotch talk that his time is passing as leader of the province's resistance to political change.   ''There's our man!'' shouted a parade watcher as Mr. Paisley offered a white-gloved wave and a tip of his black bowler hat while a band boomed out ''The Wild Colonial Boy.''   ''Ulster still says no!'' he shouted, beaming.

headline: BankAmerica and Arco Sell Plaza
abstract: The BankAmerica Corporation and the Atlantic Richfield Company said today that they had signed an agreement to sell their interests in the Arco Plaza in downtown Los Angeles to the Shuwa Investments Corporation.   Shuwa, a California corporation, is a subsidiary of the Shuwa Company of Tokyo, one of Japan's largest developers of commercial buildings.

headline: Fannie Mae Offer
abstract: The Federal National Mortgage Association is offering $900 million of 7 percent debentures due 1991 at a price of par through various securities dealers. When the interest rate was announced yesterday morning, the new five-year agency issue yielded about 32-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes of comparable maturity.

headline: DESPITE SETBACKS, A STILL-LARGER-THAN-LIFE TEXAS FAMILY
abstract: Even as the Hunt financial empire seems to be crumbling, the Hunt family, which includes 15 children whom H. L. Hunt fathered by three women over 35 years, remains the stuff that makes television soap operas and potboiler novels pallid by comparison.   It is a family whose members say things such as ''a billion dollars isn't what it used to be,'' that continues its patriarch's superstition of giving its companies six-letter names starting with the letter ''P'' (the company that went into Chapter 11 yesterday is Placid, the oil-drilling company is Penrod and an investment company set up in connection with the family's silver trading was Profit) and whose internal divisiveness is legend.   ''Texans still regard them as larger than life in a state that's larger than life,'' said Jerome Tuccille, the author of ''Kingdom, the Story of the Hunt Family in Texas.'' The Latest Drama    The latest drama surrounds three of the sons of Lyda Bunker and H. L. Hunt, the eccentric one-time professional gambler who parlayed a few oil leases bought with money made at the poker table into one of the nation's largest fortunes.

headline: PHILIPPINE CHURCH BLAST KILLS 8
abstract: Moslem rebels tossed a grenade inside a Roman Catholic church during a wedding mass today, killing 8 people and wounding 56, the military authorities said.   Two of those believed involved in the attack at the church in the town of Salvador, in Lanao del Norte Province 500 miles south of Manila, were later shot and killed by soldiers, authorities said.   Col. Raul Aquino, the commander of the army brigade in the province, said in a telephone interview that the slain attackers were members of Moro Islamic Liberation Front, one of three Moslem factions in the region.

headline: 2 WALL STREET FIRMS WIDEN DRUG TESTING OF THEIR EMPLOYEES
abstract: Two Wall Street firms have toughened their drug testing programs of employees, apparently becoming the first brokerage houses to check not just incoming, but existing employees for use of illegal drugs.   Kidder, Peabody & Company and Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company said yesterday that the firms had recently made the changes. Kidder began its program last month and had all of its management committee members take urine tests, which they passed, a Kidder executive said. The program upgrades the firm's policy of testing all incoming employees for drug use.

headline: QUAKE TOLL IN SOUTH GREECE RISES TO 17 DEAD AND 8 TO 12 MISSING
abstract: At least 17 people were reported dead today and 8 to 12 were missing in an earthquake that struck a southern port town on Saturday night. Thousands of people were left homeless.   Rescue workers were searching the rubble of the Kalamata, on the southern shore of the Peloponnesus, the southernmost region of mainland Greece. When shovels and other equipment were not at hand, some were grappling at stones and chunks of fallen concrete with their bare hands.

headline: ITALIAN MILITARY SCANDALS SPUR CALL FOR CHANGE
abstract: First there were several suicides in barracks and revelations of violent hazing. Then a general cursed at his troops. And now three soldiers are dead after an accident during maneuvers.   These events have combined to focus attention on the Italian military this summer and to produce a growing number of proposals for change.

headline: U.S. AND EGYPT PLAN MANEUVERS CLOSE TO LIBYA
abstract: Egypt and the United States will conduct military exercises this week over the Mediterranean Sea not far from waters claimed by Libya, the Defense Department said tonight.   The exercises, which the department said have been planned ''for a long, long time,'' are designed to provide the Egyptian Air Force with practice in defending that nation's air bases, a Pentagon official said.   He said American and Egyptian forces, which will also include naval units, would not cross into the Gulf of Sidra. Libya claims the gulf as part of its territory but the United States considers it international waters and . warplanes of the two nations have clashed there in the past.

headline: Colombia Frees Suspect
abstract: Jorge Luis Ochoa Vazquez, reputed head of a major cocaine ring, was freed from jail despite American attempts to extradite him for trial on drug-smuggling charges, officials in Colombia said today. Authorities said Mr. Ochoa Vasquez dropped out of sight Wednesday after receiving a 20-month suspended sentence and a $1,000 fine on charges of falsifying documents.

headline: Key Rates
NICARAGUA FAMILY SAGA (CONT.): A WAR, A WEDDING
abstract: When Claudia Chamorro Barrios is married in Mexico on Tuesday, many members of her illustrious Nicaraguan family will be present to wish her well.   But two of her favorite relatives will be absent, both of them too busy to tear themselves from their opposing crusades.   Xavier Chamorro Cardenal, the uncle who doted on Claudia, cannot spare time away from Nuevo Diario, the pro-Sandinista daily newspaper he edits in Managua.   The other absentee will be Claudia's older brother, Pedro Joaquin Chamorro Barrios, who lives in exile in Costa Rica. He cannot attend the wedding because he spends Tuesdays putting together his virulently anti-Sandinista weekly Nicaragua Hoy, a tabloid that circulates in seven Latin American countries.

headline: Robertshaw Seeks Buyer for Company
abstract: The Robertshaw Controls Company, which makes residential and commercial thermostats and other electrical products for the home and car, said yesterday that it would seek a buyer for the company, reportedly at the insistence of its largest shareholder, the Reynolds Metals Company.   Robertshaw, which has 5 Reynolds representatives on its 15-member board, announced yesterday that it had hired Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment banking firm, to seek a buyer. It said the action had been taken to maximize the value to all of its shareholders.

headline: The U.N. Today: Aug. 19, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Preparatory Commission for International Seabed Authority and Law of the Sea Tribunal - 10:30 A.M.   Law of the Sea, Special Commission 2 - 10:30 A.M.   Law of the Sea, Special Commissions 3 and 4 - 3 P.M.

headline: A MERGED DDB GETS A LAST SALUTE
abstract: MOMENTS before the conclusion of the stockholders' meeting yesterday at which Doyle Dane Bernbach was merged out of independent existence and into the Omnicom Group, Paula Green, who had been a copywriter at the agency during its glory days two decades ago, stood up and injected a little emotion into what had until then been a perfunctory, by-the-numbers affair.   Ms. Green, who now owns her own small agency, said she wanted to pay tribute to the men who had founded DDB in 1949. Ned Doyle, Maxwell Dane and William Bernbach, she said in a quavering voice, had ''put all of us on our way'' and engendered ''love and honor and respect'' among those who worked with them.   Alluding to the role the agency played during the late 1950's and 60's in setting a new standard of creativity for the industry, she concluded by saying: ''I would like to see the tradition continue, even though the name may change.''

headline: President Is Chosen By Marine Midland
abstract: The Marine Midland Banks Inc. announced yesterday that it had named Geoffrey A. Thompson president and chief operating officer, effective at the end of the year.   Mr. Thompson, 45 years old, will fill a position that has been vacant since 1983 when John R. Petty, 56, moved from president to become chairman of the holding company, Marine Midland Banks Inc., and the bank. Mr. Thompson will also be president of both the holding company and the bank.   Mr. Petty operates the bank with an office of the chairman, and the bank said yesterday that that system would continue. Mr. Petty, Mr. Thompson and four other sector executives will make up the office.

headline: CONSTRUCTION SPENDING ADVANCED 0.5% IN JULY
abstract: Construction spending advanced five-tenths of 1 percent in July, the best performance since April, as strength in single-family homes helped offset declines in office buildings and apartments, the Commerce Department reported today.   The increase put total spending for private and public construction projects at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $376.7 billion in July after gains of one-tenth of 1 percent in both June and May and a 1.7 percent surge in April.   Construction spending in the first seven months of the year ran 6.7 percent ahead of the pace set a year earlier. Construction, helped by falling interest rates, has been one of the few bright spots in the economy.

headline: Taiwan Trade Surplus
abstract: Taiwan registered a record trade surplus of $1.58 billion in August, surpassing the previous record of $1.43 billion set in July, a Government agency reported today. It said that for the first eight months of this year, Taiwan's trade surplus came to a record $9.86 billion, up 46 percent from the period last year. The agency attributed the surpluses to lower oil prices and increased exports, mainly to the United States and Japan.

headline: THE PEERAGE, BRITAIN'S ULTIMATE EXECUTIVE PERK
abstract: SOON after the honor was announced to Ralph Halpern, one of England's highest-paid and hardest-driving business executives, that the Queen was dubbing him ''Sir Ralph,'' he sent a note of congratulations to all 30,000 workers in his own empire of specialty clothing shops, telling them they shared the honor.   That was democratic behavior by the newest knight, but Sir Ralph still kept the ''Sir'' for himself. He felt personally honored for ruling over the revival of his kingdom, the Burton Group, as a booming enterprise of 1,500 outlets.   ''I'm only third-generation English - the family came from Vienna - so knighthood is most special to me, a great honor,'' he explained.   Sir Ralph is one of the latest crop of British business executives to join a privileged circle of commoners singled out twice a year for that particularly kind word from the sovereign -be it ''Lord,'' the highest of all honors, or ''Sir'' or something lower in the hierarchy. All are relishing that rarest board room perk, the Queen's honors, which money is not supposed to be able to buy.

headline: CHILEAN JUNTA MEMBER CALLS FOR 'FULL DEMOCRACY' IN '89
abstract: A member of the ruling military junta today repeated his announced intention to retire in three years, further eroding support for Gen. Augusto Pinochet to continue ruling past 1989.   The comments by Gen. Fernando Matthei, the Air Force commander, came a day after two other members of the four-member junta indicated that they would not necessarily support General Pinochet in a referendum on his rule scheduled for 1989.   ''Full democracy begins in 1989,'' General Matthei told the newspaper La Segunda. ''As of that date, there is nothing left for me to do. There will be an elected congress, political parties and everything that represents a full democracy.''

headline: IN THE NEW HAITI, SMUGGLERS FIND A PARADISE
abstract: The little harbor here on the north coast of Haiti used to be a favorite hangout for pirates. Then, farther back than anyone can remember, it became a haven for smugglers. Lately, business has been booming. When President Jean-Claude Duvalier fled into exile last February, the 15,000 Tontons Macoute, the security men who had protected him and plundered as they pleased, also fled or dropped out of sight, leaving something of a power vacuum.   Suddenly, there was no one taking a cut from the smugglers and no one to back up whatever demands were made by customs agents for duties on goods that came across the wharf legally. Gone, also, were the so-called anti-contraband squads that used to raid ships and warehouses and then sell the goods.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Alaska Airlines Inc., Seattle, said it had reached agreement with its pilots on a voluntary wage reduction of 8.63 percent.    * Ashton-Tate Co., Culver City, Calif., said it had signed a three-year, $42.1 million contract with its French distibutor for the production, translation, distribution and marketing of French language versions of Dbase III Plus, Framework II and its Multimate word processing product line.    * Autospa Corp. said its real estate subsidiary had entered agreements with International Courtyards Inc. providing for the development, over three years, of 800 Autospa locations.

headline: REAGAN MAY SEEK TAX BILL CHANGES AFTER ENACTMENT
abstract: President Reagan could seek to revise the House-Senate version of the tax bill once it is enacted, White House officials said today.   By supporting the bill and yet raising the possibility of making changes in the future, the Administration hopes to insure that the sweeping proposal becomes law when Congress returns next month. The Administration has become concerned about a possible Senate filibuster by opponents of the version that was approved Saturday by the conference committee.   Officials at both the White House and Treasury said that parliamentary procedures in the Senate made it virtually impossible for the Administration to revise the tax bill before passage, even if it wanted to. These procedures do not allow the bill to be amended; the only options are passage, rejection or a filibuster.

headline: LEASE FINANCE ORDERS 30 JETS
abstract: The International Lease Finance Corporation said that it ordered 30 commercial jet aircraft worth $840 million in three separate transactions.   The company said it has signed definitive lease agreements or is finalizing lease agreements with nine airlines for all 30 planes.

headline: American Brands' Rise
abstract: Takeover speculation revived yesterday around American Brands Inc., causing the company's stock to rise sharply on heavy trading.   For months, there have been rumors that Revlon Group Inc., the company acquired last year by Ronald O. Perelman, might attempt to gain control of American Brands, a tobacco and consumer products concern.

headline: 11 Are Feared Killed By Storms in Britain
abstract: Heavy rain from the tail of Hurricane Charley flooded rivers and coastal towns in Ireland and Britain today and at least 11 people were feared killed by the floodwaters.   The storm, with gale-force winds, swept across southern Ireland on Monday and earlier today, causing at least six storm-related deaths. The storm then struck Britain, and five people were reported missing and feared drowned in England, Scotland and Wales.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM THE ADDRESS BY AQUINO BEFORE CONGRESS
abstract: Following are excerpts from an address by President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines to a joint meeting of Congress today:   My predecessor set aside democracy to save it from a Communist insurgency that numbered less than 500. Unhampered by respect for human rights, he went at it with hammer and tongs. By the time he fled, that insurgency had grown to more than 16,000. I think there is a lesson here to be learned about trying to stifle a thing with the means by which it grows.

headline: JAPANESE, CITING NUCLEAR BAN, PROTEST U.S. SHIPS
abstract: Port calls by United States warships touched off scattered demonstrations across Japan today as protesters accused the Americans of bringing in nuclear weapons in violation of Japanese policy.   American officials, in keeping with policy, refused to say whether or not nuclear weapons were aboard the ships.   By far the biggest protest today occurred in the southern city of Sasebo, where a United States battleship, the New Jersey, sailed into port for a nine-day stay.   As the 45,000-ton ship entered Sasebo Bay, it was approached by 47 fishing boats and other small vessels filled with anti-nuclear demonstrators. They were kept far away by an equal number of patrol boats from Japan's Maritime Safety Agency.

headline: WEAK G.N.P. DATA EXPECTED
abstract: Figures on the gross national product for the second quarter, due to be released tomorrow, will provide economists with their first real clues about the shape of the economy in the current quarter and give the credit markets new reasons for hope or despair about prospects that the Federal Reserve Board will cut the discount rate again this year.   Economists as well as the markets are expecting the figures to show an anemic 1 percent to 1.5 percent annual rate of expansion in the economy during the April to June period. But interpretations differ as to what that weakness signifies for economic growth and hence for the Fed's intentions.   ''I don't see the Fed rushing to implement easier monetary policy, but I don't think it can wait until the end of the year,'' said Norman Robertson, the chief economist for the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. ''Another month of these listless economic statistics and I think you'll have a cut in the discount rate by Labor Day.''

headline: Analysts' View Of Bank Stocks
abstract: WALL STREET analysts are selective in picking their favorites among New York City banks and other money center banks in the wake of the $640 million quarterly loss reported Wednesday by the BankAmerica Corporation. Although the magnitude of this loss - the second largest for an American bank - came as a surprise, analysts were quick to note that it represented a long-identified problem.   BankAmerica officials attributed the loss mainly to loans to energy and real estate companies. A significant part of the loan write-offs, too, covered private borrowing in the Middle East.

headline: Italy Balks at Citrus Pact
abstract: Italy will veto an agreement negotiated by the United States and the European Community to end a trade dispute unless the pact is changed radically, Italian Trade Ministry officials said today.   They told a news conference that the European Community's Commissioner for Trade Relations, Willy de Clercq, who represented the community in the talks, had not taken Italy's interests into account.

headline: MITSUBISHI TO ACQUIRE SILTEC
abstract: The Siltec Corporation, one of the two major American producers of silicon wafers used to make computer chips, said today that it had agreed to be acquired by the Mitsubishi Metal Corporation of Japan in a $32 million deal.   The sale highlights a problem that has gotten little attention: American chip makers, even as they struggle to compete with the Japanese, are becoming more dependent on Japanese companies for raw materials.   The acquisition would leave the Monsanto Company as the last major American supplier of silicon wafers, which are the raw materials used in producing semiconductors.

headline: FOR SHCHARANSKY IN PARIS, EMBRACES AND DOUBTS
abstract: Amid a round of Russian bear hugs, Anatoly Shcharansky met one night this week with a small group of French intellectuals and fellow former Soviet dissidents, some of whom he had not seen since his arrest in Moscow nine years ago.   ''It's amazing! He looks exactly the same,'' said Alexander Ginzburg, who with Mr. Shcharansky helped found the Helsinki Watch Committee in 1976 to monitor Soviet violations of human rights.   ''That's what being free does for you,'' Mr. Ginzburg added. ''My first year in the West, in 1979, I looked five years younger. But after a while in the West, after I thought about all that had happened, I suddenly aged 10 years.''

headline: Advertising; Print for Frye Boots
abstract: Frye Boots, the 123-year-old shoe manufacturer, will initiate its first consumer print campaign since Stanley Kravetz bought the company from Alberto-Culver last July. Ally & Gargano put together the two- and three-page black and white 1960's nostalgia package, which will first appear in three issues of Rolling Stone, beginning with the Aug. 28 issue.

headline: Secure-Phone Contracts Let
abstract: The National Security Agency has awarded initial production contracts to three companies for a new generation of scrambler telephones.   The contracts, announced by the Defense Department today, total $190 million and call for production of almost 50,000 of the new secure telephones for Government offices.

headline: 5 Executed in China
abstract: Two police officers and three railway workers were executed this month for a series of murders, rapes and armed robberies in the northern Chinese city of Jinzhou, the official China Legal News newspaper said today. The five men used firearms, hand grenades and other weapons to carry out at least 29 crimes between March 1979 and January of this year, the paper said. ''On Aug. 7, their life of crime ended on the execution ground in a volley of gunfire,'' it said.

headline: NO INCREASE IN SPENDING EXPECTED
abstract: Even if interest rates drop further in coming days, capital spending, which has been depressed, is unlikely to revive any time soon, business analysts say.   Interest rates, including the prime rate used by banks to set rates for loans to most medium-sized and small corporate borrowers will fall,the analysts say, in response to the Federal Reserve's decision last week to again lower its discount rate, the rate it charges on loans to financial institutions.   But with factories working at roughly 78 percent of capacity and with the effects of the proposed tax changes uncertain, they say, a drop in rates alone will hardly matter when it comes to business executives' decisions to invest in new plants and equipment.   Indeed, executives have repeatedly revised downward their spending plans even as rates have dropped steadily this year. Last fall, for instance, executives told the Commerce Department that they planned to increase spending by 2.4 percent in 1986 over 1985. By last spring, the figure had slipped to 2.3 percent, and in June respondents were predicting a rise of only two-tenths of 1 percent. By comparison, spending rose 9 percent in 1985 and 16.3 percent in 1984.

headline: Countersuit Against Perot
abstract: The developer William T. Criswell denied accusations of fraud made last week by H. Ross Perot, the wealthy businessman and chairman of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation.

headline: U.S. MAKES OFFER ON MID-RANGE ARMS
abstract: The United States has offered to the Soviet Union a new proposal on medium-range arms that would limit each side's weapons to 200 missile warheads, according to Administration and diplomatic sources.   The proposal, which officials disclosed today, was put forward Thursday at the Geneva arms talks.   Administration officials have previously said the United States was prepared to agree to a Soviet suggestion that each side deploy only token medium-range missile forces in Europe.   But officials disclosed today that the Administration had incorporated the Soviet suggestion into a new comprehensive approach to limiting medium-range missiles in Europe and Asia. The American proposal also marks a modest shift in its position on how to limit Soviet missiles in Asia, which has been one of the most contentious issues.

headline: Talks Planned in Peking On Chinese-Soviet Ties
abstract: A ninth round of talks aimed at improving relations between China and the Soviet Union will begin in Peking next month, the first formal discussions between the Communist powers since Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, called for better relations in July, Chinese officials said today.

headline: CONSCRIPTS COME HOME, WELL-DRILLED SANDINISTAS
abstract: During his two years in the Sandinista army, Marlon Antonio Flores fought off rebel ambushes, survived bombardment and lived in inhospitable mountains for months at a time.   But as he was officially discharged from the army on a recent Saturday afternoon, Mr. Flores said his ''revolutionary work'' was far from over.   ''The army changed me a lot,'' he said. ''There was political instruction all the time. You come back very aware of your responsibility to the revolution.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, AUGUST 16, 1986
abstract: The Economy    Agreement on a tax revision bill was reported by Senator Bob Packwood after 12 hours of negotations with Representative Dan Rostenkowski. The 20 other members of the conference committee were to meet later today to discuss and possibly vote on the agreement. The accord had earlier been thought to be near until a serious obstacle arose Thursday: projections indicating that an additional $17 billion in revenues would be needed.  [ Page 1. ]  The projection that a sagging economy would reduce Federal revenues was bitter news to the tax negotiators.  [ 37. ]  The effort at tax overhaul continued to display the makings of high legislative drama.  [ 35. ]    Output at factories, mines and utilities fell in July, for the third consecutive month. The 0.1 percent decline was less than in May or June, but still produced the first three-month drop since the 1982 recession.  [ 35. ]  Producer prices fell 0.4 percent in July, the fifth decline of the year.  [ 36. ]

headline: Auto Sales Rise 8.9%
abstract: Sales of new American made automobiles increased 8.9 percent in the first 10 days of July compared with the corresponding period in 1985, the seven major manufacturers reported today. Analysts attributed the gain to the new round of low-interest sales incentives offered by many of the domestic car makers.   Light-truck sales, meanwhile, declined 1.9 percent in the period. But the surge in car sales was sufficient to increase the overall market for vehicles sold by 5.1 percent.

headline: U.S. Planes in NATO Games
abstract: The United States will send six Air Force units to England next week to take part in an annual NATO exercise involving tactical fighter aircraft, the Pentagon said today. Units from Canada, Belgium, Denmark, France, the Netherlands, West Germany and Britain will also take part in the exercise, which will be held from Aug. 4 to 8.

headline: Coke Dropping Dr Pepper Bid
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it was ending its agreement to acquire the Dr Pepper Company, at the request of Forstmann Little & Company, an investment firm that bought Dr Pepper in February 1984.   The Federal Trade Commission had said in June that it would fight the $470 million acquisition on the ground that it was anticompetitive.

headline: MILITARY ELECTRONICS STOCKS SURGE
abstract: Leading a general rise in military electronics stocks, Sanders Associates' shares soared $5.125 yesterday, to $61.875, exceeding the $60-a-share takeover agreement announced Wednesday with the Lockheed Corporation.   Traders interpreted the price rise as suggesting that Lockheed's agreement might not be the last word.   Sanders was the volume leader on consolidated turnover of nearly 3.2 million shares. Lockheed was also active, falling $3.125, to $52.125.

headline: Canada's Joblessness
abstract: Canada's unemployment rate declined one-tenth of 1 percent in June to a seasonally adjusted level of 9.5 percent, the Government said today. Statistics Canada, which compiles jobless figures, estimated that almost 11.7 million were employed last month, up 49,000 from May, when unemployment stood at 9.6 percent. The Government agency said most of the increase in employment resulted from hiring to carry out the 1986 census.

headline: WHAT THEY SAY ABOUT MARSEILLES: IT'S CRIMINAL!
abstract: The chamber of commerce in this bruised and maligned city put some foreign journalists in an Alouette 2 helicopter the other day and flew them over oil refineries, factory sheds, sparkling beaches, chemical pipelines, chalk cliffs and busy wharves.   The idea was to demonstrate that Marseilles, unfavorably viewed in this country and abroad as a center of organized crime, the European drug trade and urban dilapidation, is actually a place of many virtues.   There is a strong belief among elected officials and business leaders here that the city's reputation as a French Gomorrah is unfair and damaging. They have embarked on a campaign to scrape away what they see as the accumulated cliches about Marseilles and to attract tourists, conventions and high-technology industries.

headline: Schlumberger's Net Falls 74%
abstract: Schlumberger Ltd., hurt by the continuing steep decline in domestic oil field exploration and development, reported yesterday that its earnings in the second quarter had plunged 74 percent on a 14 percent decline in revenues.   Schlumberger said that net income in the three-month period ended June 30 had dropped to $55.2 million, or 19 cents a share, from $212.1 million, or 71 cents a share.

headline: FRONTIER: RUGGED, BIG-HEARTED
abstract: Weathered ranchers, well-heeled oilmen, dungareed backpackers and vacationers in T-shirts jackets were the stock in trade of Frontier Airlines.   The carrier, which was put into bankruptcy by its parent, People Express, not only catered to travelers in its own region but was often the airline that brought skiers, hikers, rafters and hunters into Stapleton International Airport in Denver to connect to some of the most beautiful and spectacular places in the nation, such as Jackson Hole, Wyo., and West Yellowstone, Mont.   It also flew into some of the starkest places, such as Midland, Tex., where oilmen sought their riches. Founded in 1946    The airline was founded in 1946 by Ray Wilson, a barnstorming pilot, with two planes and a handful of employees. It gradually replaced the passenger train as the main form of transportation in the West and before its demise knitted together 55 cities in 22 states and Canada.

headline: INVESTING; CONVERTIBLES: A DOUBLE-EDGED ALLURE
abstract: ON Wall Street, which is often as fashion conscious as Seventh Avenue, convertible securities are in vogue. The combination of falling interest rates and a rousing stock market has made these hybrid securities particularly attractive. Indeed, over the last 12 months, they outperformed all other fixed-income investments.  ''Convertibles are becoming very trendy,'' said Thomas C. Noddings, chairman of Noddings, Kalamos Asset Management, an Oakbrook, Ill., firm that manages two convertible mutual funds.

headline: COMPUTERS' MORRIS SET FOR BUSINESSLAND ROLE
abstract: Anthony T. Morris, who in six years cultivated a $40 million-a-year business, agreed Wednesday to sell his three computer centers to the industry's giant, Businessland Inc. The centers - two in New York and one in Westport, Conn. - are called Morris Decisions Systems Inc. They will become Businessland outlets.   Mr. Morris will be vice president of sales and marketing for his company's new owners.

headline: Motorola to Resume Sales of RAM Chips
abstract: Motorola Inc. plans to re-enter a major segment of the computer chip business that most American manufacturers have abandoned to the Japanese, industry analysts said today.   Motorola will once again begin selling dynamic random-access-memory chips, or dynamic RAM's, the main chips used to store information in computers and the biggest selling product in the semiconductor industry.

headline: 4 Killed in Taiwan Crash
abstract: Four soldiers were killed today and two were seriously injured when a military truck skidded off a bridge and tumbled onto a road in central Taiwan, the police said.

headline: RAIDING RETIREMENT FUNDS IS PIRACY
abstract: TEMPTED by overflowing returns on stocks in their pension plans, more than 1,000 companies have recently siphoned off $12 billion in pension fund assets meant for workers and retirees. The corporations then used the funds to fuel scores of ventures completely unrelated to the employees on whose behalf the plan was established.   Why would Exxon and other major corporations embark on such raids? The Doonesbury cartoon strip caught the spirit of the trend when a character remarked: ''The pension fund was just sitting there.''   Pension plan reversions, as this piracy is called, are a relatively new phenomenon. Only in the past six years have companies dared to use their pension plans as corporate piggy banks. Before that employers felt bound by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, which states that money in pension funds must be used exclusively for the benefit of workers and retirees so long as the plan is in operation. But when the stock market boomed, pension funds doubled in value, becoming a tempting target to executives.

headline: Auditor's Settlement On E.S.M.
abstract: A Federal District Court judge today cleared the way for a $50 million settlement paid by the auditor of the failed E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. to 17 municipalities that lost money when the securities firm collapsed.   Judge Jose Gonzalez approved an out-of-court settlement between E.S.M.'s auditor, Grant Thornton, formerly called Alexander Grant & Company, and the 17 claimants.

headline: Economic Scene; Negative Effect Of Cheap Oil
abstract: MINISTERS of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will gather on Monday in Geneva to continue a search for means to stabilize oil prices, with little indication that they are any closer to agreement than they were during three earlier attempts this year.   At stake over the short term are continued low oil prices. But over the long term, the results of the conference could have much to do with doubts that are spreading about the economic risks involved in cheap oil, and how they overlap into questions of political decision-making.   Just as the major industrialized nations that are net importers of their energy sources, such as Japan and West Germany - with responsibility for pulling ahead many of the marginal economies of Asia and Western Europe - were beginning to relish the idea of a $10 barrel of crude oil, some of the economic assumptions deriving from the new price arrangement seemed threatened.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.  Monday  None  Tuesday  Factory Orders July  Wednesday  None  Thursday  None  Friday  Unemployment

headline: Addenda
abstract: * Venture magazine will increase its rate base 13 percent from 300,000, to 375,000 in January.    * Better Homes and Gardens will raise its ad rates 4 percent with the January issue.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA MINERS' RITES DISRUPTED
abstract: Hundreds of militant black mine workers, waving sticks and chanting slogans, disrupted a memorial service today for 177 miners who were killed in a South African gold-mine disaster last week.   ''We don't respect the management and we don't respect their memorial,'' one angry miner told a reporter at the multiracial service, organized by the mine owners at Evander, 60 miles east of Johannesburg.   Last Tuesday, 172 blacks and 5 whites died when fire swept through a mile-deep underground passage, asphyxiating many with toxic fumes thought to have been emitted by a burning polyurethane sealant on the shaft walls. It was the worst recorded gold-mine disaster in South African history.

headline: TUTU'S TITLE IS NOW ARCHBISHOP
abstract: Desmond M. Tutu has formally become the Archbishop of Cape Town, head of the Anglican Church in southern Africa, in a brief, private ceremony at St. George's Cathedral.   After the ceremony Wednesday, Archbishop Tutu chatted with reporters, then met with organizers of his public enthronement, which is to be held Sunday.   His enthronement will make the cleric, who won the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, the first black to head the Anglican Church in southern Africa.

headline: Continental Bank
abstract: The board of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has decided not to oppose the proposed takeover of three small Illinois banks, with about $170 million in total assets, by the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company of Chicago. Continental must still receive approval from the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve. The banks are First Suburban Bank of Olympia Fields, the First National Bank of Deerfield, and the First National Bank of Western Springs.

headline: CHILEAN OPPOSITION TO PROTEST PINOCHET PLAN
abstract: Opposition parties vowed today to begin a new round of protests after President Augusto Pinochet indicated he would seek to stay in power until 1997.   The centrist Social Democratic Party said it would organize ''a wide mobilization, at all levels, to stop Pinochet.''   Even some right-wing organizations that have generally been sympathetic to General Pinochet's 13-year-old Government expressed opposition to a second term for the President.

headline: 2 Groups Selling Maryland Issues
abstract: The Maryland Department of Transportation is selling $111.4 million of double-A rated bonds through two separate underwriting groups.   Underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Capital Markets Corporation are offering $100 million of consolidated transportation revenue bonds with yields ranging from 5.20 percent in 1989 to 5.75 percent in 1991, 6.75 percent in 1996 and 7.10 percent in 2000 and 2001.   Separately, underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company are offering $11.4 million of county transportation bonds with yields ranging from 4.80 percent in 1988 to 7.25 percent in 2001.

headline: DATA BANK: Sept.14, 1986
U.S. WITHHOLDS U.N. POPULATION FUNDS
abstract: The Agency for International Development has withdrawn its contribution to the United Nations Fund for Population Activities this year because of its involvement in China's population program, officials said today.   The United Nations group, which provides aid to 134 countries, will lose $25 million as a result of the decision, which was disclosed today to Congressional leaders and others.   The American action comes after months of intensive lobbying by anti-abortion activists, who asserted that the Chinese Government's population program involved the widespread use of compulsory abortions. Chinese officials have repeatedly denied reports that their program coerces abortions or sterilizations.

headline: Amfac Expects Quarterly Loss
abstract: Amfac Inc., which has interests in wholesaling, food processing, retailing, hotels, sugar processing and real estate, said it anticipates a loss in its second quarter ended June 30.

headline: Money Fund Assets Off
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell by $315.3 million, to $223.54 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

headline: Washington Watch; Licensing Truck Drivers
abstract: THERE appears to be some consensus growing on at least one proposal for the stricter regulation of business, coming in the form of a national truck driver's license.   House and Senate committees have been gathering data for several years on what some lawmakers say is a frightening trend of abuse by interstate truck and bus drivers of highway speed laws and common work rules such as rest time during and between trips.

headline: West Germans Throng To Anti-Nuclear Concert
abstract: Tens of thousands of West Germans and Austrians descended on this Bavarian hamlet today for a two-day rock concert to protest nuclear power.   The event was organized by local activists with the backing of national parties of the left, including the Greens, the Communist Party and the youth wing of the Social Democrats.

headline: Convent at Auschwitz Is Subject of Debate
abstract: A meeting between some of Europe's Roman Catholic and Jewish figures took place today to try to resolve a dispute over the establishment of a Carmelite convent near the Auschwitz death camp in Poland, where millions of Jews were killed by the Nazis. Some Jewish organizations say that the monastery is an insult to the memory of those who died there.

headline: STOCKHOLM EAST-WEST PACT CALLED NEAR
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that recent concessions by the Soviet Union and the United States had significantly improved the chance for an East-West agreement in coming weeks on guidelines to avoid an accidental war in Europe.   The Soviet Union has in the last two weeks accepted the principle of allowing on-site and aerial inspections of its troop formations from East Germany to the Ural Mountains. The United States has agreed to notify Moscow whenever it sends large numbers of troops for duty in Europe, the officials said.   The two sides have also come closer to agreeing on how large a movement of troops should require one country to notify the others to avoid misundersting or misinterpretation.

headline: Rockwell to Buy Electronics Corp.
abstract: The Rockwell International Corporation said that its Allen-Bradley Company subsidiary had agreed to buy the Electronics Corporation of America for $52 a share, or $99 million.

headline: BRAZIL CHIEF MEETS POPE ON CHURCH-STATE STRAINS
abstract: The President of Brazil, upset over strong criticism of his Government's land redistribution program by elements of the Brazilian Roman Catholic hierarchy, met with Pope John Paul II today in an effort to win his help in calming church-state relations.   President Jose Sarney expressed satisfaction with the meeting and said ''a conversation with the Pope is almost like a confession.'' He said the Pope had offered ''friendship, encouragement and help.''   For his part, John Paul strongly endorsed agrarian reform in a homily given at a mass said in honor of Mr. Sarney.

headline: Paying For School Costs, No Easy Task
abstract: LAURENCE CLARFELD is only 14 months old. But his father, Robert, is already thinking about saving for Laurence's education.
