''If this were last year, I would have set up a trust fund that would generate income that would be taxed at my son's rate,'' said Mr. Clarfeld, whose Manhattan accounting firm, Clarfeld & Company, specializes in financial planning for corporate executives. ''But under the proposed legislation, I've abandoned the idea of a trust.'' Instead, Mr. Clarfeld's firm is now recommending that real estate investments be used to provide funding for a child's education.   Mr. Clarfeld is scarcely alone among parents who are developing new ways to finance their children's education. As tuition costs continue to rise, and as tax laws and student loan programs are revised, financial analysts say that many families will have to rethink their financial plans for school.

headline: Knudsen to Sell Parts of Unit
abstract: Knudsen Foods Inc., the troubled company that is the West Coast's largest dairy products concern, said today that it had signed a letter of intent to sell many of its western division operations in California and Nevada to Kraft Inc. and Hughes Markets Inc.   Knudsen, which filed for protection under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws last week, declined to release terms of the proposed sale, but it said that the affected operations, in Los Angeles, Visalia, Modesto and Fresno, Calif., and Las Vegas, Nev., accounted for about 50 percent of its overall operations.

headline: Negotiations For Byoir Sale
abstract: Hill & Knowlton Inc., the nation's second-largest public relations firm, said yesterday that it was negotiating to acquire Carl Byoir & Associates, the third-largest public relations agency, from Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc.   If the deal were completed, it would create the nation's largest public relations firm, displacing Burson-Marsteller, which is owned by Young & Rubicam Inc.

headline: OPEC REACHES TENTATIVE ACCORD ON IRANIAN PLAN TO LIMIT OUTPUT
abstract: Ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries unanimously reached a tentative agreement tonight on an Iranian proposal to limit the group's production in a bid to stop the steep decline in prices.   The agreement, which will be presented in detail on Tuesday, is designed to cut OPEC production to 16 million barrels a day from roughly 20.5 million barrels at present. Analysts said that the accord, if enforced, would likely mean that prices, now at an average of about $7 a barrel for some grades, might bottom out or be reversed. OPEC ministers have said in the past that they hoped such a production target would lift prices to between $15 and $19 a barrel. Prices had been more than $30 a barrel late last year.

headline: Sony-Warner Pact
abstract: The Sony Corporation of America said Warner Home Video had agreed to release a selection of prerecorded video cassettes in the 8-millimeter format.

headline: TAFT IS CONSIDERING SALE OF 5 TELEVISION STATIONS
abstract: Just a year after the Taft Broadcasting Company moved to become a major force in broadcasting, it is considering the sale of five of its independent television stations, the company said yesterday.   Last year Taft bought five television stations from the Gulf Broadcasting Company for $760 million. Taft already owned seven stations. Now it is planning to sell three of those and two from the Gulf deal.

headline: HUNTS' APPEAL TO DELAY FORECLOSURES IS REJECTED
abstract: A Federal judge today turned down a request by the Hunt brothers to delay foreclosure sales on more than $100 million worth of their personal assets.   The ruling will, in effect, force the Hunts to consider bankruptcy filings before Friday morning for the two companies that are the centerpiece of the Hunt family fortune, the Placid Oil Company and the Penrod Drilling Company.   The first of two foreclosure sales, involving oil and gas reserves in Mississippi, is set for Friday. A second, including the brothers' share of a landmark office tower here and valuable land north of the city, is scheduled for next Tuesday in Texas.

headline: A SUBWAY JOLT FOR THE MEXICANS: THE 3-CENT FARE
abstract: Ever since it opened in 1969 the Mexico City subway has been one of the world's great urban transportation bargains. For a single peso - 0.15 cents in United States money - passengers can ride anywhere on the 75-mile Metro system and get off at any of its 109 stations.   But on Friday, Mexico City residents will say goodbye to such good fortune. The cost of a subway ride is going up 2,000 percent - to 20 pesos, or slightly more than 3 cents.

headline: MEXICO VOTE: NEW VOICES JOIN PROTEST
abstract: In the 17th-century cathedral here, the priests recently erected two large, hand-lettered signs quoting a pastoral letter issued in March by a group of Roman Catholic bishops in the state of Chihuahua.   ''We have every right,'' the signs say, ''to ask ourselves whether the political activity in Mexico - the exercise of which has become synonymous with corruption in the eyes of many people - would be the same if those lay Catholics who are public servants functioned in accordance with their Christian vocation.''   The words are from a pastoral letter condemning Government corruption and electoral fraud, and the signs seem striking to the cathedral parishioners and the people of Chihuahua, coming as they do from a clergy that for decades was silent about Mexican politics and is forbidden by the Mexican Constitution from taking any role in politics.

headline: A Summer House Without Uncle Sam
abstract: VACATIONERS in the market for a second home, as well as people who already own them, may want to rethink their plans for that seashore or mountainside cottage as a result of the tax revision proposals before Congress. Many rules concerning vacation homes are likely to be tightened, to the extent that, in the view of some tax advisers, it could make economic sense to act now to get under the current, more generous measures. If owners are contemplating selling, experts say, they should sell now to benefit from more generous capital gains treatment. Alternatively, would-be home-buyers might consider buying sooner than planned, to lock in more liberal tax breaks.   Some tax experts have even more draconian advice. Although Congress ''has come out fairly liberal on vacation homes, get into the deal only if you expect to see a lot of appreciation,'' cautioned Lawrence W. Goldstein, a tax partner with the accounting firm of Arthur Young.

headline: Dow, Halting Slide, Rises by 5.34
abstract: After two days of heavy losses for Wall Street, stock prices inched higher yesterday even though volume tailed off and investors seemed most interested in speculative issues.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which lost a record 61.87 points on Monday and another 18.27 on Tuesday, rose by 5.34 points yesterday, to 1,826.07. The gain erased some slippage early in the session.   The market's focus, traders said, was on potential takeover stocks, with Safeway, up 4 5/8, to 58 1/8, and American Brands, up 8, to 102 1/2, getting much of the attention.

headline: HAITI'S SMALL INDUSTRIES FACE A STRUGGLE WITH UNCERTAINTY
abstract: It was early afternoon, and the rows of sewing machines in the lingerie factory were silent.   There had been another political protest downtown, and the machine operators had gone home.   Remy Mendoza, the 35-year-old manager of the American-owned plant, was alone in her office.   ''We're on the verge of deciding whether to continue this operation,'' she said. ''You just don't know what's going to happen. Today it may be very normal, tomorrow there is no transportation.'

headline: Typhoon on Vietnam's Coast Kills 400 and Injures 2,500
abstract: A typhoon killed nearly 400 people and injured more than 2,500 when it battered Vietnam's northern coastal provinces, the official Vietnam News Agency reported today.

headline: Jersey Is Planning Book-Entry Issue
abstract: The State of New Jersey plans to sell its first book-entry issue next month when it accepts bids on $130 million of general obligation bonds.

headline: Attack on Haitian Protesters Leaves Two People Wounded
abstract: Men wearing civilian clothes and armed with clubs and machetes on Friday attacked about 400 people protesting the cost of food and lack of jobs.

headline: ISRAELI LAWYERS IN A DISPUTE: MINISTRY VS. SECURITY AGENCY
abstract: A dispute between lawyers in the Justice Ministry and the security agency Shin Beth is hindering the Government's ability to sustain punishments imposed on suspected terrorists or security offenders, according to Justice Ministry sources.   Lawyers in the Justice Ministry are incensed that the two top lawyers of Shin Beth, Israel's domestic intelligence agency, have been allowed to keep their jobs after having admitted falsifying documents and testimony to cover up Shin Beth's killing of two captured Palestinian bus hijackers in April 1984.   To protest, Justice Ministry lawyers are refusing to cooperate with Shin Beth's legal department until its chief and his deputy are dismissed.   ''The boycott is unprecedented,'' a senior Justice Ministry source said.

headline: Manville Picks Chief Executive
abstract: W. T. Stephens, 43 years old, has been elected chief executive of the Manville Corporation, the company said yesterday. The move, which had been expected, completes the installation of a new management team in connection with the company's bankruptcy reorganization plan.   Manville, which filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code in 1982 because of thousands of asbestos-related lawsuits, had announced the management reorganization last spring.

headline: U.S. CHOICE OF ENVOY PART OF REAGAN TACTIC
abstract: Reagan Administration officials acknowledged today that a tentative decision to name a black businessman as the next Ambassador to South Africa was part of an effort to buy time in the face of increasing Congressional pressure to impose severe economic sanctions against South Africa.   The officials made it clear that the White House was determined to prevent a Congressional takeover of United States policy toward Pretoria. Toward that end, President Reagan's advisers are trying to put the boldest possible face on the policy ''reassessment'' under way within the Administration.   But Reagan advisers are struggling to find proposals that are strong enough to satisfy Congress and still fit within the narrow policy limits defined by the President, who continues to oppose economic and diplomatic sanctions.

headline: Helping an Industry Fight the Good Fight
abstract: THE United States and Japan recently signed an agreement that will radically restructure their semiconductor trade. Neither protectionist nor overtly mercantilist, the agreement promotes American interests while helping world trade.   The deal guarantees the United States ''more than 20 percent'' of Japan's semiconductor market by 1991, compared with only 8.2 percent today. In addition, the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry will monitor prices and clamp down on dumping of selected semiconductors exported to America and third markets. In exchange, we have suspended retaliation against alleged unfair Japanese trade practices in semiconductors.

headline: Prudential Gets a Briton To Head a London Unit
abstract: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., seeking to become a stronger player in merchant banking in London, has hired a Briton, John MacArthur, to lead the initiative.   Mr. MacArthur has joined P-B Capital Funding Ltd. as chairman of U.K. Merchant Banking, Prudential-Bache announced yesterday. P-B Capital is Prudential-Bache's newly established global merchant and investment banking arm.

headline: Two New Commercials Promoting WPLJ-FM
abstract: The people behind the clever TV commercial that shows a radio station's janitor lip-syncing the programming as a way of promoting the contemporary-hits format of WPLJ-FM will today introduce the first of two 30-second TV commercials that will promote the featured players in its popular morning drive-time program, ''Jim Kerr and the Morning Crew.''   They are the frantic Mr. Kerr, the equally frantic Howard the Cab Driver, whose infrequently used surname is Henkin, and the more sedate, and also pregnant, Shelli Sonstein.

headline: Guinness Sells Huge B.P. Block
abstract: Guinness P.L.C., the British brewery and distilling company, said that it had sold 18.8 million shares of the British Petroleum Company in one of the largest block trades in British history. Guinness said that it sold the shares for $:5.75 each, or a total of $:108.1 million.

headline: Dollar Declines Further Against Yen and Mark
abstract: The dollar fell further against most major currencies yesterday, as pessimism deepened about growth prospects in the United States. Traders said that activity was quite light.   Once again, much of the price erosion was registered against the Japanese yen and German mark. However, the dollar did register some improvement against the British pound, which has come under pressure as a result of sagging oil prices.

headline: Farming Concessions Demanded by French
abstract: The French trade minister, Michel Noir, demanded far-reaching agricultural concessions today from the United States, Canada and other big farming nations.   Mr. Noir warned that, if the concessions were not granted, it could result in the failure of the meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that starts Monday in Punte del Este, Uruguay. The meeting is designed to come up with an agenda for the eighth round of trade liberalization talks since the pact was agreed on 38 years ago.

headline: THE TERROR DEMOLISHES SANG-FROID
abstract: Sirens wailed. The blue lights atop police vehicles flashed. And dozens of policemen and bomb experts descended today on the Air France terminal near the landmark Hotel des Invalides.   As people fled the area and barricades were erected, the police surrounded an abandoned, suspicious-looking package.   What they feared might be a bomb turned out to be a package of Camembert cheese.

headline: Zero Inflation in Israel
abstract: Israel's inflation rate, which was above 400 percent annually until a wage-price freeze began last summer, fell to zero in July, the Government said Friday. The July rate in 1985 was 27.5 percent.

headline: SENATE PANEL BACKS AID TO NICARAGUA INSURGENTS
abstract: A Senate subcommittee approved President Reagan's request today to send $100 million in aid to the insurgent forces fighting the Government of Nicaragua.   But the measure still faces the threat of a filibuster once it reaches the Senate floor, and the issue has become ensnarled in parliamentary infighting as Congress tries to get away for an August holiday.   The appropriations subcommittee on military construction decided on a voice vote to add the aid package to the military construction bill. It includes $70 million for military aid and $30 million in nonmilitary aid for the rebels, known as contras.

headline: Iran Tanker Reported
abstract: Iran has chartered one of the world's largest supertankers to provide floating storage for its crude oil in the Persian Gulf, area oil industry sources said today. The 564,739-ton Liberian-registered Seawise Giant would probably be used at Iran's recently established floating oil terminal off Larak Island in the Strait of Hormuz, said the sources who spoke on condition they not be identified.

headline: MEXICO GIVEN DEBT AID BY 'PARIS CLUB' NATIONS
abstract: Western governments agreed today to give Mexico more time to repay some $1.8 billion it owes them. The agreement followed all-night talks between the chief Mexican debt negotiator, Angel Gurria, and the so-called Paris Club of creditor nations.   The rescheduling agreement carries Mexico a step closer to becoming the first heavily indebted developing country to subscribe to the so-called Baker debt initiative, originated by James A. Baker 3d, Washington's Secretary of the Treasury, a year ago. This plan seeks to resolve developing nations' debt problems by encouraging faster economic growth rather than belt tightening.

headline: Pacific Stereo Deal Collapses
abstract: The Pacific Stereo Corporation, once the world's largest retailer of brand-name stereo equipment, said today that plans for the company's reorganization by the U.S. Electronic Group had fallen through. As a result, Pacific said liquidation of remaining furniture, fixtures and leases would begin around Oct. 1.

headline: Long-Term Securities Strong
abstract: Prices of long-term Treasury securities posted strong gains yesterday in a rally based largely on technical factors but underpinned by growing hopes of a new round of internationally coordinated interest rate cuts.   As the trading day ended in New York, the price on Treasury's bellweather 30-year bond was up nearly a point, to 99 25/32, pushing the yield down to 7.27 percent. Price gains on other actively traded long-term issues ranged from 20/32 to 1 10/ 32.   Short-term and intermediate-term issues posted gains of between 7/32 and half a point, and rates on Treasury bills were down four to seven basis points.

headline: Lear Siegler Retirement
abstract: Lear Siegler Inc. said that Robert T. Campion, chairman and chief executive, would retire, effective Aug. 15. Norman A. Barkeley, president, will assume the roles of chairman and chief executive of the diversified company. Mr. Campion, 65 years old, will work as a consultant to the company and will continue to serve as a board member and chairman of the executive committee. Lear Siegler, which was formed in 1962 through the merger of Lear Inc. and the Siegler Corporation, has interests in electronics and electromechanical products, automotive products and industrial products.

headline: Japan Lowers Growth Goal
abstract: The stronger yen has forced the Japanese Government to cut its real annual growth-rate forecast to 2.8 percent, from 4 percent, for fiscal 1986-87, reports said today.

headline: THE PAIN OF THE STEELWORKER
abstract: Battered by imports and slack demand, many of the nation's largest steel companies looked to labor three years ago to cut costs and help them become more competitive. After painful negotiations, the United Steelworkers of America reluctantly agreed to as much as $1.8 billion in concessions.   This year, with the industry in even more woeful shape, the companies have come back for more. But while the union's strength has weakened along with that of the companies, the steelworkers, under a new president, Lynn R. Williams, are struggling this time around to get something in return.   Still willing to grant concessions, the union is demanding that the companies open their books to prove ''dire'' need, and provide stock, profit sharing or other compensation for any new givebacks. And it contends that new cuts are only part of the solution, stressing the need for other kinds of company efficiencies and for greater protection against imports.

headline: POLITICS IN ULSTER TURN A SPOTLIGHT ON THE POLICE
abstract: In the heat of still another night of sporadic confrontation and violence, the police force of Northern Ireland quietly indicated Saturday at midnight just how beleagured it has become in the treacherous politics of a divided Ireland.   Leaders of the force announced the suspension of two senior officers in the investigation into charges that the police might have victimized unarmed Roman Catholics in ''shoot to kill'' excesses directed at Irish Republican Army terrorists four years ago.   The action was the first to be announced against ranking policemen in the long simmering controversy about the force, which is formally known as the Royal Ulster Constabulary.   It was an instant flag to both sides in the sectarian struggle. In the absence of a full-fledged political life because of the province's dependence on England, the behavior of the local police in life-and-death confrontations is often the main stuff of debate.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA TO LIFT SOME MINOR SEGREGATION RULES
abstract: The Ministry of Constitutional Development and Planning said today that the Government planned to let all restaurants and movie theaters decide whether to serve people of all races.   Since April, owners of businesses with a liquor license have been allowed to decide whom they would serve. A ministry spokesman, Peter Pullen, said the planned new move would extend that choice to owners of fast-food outlets, cinemas and restaurants without liquor licenses.

headline: Solidarity Activist Freed In Government Amnesty
abstract: A leading Solidarity activist, Zbigniew Bujak, was freed from prison today under an amnesty for hundreds of political prisoners.

headline: COMPUTERS KEEP UP WITH ACTION
abstract: Because of sophisticated computerization, Wall Street had little difficulty in handling yesterday's record trading volume of 240.5 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange or the 237.6 million shares traded the previous day.   Although turnover set new highs each day, both the Big Board and its member firms handled the trading without the kinds of problems that plagued the exchange during the ''back office'' crisis of the late 1960's. While the ticker tape that lists each transaction fell behind a number of times during the day - including a 33-minute delay at 11:11 A.M. - the computers and other systems on the trading floor and in member offices were generally able to handle the flow of orders and extra weekend work was not scheduled. $150 Million Investment ''In the last five years, we've invested $150 million in systems and communications to handle all this,'' said John J. Phelan Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of the New York exchange. ''We're anticipating peak volume of 300 million shares a day and sustained volume of 200 million shares a day, and if we could do it with the same lack of problems we had today, we'd be very pleased.''

headline: East and West Germany Spar Over Economist
abstract: East and West Germany exchanged accusations today over what appeared to be a failed attempt by a senior East German academic figure to flee to the West.   The East German press agency accused West German intelligence agents of seeking to kidnap the scholar, Herbert Meissner, an economist and Deputy Secretary General of the East German Academy of Sciences, while he was traveling in West Berlin.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Fear of Inflation    Last week, reports of an OPEC pact to curtail output raised oil prices on world markets - and the specter of renewed inflation. But even without the oil factor, economists have been worrying about inflationary pressures. Most responding to a recent survey by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, of Sedona, Ariz., said it was their top economic concern. On average, they see the Consumer Price Index rising at higher annual rates - up to 3.9 percent in second-quarter 1987, compared with 1.5 percent in this year's second quarter.   Victor Zarnowitz, a University of Chicago economist, is less worried, but agrees that inflation is likely to rise. A rise in food prices and in the cost of services - especially health services - he says, may put the C.P.I.'s annual growth rate at 2.6 percent this quarter and at 3.4 percent by the fourth quarter.

headline: FREUHAUF SETS BUYOUT BY MERRILL, MANAGERS
abstract: The noisy battle for the Fruehauf Corporation ended yesterday, with Asher B. Edelman dropping his bid for the truck trailer and auto parts manufacturer after two days of around-the-clock negotiations and Fruehauf agreeing to a $1.1 billion leveraged buyout deal.   Fruehauf will be bought by a group that includes Merrill Lynch & Company and Fruehauf's management for a price that analysts said worked out to somewhat less than the $49.50-a-share face value of the transaction.   The group will buy 71 percent of Fruehauf's shares with $49.50 in cash. The remainder will be bought with a package of securities, including preferred and common stock in the new entity, that analysts said was worth about $48.75 a share.

headline: THE AUSTRIAN COALITION COLLAPSES OVER PARTY ELECTION OF A RIGHTIST
abstract: Austria's Government collapsed today after the junior party in the coalition, the Freedom Party, elected a far-right nationalist as party leader over the weekend.   The new party chairman, Jorg Haider, 36 years old, is the most conspicuous exponent of the Freedom Party's so-called national wing, which inclines to a glorification of a pan-German national identity.   Last year, Mr. Haider became embroiled in a controversy when he called a convicted Nazi war criminal ''a soldier who had done his duty.''

headline: Shift by Penn Athletic
abstract: Penn Athletic Products, a tennis and racquetball maker in Phoenix, has sent $2 million to $3 million in billings to Fallon McElligott. The agency will develop a trade and consumer campaign, which it plans to break early next year. Ketchum Advertising/Pittsburgh was the previous agency.

headline: Addendum
abstract: * Harcourt Brace Jovanovich has acquired the trade magazine Independent Restaurants.

headline: PERUVIAN JUSTICE MINISTER RESIGNS AND PRISON GUARD CHIEF IS OUSTED
abstract: Peru's Justice Minister, accused of sharing responsibility for the brutal crushing of a prison mutiny earlier this month, resigned from his post today.   The official, Luis Gonzalez Posada, a 40-year-old lawyer regarded as a close adviser to President Alan Garcia, said he had to step down because of excesses committed by security forces in quelling a riot by accused leftist guerrillas at the Lurigancho prision in Lima on June 19.   His resignation came hours after the Government dismissed Gen. Andres Maximo Lira, the chief of the paramilitary Republican Guard police force.

headline: The U.N. Today: Aug. 8, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on Decolonization at 3 P.M.   Special Committee Against Apartheid at 10 A.M.

headline: A Selective Approach At Kurnit's New Shop
abstract: Shep Kurnit is now running the recently formed Kurnit Communications, which seeks to do advertising for the public good.

headline: AGONY OF SUCCESS
abstract: To the Editor:   As a young M.B.A. who started a career on Wall Street but has since moved to a small firm, I found that employers expected young employees to give up everything else for their jobs.

headline: Burroughs-Sperry
abstract: The integration of the Burroughs Corporation and the Sperry Corporation is proceeding more smoothly than expected and earlier estimates of efficiency savings of $150 million in the first year now appear to be conservative, W. Michael Blumenthal, the chairman of Burroughs, said. He told a news conference that since the $4.8 billion merger was completed 35 days ago, management of both units had identified an unexpectedly large number of areas in which competitiveness could be increased.

headline: U.S. BORROWERS LURED ABROAD
abstract: Major American companies are lining up to tap the emerging market overseas for short-term loans. At a time when business borrowing in the United States has remained sluggish despite the decline in interest rates, some 240 American corporations now have more than $25 billion in short-term loans outstanding with overseas lenders.   The nascent market for what is known as Eurocommercial paper was less than half that size earlier this year, and has added at least 100 American issuers and $5 billion in outstanding paper over recent months, say dealers in the London-based market. Recent issuers of the paper, which matures in 30 to 270 days, include General Electric, Nynex, Avon, Eastman Kodak and the General Motors Acceptance Corporation.

headline: WALL STREET SETS ITS SIGHTS ON THE NEWLY RICH
abstract: GIFFORD-HILL & Company, a cement and construction supply operation in Dallas, happily announced last week that it had agreed to be acquired by a British concern for $275 million, much of which would go into the pockets of some of its executives. Within hours, the executives' phones were ringing with calls from investment advisers whose specialty is catering to the rich. ''They do seem to descend on you pretty quickly,'' said Roy G. Turner, the chief financial officer.   Mr. Turner's experience was not unusual; America's wealthy, new and old, have become the most hotly courted of investors. With the fervor of evangelists, brokers and investment bankers talk of the complex financial needs of America's millions of well-to-do households and the sophisticated financial products and services they offer.   The strategy has been spurred by Wall Street's realization that the number of people with hundreds of thousands of dollars to invest has grown by leaps and bounds in recent years. Securities industry executives say that millions of people have apparently joined the once-thin ranks of those with $200,000 or more of capital for investment. According to Federal Reserve Board figures, the number of households with a net worth of $327,500 or more in constant 1983 dollars has shot up to 7 percent of all households from 2 percent in 1962.

headline: U.S. WEIGHS MOVES AGAINST MOSCOW IN REPORTER CASE
abstract: Administration officials said today that they were drawing up a set of graduated measures against the Soviet Union - including a personal statement by President Reagan - to be used if an American reporter held in Moscow on suspicion of espionage is not freed promptly.   Washington is said to be considering reducing Soviet personnel stationed in the United States, limiting negotiations to key issues like arms control, delaying the issuance of export licenses for some goods and urging groups to boycott meetings with Russians.   For the moment, all scheduled negotiations are going ahead, officials said, including a second round of arms control talks opening here Friday. The negotiations are aimed at finding common ground that might make a summit meeting possible later this year.

headline: Iceland Ends Dispute With U.S. Over Shipping
abstract: Foreign Minister Matthias Matthiesen announced an agreement with the United States today that promises to end a bitter two-year dispute over shipping to the United States Navy base at Keflavik, on the southwestern tip of the island.   The agreement puts Icelandic and American companies on an equal footing in bidding for contracts on shipping to the Keflavik base, he said.   Mr. Matthiesen said the agreement, if ratified by the Senate, would supersede a 1904 United States statute giving American companies priority on shipping to overseas bases.

headline: Guccione to Suspend NewLook Magazine
abstract: Blaming ''the Reagan White House'' for his distribution problems, Bob Guccione, chairman of Penthouse International, has announced that he would suspend publication of NewLook magazine with its September issue.   The magazine made its United States debut with the May 1985 issue, and had a circulation rate base of 500,000.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: * Walter W. Woodward is returning to Griswold Inc., Cleveland, as executive vice president and creative director.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 28, 1986:

headline: SHARING THE THRONE AT BLACK ROCK
abstract: AT the end of CBS's dramatic nine hour board meeting last Wednesday, the company's two triumphant power brokers, William S. Paley and Laurence A. Tisch, seemed to be acting quite independently of each other. The 84-year-old Mr. Paley, once again chairman of the company he founded 58 years ago, sat smiling at the boardroom table of fine English walnut. He was clearly tired but his jacket was still on and he looked crisp and ready for action.   Mr. Tisch, the 63-year-old chairman of the $6.7 billion Loews Corporation and now CBS's new chief executive, was already on the move. His jacket was also in place, and he sat outside the board room, intently talking on the telephone.   But appearances aside, the two men actually have evolved an intricate balance of power in the 10 months since Mr. Tisch joined the CBS board. Together, Mr. Tisch and Mr. Paley and their friends control more than 34 percent of CBS's stock, and this week their newly forged alliance proved powerful enough to unseat Thomas H. Wyman as CBS chairman and chief executive. Mr. Paley became acting chairman and Mr. Tisch acting chief executive until a successor to Mr. Wyman can be found. Mr. Paley will concentrate almost exclusively on programming, while Mr. Tisch will tend to the company's management and fiscal health.

headline: TURNING KEY EXECUTIVES INTO STARS
abstract: EXECUTIVES are casting themselves in their videos these days. ''The more we are working with corporate videos, the more we are working with executives,'' said Dennis H. Paget, manager of creative services at Jack Morton Productions, a $25 million company whose corporate video production has doubled in the past two years.   The reasons that executives go on-camera are as varied as the films themselves. ''It accentuates the credibility of the product,'' said Al Weiss, vice president of business communications at American Express. ''One manager said to me, 'I want my employees to see the look in my eyes and know that I mean what I'm saying,' '' added Judith Brush, the consultant.

headline: DOW DROPS 18.27 MORE, TO 1,820.73
abstract: Wall Street did not do half as bad yesterday as it did during the record-breaking 61.87-point drop on Monday, but stock prices still fell sharply as smaller investors, mimicking their bigger counterparts, sold equities furiously.   The Dow Jones industrial average lost another 18.27 points, to close at 1,820.73. The blue-chip indicator was down nearly 30 points several times during the session, and was helped only by a big rebound in the final hour.   As expected, the stock market got off to a poor start yesterday morning as the average investor, after mulling over the market's big drop on Monday, apparently decided to take some profits. Selling pressure was so heavy that trading averaged a million shares a minute in the first 30 minutes, one of the largest volumes on record, and the Dow dropped nearly 29 points.

headline: CHERNOBYL FALLOUT: APOCALYPTIC TALE AND FEAR
abstract: A prominent Russian writer recently produced a tattered old Bible and with a practiced hand turned to Revelations. ''Listen,'' he said, ''this is incredible: 'And the third angel sounded, and there fell a great star from heaven, burning as it were a lamp, and it fell upon the third part of the rivers, and upon the fountains of waters; and the name of the star is called wormwood: and the third part of the waters became wormwood; and many men died of the waters, because they were made bitter.' ''   In a dictionary, he showed the Ukrainian word for wormwood, a bitter wild herb used as a tonic in rural Russia: chernobyl.   The writer, an atheist, was hardly alone in pointing out the apocalyptic reference to the star called chernobyl. With the uncanny speed common to rumor in the Soviet Union, the discovery had spread across the Soviet land, contributing to the swelling body of lore that has shaped the public consciousness of the disaster at the Chernobyl atomic power plant in the Ukraine.

headline: Production Down at G.M.
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said its American car production declined 35.4 percent in August from the 1985 month, to 210,811 units.

headline: SALVADOR REBELS OFFER PEACE PLAN
abstract: Leftist Salvadoran rebels have offered a peace proposal that includes a cease-fire and an offer to take part in elections after a transitional government is formed.   The proposal, announced on Friday night, was aimed at breaking a stalemate in efforts to reconvene peace talks with the Government.

headline: Lin Broadcasting To Sell 10 Stations
abstract: Lin Broadcasting, the New York-based media company, is putting its 10 radio stations up for sale. Lin Broadcasting also owns seven televison stations and has extensive interests in the cellular radio business and a small speciality publishing operation.

headline: Salvadorans to Meet Rebels At Mexico City Talks Today
abstract: The Government and rebels of El Salvador are to meet here Wednesday to lay the groundwork for a new attempt to end their seven-year-old civil war.

headline: KEY SECTIONS OF SOVIET FOREIGN MINISTER'S SPEECH AT THE U.N.
abstract: Following are key sections of Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's speech today to the General Assembly, as distributed in translation by the Soviet Mission:    Mr. President, distinguished delegates, as we come to this high rostrum, we speak of our perception of the world. In this way, collective efforts produce a picture of present-day international realities. How do we see that picture today? At first glance, the period since the previous session of the General Assembly has not added bright colors to the panorama of our time. It has been marked by a number of factors which have aggravated old concerns. The arms race has not been halted; it is going ahead in a steep spiral. The danger of the arms race spreading to outer space has become more real. Dangerous hotbeds of armed conflict persist. Misery and poverty in many parts of the world are becoming more acute.   All this being so, we nevertheless believe that the International Year of Peace will go down in history with something more than just its symbols of peace.

headline: Hyundai Canada
abstract: Hyundai Auto Canada Inc., a unit of the Hyundai Motor Company of South Korea, said the plant it is building in Bromont, Quebec, will produce a new car model that is still in the planning stages. The company began construction of the plant this week. It is scheduled to start production in 1988 and produce 100,000 cars a year by 1991.

headline: Citicorp Notes
abstract: Citicorp is offering $250 million of extendible notes due in 1998, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The notes carry an initial interest rate of 6 7/8 percent and were offered at 99.80 to yield 6.963 percent to April 1, 1989. At that time, investors may redeem their notes at par, or accept new terms.

headline: Israeli Test Flight Is Off
abstract: The maiden test flight of the Israeli Lavi warplane will be postponed for an undetermined period because of late delivery of a crucial part by an American subcontracter, according to a senior Israeli military source. The flight had been planned for late September.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Advanced Systems Inc. is offering $30 million of 7 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2011, at 100, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. They are convertible at any time into common stock at a price of $20 a share. A mandatory sinking fund beginning in 1997 will retire 70 percent of the issue before maturity.

headline: World Airways Disputes Rumors
abstract: World Airways Inc. said that it is significantly stronger, both financially and operationally, than it has been in the recent past, contrary to rumors that arose recently.

headline: HOUSE APPROVES A YEAR'S TEST BAN ON MOST A-ARMS
abstract: The House of Representatives voted today to impose a one-year moratorium on all but the smallest American underground nuclear tests if the Soviet Union would reciprocate and agree to on-site monitoring instruments.   The measure, which would be binding on the Reagan Administration if incorporated into final legislation, was approved by an unexpectedly large margin, 234 to 155.   The vote was the first Congressional move to halt nuclear weapons testing. Until today, Congress had voted for only nonbinding measures that urged the Administration to negotiate a ban on nuclear tests. Underground tests are the only type permitted under the 1963 partial test-ban treaty.

headline: China Daily in London
abstract: The official China Daily, the country's only English-language daily, will be printed in London and distributed in western Europe beginning Sept. 1, the newspaper said today. It said it had reached an agreement with the Mirror Group newspapers in Britain, owned by Robert Maxwell, giving the group the right to print and distribute the eight-page broadsheet paper in West Europe.

headline: A Marketing Director To Become a Professor
abstract: Robert F. Lauderborn is resigning his job as director of marketing communications and corporate advertising at the International Paper Company on Aug. 15 to become the first James L. Knight Professor of Advertising at the University of North Carolina School of Journalism.   The move is causing a slight problem for the Association of National Advertisers, of which Mr. Lauderborn has been vice chairman, because he was scheduled to take the top spot in October at the annual meeting.

headline: Angola Says Its Troops Killed 230 Rebels in Northern Area
abstract: Angolan Government troops killed 230 rebels and captured 15 in recent operations in Angola's two northern provinces of Uige and Zaire, the official Angolan news agency, Angop, said today.   Angop, monitored in Lisbon, said rifles, mines, mortar and artillery shells and ammunition were seized in the operations against the Western-backed rebels' organization, which it said took place over the last few days.   In Menongue, in southeast Cuando Cubango province, a military court sentenced six rebels to terms from 12 to 24 years for treason, crimes against the state and armed rebellion.

headline: Cable Guide Available On Co-op Advertising
abstract: The Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau has published ''Advertiser Co-op Plans Approved for Cable/ 1986-87.''

headline: YALE PANEL ON SOUTH AFRICA SAYS IT'S SPLIT ON DIVESTMENT
abstract: A delegation from Yale University that spent eight days in South Africa reported today that it was divided on whether Yale should get rid of its stock in American companies doing business in that country.   Leaders of the 10-member delegation, speaking at a news conference here, said the group did unanimously agree that Government-imposed sanctions would have more effect in forcing the South African Government to ease its restrictive racial policies.   The delegation, composed of university trustees, faculty members, students and administrators, returned July 2 from its trip, which included visits to South African universities and American plants and offices there.

headline: SIMMONS CONTROLS NL AFTER TWO-MONTH BATTLE
abstract: After two months of battling to take over NL Industries, Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, gained control of NL today by reaching an agreement to place five representatives on the company's new nine-member board.   Theodore C. Rogers, NL's chairman and chief executive, will remain in both posts and senior managers of NL's chemical and oilfield service units also are being asked to continue in their jobs, according to a statement from both sides. In turn, NL agreed to drop its legal attempt to thwart Mr. Simmons's bid. Last week, he had increased his holdings of NL's stock to 51.1 percent, from 20.1 percent.

headline: Washington Watch; Glum Forecast For Philippines
abstract: THE World Bank, finding that the economy of the Philippines is in significantly worse shape than its Government has publicly acknowledged, has concluded that the nation probably will not be able to repay debt projected to rise nearly 47 percent, to $38 billion, by 1995.   The bank's grim assessment could make it easier for President Corazon Aquino, who arrives here this week, to persuade lenders to provide fresh credit to help her revive the economy. She will address a joint session of Congress, and some of her top aides will remain in Washington for the annual meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund at the end of the month.

headline: Key Rates
Fighting Scandal at Lockheed
abstract: EACH day, for up to 18 hours at a stretch, Lockheed Corporation officials paraded through a hastily prepared conference room in the company's headquarters. Their interrogator was merciless: He grilled them about security on a top-secret project, believed to be the new Stealth fighter plane. He took them painstakingly through every detail of how documents are accounted for at Lockheed, and how it could happen that hundreds of papers appeared to be missing.   When they did not know the answers, Larry Kitchen sent them away to find out. When the weekend came, he continued to hold court in the conference room, quizzing employees until he understood Lockheed's security arrangements better than any other senior executive. Then he arranged what he called a ''murder board'' in which Lockheed executives mimicked a Congressional panel and goaded him with hostile questions.   So Lawrence O. Kitchen, the new chairman and chief executive of the Lockheed Corporation, was ready when he went to Washington in late July to explain what a Pentagon official called a ''near disaster'': the company's inability to account for 1,400 documents related to the Stealth program, a project so secret that officially it does not even exist.

headline: Dynamics Net Rises by 3.9%
abstract: The General Dynamics Corporation, a leading military contractor, said yesterday that its net income in the second quarter increased 3.9 percent, to $103.5 million, or $2.43 a share, from $99.6 million, or $2.35 a share, a year ago. Sales were up 18.9 percent, to $2.33 billion, from $1.96 billion.

headline: Bangladesh Elephants Kill 5
abstract: Two wild elephants smashed a mud-and-straw hut in a village in the Chittagong Hills, crushing to death a woman and her four sons while they were sleeping, a Government-owed newspaper said today. The elephants emerged from a forest on June 26 and attacked the hut in Buichara village, 220 miles southeast of Dhaka.

headline: Dayton-Hudson In Note Offering
abstract: The Dayton-Hudson Corporation is offering $150 million of 8 3/8 percent notes due in 1996 at a price of 99.60 to yield 8.435 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Co.   The notes are not callable for seven years, and are rated Aa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by Standard & Poor's Corporation. Dayton-Hudson's notes yielded about 81-hundredths of a percentage point more than 10-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.

headline: CAMPEAU'S GOAL: RETAIL REAL ESTATE
abstract: Robert Campeau, who, through his Campeau Corporation, is pursuing the Allied Stores Corporation in a $3.11 billion offer, lacks neither luck nor ambition.   Born poor in the hardscrabble nickel-mining town of Sudbury, Ontario, he discovered the lure of development in 1949 at the age of 25, when he was building a home for his family in Ottawa. It cost $5,000 to build, but before the house was even finished he accepted a $7,300 offer for it.   The next year, Mr. Campeau built 250 houses in Ottawa, the first of more than 20,000 he would erect in Canada's capital. By 1977, homebuilding seemed small potatoes, and he abandoned the business in favor of his growing commercial and industrial development interests.

headline: President Is Chosen At Arthur D. Little
abstract: Arthur D. Little Inc., the consulting firm based in Cambridge, Mass., said yesterday that it had named Charles R. Lamantia president and chief operating officer.   Mr. Lamantia, 46 years old, has for the last five years been chief executive of Koch Process Systems of Westboro, Mass., which hired him away from Little while it was one of Little's clients. Before going to Koch, a unit of Koch Industries, he had risen to vice president of one of Little's operating units.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Tobacco Co., Stamford, Conn., an independent subsidiary of American Brands Inc., has promoted Vivian A. Parks Jr. to controller and vice president.    * Bishop Graphics, Westlake Village, Calif., a maker of circuit design products, has elected Richard M. Drysdale chairman, president and chief executive officer, succeeding its founder, Martin J. Salvin, who will remain on the board of directors.    * Chronar Corp., Princeton, N.J., which sells turn-key photovoltaic panel manufacturing plants, has named Kenneth A. Watson chief financial officer.

headline: ITALIAN JURY GIVES CRUISE-SHIP KILLER 30-YEAR SENTENCE
abstract: A Palestinian who confessed to the murder of Leon Klinghoffer, an American tourist aboard the liner Achille Lauro, was convicted and sentenced today to 30 years in prison for his actions during the ship's hijacking in October.   In passing sentence, an Italian jury rejected a prosecution demand that the defendant, Magid al-Molqi, be given a life term, Italy's maximum sentence, for killing Mr. Klinghoffer, a 69-year-old New Yorker who used a wheelchair.   Mr. Molqi and two confederates were found guilty of a ''kidnapping for terrorist ends that caused the killing of a person.'' The other two were given prison terms of 24 years and 15 years. Life Terms for 3 Fugitives   The jury, however, ordered life sentences for three fugitives - the Palestinian leader Mohammed Abbas and two associates - who were tried in absentia and whom Italian officials acknowledge they are unlikely to apprehend. All were convicted for their role in organizing the hijacking.

headline: ANOTHER COUP FOR THE FIGHTING GALLOS
abstract: BY now, almost everyone who watches television is familiar with Frank Bartles and Ed Jaymes, the lovable pair of geezers who hawk Bartles & Jaymes wine cooler from their porch. ''Ed took out a second  [ mortgage ]  on his house, wrote to Harvard for an M.B.A., and now we're preparing to enter the wine-cooler business,'' intoned Frank in the first of a series of more than 30 commercials that always end with him humbly thanking the viewers for their support.   But don't let commercials fool you. Frank and Ed are fictional characters portrayed by novice actors. The two people really behind Bartles & Jaymes are not innocent rubes, but two of the shrewdest, most aggressive, most secretive and most feared men in the wine business - Ernest and Julio Gallo.   And with one-year old Bartles & Jaymes, the Gallo brothers have stormed into first place in the booming wine cooler business, one of the few bright spots in an industry suffering from flat sales. That coup, which reversed a two-year decline in sales for Gallo, was only the latest of the remarkable string of successes that allowed the E.&J. Gallo winery to grow from a shed in the Great Depression into the world's largest winery. And the cooler's success has left its stunned competitors gaping in awe.

headline: The U.N. Today: July 15, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Hughes Tool Takes Write-Off
abstract: The Hughes Tool Company, the world's biggest maker of oil-well drilling bits, said today that the ''collapse'' in drilling activity caused it to write down assets $495.7 million in the second quarter.   The write-down, which analysts said was deeper than anticipated, was the largest of several taken by its major competitors, such as the Baker International Corporation and Dresser Industries, already this year.   The move also seems to insure a record loss for the year at Hughes. The company, which posted a profit of $4 million last year, lost $134 million in 1984 and $91 million in 1983.

headline: Payment Halt By Cuba Cited
abstract: Cuba has suspended payments on its short-term commercial debt to Western nations because of an acute shortage of foreign capital, diplomatic sources said today.

headline: PARIS BLASTS POSE A DILEMMA
abstract: It is a safe bet that until a few months ago only a small number of Government officials and journalists in France had heard of a 35-year-old Lebanese named Georges Ibrahim Abdallah.   But Mr. Abdallah, who is the presumed head of a group called the Lebanese Armed Revolutionary Faction, has become a troubling presence since his arrest in Lyons in 1984. Since December, France has been shaken by a wave of terrorist bombings designed to force Mr. Abdallah's release from prison.

headline: British Telecom Net
abstract: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said today that earnings in its first quarter rose 20.6 percent, to $:304 million, or $465 million at the exchange rate at the end of the quarter, from $:252 million a year earlier.

headline: Student Killed in Peru Clash
abstract: One student was killed and 15 were injured in clashes between rival political groups over the results of a campus election at the University of the Center here, the university authorities said today.

headline: Tandon Ties Loss to Shifts
abstract: The Tandon Corporation announced today that it would discontinue the domestic manufacturing of its Winchester disk drives. It also said that its shift to microcomputer manufacturing would result in a substantial loss for the third quarter and affect earnings at least through the end of the year.

headline: Gallo Drops Time Inc. Ads
abstract: The E & J Gallo Winery, based in Modesto, Calif., said today that it was withdrawing all of its advertising from Time Inc. publications because of a cover article in the Sept. 1 issue of Fortune magazine. The winery said the article contained ''many vicious and damaging inaccuracies.''

headline: People
abstract: * David W. Scott has been promoted to vice president, public affairs at Ford Motor Co.

headline: Colombians Accused Of 'Dirty War Tactics'
abstract: Government and guerrilla forces in Colombia are using ''dirty war tactics'' in their fight against each other, according to a group that monitors human rights violations in the Western Hemisphere.

headline: New Ted Bates Chief An Acquisition Expert
abstract: Donald M. Zuckert, the new chairman and chief executive of Ted Bates Worldwide, was deeply involved in the company's acquisition program that helped his predecessor, Robert E. Jacoby, increase billings from about $400 million a year to $3 billion and make Bates worth $450 million to Saatchi & Saatchi of London.   Mr. Zuckert joined the agency in 1960 after serving as an Army captain.

headline: President Leaves Fox's Film Unit
abstract: Alan Horn, the president and chief operating officer of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, resigned yesterday because of differences with the studio chairman who hired him 10 months ago, the company said.   Mr. Horn is the second top Fox executive to leave the company this year. Lawrence Gordon, the president of 20th Century-Fox Entertainment Group, a subsidiary, resigned in January. He cited health problems, but disputes with Barry Diller, Fox's chairman and chief executive, were widely believed in the industry to be a factor in Mr. Gordon's departure.

headline: Nigerian Bus Crash Kills 72
abstract: Seventy-two people died and 30 were seriously injured when two buses collided Sunday in the southern Nigerian state of Bendel. A police spokesman, Bayo Balogun, said today that the accident occurred between Benin City and Agbor, 40 miles east of here. He said the exact cause of the accident was not known.

headline: Daughter of Marcos Granted Stay by Burger
abstract: Chief Justice Warren Burger has stayed a mandate ordering Irene Marcos, daughter of Ferdinand E. Marcos, the deposed Philippine President, to testify before a grand jury or go to jail for contempt of court, a spokesman for the Supreme Court said today.

headline: 4 Americans Among 5 Killed In an Airplane Crash in Brazil
abstract: Four Americans and a Brazilian died when a Brasilia commuter airplane crashed shortly after takeoff Friday near Sao Jose dos Campos, in Sao Paulo State, the air force reported today.   The report gave no details of the crash, except that the aircraft exploded north of Sao Jose dos Campos.   The victims were identified as the pilot, Max Millican; a mechanic, Allan Wilson; two other pilots, Larry McElwaney and Jay Lawrie, all employees of the Atlantic South East Airline of Georgia, and Euclides Silva, a mechanic for the Brazilian State Aeronautic Company.

headline: U.S. Financings Smaller Than Usual
abstract: A light supply of new debt issues is scheduled for sale in the Treasury, corporate and tax-exempt markets this week.   In the Treasury market, the absence of legislation to increase the Federal debt ceiling caused the Treasury to reduce the size of today's regular auction of three-month and six-month bills to a total of $12.6 billion, from the $15.6 billion that had been offered in recent weeks. Late Friday, the outstanding three-month issue was bid at 5.25 percent, and the six-month issue was at 5.38 percent.

headline: A Merger In Public Relations
abstract: AS a byproduct of last week's mega-merger of three major advertising agencies, a mini-merger of two well-known public relations agencies was announced yesterday, creating the third-largest of its kind in the country.   Doremus Public Relations, a division of Doremus & Company, and Needham Porter Novelli, a subsidiary of Needham Harper Steers, are becoming Doremus Porter Novelli. Both are already part of the Omnicom Group Inc., the holding company created by the merger of BBDO International, the Doyle Dane Bernbach Group and Needham Harper Worldwide, and are also part of Omnicom's Diversified Agency Services Group.

headline: SAUDI KIDNAPPED AND FREED IN 2 HOURS IN LEBANON
abstract: A Syrian-sponsored security plan in Moslem West Beirut helped save a Saudi kidnapping victim today.   The abducted man, Soleiman Mohammed al-Mubarak, was freed two hours after he had been seized by gunmen. The authorities here said they thought it was one of the quickest hostage rescues they ever heard of in Beirut, where such abductions are virtually everyday events.   Mr. Mubarak, who is 45 years old and was sent here by the Saudi Government to inspect its closed embassy, was seized by three gunmen as he drove in the residential Sakiet al Janzir quarter. The gunmen forced him out of his red Honda, bundled him in their own Mercedes-Benz and drove off.

headline: SOVIET SEIZES SHIP CAPTAINS OVER SINKING
abstract: The captains of a Soviet passenger liner and a freighter that collided in the Black Sea on Sunday night, killing nearly 400 people, have been arrested, a Soviet official said today.   The official, Albert I. Vlasov, who is a first deputy chief of the Central Committee's Propaganda Department, said in a briefing, the second on the accident, that the two men were in custody and that, after an investigation, ''we will submit the case to a court and the court will mete out punishment.''   Pravda, the party daily, said the captain of the passenger liner, Vadim G. Markov, and the captain of the freighter, Viktor I. Tkachenko, had violated navigational safety rules.   The passenger ship, the Admiral Nakhimov, sank seven minutes after the collision, which occurred at 11:15 P.M. Sunday, Mr. Vlasov said. Soviet officials said previously that the ship sank within 15 minutes.

headline: Rights Group Faults Guatemala for Patrols
abstract: A Guatemalan program of rural security patrols is being used as an instrument of Government oppression, Americas Watch, a New York-based human-rights group, charged in a report released today.   The patrols, called Self-Defense Civil Patrols, enlist villagers to police the areas near their homes.

headline: PROFIT AT CITICORP, HANOVER OFF
abstract: Citicorp and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation reported lower second-quarter earnings yesterday and Wall Street analysts said the profits were well below expectations.   Citicorp, the nation's largest banking organization, said its net income fell 6.3 percent, to $235 million, from $251 million. Earnings per share slid 12 percent, to $1.60, from $1.81.   Manufacturers Hanover, the nation's fourth-largest bank, said earnings fell 4.7 percent, to $93.9 million, from $98.5 million in the 1985 quarter. Earnings per share rose to $1.99, from $1.97, reflecting a lower dividend requirement on preferred stock.

headline: COMMONWEALTH GAMES OPEN ON A NOTE OF WORLD DISCORD
abstract: The Commonwealth Games opened tonight as an unintended showcase of international discord, with 31 of 58 nations withholding their athletes in order to protest Britain's rejection of economic sanctions against South Africa.   World-class politics was the dominant event as Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, welcomed 1,600 athletes in the name of global fellowship. More than 700 other competitors were absent from the ceremony in Meadowbank Stadium in what was designed to be an embarrassing rebuff of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain.

headline: CRAXI SAYS NEW ACCORD WILL LET HIM STAY AS PRIME MINISTER
abstract: Bettino Craxi announced today that political leaders had reached an understanding under which he would stay on as Italy's Prime Minister.   The political leaders said the agreement between Mr. Craxi, a Socialist, and Ciriaco De Mita, the leader of the Christian Democrats, would bring an end to the crisis that has paralyzed Italy's Government for almost a month.   Mr. Craxi declined to go into details or to say whether there was a full resolution. But he said the talks had laid the foundation for ''political stability for the rest of the legislature.'' Parliament's term expires in 1988.

headline: SHULTZ, SEEKING SANCTIONS DELAY, SAYS U.S. AND ALLIES MAY ACT SOON
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz held out the possibility today that the Reagan Administration might join its allies in imposing sanctions against South Africa in two months if Pretoria does not move by then to open negotiations on ending apartheid.   Although he repeated President Reagan's opposition to efforts in Congress to impose economic sanctions, Mr. Shultz, apparently in an effort to delay such moves, introduced the possibility for the first time of joint American-European sanctions in September. He said the Administration wanted the flexibility to increase pressure in coordination with its allies as the situation evolved.   In South Africa, meanwhile, the Government offered a broad welcome today to President Reagan's statement Tuesday on the nation's crisis and said ''foreign intervention and threats'' would only promote a siege mentality in Pretoria. Opposition leaders, by contrast, scorned Mr. Reagan's speech.  [ Page A4. ]  In an atmosphere often charged by emotional debate, Mr. Shultz testified for four hours before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. The debate was dominated by the sanctions issue. On Tuesday, President Reagan strongly opposed any sanctions, leading many in the committee today to express sentiments ranging from disappointment to outrage.

headline: CONFEREES TO STEP UP TAX EFFORT
abstract: After four weeks of reviewing and refining their positions, the House and Senate negotiators on tax revision legislation plan to sit down together this week to try to write a final bill that could affect the finances of nearly every person and company in America.   The time has come, Senator Bob Packwood said over the weekend, to ''lock ourselves in a room and work until we finish.'' The Oregon Republican and head of the Senate conferees said that if the lawmakers failed to reach an agreement before the end of this week, when Congress begins a three-week recess, their task would become more difficult.   ''The problem with going out without a complete package,'' Mr. Packwood said, ''is that every single special-interest group would have one last shot at every single senator and congressman'' during the recess.

headline: Calling In the Credit Counselors
abstract: MOST of us have lived through a cash crisis where ''there is too much month left at the end of the money,'' as the saying goes. Usually the crunch is short-lived - but for some, red ink becomes a way of life.   When debt becomes too much to handle alone, a professional counselor can help. A credit union may be able to refer members to one. Another source of help is a nonprofit organization called the National Foundation for Consumer Credit. The foundation acts as an umbrella for 256 affiliated agencies around the country, most of them operating under the Consumer Credit Counseling Service name. (Do not confuse these agencies with expensive credit clinics that promise to repair poor credit histories.) The C.C.C.S. agencies provide counseling services free, and if a client undertakes a formal debt-repayment program, some groups impose a small charge. In California, for example, the average fee is $13.25 a month. In some states the agencies are funded by donations from local businesses and civic organizations; in others, they keep 10 percent of the money they collect, although the client is credited with the full amount that he or she has paid.

headline: Safeway Net Falls by 8.6%
abstract: Stung by depressed economies in key market areas and strong competition, Safeway Stores Inc. said today that its second-quarter earnings slumped 8.6 percent, to $45.6 million, or 75 cents a share, from $49.9 million, or 83 cents a share, a year ago. The 1986 earnings figure also includes $8.2 million recouped from overfunded pension plans.

headline: WALKER SET TO SELL HOME OIL
abstract: Hiram Walker Resources Ltd. announced an agreement in principle today to sell its Home Oil Ltd. unit to Interprovincial Pipe Line Ltd. for about $1.1 billion (Canadian), or about $793 million (United States).   Ninety-three percent of Hiram Walker is owned by the Gulf Canada Corporation. About 80 percent of Gulf, in turn, is owned by the Reichmann family of Toronto.

headline: WHAT'S NEW AT THE SUPERMARKET
abstract: RUNNING the nation's 31,000 supermarkets is no easy task these days. In New York City and some other urban areas, skyrocketing rents and competition from gourmet takeout places and other food sources are forcing some markets to close their doors. And in others, a leveling off of population growth has caused huge competitive battles for customers.

headline: RESPITE FOR SOUTH AFRICA: A ROYAL WEDDING
abstract: At an office here, the secretary said that the boss had been generous: Television sets were provided to view the event and the staff was permitted to bring cucumber sandwiches and champagne to celebrate.   The cucumber, the secretary added with some pride, was not just any old cucumber, but English cucumber, flown in for the day. The event, she did not need to add, was the royal wedding, live via satellite, from London.

headline: ADVANCED MICRO, INTEL CITE LOSSES
abstract: Citing weak demand from the computer industry, two of the largest semiconductor manufacturers today reported continuing losses for the quarter ended in June. They were Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and the Intel Corporation.   Earnings at Motorola Inc., however, more than doubled, helped by its semiconductor operations.

headline: HOSTILE BID FOR ANDERSON, CLAYTON
abstract: Bear, Stearns & Company and Gruss & Company said they would begin a hostile tender offer tomorrow to acquire Anderson, Clayton & Company for $56 a share in cash, totaling $697 million. The Quaker Oats Company restated its commitment to provide $250 million of the financing in return for getting to purchase the Gaines pet food division of Anderson, Clayton afterward.   In conjunction with the offer, the two New York investment firms filed a lawsuit in the Delaware Chancery Court against Anderson, Clayton and its directors. The suit charges, among other things, that the board did not negotiate with the suitors.

headline: POLITICS IN SUDAN IS DELAYING RELIEF
abstract: A planned relief operation for famine victims in the war-ravaged southern Sudan appears to be caught in a tangle of opposing political considerations.   Officials overseeing the $1 million project, known as Operation Rainbow, had expressed hope that the airlift of an initial 32 tons of food, along with medical supplies, would begin this week to Wau, a Government-held area, and to Yirol, a rebel-held area.   But the officials said Government opposition to the plan had cast doubt on the timing. The operation eventually hopes to carry out two flights a day, delivering 210 tons of food a week.

headline: BEATRICE UNIT SALE CONFIRMED
abstract: BCI Holdings, confirming reports that it would sell the Beatrice Companies' personal products operations for $1.25 billion to an investment group, announced yesterday that it would retain a 20 percent interest in the new company.   The investment group purchasing the operations - known as International Playtex Inc. - is headed by Joel E. Smilow, chairman and president of Playtex.   At the same time, the Revlon Group confirmed that once the purchase became final, Revlon would purchase the division's cosmetics operations from the new owners for $375 million.

headline: Article 482886 -- No Title
abstract: The Boeing Company said today that British Airways had placed what could become the largest order ever for new planes.   The state-owned airline ordered 16 of Boeing's newest jumbo jet, the 747-400, for a total price of $2.3 billion, with deliveries in 1989 and 1990.   In addition, British Airways has options to acquire 12 more of the planes, which would bring the total contract value to $4.1 billion, surpassing the $3.3 billion order Boeing received from Singapore Airlines in March.

headline: Spelling Stake Up
abstract: The Cincinnati-based American Financial Corporation and its chairman, Carl H. Lindner, have raised their stake in Aaron Spelling Productions to 10.2 percent, or 825,000 shares, from 7.7 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Lindner group did not amend its previous statement to the S.E.C. that it intends to review its investment in Spelling ''on a continuing basis.''

headline: Fleet Financial
abstract: The Fleet Financial Group, already among the top five mortgage agencies in the nation, reached agreement to buy the Security Pacific Mortgage Corporation, based in Denver. J. Terrence Murray, Fleet's chairman and president, said the purchase would increase the Providence bank's mortgage servicing portfolio by $2.5 billion, to $17 billion, making Fleet the nation's third-largest mortgage banking company.

headline: Japan Credit For Mexico
abstract: The Export-Import Bank of Japan has agreed to extend Mexico $1 billion worth of credit for three major industrial projects, Mexico's Finance Minister, Gustavo Petrocioli, said today.   Mexico will use the loan for a steel plant, an oil pipeline and development of export-oriented industries, Mr. Petrocoli said at the Japan National Press Club.

headline: Sri Lanka's Account of Blast Is Contradicted by Witnesses
abstract: The Government said today that 13 civilians had been killed in a car-bomb explosion in the eastern city of Batticaloa on Thursday, but residents said many of the victims were killed by security forces in reprisal for the bombing.

headline: FED OFFICIAL SEES NEW RATE DROPS
abstract: A top Federal Reserve official, in a rare prediction on interest rates, said today that mortgage and other long-term rates would decline still further.   ''Long-term interest rates will continue to trend downward,'' said Manuel H. Johnson, a member of the Federal Reserve Board who is awaiting Senate confirmation as vice chairman. The only condition Mr. Johnson attached to his prediction was that the central bank continue to pursue stable prices, which he indicated was scarcely in question.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
K MART STORES PRESIDENT WILL RETIRE IN FEBRUARY
abstract: When Norman G. Milley, the president of K Mart Stores Group, began working full time for the S. S. Kresge Company more than 40 years ago, he earned $21 a week and worked 60 hours.   ''That was the standard workweek in those days,'' he said. ''And it hasn't changed too much. I still work 60 hours a week.''

headline: Tokyo Bonds For Subways
abstract: The Tokyo Metropolitan Government is planning a 100 million Swiss franc bond issue, the first part of 60 billion yen in foreign bonds it plans to issue in the fiscal year ending March 31.

headline: REMARKS BY PREMIER HIGHLIGHT JAPAN'S ATTITUDES ON MINORITIES
abstract: Whatever Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone meant by his remarks about minorities in the United States, some intellectuals and members of minority groups here say, he was reflecting a widespread assumption among Japanese that their homogeneity breeds strength while diversity in other societies can mean weakness.   Today, as he was questioned by opposition politicians in Parliament, Mr. Nakasone again insisted he had intended no slur against ethnic minorities nor the United States. On Tuesday, two Japanese newspapers quoted Mr. Nakasone as having said that the presence of blacks, Puerto Ricans and Mexicans had impaired educational achievement in the United States.   The intellectuals and minority group members seized on his remarks as symptomatic of Japanese attitudes toward outsiders, whether they be foreigners or minorities within Japanese society. For some Japanese, these critics said, the nation's economic success has also bred arrogance.

headline: A Reeling U.S. Industry Is Hopeful
abstract: The resolution of the yearlong trade dispute over semiconductors may breathe new life into the sagging American semiconductor industry.   Analysts estimate that the settlement could mean $2 billion increase in sales annually for American semiconductor manufacturers, but they note that many manufacturers are no longer around to benefit, having abandoned all or part of the market.   The dispute centered on three separate cases against the Japanese, involving Eprom's, and 64-kilobyte and 256-kilobyte random access memory, or RAM, chips. Eprom stands for erasable, programmable, read only memory chips.

headline: DOUBLEDAY: A SHAKY EMPIRE
abstract: Data prepared by a Wall Street investment firm for the possible sale of Doubleday & Company, the publisher and owner of the Mets, shows a company with little growth in its well-known publishing business and an increasing dependency on its baseball club for profitability.   According to the ''introductory memorandum'' and related data being distributed by Dillon Read & Company to potential buyers, Doubleday had $482 million in total revenues for the 1986 fiscal year ended April 30. For that year, it had $7 million in net income, up from $300,000 the previous year and slightly less than in 1984.   More importantly, the Mets contributed $9 million and a one-time sale of radio stations brought in about $14 million last year. Without those non-publishing profits, it appeared that Doubleday would have lost money.

headline: BROWN DROPS OUT AS POSSIBLE ENVOY
abstract: At the urging of the White House, Robert J. Brown today officially removed his name from consideration as the next United States Ambassador to South Africa because of difficulties he was expected to face in winning confirmation by the Senate.   Mr. Brown withdrew as Mr. Reagan prepared for a major policy address in which White House aides said they expected him to call for the release of Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned leader of the African National Congress.   It is already Administration policy, expressed publicly by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, that Mr. Mandela should be released.

headline: Quake Off Mexico's Coast
abstract: An earth tremor measuring 5 on the open-ended Richter scale was recorded early today off the Pacific coast near the Mexican resort of Mazatlan, the National Autonomous University of Mexico said. No damage or injuries were reported

headline: FUND, C.D. YIELDS FALL
abstract: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were lower for the week ended yesterday.   According to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index, the average yield for a six-month C.D. dropped three basis points, or hundredths of a point, to 6.73 percent from 6.76, and the average yield of bank money market accounts, which compete directly with money market mutual funds, declined three basis points, to 6.17.   The drop in yields also extended to C.D.'s with longer maturities, with one-year certificates off five basis points, to 7.01 percent; a two-and-half year certificate down six basis points, to 7.35 percent, and five-year C.D.'s off four basis points, to 7.81.

headline: Cyclops Corp.
abstract: The Mutual Shares Corporation and its affiliates, which hold a combined 11.5 percent stake in the Cyclops Corporation, said they would oppose Cyclops's planned partial liquidation.

headline: Chesebrough Disputes P.& G. Lotion Claim
abstract: Apparently Procter & Gamble and its agency D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles thought that consumers would see a benefit in the fact that its skin lotion, Wondra, dripped less readily from the overturned palm of a hand than did the ''best selling product,'' which happens to be Vaseline Intensive Care Lotion.   It was a case of the old ''rich and creamy'' vs. ''thin and runny.''

headline: PEPSICO TO ACQUIRE KENTUCKY FRIED
abstract: Pepsico Inc., long the No. 2 player in the soft drink business, yesterday said it would acquire the Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant chain for $850 million, a move that would vault it into the No. 2 position in the fiercely contested fast-food industry as well.   The purchase of Kentucky Fried Chicken from RJR Nabisco Inc. would give Pepsico ownership of three of the nation's 10 largest restaurant chains. It already owns Pizza Hut and Taco Bell, both leaders in their categories, and with the addition of Kentucky Fried Chicken, by far the biggest of the chicken chains, Pepsico's restaurant operations would have systemwide sales of more than $7 billion.   The combined operations would push Pepsico past the Pillsbury Company's Burger King unit, which had sales of $4.3 billion last year, and leave it trailing only the ubiquitous McDonald's, which took in $11 billion in 1985. In terms of numbers of outlets, the combined Pepsico chains, with 14,000 restaurants, would exceed McDonald's, which has 9,000.

headline: LONG TERM SECURITIES SHOW SHARP PRICE DROP
abstract: Prices of long-term Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday after economic growth figures gave the credit markets conflicting signals about the direction of the economy.   The weak 1.1 percent rise in G.N.P. for the second quarter was in line with market expectations, but traders were caught off guard by the sizable upward revision in growth for the first quarter of this year and the final quarter of 1985. That suggested that the second quarter could be revised upward too.   ''What got everybody's motor running was the revisions,'' said Alfred G. Roth, a managing director at Chemical Bank. ''Volcker's testimony has now taken on much more importance.''

headline: Court Delays Economist Bid
abstract: A temporary restraining order, issued Thursday, bars the Business International Corporation and Economist Newspaper Ltd. from consummating a sale of the former to the latter.

headline: Colt Chairman Cites Stockholder Gains
abstract: ''Stockholders have always done very well by us,'' said David I. Margolis, chairman and chief executive of Colt Industries. ''It's been our history.''   Colt's latest entry to that history is a recapitalization plan to increase shareholder values. Yesterday, just a day after the plan was announced, Colt's stock zoomed $26.875, to $93.625.

headline: INVESTIGATORS SEEK TO DETERMINE GUNMEN'S IDENTITIES AND AFFILIATION
abstract: With the hijacking of the Pan American plane at Karachi International Airport in Pakistan ending in carnage, the next problem will be for investigators to determine the identities and political affiliation of the gunmen who seized the plane.   Two previously unknown groups in the Middle East said early on that they were responsible for the hijacking, but neither appears to be genuine.
