In Nicosia, Cyprus, an anonymous caller told a Western news agency that the hijacking was done on behalf of the Libyan Revolutionary Cells.   That report suggested that Libya was behind the incident, but the Libyan Government quickly issued an emphatic denial.  [ In Washington, a State Department spokesman said the department had received reports that the terrorists who seized the airliner claimed to be members of a group calling itself the Arab Liberation Organization, which he said was ''previously unknown to us.''  [ When asked if the gunmen might have been acting on behalf of or with assistance from Libya, Syria or Iran, the spokesman said, ''We have no information right now about any kind of involvement by Libya or any other country.'' ]  An official statement broadcast by the Tripoli radio expressed surprise that Libya's name was brought up. ''Libya,'' it said, ''is against terrorism and the killing of innocent people everywhere.''

headline: Key Rates
COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Amsouth Bancorp., Birmingham, Ala., said it agreed to acquire First Tuscaloosa Corp. for stock valued at about $105.6 million.    * Delamarva Power and Light Co., Wilmington, Del., said the Delaware Public Service Commission had cut its electric rates by 6.9 percent, or about $22.8 million.

headline: Founder of Jackson Life Calls Deal a Compliment
abstract: After World War II, Athanase (Tony) Pasant married his high school sweetheart, enrolled at Michigan State University and lived in a 14-foot house trailer. After Army service in the South Pacific, where he contracted malaria, he took a part-time job selling insurance.   Mr. Pasant stayed in the insurance business and has thrived. In 1961, he founded the Jackson National Life Insurance Company in Lansing, Mich.

headline: MANILA PROTESTS U.S. WARNING ON SAFETY OF AIRPORT
abstract: The manager of the Manila airport has asked the United States Federal Aviation Administration to carry out a new inspection and has requested a withdrawal of a Transportation Department warning that security measures at the airport are inadequate.   A senior security official at Manila International Airport said the request had been made both because corrective measures had been taken since a previous inspection and because ''the deficiencies they saw do not warrant the kind of actions they made.''   The airport manager, Reli German, defended the airport, saying, ''Our security measures at the Manila International Airport are in fact better than most international airports, including several in the United States.''

headline: Intermountain Offers Novel 'Crossover' Issue
abstract: The Intermountain Power Agency, in a novel financing that has attracted much attention in the tax-exempt bond market because it is a cheaper way to refund outstanding bonds, is offering $405 million of ''crossover'' bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.   ''There probably will be a lot more issues like this,'' said Bradford R. Higgins, a vice president at Goldman. Under current interest rates, with tax-exempt bonds yielding more than Treasury issues, the new ''crossover'' financing technique saves the Utah-based agency three or four times the amount that would be saved by a more normal refunding, he added.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
FED SEES SUSTAINED GROWTH
abstract: The Federal Reserve predicted today that the economy would show sustained -though not vigorous - growth through 1987 and that inflation would rise moderately from current levels.   At the same time, the central bank effectively downgraded its widely followed M-1 money supply target by reaffirming present ranges while declaring that they had become significantly less meaningful.   This suggested the Fed would continue to allow whatever expansion in the money supply it believed was needed to keep alive the business recovery, which has now lasted more than three and a half years. Semiannual Report to Congress    Today's semiannual report to Congress on its view of the economy and its monetary strategy came in the wake of a recent series of poor to lackluster economic reports that prompted the Fed to cut its discount rate last week without waiting for similar moves by foreign central banks. Because an independent reduction increased the risk of a sharp decline in the value of the dollar, analysts said the action showed the Fed had become worried about the domestic economy.

headline: Stock Buybacks
abstract: To the Editor:   The high real interest rates and dollar exchange levels that resulted from a historic squeeze between savings and planned investment is the root of the repurchase process. The effect of these pressures has been to push down stock valuation in the early 1980's while cash flows, as distinct from reported earnings, were rising to record levels.

headline: World Airways Plan Reported
abstract: World Airways is planning to end all scheduled flights by Sept. 15, according to The Oakland Tribune.   The airline, which started scheduled service out of Oakland Airport on April 11, 1979, will disclose its decision in a letter to employees, the newspaper reported on Sunday.

headline: Airline Proposal
abstract: The Justice Department's Antitrust Division said it still opposes the proposed merger of NWA Inc.'s Northwest Airlines Inc. and Republic Airlines Inc. It said a Transportation Department administrative law judge was wrong in ruling on June 27 that the deal would not substantially reduce competition in any market.

headline: HAMMERHILL GETS BID OF $722 MILLION
abstract: Paul A. Bilzerian, the California investor, said he would begin a cash tender offer today for the Hammermill Paper Company, offering $52 a share in cash, or about $722 million.   Mr. Bilzerian's announcement, which came after the close yesterday of a hectic day of trading in Hammermill stock, confirmed rumors of a takeover bid that had been making the rounds for months. Those rumors, which died down for a while, had arisen again in recent days.

headline: LABORITE LEADER'S WIFE: A POLITICAL PARTNER, TOO
abstract: One recent morning's newspapers carried a picture of Glenys Kinnock setting out from Northampton on an antinuclear march on behalf of the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament.   A few days later, she was shown standing under an umbrella on a rain-drenched London street as anti-apartheid protesters kept a vigil outside a meeting of Commonwealth leaders.   Mrs. Kinnock is photogenic, but she knows that is only part of the reason she gets snapped whenever she shows up to demonstrate for a cause in which she believes. Obviously, the main reason that this part-time teacher of reading in a state school has the status of a political celebrity is that her husband, Neil Kinnock, is leader of the opposition Labor Party and thus a potential Prime Minister after a general election likely to be called next year.

headline: Publishing Unit at I.B.M.
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had created a new business unit to enter the electronic publishing market -small computer systems that create typeset-quality text and pictures camera-ready for printing.   Among personal computer makers, only Apple Computer Inc. has made inroads in electronic publishing, and its Macintosh computer is used to create hundreds of newsletters, company publications and books.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * AFG Industries is offering $100 million of Ba-2/BB--rated 6 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures, due in 2006, at 100 through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The debentures, noncallable for two years, are convertible into the company's common stock at $37.75 a share. In a separate development the company's subordinated debenture rating was raised to Ba-1 from Ba-2 by Moody's.

headline: OIL MARKET STABILIZES, IGNORING BIG INVENTORY
abstract: The oil market yesterday shrugged off an industry report showing increases in crude oil and product inventories. The market seemed to steady after two days of volatile trading and sharp price increases sparked by the OPEC production-limiting agreement.   Yesterday's market action, with prices recovering in the afternoon after a substantial slide in the morning, led some analysts to say oil prices were on a clear upward course.   Other analysts and industry figures, however, continued to express skepticism about the durability of the OPEC accord and the price rise.

headline: Ex-Head of Eaton Unit Gets Posts at Tracor
abstract: Mellon C. Baird was named today president, chief operating officer and a director of Tracor Inc., the company said. Mr. Baird, 55, and the former president of the Eaton Corporation's Defense and Electronics Group, will assume his position as a director tomorrow and his executive posts on Sept. 10.   Mr. Baird will be responsible for the five divisions that make up Tracor's Defense Electronics, Instruments and Components segments, said Frank W. McBee Jr., the company's founder, chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Baird was hired to facilitate the ''expansion of breadth'' of the company's operations, Mr. McBee said.   Mr. McBee, 66, will resign as president but said he had no plans to retire from the company.

headline: China Is Said to Study Proposal by Gorbachev
abstract: Deng Xiaoping, China's top leader, said today that a speech by Mikhail S. Gorbachev calling for improved Chinese-Soviet ties contained positive elements but that China needed to study it carefully, Japanese sources said.   It was the first reported high-level Chinese reaction to the Soviet leader's speech, which Western diplomats say offered several important concessions aimed at improving relations.   The sources said Susumu Nikaido, senior adviser to Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, met today with Mr. Deng and the Chinese Communist Party leader, Hu Yaobang, at the northern Chinese resort of Beidaihe.

headline: Sheaffer's New Chief 'Passionate About Pens'
abstract: When Murray R. Eisner was being interviewed 10 years ago for a marketing job at the Sheaffer Eaton division of Textron Inc., he used a ballpoint pen to take notes at a luncheon. He was immediately chastised by a Textron executive for not using a Sheaffer pen. Mr. Eisner tried to give the pen to a waitress, then the Textron executive told him to ''get it out of circulation.'' He threw it away.

headline: FEARS OF U.S. COMPANIES RISE ON COST OF SOUTH AFRICA TIES
abstract: New pressures are increasing the burden on American companies operating in South Africa, prompting many to leave or consider doing so.   American corporations are having to grapple with the possibility that remaining in South Africa may cost them substantial business with local and state governments at home and could drive down their stock price, according to many investment experts, consultants and corporate executives.   At least 18 American companies have pulled out of South Africa so far this year, and many of the 250 remaining seem to be re-examining their options. ''In five years almost no American investment will be left in South Africa,'' Pierre A. Rinfret, who runs an international business consulting firm in New York, predicted recently.   Even the International Business Machines Corporation, one of the largest companies in South Africa, said earlier this year that it was ''increasingly discouraged'' with the situation there. In conversations, both on and off the record, executives at several companies appeared far less sanguine about their South African operations than they were just a year ago.

headline: WHAT'S NEW AT THE SUPERMARKET; Meeting a Mate Amidst the Produce
abstract: FEW Washingtonians call the Georgetown Safeway by its proper name. The store, which is in one of the country's hottest singles spots, is usually called the ''Social Safeway.'' Cosmopolitan Magazine just listed it as one of the country's most likely places to meet eligible men.

headline: Oil Drop Gives Dekalb a Loss
abstract: The Dekalb Corporation today reported a loss of $51.2 million in the fiscal third quarter, ended May 31, in contrast to a profit of $5.5 million, or 45 cents a share, a year earlier. The oil and gas exploration and farm seed company, based in De Kalb, Ill., said the loss reflected a $49.1 million write-down of its energy-related assets.

headline: Kraft to Acquire Keeler
abstract: Kraft Inc., one of the nation's largest food distributors, has signed a definitive agreement to acquire Keeler Foods Inc., a food distributor based in Santa Ana, Calif., for $16.4 million in cash and notes. Keeler, which had sales of $84 million last year, distributes more than 8,000 items such as meats, seafood, dairy products, and kitchen appliances, to about 3,000 accounts.

headline: Advertising; Purolator Hires Road Runner
abstract: AS advertising spokesman for an overnight express service, the Road Runner seems an almost inspired choice.   That frantic little dickens, who has been starring in Warner Brothers' animated Looney Tunes since 1948, has in the eyes of consumers so many of the positive qualities - such as speed and dependability - that an express company might desire, he would be a natural. And he has the built-in foil, Wile E. Coyote, who always comes out second best and can easily be adapted to play a role that embodies all other courier services in that highly competitive world.   Best of all, the batty bird's only known dialogue can be adopted to a sales purpose, as in 1-800-BEEP BEEP.

headline: BUSINESS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, AUGUST 14, 1986
abstract: The Economy The heads of the Senate and House tax delegations neared an agreement on the main elements of a tax overhaul bill. Representative Rostenkowski said that he and Senator Packwood might have a completed package ready to present to the other conferees by noon today. If so, the conference committee should be able to reach a basic accord by the end of the week, when Congress begins a three-week recess, although formal approval cannot come until after Labor Day.  [ Page D1. ]  Retail sales inched up 0.1 percent in July. The rise would have been more, but a big drop in auto sales held the total down. Many economists are optimistic about consumer buying in the months ahead.  [ D1. ]  Sales of new American-made cars rose 7.4 percent in the Aug. 1-10 period, compared with the period last year.  [ D6. ]  A bill to help deal with failures of financial institutions was approved by the Senate Banking Committee. The bill would provide $15 billion over three years to the fund that insures thrift institution deposits, and it would give Federal regulators emergency powers to arrange bank takeovers.  [ D15. ]  The House Budget panel is seeking ways to cut $10 billion in Federal spending.  [ A24. ]  Companies Charles R. Schwab resigned from the BankAmerica board. Mr. Schwab had become known as the dissident among the ailing bank's directors. He joined the board in 1983 after selling his Charles Schwab & Company discount brokerage to the bank in a deal that made him BankAmerica's largest shareholder, but he has since sold most of his stock. Mr. Schwab said last night that he was leaving the board to give full attention to the brokerage.

headline: Coke-Dr Pepper Deal Is Blocked
abstract: A Federal District Court Judge today issued a preliminary injunction against the Coca-Cola Company, halting its bid to buy the Dr Pepper Company for $470 million.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 11, 1986:

headline: Advertising; Evaluating Children's Preferences
abstract: ''CHILDREN have gotten to be a hot item,'' said Elaine Morgenstein, who was talking about children as targets of consumer research. And she couldn't be more pleased, since that is what she does.   She interviews them from kindergarten age up to get their reactions to advertising concepts and messages, advertising spokesmen, product performance, food taste and that sort of thing.   And as she has discovered as executive vice president of M/E Marketing and Research, there is a new interest on the part of marketers in getting the opinions of children as well as those of their mommies.

headline: Film Makers Study Venture
abstract: Lorimar-Telepictures Inc. and Tri-Star Pictures have been considering the possibility of joining together to raise several hundred million dollars in equity and debt to produce motion pictures.   Such an agreement would provide additional films for Tri-Star.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: * Mark J. Minkin has joined Altman & Manley, Boston, as executive vice president.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM SHULTZ REMARKS TO REPORTERS
abstract: Following are excerpts from Secretary of State George P. Shultz's news conference in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times:   OPENING STATEMENT     Prime Minister Shevardnadze and I have concluded two days of serious substantive talks that have included around an hour's session with the President. All together, between he and I we have spent around 14 hours together in various ways and we covered a full agenda.   These two days have indicated that considerable potential for progress exists. But the cloud that hangs over all this is the fact that Nicholas Daniloff is not free to leave the Soviet Union. That issue was at the top of our agenda throughout these meetings. Other human-rights issues also received full attention. The case of Nicholas Daniloff must be brought to a satisfactory resolution quickly if the potential that exists is to be realized.

headline: HealthAmerica Chief Resigns
abstract: The HealthAmerica Corporation, a large health maintenance organization, said Friday that Philip N. Bredesen had resigned as president and chief executive for personal reasons. Mr. Bredesen will continue as chairman.

headline: Spotting the Real Costs of Regulation
abstract: Who Profits: Winners, Losers, and Government Regulation, by Robert A. Leone. Basic Books, N.Y. 248 pages, $17.95.    ONE problem with economics, according to the economist who wrote this book, is that it has become preoccupied with questions of macroeconomics: ''What should we do about the Federal deficit? Is the money supply expanding too rapidly? Is Keynesian economics dead? Should 'supply-siders' control Federal fiscal policy?''   They are all important questions, but the economic challenges most of us face are at the level of individual industries, individual companies and governmental agencies. Thus, this book concentrates on the microeconomy - individual enterprises competing in individual markets and dealing with public policy initiatives.

headline: Gray Drug Fair Put on the Block
abstract: The Sherwin-Williams Company said that it planned to sell its 450-store Gray Drug Fair chain, and had retained Goldman, Sachs & Company to find a buyer.

headline: INVESTIGATION IS SOUGHT
abstract: Two human rights organizations called yesterday for an investigation of reports that a military patrol in Santiago had set fire to two teen-agers, one of whom is a permanent resident in the United States.   The teen-agers were taken to a hospital in Santiago, where they were reported to be in critical condition.   The two groups, Amnesty International and Americas Watch, said they had received reports that soldiers beat the teen-agers, 19-year-old Rodrigo Andres Rojas de Negri and 18-year-old Carmen Quintana Arancibia, who were touring a shantytown early Wednesday morning, doused them with a flammable liquid and set them on fire.

headline: U.S. Envoy on Latin Tour
abstract: President Reagan's special envoy for Central America, Philip C. Habib, arrived in El Salvador today for talks with President Jose Napoleon Duarte and other officials, Government and United States Embassy spokesmen said.

headline: GORBACHEV URGES EUROPE TO PURSUE OWN INTERESTS
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev told President Francois Mitterrand today that Western Europe should not let itself be treated as a ''theater of operations'' and should set an example of peaceful coexistence.   The Soviet leader did not mention the United States by name, but the thrust of his comments at a dinner for the French visitor was that Western Europe should be more assertive in pursuing its own interests.   President Mitterrand arrived today on a four-day visit after meeting with President Reagan at the July 4 celebrations in New York.

headline: Top Official of I.M.F. Is Said to Plan to Quit
abstract: Jacques de Larosiere, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, has told its executive board that he intends to resign at the end of this year or as early as possible next year, according to sources close to him.   The leading candidates to succeed Mr. de Larosiere, who is midway through his second five-year term, include Onno Ruding, Finance Minister of the Netherlands, and Lomberto Dini, deputy governor of the Bank of Italy, according to the sources, who asked not to be identified.

headline: Arms Aide Is Nominated
abstract: President Reagan announced today that he was nominating Lynn Marvin Hansen to be assistant director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. Mr. Hansen has been an alternate delegate at the East-West talks on security in Stockholm.

headline: Honduran Chief Affirms Ban On U.S. Trainers for Contras
abstract: President Jose Azcona Hoyo has said that ''not a single U.S. soldier'' will be allowed into Honduras to train rebels who seek to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government.

headline: Indonesia Aircraft Deal
abstract: The Indonesian Government has signed an agreement to buy 12 F-16 fighters from the General Dynamics Corporation for at least $432 million, spokesmen for the Indonesian military and the United States Embassy said today.

headline: Chairman of Color Tile Not Surprised by Offer
abstract: When Tandycrafts Inc. was spun off from the Tandy Corporation, John A. Wilson went with it. When Color Tile Inc. was spun off from Tandycrafts in April 1979, Mr. Wilson went with it again. Today, as chairman, president and chief executive of the large home improvement products retailer in Fort Worth, he is faced with the possibility of his company going private.   The company announced Friday that a group made up of senior management and major shareholders had offered to acquire the company for $25 a share in cash, or a total of $237 million. The group, which already owns about 25 percent of the 9.5 million shares outstanding, is led by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners Inc. Mr. Wilson is not part of the group, which owns 25 percent, and would not say whether he himself would stay on and participate in the buyout.

headline: THE RUSH TO HIRE L.A. LAWYERS
abstract: ANTHONY J. ONCIDI, a young associate at a Los Angeles law firm, received a tantalizing telephone call the other day. A ''headhunter'' asked if he was interested in moving four blocks to the rapidly expanding Los Angeles branch of a New York law firm, for a 50 percent pay increase to $90,000.   ''It was very seductive,'' Mr. Oncidi recalled. ''It's easy to be dazzled.'' But he decided that he was happy at his current firm, Sheppard, Mullin, Richter & Hampton, and he thought his chances of becoming a partner were not as good at the New York-based firm, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. He also assumed he would have to work many more hours if he switched jobs. So he declined.   Someone else will take the job. New York law firms are streaming into Los Angeles these days, snatching away partners and associates from local firms with juicy wage hikes. At least 37 New York law firms have opened offices in Los Angeles, mostly in the past few years and many of them within the last 12 months.

headline: 2 POWERS AGREE TO DISCUSS WAYS TO VERIFY A-TESTS
abstract: The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed in principle to discuss problems of verifying the underground testing of nuclear weapons, Administration officials said today.   Officials said the proposed meeting was likely to be held this summer, although no decision has been made on time or place.   These discussions would be the first on verification under the Reagan Administration and might lead to progress on the issue of nuclear testing, some officials said. Two Sides Long Deadlocked    The two sides have been deadlocked on the testing issue. The United States wants to improve verification procedures under two existing treaties that limit the size of underground explosions. The United States has said that it will not ratify the two treaties, which were signed in the 1970's, until additional measures are agreed to. The Soviet Union wants to discuss ways to verify a total ban on weapon testing.

headline: PRESIDENT CHOSEN AT B.F. GOODRICH
abstract: Leigh Carter was named president and chief operating officer of the B. F. Goodrich Company yesterday.   The title of president was previously held by Patrick C. Ross, who has become chairman and chief executive officer of the Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Company, a 50-50 joint venture. Since Aug. 4 it has included the tire operations of Uniroyal Inc. and B. F. Goodrich.

headline: THE PEOPLE WHO WERE PATCO
abstract: THE change in speeds is what amuses David Livingston. All those years, the big airplanes flying at hundreds of miles an hour depended on him to get in and out of airports. Now commuter trains in Philadelphia follow his instructions. To him, they barely seem to move. ''One of the controllers from Newark who's doing this too said that it's like going from Star Wars to stagecoaches,'' Mr. Livingston chuckled. ''That's about what it's like.'' It was Mr. Livingston's day off, and he was having coffee with his wife at the Ritz diner in Philadelphia, where he lives. He is a sturdy, solemn-eyed, genial man of 38. He laughed some -a good, hearty laugh - even though his life over the last five years hasn't been a great deal of fun.   On Aug. 3, 1981, David ''Doc'' Livingston joined one of the most famous strikes in recent history. Defying the orders of President Reagan, 11,345 air traffic controllers belonging to the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization (PATCO) walked off their jobs in a dispute over work conditions and money. The President decertified their union and terminated every one of them.   In the ensuing years, Mr. Livingston has bounced from job to job, suffering considerable family ferment and self-doubt. He is trying to crawl out from under heavy debt, he has lost his house and he is looking for a profession that will thrill him as much as keeping apart airplanes did.

headline: PRETORIA'S FORCES SAID TO CONDUCT DRIVE IN SOWETO TO END RENT STRIKE
abstract: South African security forces were reported yesterday to have made a sweep through the black township of Soweto in an attempt to get striking residents to pay their rents.   The Soweto municipal council had set Tuesday as a deadline for the rent boycotters to pay for their municipal housing but few showed up, according to sources in South Africa reached from New York.   ''They went in demanding to see receipts for rent,'' Len Kalane, the news editor of The City Press, a leading black Soweto weekly newspaper, said by telephone.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Alumax Inc., San Mateo, Calif., an integrated U.S. aluminum company, has named Paul E. Drack president and chief executive, effective Aug. 15.

headline: REACTION IN CONGRESS TO SPEECH IS MOSTLY NEGATIVE
abstract: Congressional leaders from both parties voiced dissatisfaction today with President Reagan's speech on South Africa and said that Congress would ignore his objections and adopt economic sanctions.   Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the Republican whip, said of the President: ''He knows we have got to do something. He knows we will do something. He knows it is an issue we cannot hide from.''

headline: Saudi Oil Output Up
abstract: Saudi Arabia, the biggest oil producer in the Middle East, is raising the ante in its high-risk strategy to force coordinated production cuts on other major petroleum exporters, oil analysts said today.   With oil prices dropping this week to their lowest levels in years, Saudi Arabia is continuing to increase production, the analysts said.

headline: KMG Main Denies Merger Report
abstract: KMG Main Hurdman, the international accounting firm, said that it had received offers to merge with ''a number of accounting firms,'' including Peat Marwick. But it denied a report in The Wall Street Journal that it is close to a combination with Peat Marwick, and it said any merger was some time off.

headline: U.S.-Japan Air Talks
abstract: Japanese and American negotiators began talks today to revise a 34-year-old civil air transport agreement, an American Embassy official said.

headline: CUBANS ARE OUT IN FORCE AT THE 11TH TORONTO FILM FESTIVAL
abstract: From the smoke of their cigars to the rich bite of their dark rum, but particularly through the 23 films they brought from Havana, Cubans are a major presence at this year's Toronto Film Festival.   A group of some 20 film makers and Government officials said part of their purpose was to heighten awareness of Cuban movies in North America, including the United States. In addition, they are seeking to publicize both the Havana film festival in December and a film school for Latin Americans opening in Havana later this year.

headline: New Bentley Cars
abstract: Rolls-Royce Motors Inc., a unit of Vickers Ltd. in Britain, is starting a new line of Bentley cars in an effort to increase sales of its luxury cars, according to Robert Schwartz, president and chief executive. Mr. Schwartz indicated that the new Bentleys would be aimed at young, wealthy professionals who could afford the $90,000 price. The two models, the Bentley ''8'' and the Continental Convertible, will be available in mid-October.

headline: Carter Faults Reagan On Zimbabwe Aid Cut
abstract: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that the Reagan Administration was wrong to have cut off economic aid to Zimbabwe as a result of a diplomatic episode there July 4 that caused Mr. Carter to walk out of a reception.   Mr. Carter and an American diplomat left the reception at the United States Embassy in Harare after a Zimbabwean Cabinet minister read a speech attacking United States policy toward South Africa.

headline: U.S. News to Publish Edition in Chinese
abstract: U.S. News & World Report said yesterday that it would publish a Chinese-language version of the newsweekly in conjunction with United Daily News in Taiwan, which will translate the magazine's contents and print the Chinese edition.

headline: Soviet Says U.S. Conducted Secret Nuclear Test in Desert
abstract: The Soviet Union said today that the United States held a secret nuclear test last week in the Nevada desert.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, JULY 5, 1986
abstract: The Economy    Banking legislation is unlikely to be passed this year, members of Congress and banking regulators say, because of the short time left before elections and disagreements among those supporting and opposing various measures. A major bill was introduced in the Senate and four bills are pending in the House.  [ Page 33. ]

headline: Minstar Stake in Enron
abstract: Minstar Inc., controlled by the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs, raised its stake in Enron Inc. to 11.4 percent from 10.2 percent. Separately, the Leucadia National Corporation said it had lowered its stake in Minstar to 1.8 percent, from 11 percent.

headline: LONG LEGAL ORDEAL FORECAST FOR REPORTER IF U.S.-SOVIET ACCORD EMERGES
abstract: A leading expert on the Soviet legal system said today that the American journalist accused of espionage in the Soviet Union may face a long ordeal if the United States and the Soviet Union do not make political arrangements to free him.   The expert, Harold J. Berman, who taught at Harvard Law School from 1948 to 1985, discussed the criminal statute under which the journalist, Nicholas S. Daniloff, has been charged and described the procedures that would ordinarily be followed in such a case.   Mr. Daniloff, a correspondent for U.S. News & World Report, told a colleague in Moscow by telephone today that he had been accused of violating Article 65 of the criminal code of the Russian republic, the largest of the 15 republics in the Soviet Union. Mr. Daniloff has been in Lefortovo Prison in Moscow since he was arrested Aug. 30 by K.G.B. agents who said a Soviet acquaintance had given him secret materials.   Mr. Berman said Article 65 was a very broad law. ''It is applicable even if the accused person was not working for any foreign intelligence agency, provided that the information in question was a state secret,'' he said.

headline: Texas Bill To Aid Banks
abstract: Gov. Mark White today added an interstate banking proposal to the agenda of a special legislative session that will also consider a tax increase. The Governor initially called the special session for budget cuts to ease the state's $3.5 billion deficit.

headline: Net Rises 7.2% at Whirlpool
abstract: The Whirlpool Corporation said today that it had earned $52.4 million, or $1.42 a share, in the second quarter, up 7.2 percent from $48.9 million, or $1.34 a share, a year ago.   About 11 cents of the new quarterly per-share profit was the result of new pension accounting guidelines, the company said.

headline: Budget Chief On Changes
abstract: James C. Miller 3d, the Federal budget director, said today that the Reagan Administration was unlikely to seek major changes in the tax bill after it was enacted.   However, Mr. Miller, who directs the Office of Management and Budget, said the Administration might seek future adjustments in the legislation.

headline: Three New Reasons to Fear Junk Bonds
abstract: EARLIER this summer, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued its first study ever of the market for high-risk bonds - so-called junk bonds. The study, which will strongly influence the Administration's policy toward junk bonds and, indirectly, toward the hostile takeovers that the bonds often finance, arrived at a startling conclusion: There is no cause for concern, even though junk bond issues have soared in recent years. Rather, the report concluded that junk bonds are an ''innovative reaction,'' with only such risks as were ''fully obvious'' to investors. There is no justification, it said, for limits to junk-bond financing in takeovers - or anywhere else, for that matter.   Such assurances ought to be welcome from an agency that was created to deal with highly leveraged holding companies and other securities abuses of the 1920's. Alas, in this study the S.E.C. staff lobbied the issues rather than explored them. The report seems designed more to discredit the Federal Reserve Board's recent ruling restricting junk bond financing of tender offers than to examine important issues.

headline: The U.N. Today: Sept. 18, 1986
BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Adelphia Communications Corp. is offering $100 million of B-3/CCC+ rated 13 percent senior subordinated notes due in 1996 at 98.632 to yield 13 1/4 percent, and 2.5 million common shares at $14.25 a share through Paine Webber Inc. The notes are not callable for five years.    * Champion International Corp. is issuing $75 million of 8 1/4 percent non-callable Eurobonds due in 1991 at 101 1/8 through Morgan Guaranty Ltd.

headline: Tanker Is Reported Hit By Iraqi Jets
abstract: Iraqi jet fighters crippled a tanker and an Iranian tugboat in the northeastern Persian Gulf in an effort to tighten a blockade on Iran's Kharg Island oil terminal, gulf-based marine salvage executives said today.   An Iraqi military official speaking on the Baghdad radio announced in a series of broadcasts beginning Saturday night three raids on large maritime targets.

headline: MILLIONS IN AFRICA HURT BY DIP IN AID, RELIEF UNITS SAY
abstract: A drastic drop in private and Goverment contributions to African emergency relief programs threatens millions of people still facing starvation, officials at relief and development agencies report.   Officials at Unicef, Save the Children, World Vision and other organizations said the drop might harm their ability to sustain both relief and rehabilitation programs at a time when millions of Africans still depend on food distribution and battered African countries are trying to farm again.   ''The fund-raising situation is catastrophic,'' said Reinhard Freiberg, the deputy director of funding at Unicef, whose emergency appeal for Africa has netted only $13 million this year compared with $102 million last year. ''Our field offices are screaming, and we could soon face a situation that is at least as serious as last year.''

headline: Lorimar Plans Separate Unit
abstract: The Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation, the diversified entertainment and communications concern, said today that it planned to make its entertainment arm a separate affiliate in a partial restructuring.   The new unit, Lorimar-Telepictures Entertainment Corporation, which produces such television hits as ''Dallas'' and ''Falcon Crest,'' told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it planned an initial public offering of 16 million shares of common stock.   The parent company will be renamed Lorimar-Telepictures Group Inc. and will still own about 85 percent of the outstanding common stock of the entertainment affiliate.

headline: Japan View of Baker Talks
abstract: Japan's Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, said today that during a weekend meeting, the American Treasury Secretary, James A. Baker 3d, did not request interest rate cuts or other specific measures to stimulate Japan's economy.   Mr. Miyazawa, who met with his counterpart for three hours in San Francisco, said that Mr. Baker had said he welcomed current Japanese attempts to increase economic growth.

headline: AUG. 11-20 AUTO SALES DOWN 1.3%
abstract: Sales of new cars by the major domestic manufacturers fell 1.3 percent in the August 11-20 period, hurt by a 10.4 percent drop at the General Motors Corporation.   Brisk sales of light trucks, however, brought the total light-vehicle sales, including cars and light trucks, to 297,790, up 6.6 percent from mid-August of 1985.   Truck sales were especially strong at the Ford Motor Company which reported a 77.4 percent increase in light-truck deliveries from a somewhat soft period last year.

headline: Careers; Doctorates In Business Strategy
abstract: WANT to see doors opening to a better job? Obtaining a doctorate in strategic management might be the way.   ''It is not for the disgruntled, but it does offer career opportunities,'' said Dr. Arnold C. Cooper, professor of management at Purdue University.   In its Krannert Graduate School of Management, Purdue has a program for students, some middle-aged and with M.B.A. degrees, to gain Ph.D.'s in strategic management. Although it can take about three years to obtain, the degree can lead to a better job. One reason is that businesses, both large and small, have been developing and upgrading strategic management groups.

headline: G.M.-Suzuki Deal Seen
abstract: The General Motors Corporation and the Suzuki Motors Company of Japan are expected to announce on Wednesday a $466 million joint venture to build subcompact cars and four-wheel-drive vehicles in Canada, according to industry sources and published reports.   G.M. and Suzuki are expected to announce that the plant, where the automobiles will be assembled, will be built in Ingersoll, Ontario, about 100 miles southwest of Toronto. The project, which has been under discussion for two years, is to produce 120,000 subcompact cars and 80,000 four-wheel-drive vehicles a year, sources said.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday   None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Producer PricesJune

headline: Apple Price Cuts
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. said that it was lowering prices for its Macintosh computers and Laserwriter printer.

headline: ISRAEL ATTACKS PRO-SYRIAN GROUPS WITH AIR STRIKE DEEP IN LEBANON
abstract: Israeli Air Force planes attacked pro-Syrian Palestinian positions 15 miles from the capital today. Four people were reported killed and five wounded.   It was the second Israeli air strike against Palestinian guerrilla bases in Lebanon in less than a week and one of the deepest into Lebanon in many months.

headline: Envoy to Ivory Coast Named
abstract: Dennis Kux, a career diplomat, was nominated today as Ambassador to the Ivory Coast, the White House announced. Mr. Kux, 54 years old, has held posts in Pakistan, India, West Germany and Turkey. He would succeed Robert Hopkins Miller.

headline: Senate Debates Tax Bill; Wide Approval Is Predicted
abstract: With no doubt that the bill will be approved by a comfortable margin, the Senate began its final debate on tax revision legislation today.   Senator Bob Packwood, the chairman of the Finance Committee, predicted that between 70 and 85 of the 100 senators would vote for the bill.   One of the leading opponents, Senator John C. Danforth, said he was speaking against the measure because he wanted to explain his views to the Senate and ''not because I think I'm going to win.''   The House of Representatives approved the final version of the sweeping legislation on Thursday. After Senate approval, which is likely no later than early next week, the measure will go to the White House for President Reagan's signature. The President has given enactment of what he calls tax reform the highest legislative priority of his second term.

headline: CHILE POLICE SCATTER MOURNERS
abstract: Riot policemen firing tear gas and water cannon disrupted a funeral procession of 2,000 people today as they mourned a youth believed to have been burned to death by soldiers.   Four mourners were injured and the United States Ambassador to Chile was trapped briefly in the panic after the police moved in while the coffin of the youth, 19-year-old Rodrigo Rojas de Negri, a Chilean-born resident of Washington, was carried out of the Chilean Human Rights Commission.   Angry mourners shouting ''We want justice!'' and ''Fascism killed him!'' began yelling ''Assassins!'' as the police fired tear gas and jets of water into the crowd of 2,000 awaiting the start of the funeral march. Witnesses said the police also used tear gas to disperse another crowd that planned to join the march.

headline: Farm Credit Shortfall Seen
abstract: According to the General Accounting Office, the $64 billion Government-regulated Farm Credit System, the nation's largest farm lender, probably will exhaust its financial reserves early next year and have to ask Congress for a bailout.   The G.A.O. has estimated that the system's losses this year would hit $2.9 billion, eclipsing losses in 1985 of $2.7 billion.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Cincinnati Microwave Inc., Cincinnati, said James L. Jaeger, its chief executive, had offered to buy about 5 million shares at $11.25 a share, or the shares in Cincinnati Microwave he did not already own.    * CNB Bancshares Inc., Evansville, Ind., said it had agreed in principle to merge with Farmers National Bank, in a stock transaction.    * CNW Corp., Chicago, said it had completed the sale of 826 miles of railroad track in its Chicago and North Western Transportation Co. subsidiary's system to Dakota, Minnesota & Eastern Railroad Corp. for about $26 million.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
Elf Aquitaine Stock
abstract: The French Finance Ministry said it had fixed a price of 305 francs a share, or the equivalent of about $45.54, for the sale of a 14 percent stake in Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine. The shares closed yesterday at 339 francs. The state-owned Entreprise de Recherches et d'Activites Petrolieres owns 64.4 percent of Elf Aquitaine.

headline: 2 LEBANESE BROTHERS DENY ROLE IN WAVE OF PARIS BOMBINGS
abstract: Two Lebanese men whom French authorities are seeking for questioning in the Paris bombings convened a news conference here today to deny that they were involved in the attacks.   France has offered a $150,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of the men, who are brothers of Georges Ibrahim Abdallah, a suspected Lebanese terrorist currently serving a four-year prison term on weapons charges. The group believed responsible for the wave of Paris bombings has demanded the release of Mr. Abdallah and two other terrorist suspects.

headline: Bond Market's Revival Seen
abstract: The bond markets, which dote on bad economic news, almost seem certain to flourish in coming weeks. In spite of revival efforts, the outlook for growth remains tepid at best, most analysts say. That means interest rates, which have been falling for the better part of a year, are likely to decline further.   ''The economy has been in a listless growth pattern ever since the middle of 1984,'' said Milton W. Hudson, senior vice president and head of the economic analysis department at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. ''It's a worrisome situation.'' News about the economy is never far from the minds of market participants, but it will return to center stage this week, now that the Treasury's $28 billion quarterly refunding has been completed. Government reports on industrial production and retail sales for July are scheduled to be released this week, the first real signs of how the economy is doing as it enters the second half of the year. Not many analysts are looking forward to great things.

headline: Chairman of Owens Fights Hostile Bid
abstract: When William W. Boeschenstein was young, his father, Harold, was put in charge of a company that was being formed by the Owens-Illinois Corporation and Corning Glass Works to manufacture glass fibers and develop uses for the new technology.   Forty-eight years after the founding of Owens-Corning Fiberglas, William Boeschenstein, the second member of his family to hold the title of chairman, finds himself in a desperate fight to retain control of the concern, which now has sales of more than $3 billion a year and a market value of more than $2 billion.   Earlier this week, Wickes Companies, a retail and building products concern, based in Santa Monica, Calif., started a hostile tender offer in an attempt to acquire Owens-Corning, a public company in which neither Corning nor Owens-Illinois has a stake. If successful, the $2.1 billion acquisition of Owens-Corning would be the boldest expansion move yet for Wickes, a company that emerged from bankruptcy last year under Sanford C. Sigoloff, its chairman, who has kept a high-profile while aggressively expanding his company.

headline: 6 SUSPENDED AT KARACHI AIRPORT
abstract: At least six members of the Karachi airport security force have been suspended for negligence in allowing the hijackers of a Pan American World Airways jumbo jet to drive onto the tarmac in a van disguised to look like an official security van, official sources at the airport disclosed yesterday.   According to reports there, three of the hijackers wore security personnel uniforms, consisting of light blue shirts and dark blue trousers. They were also apparently able to obtain security badges or stars in a marketplace in Karachi, the informants said.   In addition, officials said the Suzuki van the hijackers rented had apparently been painted the same blue color of the official van used by the airport security force. There was an unconfirmed report that they had added a light and a siren on the roof to help complete the disguise.

headline: RULING TODAY ON HUNTS' BANKRUPTCY FILING SITE
abstract: A Federal judge said today he would rule Thursday on whether bankruptcy filings made by the Hunt brothers should be transferred to his jurisdiction in Dallas from the Federal Bankruptcy Court in New Orleans.   If the judge does decide to transfer the case, he could determine whether he would preside over the bankruptcy proceedings himself in Federal District Court or turn the case over to one of two Federal bankruptcy judges in Dallas.   Banks locked in a multibillion-dollar dispute with three Hunt brothers - Nelson Bunker, W. Herbert and Lamar - consider the ruling from Judge Barefoot Sanders of great importance. They say the bankruptcy reorganization could be executed more quickly in Dallas, where the banks are defending themselves against two suits brought by the Hunts.

headline: Treasury Bonds in Rebound
abstract: The credit markets did an about-face yesterday, with prices of Treasury securities rising enough to more than offset Tuesday's declines.   Dealers said there was substantial retail buying in all Treasury issues, as investors who have been sitting on the sidelines rushed to take advantage of the more attractive prices and higher yields that resulted from Tuesday's selloff. By late in the day, the price of the key 30-year Treasury bond was up about a point to 101 11/ 32, to yield 7.14 percent.   Price gains for other actively traded Treasury issues ranged from 18/32 to 1 1/2 points. The interest rate for three-month bills was 5.86 percent, down 9 basis points, and the rate for six-month bills was 5.88 percent, down 11 basis points. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.

headline: SUDDENLY, A HAVEN FOR BASQUES IS FULL OF HAZARDS
abstract: His name was Iker, he said, and in recent weeks he had been living on the run, sleeping in friends' houses and going out as little as possible.   One of nearly 700 Spanish Basques living in France as temporary refugees, he was a potential assassination target for G.A.L., a mysterious underground group that is said to have links to the Spanish intelligence services.   ''But it's not G.A.L. I'm afraid of,'' he said. ''It's the French Government.''

headline: SPEAKERS AT U.N. URGE ACTION AGAINST TERRORISM
abstract: The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, urged the General Assembly today to combat ''the scourge of international terrorism.''   Sir Geoffrey was one of 11 speakers, including Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union, on the second day of the Assembly's 41st session, and terrorism was a recurrent theme.   Speaking for the European Community, Sir Geoffrey said the 12-nation group had served as a model for other nations in building stability and trust. This trust, he said, ''has allowed us to build up our joint political and economic strength.''

headline: CHAPTER 11 DELAYED FOR FRONTIER
abstract: People Express Inc. said yesterday that it had put off until today placing its Frontier Airlines subsidiary under protection of the bankruptcy laws while it continued to seek other resolutions to Frontier's crisis. The airline stopped operating on Sunday.   According to a source close to the negotiations, People was contacted by two airlines - one interested in taking over all of Frontier and one interested in buying just its assets.   There also is a possibility, the source said, that United Airlines could change its position and try to find a way to complete its agreement to buy the Denver-based Frontier.

headline: FRANCE REPORTS TWO IRAQIS CITED BY MILITANTS MAY RETURN
abstract: France's Foreign Minister said this week that two Iraqi students, whose return to France is being demanded by Moslem extremists holding French hostages in Lebanon, are free to return to this country whenever they choose to.   The statement by the official, Jean-Bernard Raimond, seemed indirectly intended to reassure the militants holding the hostages that at least one of their demands was being met.   Mr. Raimond said Thursday that visas had been issued for the two students to resume their studies at the University of Paris in the fall.

headline: NICARAGUAN REPRESSION CITED
abstract: The repression of human rights in Nicaragua is systematic and widespread, a human rights group asserted in a report made public yesterday.   The group, the International League for Human Rights, examined the Nicaraguan Government's treatment in recent years of religious organizations, the press, labor unions, political parties and other groups that have opposed the Sandinista leadership.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: Key Officer Resigns At Diamond Shamrock
abstract: J.L. Jackson, president, chief operating officer and a director of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, resigned yesterday in what appears to be further fallout from the company's restructuring.   Diamond Shamrock's chairman and chief executive, William H. Bricker, 54, was given the additional role of president, while the post of chief operating officer was eliminated. Mr. Jackson's vacated seat on the board will not be filled, the company said.   Diamond Shamrock, an independent energy and chemical company in Dallas, has been undergoing a large, four-part reorganization since July 1985, including vast asset writedowns, a stock buyback program, changes in cash dividends and the formation of a master limited partnership.

headline: South Korea Closes 3 More Universities
abstract: The Government closed three universities in Seoul today, bringing to five the number of schools ordered to shut down during the 16-day Asian Games, which are to open here this weekend. Officials said more closings were possible.

headline: Corporations' Tax Escape
abstract: Forty-two profitable big corporations legally used deductions and credits to eliminate their Federal income-tax liability and claim a tax refund in each of the last four years, a Washington study group said today.

headline: Home Resales Up by 7%
abstract: Sales of existing homes jumped 7 percent in August to an annual rate of 3.69 million units, the fastest sales pace of this decade, a real estate trade group said today.   The National Association of Realtors said its monthly survey found that declines in mortgage rates helped spur sales in August after a smaller 1.8 percent increase in July.

headline: POSNER CONVICTED ON TAXES
abstract: A Federal jury convicted the millionaire financier Victor Posner today of evading $1.2 million in Federal income taxes on a gift of 22 acres to a small Christian college.   The 12-member jury, which deliberated 14 hours over two days, found Mr. Posner guilty on four counts of tax evasion, five counts of making false statements and one count of conspiracy to defraud the Government.   The Miami Beach investor and corporate raider, who is 67 years old, could be sentenced to as many as 40 years in prison and a $75,000 fine. Federal District Judge Eugene P. Spellman set sentencing for Sept. 19.

headline: TIME'S FIGHT TO SAVE DISCOVER
abstract: Time Inc.'s ill-fated TV-Cable Week may have grabbed all the headlines a few years back with its $47 million in losses, but another Time publication, Discover, has been quietly chalking up disappointing numbers of its own. In the six years since it was introduced, losses from the monthly science magazine have mounted to an estimated $40 million.   Nevertheless Time, whose reputation in magazine publishing was virtually untarnished until it shut down the fledgling TV-Cable Week in 1983, seems determined this time not to throw in the towel.   In a commitment recalling its experience with Sports Illustrated, which lost money for 11 years before going into the black, the giant publisher has pulled out all the stops to turn Discover into a profitable late bloomer. Over the last two years, Time has brought in a new managing editor for the magazine, Gilbert Rogin, livened up its editorial approach, and in its most controversial - and costliest - move, spent close to $8 million to buy up the subscriber lists of two failing rivals in the overcrowded science field: Science 86, owned by the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and Science Digest, a Hearst publication.

headline: Weighing Books on Financial Scales
abstract: DURING a party at New York's Parker Meridian Hotel in 1984, which Bantam Books gave to celebrate the publication of Lee A. Iacocca's autobiography, three men huddled in a corner, carrying on a spirited discussion about scientific esoterica. One of the men was a former rocket engineer; one was Bantam author Alvin Toffler, and the third was Alberto Vitale, then Bantam's co-chief executive officer.   ''When we have dinner together, we don't talk that much about publishing,'' said Mr. Toffler, whose book, ''Future Shock,'' added a new expression to the language. ''Alberto is a very broad person, and we talk about organization, and computers and where the society is going.''   Not surprising for a publisher, some would say. After all, publishers make their living from eclectic ideas.

headline: BEIRUT SEES NEW CAR-BOMBINGS AS A GRISLY OMEN
abstract: Two devastating car-bomb attacks in as many days here have generated fears that unless the country's continuing political deadlock can be broken, another cycle of violence is unavoidable in Lebanon's 11-year-old civil war.   The car-bombings, one on Monday in a predominantly Christian suburb, the other 24 hours later in mostly Moslem West Beirut, killed a total of 58 people, wounded 300 and caused damage valued at $50 million. All of the casualties were said to be Lebanese.   The ''Slaughter of Innocents,'' as newspaper headlines here called it, was preceded by an outbreak of artillery duels across the Green Line, the demarcation line from the Mediterranean Sea to the southern suburbs that cuts the Lebanese capital into Christian and Moslem sectors. Four people, two of them children, were killed and 38 wounded when artillery shells struck residential areas on both sides of the line.

headline: PATENTS; Automated Office Plan Criticized
abstract: A REPORT by the General Accounting Office, made public by the House Committee on Government Operations, has recommended that no further funds be expended on a contract for the automation project of the Patent and Trademark Office until further assessments of it are made.  The report by the auditing arm of Congress specifically criticizes the planning and oversight on the automation project that has been done by the Commerce Department and the Patent and Trademark Office.

headline: Japanese Official's Airplane Is Delayed by a Bomb Threat
abstract: A plane carrying Japan's Foreign Minister, Tadashi Kuranari, was delayed for three hours at John F. Kennedy International Airport yesterday after a bomb threat, a Japan Air Lines spokesman said.

headline: JAPAN PHONE COMPETITION STIRS
abstract: Officially, Japan's century-old telecommunications monopoly ended in April 1985, when a law opening the market to competition went into effect. Practically, however, the monopoly ended just a few days ago, when the first of many would-be competitors cut a ribbon, flipped a switch and began offering its customers telecommunication services at rates from 20 to 25 percent lower than Nippon Telegraph and Telephone.   The new company, Japan Telecom, is but one of several that hope to compete in both domestic and international telecommunications markets that are hotly sought and estimated to be worth billions of dollars in potential sales. Its entry is another signal that the rules are changing, creating new opportunities for foreign companies and foreign products.   In monitoring the new market, Government officials and industry leaders have labored to make sure that competition was orderly. Rather than opening the market to all comers, Japan's regulatory authorities have preferred to designate a limited number of competitors so that the new entrants would not battle each other into bankruptcy.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: Loss at Deere On Sales Drop
abstract: Deere & Company has reported a $39.6 million loss for its latest quarter, in contrast to a profit of $4.5 million, or 6 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: INVESTING; HOPE GLIMMERS FOR FARM BELT BANKS
abstract: Some early-bird investors are betting that the worst of the drought in agricultural and land prices is over: the stocks of some farm belt banks have been creeping upward.  For example, in the past year, First Interstate of Iowa, the third-largest bank holding company in that state, has rallied from about $2 to a recent high of $3.50. That quote remains well below the hard book value of about $4.15 a share, noted Marc Perkins, a principal in Perkins, Smith Inc., a Tampa, Fla., investment banking firm.

headline: GERMANS LOOK BACK, GINGERLY, TO THE '36 GAMES
abstract: Seventy-seven German medal winners from the 1936 Berlin Olympic Games gathered here over the last three days for a nostalgic, and awkward, 50th anniversary reunion.   The West German Olympic Commmittee, which organized the event, went to jittery lengths to reassure itself and the outside world that it was not ''celebrating'' the memory of the 1936 Games. For that was the Olympics that Hitler's three-year-old Nazi regime exploited to cultivate an image of hospitable efficiency and to break out of its international diplomatic isolation.   ''As you know, ladies and gentlemen,'' said Willi Daume, the president of the West German Olympic Committee, addressing the former athletes at their concluding session today, ''no commemoration of the Olympic Games of 1936 is taking place in Berlin at this time. There are no bells ringing, no national anthem or national flag involved.''

headline: DEFICIT-PARING SETBACK IS EXPECTED TO BE SLIGHT
abstract: The Supreme Court's rejection of a central feature of the balanced-budget law could slow efforts to reduce Federal budget deficits, members of Congress and the financial world said today.   But they doubt that the war has been lost against the deficits that have dogged the economy since the start of the Reagan Administration, they said, adding that deficits are still likely to begin falling - next year if not this.   Moreover, the financial markets, once the harshest real-world judge of deficit spending, appear to assume that the deficits are still heading down, regardless of the Court's ruling.   The stock market plunged today, but analysts blamed factors other than the Court's decision. And they noted that the credit markets, which would be the first to reflect a fear of widening deficits because they would tend to push up interest rates, were not much affected.

headline: The U.N. Today: July 25, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on Indian Ocean - 11:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Council for Namibia - 3 P.M.

headline: Bankers Trust Net Increases
abstract: Two of the nation's leading banks reported higher earnings for the second quarter yesterday. The Bankers Trust New York Corporation, the parent of the nation's seventh-largest bank, reported sharply higher earnings, benefiting from strong gains in interest and fee income and from lower provisions for potential losses on its loan portfolio.

headline: Advertising; Fallon, McElligott Gets Brooks Shoe
abstract: Brooks Shoe Manufacturing of Rockford, Mich., has beaten a path to the door of Fallon, McElligott of Minneapolis, bringing the client list there to 26 accounts with total annual billings of some $85 million.

headline: Mack Truck Staff Trims
abstract: Mack Trucks Inc., the No. 2 maker of heavy-duty trucks, said Friday that 700 white-collar employees have agreed to take early retirement under an offer made by the company as part of a cost-cutting plan. Mack said it hopes to save more than $20 million this year through layoffs and early retirements.

headline: Point Four Data
abstract: The Point Four Data Corporation said it had terminated its offer for up to 49.9 percent of Alpha Microsystems' shares at $6 each. Point Four had intended to acquire remaining shares through an exchange of notes with a face value of $5.50 a share. Point Four said the offer had been ended because of a merger accord announced this week between Alpha and Televideo Systems Inc.

headline: Northrop Teams With McDonnell
abstract: The Northrop Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation said they had formed a team to compete for contracts to develop the Air Force's next-generation fighter aircraft, the Advanced Tactical Fighter.

headline: French Set Foreign Curb
abstract: Foreign participation in newly privatized French companies will be limited, at least initially, to 15 percent, Economy Minister Edouard Balladur said today.

headline: American Can To Sell Complex
abstract: The American Can Company said it would sell its headquarters complex in Greenwich, Conn., to a real estate partnership and lease back half the space. The partners, Paul B. Liles and Jeffrey B. Lewis, agreed to pay $170 million for the campus-style complex on 155 acres along the New York-Connecticut border.

headline: REVIVAL OF THE BERLIN WALL DEBATE: IF WEST HAD KNOCKED IT DOWN...
abstract: President Reagan, in remarks at a news conference on Tuesday, revived a long-dormant debate over the Berlin wall.   What would have happened, he asked, if the Western allies had ''knocked it down'' when it was still a barbed-wire fence instead of a thick concrete barrier?   Mr. Reagan said the United States should have responded promptly and ''knocked down that wire then.''   ''I don't think there would be a wall today because I don't think they wanted to start a war over that,'' he said.

headline: GETTING THE MOST FROM YOUR ASSETS; The Right Planner Can Help
abstract: IN personal finance, horror stories are a dime a dozen.  Some of the horrors are self-inflicted; others a result of bad luck. One increasingly popular preventive: Hire a financial planner. The right one can help you avoid mistakes and devise a strategy to build your net worth through bad times and good.  Occasionally, however, planners play the villain. Recently, an Alabama planner sold a fake ''Treasury bond'' to a client -and spent the money. A New Jersey planner promised investors safety and high returns from a mysterious ''special money market account,'' and lost their money in a real estate venture. In Bellevue, Wash., a planner ''invested'' $100,000 of clients' funds in his own account - and disappeared.

headline: Kodak Plans Drug Tests
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company will require all job applicants to take drug tests and will ask current workers suspected of drug use to take a test or face suspension, a company spokesman said today.

headline: FINAL STEPS MAPPED ON TAX BILL
abstract: When Congress reconvenes Monday after its three-week summer recess, the stage will be set for the last act of the long-running drama on tax revision legislation.   Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and Senator Bob Packwood, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, plan to meet early this week to put the final touches on the legislation that was approved by a Congressional conference committee late on Aug. 16, the day after the rest of Congress left for the recess.   Mr. Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat, said the House of Representatives would probably vote on the final bill next week. The vote in the Senate will most likely come later in the month.

headline: VNU Adds Newspaper Researcher
abstract: VNU AMVEST, the American subsidiary of the largest publishing company in the Netherlands, has quietly assembled an impressive stable of marketing and media information companies in this country. Yesterday it added to those holdings by agreeing to acquire Scarborough Research, the newspaper research concern.   Scarborough will join Interactive Market Systems, Leading National Advertisers, Claritas, Birch Radio Ratings and others in the VNU family.   ''That,'' said Harold Israel, president of Scarborough, ''is a very substantial and impressive collection of companies in the information arena.''

headline: U.N. Command Accuses North Korea in Shooting
abstract: The United Nations Command said today that North Korean forces had fired across the demilitarized zone for the second time this month, setting off a five-minute exchange of gunfire.

headline: Panel Clears Fed Nominee
abstract: The Senate Banking Committee today approved the nomination of H. Robert Heller, the California banking economist, to become a member of the Federal Reserve Board.

headline: FRUEHAUF RECEIVES BIDS BY DEADLINE
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company left intact its $48.50 a share takeover offer for the Fruehauf Corporation and the investor Asher B. Edelman may have adjusted his recent $49.50 proposal somewhat, Wall Street sources said last night.   Fruehauf, which set yesterday as a deadline for a final round of buyout bids, would not disclose the offers. It said a special committee of its board met last night and would make a recommendation to the entire board.

headline: P.O.W.'S ALIVE IN VIETNAM, REPORT CONCLUDES
abstract: A Pentagon panel, after a five-month review of intelligence files, has concluded that American prisoners of war are still alive in Southeast Asia.   The head of the group, Lieut. Gen. Eugene F. Tighe, Jr., a former director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, said in an interview today that ''a large volume of evidence points'' to the likelihood that Americans are being held by the Vietnamese Government.   He said he doubted that the evidence was strong enough to give the United States added leverage to win the release of any prisoners. He suggested Vietnam might accept war reparations in return for the Americans.

headline: AIDES SAY U.S. SENT FORCE TO PAKISTAN
abstract: A United States Army counterterrorism team was sent to the scene of the hijacking in Pakistan on Friday, but it failed to get there before the incident ended in bloodshed, Administration officials said today.   The officials said the Pakistani Government had given permission for the team to land at Karachi International Airport. They said the role, if any, of the American force had not been determined in advance. 'Pakistan Is Quite Competent'   But in Karachi today, President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq appeared to dismiss the idea of such help. ''Pakistan is quite competent and confident to deal with such cases ourselves, and the Americans are fully aware of this,'' he said. ''I see no reason to ask for American help or that Americans would feel that they would have to offer help.''

headline: Advertising; Coke Has Signed Up For the 1988 Olympics
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company, the 20th-largest national advertiser, with $343.3 million spent in 1984, has committed itself to spending $50 million to advertise during the next Olympics in 1988.   It announced yesterday that it had signed with both NBC-TV, which will cover the summer Olympics, and ABC-TV, which will cover the winter games, to insure that Americans will be smitten with 10 Coca-Cola spots during the coverage.   The Atlanta soft drink company noted with pride that it has been involved with the Olympics since 1928.

headline: Swedes Report Progress In Palme Investigation
abstract: The Swedish police said this week that they were making progress in the investigation of the murder of Prime Minister Olof Palme and hoped to see arrests in the next few months.   ''We are beginning to see what we believe is a motive and what we believe to be those responsible for the motive,'' Leif Hallberg, a Stockholm police spokesman, said in an interview.

headline: U.S. Chip Talks Stir Japan Fears
abstract: As semiconductor talks continue, concern is mounting here that Japan may be giving up too much in the continuing negotiations.   In the last week, negotiators have announced two provisional agreements, but did not specify exactly what had been agreed upon and emphasized that many differences remained.   Over the last year, the United States trade deficit with Japan in semiconductors became a touchy political issue, with American semiconductor manufacturers charging that Japanese companies have been selling chips at artifically low prices while denying American manufacturers full access to Japan's $9 billion-a-year semiconductor market. Japanese makers have denied these charges.

headline: SOME SEIZED BY PRETORIA SENT TO 'YOUTH CENTERS'
abstract: Government officials said today that some young black detainees were being sent to special ''youth centers'' for ''reorientation'' before being released.   A spokesman for the Department of Education and Training, which oversees the education of some 1.8 million black schoolchildren in South Africa, described the program as ''absolutely voluntary and aboveboard'' and denied allegations by the parliamentary opposition of any ''forced attendance at secret camps.''   The spokesman, Job Schoeman, said 167 former detainees aged 15 to 25 were undergoing what he described as ''reabsorption, reorientation'' at four youth centers around the country. He said that the centers had existed for several years and that the program to enroll released detainees began about three weeks ago.

headline: ISRAELI CABINET MEMBER QUITS, AVERTING CRISIS
abstract: Justice Minister Yitzhak Modai resigned today rather than be dismissed for continuing to criticize Prime Minister Shimon Peres.   Mr. Peres, leader of the Labor Party, announced his intention to dismiss Mr. Modai, a member of the rival Likud bloc, this morning, setting off a day of political maneuvering that ended in an emergency meeting of the coalition Cabinet this afternoon.   Mr. Modai's resignation, effective in 48 hours, averted a showdown that could have endangered Israel's national unity Government and the rotation agreement under which Mr. Peres is to turn over the Prime Minister's office to Yitzhak Shamir of Likud, who is now the Foreign Minister, in October.   ''The crisis was brief,'' a Government source said. ''No one will endanger rotation.''

headline: JET SURVIVORS SAY ARMY DIDN'T HELP
abstract: Survivors of the hijacking of a Pan American jumbo jet in Karachi said today that Pakistani commandos had played no role in the freeing of the plane after four terrorists hurled grenades and sprayed machine-gun bullets at the huddled passengers.   The survivors, who arrived here on a special Pan Am flight from the Pakistani port city, also said it appeared that it was the failure of the plane's generator that had panicked the terrorists into initiating their massacre.   ''I think the generator had gone off so they thought something was being done from the outside,'' said Nari Kalwani, an Indian businessman who said he was among the first dozen passengers to leap to safety through an opened emergency door. ''Maybe that fear made them do what they did.''

headline: T.W.A. Has Loss; UAL Posts Profit
abstract: Trans World Airlines, citing discounting of air fares, yesterday reported a hefty second-quarter loss of $87 million. compared with a profit of $18.1 million in the second quarter of 1985. Meanwhile, UAL Inc., the parent of United Airlines, posted a sharp increase in earnings, compared with a loss for the 1985 quarter.   T.W.A. also attributed its results to the weaker dollar, a strike this spring by its flight attendants and apprehension about international travel because of terrorism.

headline: MOROCCO CANCELING TREATY AIMED AT UNION WITH LIBYA
abstract: King Hassan II of Morocco announced today that he was canceling a treaty of union with Libya because of Libyan criticism of his meeting with Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel.   In a message to the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the King said his decision was motivated by a communique issued on Wednesday by Libya and Syria after a two-day visit to Libya by the Syrian President, Hafez al-Assad.   The communique denounced the Peres visit to Morocco on July 22 and 23 as ''an act of treason'' by Morocco and a ''violation of the Arab consensus in defiance of the feelings of the Arab nation.''

headline: DOW FALLS 1.83 POINTS
abstract: Stock prices ended mixed for the second straight session yesterday in slow pre-holiday weekend trading.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which has shown little conviction in its direction throughout this week, ended 1.83 points lower at 1,898.34, but advances led declines by 829 to 710. For the whole week, the Dow rose 10.54 points, after climbing 32 points the week before. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange grew slightly yesterday, to 125.3 million shares, from Thursday's 125.1 million.

headline: CONCERN OVER TREASURY FINANCINGS
abstract: Although Government issues this week are confined to the regular Treasury offering of three-month and six-month bills, the auction may draw more attention than usual, as market participants weigh the possibilities of a disruption in Treasury financing.   In testimony before a Senate committee on Tuesday, Treasury officials are expected to tell lawmakers that the normal financing schedule between now and mid August cannot be followed unless the debt ceiling is increased before Aug. 15, when issues sold at the early August refunding would normally settle.   Congress has already been notified that the Treasury will reach the statutory debt limit by Aug. 1 and that despite plans to use about $15 billion in borrowing authority of the Federal Financing Bank, it will have exhausted all other means to raise funds by Aug. 14. As a result, the major quarterly refunding expected on Aug. 5-7 may have to be delayed or cut.

headline: REPORTERS IN MOSCOW FACE NEW ANXIETY
abstract: For Western journalists in Moscow, the detention of a U.S. News & World Report correspondent by the Soviet authorities has created both a wave of anxiety about being arrested themselves and concern that bartering for the reporter's freedom could set a dangerous precedent.   They say the detention of the reporter, Nicholas S. Daniloff, and the threats that he faces a long prison term are a radical increase in the severity of possible penalties against Western journalists by Soviet officials. And many say that the incident has made reporting in the Soviet Union even more dangerous and difficult.   ''Most correspondents labor under the idea that the Soviets might embarrass them, harass them, or expel them, but not imprison them,'' said Gary L. Thatcher, a reporter for The Christian Science Monitor, who returned in June after three years in Moscow. ''This should change that perception.'' #5 Years in Moscow Bureau On Aug. 30, Mr. Daniloff, a U.S. News correspondent in Moscow for five years, was arrested there after he was handed documents by a Soviet citizen he had agreed to meet in a park. The Soviet authorities have said that the documents were secret and that Mr. Daniloff was acting as a spy. The United States says the Daniloff case is a set-up.

headline: Hard-Disk Help for 'Pile Builders'
abstract: MANY years ago, just out of college, I applied for a job as a line management trainee. Following a pleasant interview, I was given a tour of my potential colleagues' offices.   Pristinely uncluttered desks evidencing a Bauhaus mindset prevailed. I was even told that whenever one left one's desk for more than a minute, any papers were to be tucked away into a drawer for the duration of one's absence. Likewise, it was pointed out to me, there were no wastepaper baskets. The bottom right-hand drawer of one's desk was to serve as that receptacle, leaving the premises visually immaculate.

headline: Dealer Rules: Law Nearing
abstract: The Senate has passed a bill that would place all dealers in government securities under a regulatory structure to be determined by the Treasury.   The bill, sponsored by Alfonse M. D'Amato, a New York Republican, was approved by voice vote late Tuesday.

headline: Western Pacific
abstract: Western Pacific Industries said it had agreed to be acquired for $156.52 a share, or about $360 million, by a group led by the private investment firm of Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen.

headline: Warning Is Issued On French Hostages
