abstract: An Iraqi opposition group said today that French hostages in Lebanon would suffer if two Iraqis deported from France in February were not allowed to return to Paris soon.   The statement was issued by the Beirut-based regional office of the Dawa Party, which is made up of Iraqi Shiite Moslems and supports mainly Shiite Iran in its six-year-old war with Iraq.

headline: Ships That Can Double as Classrooms
abstract: DO you want to learn to use an I.B.M. PC? To solve a murder mystery? To sail with an N.F.L. football team?   For a price, it is all available aboard a ship. These days there are cruises with lectures on astrology, jazz, computers, cricket, bird watching, archeology, botany and mythology. CTC Lines Ltd., a cruise operator that is Soviet-owned but London-based, is planning a cruise with, it claims, the ''world's greatest magicians'' on board. There are cruises just for honeymooners, and cruises geared toward health buffs.

headline: Soviet Acknowledges Explosion of a Missile
abstract: A Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman acknowledged today that a missile exploded during a test flight last month, but he gave no details other than that it ''did not clear the Soviet border.''   Answering questions at a news briefing, the spokesman, Boris D. Pyadyshev, said, ''I can only say such a fact indeed took place.''

headline: DATA BANK August 10, 1986
Examiner Allowed In Robins Case
abstract: Federal District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. authorized William White, a trustee named by the Justice Department, to appoint an examiner with ''very broad powers'' in the A. H. Robins Company bankruptcy case.

headline: LUGAR SEES AQUINO IN MANILA
abstract: Senator Richard G. Lugar, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, met today with President Corazon C. Aquino and gave her what he said was a letter of support from President Reagan, who will be her host in Washington next month.   The Indiana Republican, who arrived today, led Congressional observers who found fraud during the presidential election in February.

headline: Interstate Banking
abstract: To the Editor:   I agree that ''recycling'' local depositors' assets back into their own neighborhoods is desirable (''Should Banks Cross State Lines?'' Forum, June 21), but it also has its costs. I assume from their logic that the authors would also be in favor of laws which compel residents of poor neighborhoods to shop exclusively in relatively high-priced, locally owned stores.

headline: FINANCIAL TIMES PLANNING MOVE TO MODERN PLANT
abstract: The Financial Times today announced an $84 million plan to adopt modern printing technology and move to a new plant east of London. Britain's leading business daily, with a circulation of 250,000, thus joins the migration of major newspapers away from Fleet Street, London's historic newspaper district, to cut costs.   ''Fleet Street as we knew it is gone forever,'' said Frank Barlow, chief executive officer of The Financial Times. ''That's inevitable.''

headline: VICTIMS OF TERROR AT SYNAGOGUE
abstract: Following is a list of the worshipers killed and wounded in the attack on the Neve Shalom Synagogue on Saturday. The list was provided by Jewish leaders in Istanbul.  DEAD  ALHALEL, Jozef  ANJEL, Salamon  ATALAY, Yuda Levi  BABAZADE, Mirva  BAROKAS, Izak  BARUH, Danyel Daryo  BEHAR, David, a cantor  CITTONE, Selim Salom  ERESKENAZI, Binyamin  ERGUN, Aser, a cantor  ERGUN, Ibrahim  GERSON, Izak  HARA, Elyezer  LEVI, Moiz  LEVI, Rensiyon  MATALON, Yakov  MUSAOGLU, Leon Levi  NESIM, Rafael  OZFINS, Robert Israel  SAUL, Moiz  SENKAL, Sefanya   Wounded  ERESKENAZI, Avram  GENC, Yasef Levi  SAMRANO, Jak  SITRAN, Moiz

headline: LEGAL PROCEEDINGS OFFER PLUMS FOR THE LAWYERS
abstract: When the LTV Corporation began to think it might have to file for reorganization, it turned to the same two New York law firms that have been handling the Manville Corporation's bankruptcy proceedings: Davis, Polk & Wardwell, a large corporate law firm that has advised LTV for two decades, and Levin & Weintraub & Crames, a small bankruptcy firm.   As in the Manville case, it was the lawyers at Davis, Polk who suggested that LTV hire Levin & Weintraub & Crames - and in particular, Michael Crames, the principal lawyer for Manville - as bankruptcy counsel.   As the nation's largest bankruptcy, the LTV proceedings are likely to generate millions of dollars in legal fees for each of the firms. They were quite a plum - and, with 65 separate bankruptcy petitions and 10,000 pages of documents to prepare, quite a logistical challenge.

headline: Coke Limits Plans To Core Businesses
abstract: Roberto C. Goizueta, chairman of the Coca-Cola Company, told analysts that $1 billion of additional debt capacity resulting from the formation of a new bottling company would be considered for acquisitions only in Coca-Cola's three core business areas - soft drinks, food and entertainment - or for a stock buyback program.   The new bottling company, Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., will be formed from the Beatrice Companies' bottling operations, the JTL Corporation, and the company's own bottling operations. The Securities and Exchange Commission's rules, Mr. Goizueta said, prohibit the release of details on the new venture.

headline: Carbide Payment
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation said holders of special distribution rights would receive a second payment of $3.22 for each right on Oct. 14.

headline: PATENTS; Improving Resolution On Computer Screens
abstract: The two founders of Copytele Inc. of Huntington Station, L.I., received patent No. 4,598,960 this week for a method of connecting closely spaced arrays that enhance the resolution on display screens used in computers.  The inventors are Frank J. DiSanto, president of the company, and Denis A. Krusos, chairman of the board. They plan to market display screens that embody the invention.

headline: CONTROL DATA UNIT GETS WEILL
abstract: After two unsuccessful campaigns to become the head of a major company, Sanford I. Weill, former president of the American Express Company, will become chairman and chief executive of one of the nation's biggest consumer finance companies under a tentative agreement announced yesterday.   The Control Data Corporation of Minneapolis, the big, beleaguered data processing company, said it had reached an agreement in principle with Mr. Weill providing for its fully owned Commercial Credit Company subsidiary to be sold to the public and for Mr. Weill to head it.   Joseph D. Minutilli, Commercial Credit's present chairman and chief executive and a 35-year company employee, said he would relinquish his position but remain a director and become an adviser to Mr. Weill. Mr. Minutilli is 58 years old, while Mr. Weill is 53. Personal Investment    Mr. Weill would personally invest close to $10 million in the venture and, along with a new management team, hold about a 10 percent interest in the company, industry sources said. He would also receive stock options, these sources added.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 15, 1986:

headline: New 'Models' in Car Loans
abstract: THE Big Three auto companies have long been adept at coming up with car models tailored to the needs of different customers. Now their captive finance subsidiaries are beginning to adopt some of the same tactics in developing new ''models'' of financing packages aimed at certain segments of the buying public.   Among the new products: balloon loans, which combine the features of leases and standard loans; loans tailored to recent college graduates, and variable-interest-rate loans.   The new financing plans have attracted little notice, so far, compared with the subsidized interest rate incentives offered by the auto companies for the past year. But finance executives say they could become important marketing tools in any post-incentive era because, as one executive put it, the plans are designed for buyers ''with little income compared to their appetite for a car, or for people who have more car in mind than money in their wallets.''

headline: SETTLING INEXORABLY INTO AN OLIGOPOLY
abstract: WHAT does the recent rash of airline mergers tell us about the future of the industry? Will it come to be dominated by a few giant carriers that set prices and service with a damn-the-consumer arrogance? Or will competition, abetted by judicious antitrust enforcement, continue to keep fares down and service up?   Unfortunately, the evidence suggests that we have already enjoyed the major benefits of deregulation and that its drawbacks will become increasingly apparent. Those drawbacks - primarily, barriers to effective competition - will be redressed only through selected new regulation. Consider the following points:    * The industry continues to experience dangerous swings in financial performance, and efficiency is no guarantee of success. Even carriers like People Express, a model of efficiency, often must fight to survive while some high-cost carriers lead the industry in profits.

headline: TUTU SAYS HISTORY WILL JUDGE REAGAN'S VETO
abstract: Archbishop Desmond Tutu said today that President Reagan would be judged harshly by history for vetoing a bill for economic sanctions on South Africa.   The South African Government has so far not reacted to Mr. Reagan's action. Political commentators said praise for the action might make it harder for Mr. Reagan to win enough votes to sustain the veto.   Archbishop Tutu said in a statement from his Cape Town residence that by vetoing the bill Friday, Mr. Reagan ''has made his moral position quite clear.''

headline: Fighting in Beirut Mars Syrian Effort
abstract: Gunners exchanged mortar fire across the Green Line today, killing a policeman and marring Syrian security in the Moslem area.   Moslem and Christian radio stations said the policeman died and seven people were wounded when bombs crashed on both sides of the line, which divides the city's largely Moslem western section from its largely Christian east.   The Sunni Moslem radio station Voice of the Homeland said the clash erupted when gunmen in the west fired a mortar mounted on a car into the Christian enclave.

headline: Ex-Im Bank Bill Advances
abstract: The House voted today to extend the authority of the United States Export-Import Bank for six years, but it barred any financing for export sales to Marxist-Leninist countries or to Angola.   The bill, which also authorized $145 million to cover subsidy costs of Ex-Im Bank loans in the 1987 fiscal year, was passed on a voice vote and sent to the Senate, which was expected to take similar action.   The measure would allow the bank to make interest subsidy payments to private lenders to encourage private export loans if needed to compete with similar subsidies from other countries.

headline: Revamping Is Western Union Issue
abstract: This could be a critical week in the Western Union Corporation's 135-year history, according to some Wall Street analysts, as shareholders and bondholders vote on a complicated financial restructuring plan without which the company could end up in bankruptcy.   The guessing on Wall Street is that a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing will not be necessary, but some sources predict that the restructuring plan proposed by Western Union earlier this year is in danger of being turned down.   The first important vote will come today, when the holders of common and preferred stock decide on whether to allow the Western Union Telegraph Company, the operating unit, to merge into the Western Union Corporation, its holding company.   The move is the first step in a complicated financial plan that will permit Western Union to restructure its bank debt by giving lenders better access to the company's assets.

headline: Citicorp Unit Gets Fixed-Income Head
abstract: Citicorp Investment Management Inc. said yesterday that it had named Willard R. Phillips Jr. as director of fixed income.   In all, the Citicorp subsidiary manages more than $28 billion of discretionary assets and Mr. Phillips will be responsible for more than $12 billion of that total.   But Mr. Phillips, who is 36 years old, has been responsible for such large amounts of money in earlier positions.

headline: A RUSSIAN DEFECTOR, NOW BACK IN SOVIET, IS REPORTEDLY WELL
abstract: A Moscow newspaper today quoted Vitaly Yurchenko, a reputed Soviet defector, as having said that he is alive and well and back at his old job.   The article, in the newspaper Moskovskaya Pravda, was apparently an effort to dispel Western reports that he had been executed after returning to the Soviet Union.

headline: Advertising; Sperry Account
abstract: The Shimer vonCantz agency in Philadelphia has been assigned to handle the communications needs of the Sperry Corporation's Personal Computer products that were formerly handled by Lewis, Gilman & Kynett. The budget will be about $1 million, some $875,000 for media advertising and the rest for direct mail and production costs.

headline: G.M. Names Two Officers
abstract: The General Motors Corporation board named two new vice presidents and approved a job swap between two executives, the nation's No. 1 auto maker announced today.

headline: Iran Arrests American As Espionage Suspect
abstract: An American engineer working for an American company in Iran has been arrested on espionage charges, it was disclosed today.   The State Department confirmed the arrest of the American, Jon Pattis, 49 years old, but provided no additional details.

headline: DAIRIES FEWER BUT STRONGER
abstract: ''Have more milk, 'cause milk's got more,'' the National Dairy Promotion and Research Board began urging in 1983, when milk-drinking had been in an eight-year slump. The $66 million-a-year campaign got its message across: The consumption of milk and other dairy products has grown 7 percent since the ads first ran.   And for business, milk's evidently got more, too. Since milk sales turned up, the dairy industry has become more attractive. In the last few years, a number of family-owned dairies have been acquired by larger companies with greater access to capital. Many of those dairies, in turn, have acquired facilities and markets of smaller dairies.

headline: ELITE SWISS SCHOOLS SAY CURBS COULD FORCE THEM TO CLOSE
abstract: The Swiss Government has proposed regulations that would drastically cut the number of foreign students at private secondary and finishing schools. Educators say the move could seriously threaten the schools' existence and end a tradition of elite international education.   ''If the law goes through and I cannot get students for more than three months we can jolly well close,'' said Viviane Neri, director of the Institute Villa Pierrefeu, an exclusive finishing school near Montreux.   Mrs. Neri and her staff of 20 educate 36 women, 16 to 25 years old, in French, table service, cooking and entertaining at a cost of $27,439 for a yearlong course.

headline: Key Rates
BROOKLYN'S BROWNSTONES THRIVE AMID RESTORATION
abstract: One by one, over the last several years, the once-derelict brownstones within the designated historic district of the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn have made their way back to the market. An integrated middle-income community has expanded as small builders have seized the opportunity for restoration, helped by Federal tax incentives that make it possible to attract investment capital.   It is no longer the brownstones alone that are benefiting from this process. It has broadened outward to the larger buildings on the avenues, and it continues to attract youthful developers who start out with more enthusiasm than experience or financial support.

headline: WEDDING MANIA GRIPS BRITAIN AGAIN
abstract: Brushing aside unaccustomed political embarrassments, the British monarchy made its final preparations today for the splendor and display of a royal wedding.   Rain or shine, precisely at 11:16 on Wednesday morning a glass coach drawn by two bay horses is to begin the last of three royal processions down the Mall and Whitehall to Westminster Abbey. Inside will be Sarah Ferguson, only moments away from becoming the bride of Queen Elizabeth II's second son, Prince Andrew, and thus the newest member of the unending serial of the Windsor family.   ''It is going to be the best day of my life,'' the future princess said in an exuberant radio interview on her last day as a commoner. ''Fantastic! The more the merrier - more carriages, more pomp. Wonderful! I love it.''

headline: MEXICO AND BANKS MISS I.M.F. DEADLINE ON DEBT
abstract: Mexico and its bankers failed to meet a deadline today for agreement on a $6 billion loan for the country. But banking sources said that an agreement reached later this week would be just as good.   Barber B. Conable Jr., the World Bank president, joined the negotiations and later said he was optimistic that accord would be reached. ''The time is very short. The decision is a critical one. We assume there will be some resolution very quickly,'' Mr. Conable said.

headline: A PRESS MOGUL REACHES FOR MORE POWER
abstract: IT has not always been easy for France's leading newspaper mogul.   For much of his career, Robert Hersant, owner of two prominent national dailies, Le Figaro and France-Soir, and a long list of regional papers, periodicals, radio stations and printing plants, has been fighting defiantly - using illegal means, some say - to expand his publishing empire and gain political power.   In the process, the controversial Mr. Hersant, who controls 28 percent of French newspaper circulation, has tangled with the French courts, the Socialist Government, labor, and some heavy debt - as well as with his own reputation as a collaborationist during World War II.   But these days, things seem to be going his way. Le Figaro, his flagship paper, boasts a daily circulation of 367,236, the biggest of the Paris-based dailies. The 66-year-old Mr. Hersant won a seat in the National Assembly during March elections that swept Socialists from power. A few weeks ago, the new Parliament passed a law ending 42 years of antitrust regulation in the newspaper business.

headline: JSC/MS Holdings Files Offering
abstract: JSC/MS Holdings Inc. has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $652.6 million of debt securities through Morgan Stanley & Company.   The holding company is a joint venture of the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation and the Morgan Stanley Leveraged Equity Fund L. P., a limited partnership of Morgan Stanley and Cigna Investment Group, formed to acquire Container Corporation of America from the Mobil Corporation.

headline: Tamils Killed 4 Soldiers, Sri Lanka Military Says
abstract: Tamil guerrillas killed four soldiers and wounded 11 in separate attacks on a patrol and a district capital, the military reported today.   Guerrillas attacked security troops patrolling a railroad line at Tampalagamam, about 160 miles northeast of Colombo, killing two soldiers and two policemen and wounding six others in the patrol, officials said.   They said rebels exploded a mine a few hours later at the transport board office in the district capital of Batticaloa, about 140 miles east of Colombo, wounding five commandos.

headline: Australian Government Presents Tough Budget
abstract: The Labor Government handed down Australia's toughest budget in 20 years today, slashing billions of dollars off public spending.   Welfare, health, education, the military and foreign aid were all hit with cuts that Treasurer Paul Keating said would trim the equivalent of $1.9 billion in United States currency from Government spending.

headline: BONN BLOCKADES MISSION HARBORING EAST GERMAN
abstract: The West German authorities took the unusual step today of blockading the East German Mission here, where an East German scholar who is accused of being a spy was hiding for a fourth day.   An East German diplomat delivered a protest note to the office of Chancellor Helmut Kohl. But Government officials described it as mildly worded, and the Bonn Government spokesman, Friedhelm Ost, said the Government sought ''to undertake everything to prevent an escalation.''   At the root of the standoff was the double defection of Herbert Meissner, a 59-year-old East German economist and the deputy head of the East German Academy of Sciences. In written affidavits, Mr. Meissner confessed last week to West German officials that he spied for East Germany, after the police in West Berlin apprehended him for shoplifting. He later fled to the East German Mission here, and he faces an arrest order by the Bonn Federal Prosecutor on suspicion of espionage if he leaves the building.

headline: Needham Gets Part Of Eveready Account
abstract: The William Esty Company, which had handled the Eveready Batteries account exclusively for 41 years, will now share the $25 million in billings with Needham Harper Worldwide, Chicago and Avrett, Free & Ginsberg.   Ralston Purina had decided to expand the agency list after acquiring the battery company as an independent subsidiary from Union Carbide in July. It declined, however, to disclose the exact billings assigned to each agency.

headline: ISRAELI OFFICIALS RESOLVE DISPUTE
abstract: Prime Minister Shimon Peres has accepted a written retraction from his Trade and Industry Minister, Ariel Sharon, who had charged that a terrorist attack against a synagogue in Turkey was a consequence of peace overtures by Mr. Peres.   The action effectively ended a daylong Cabinet crisis.

headline: 5.5% Stake in Allied Acquired by Briton
abstract: Alan Clore, a British investor, disclosed yesterday that he had acquired a 5.5 percent stake, or 2.6 million shares, in the Allied Stores Corporation.   On Wednesday, Allied, one of the nation's leading retailers, said its board had rejected a $58-a-share tender offer by the Campeau Acquisition Corporation, a subsidiary of the Campeau Corporation of Canada.   Separately, the First Boston Corporation and the Paine Webber Group said they had committed up to $700 million to provide Campeau's financing by buying subordinated, unsecured securities to be issued by Campeau Acquisition. A First Boston spokesman called the method ''a new financing technique in takeovers going beyond the 'highly confident' letter usually supplied by investment bankers.'' The debentures will later by sold to the public. He said that the investment bankers would make a higher fee from the new method, while the client would pay less.

headline: BURLINGTON WRITES OFF $1.9 BILLION
abstract: Burlington Northern Inc., one of the nation's largest railroads, said today that it would take a $1.9 billion pretax charge against earnings because of accounting changes and weakness in its railroad and oil and natural gas businesses.   The charge, which was expected by Wall Street but was somewhat larger than expected, will primarily affect the company's second-quarter earnings, and should lead to a net loss of about $1 billion for the quarter, according to an estimate by John Kawa, analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. The company is also likely to report a deficit for the entire year.   Burlington Northern, which is based in Seattle, also said its directors today adopted antitakover provisions. The company said however, that it was not aware of any effort to acquire the company.

headline: MEXICAN FAMILIES SEE HOPE IN ILLEGAL EMIGRATION
abstract: After 12 years of scrambling to keep food on the table for his wife and four children, Baltazar Valerio Dimas is giving up on Mexico and its troubled economy. He has decided to take his family across the border, illegally, and make a new life in the United States.   ''It is a matter of survival,'' Mr. Valerio said recently at his home, a hillside shack he built out of discarded construction materials and an old car body.   ''On the other side there is work,'' he said. ''In an hour I can earn more than what I am paid in a day here. My children will be better off and they will learn English.''

headline: MAXICARE IN DEAL FOR H.M.O.
abstract: Maxicare Health Plans Inc., a Los Angeles-based health maintenance organization, said yesterday that it would acquire the HealthAmerica Corporation for a total of $400 million in cash and warrants.   The merger makes Maxicare the third-largest health maintenance organization in the country, with more than 2 million members in 32 states. Only the Kaiser-Permanente Medical Care Program and Empire Blue Cross-Blue Shield are larger than Maxicare, the nation's largest publicly owned H.M.O.   Health maintenance organizations provide full medical care benefits for a fixed prepaid fee, provided patients use H.M.O. doctors and hospitals. H.M.O.'s emphasize regular checkups and other preventative care.

headline: Class Suit Against Merrill
abstract: A Federal judge in New York has granted class representative status to a group of Michigan investors that is suing Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith for purportedly failing to disclose important information about zero coupon Treasury-backed securities.   Nelson S. Chase, a West Bloomfield, Mich., attorney representing the investors, said the June 17 order by Judge David N. Edelstein of the United States Court for the Southern District of New York would mean that potentially ''hundreds of thousands'' of other investors who had purchased the Treasury Investment Growth Receipts, or ''Tigers,'' might be eligible to become part of the suit.   Mr. Chase said that he and attorneys from three New York law firms were beginning the process of identifying such investors, which could take several months.

headline: PAKISTANI SAYS SOVIET OFFERED A 4-YEAR AFGHAN WITHDRAWAL
abstract: The Prime Minister of Pakistan said today that the Soviet Union had formally offered to withdraw its troops from Afghanistan over a four-year period, but that Pakistan believed a withdrawal could take place in four months or less.   The official, Mohammad Khan Junejo, said at a news conference that the Soviet offer, made during United Nations-sponsored proximity talks at Geneva in May, indicated that the Russians were not serious about withdrawal.   ''This indicates that things are not so easy,'' he said. ''The Soviets are not very ready to withdraw from Afghanistan.''

headline: U.S.-Taiwan Talks Stalled
abstract: Trade officials from the United States and Taiwan failed to reach agreement on limiting Taiwan's textile exports at their second round of talks in Washington, and have scheduled another meeting later this month, Taiwan's chief trade delegate said.   At a news conference today on his return from Washington after seven days of talks, Vincent Siew, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade, said, ''The two sides still have considerable differences on major issues involved, though we were near an agreement on certain other issues.''

headline: U.S. SAYS LIBYA MAY HAVE PLANS FOR NEW TERROR
abstract: Officials indicated today that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was planning terrorist attacks, and the White House warned that it was ''prepared to take whatever action is necessary'' to thwart the Libyan leader.   At the same time, Administration officials said Vernon A. Walters, the United States delegate to the United Nations, had been asked to fly to Europe soon to discuss the Libyan situation with allies. An official said Mr. Walters was planning to press allies ''to tighten up political and economic sanctions against Libya.''   In Santa Barbara, near the ranch where President Reagan is on a three-week vacation, Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said that ''the United States is prepared to take whatever action is necessary to prevent terrorist activities.''

headline: Oregon Bills Gorbachev
abstract: The Oregon Health Division has sent a bill to Mikhail S. Gorbachev for expenses incurred while monitoring radiation levels after the Chernobyl nuclear accident. It cost the division $73,060 to monitor air, rain, drinking water, vegetation and milk when radiation from the disaster drifted over the Pacific Northwest. The state legislative Emergency Board instructed the agency to seek repayment.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Best Products Co., Richmond, said it would dispose of 17 unprofitable Best stores and its Ashby's subsidiary, a chain of 33 discount apparel stores, resulting in a pretax charge of about $38 million in its third quarter ending Nov. 2.    * Canadian Marconi Co., Montreal, said its Defense Communications division had won a $46.4 million contract to supply radio sets to the United States over five years.

headline: Anti-Apartheid Move
abstract: Despite Reagan Administration resistance to formal sanctions against South Africa, Congress continues to express its distaste for the situation in a variety of pending bills.

headline: Administration Sees No Reason to Be Concerned
abstract: Despite a record two-day plunge in stock prices, officials of the Reagan Administration said today that they saw no reason to be concerned.   ''The role of this Administration is to provide an economic climate that is suitable for economic expansion, and we have done so,'' Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said.   That statement and others today not only reflected the Administration's economic approach of nonintervention in the marketplace, according to current and former Government officials, but also the fact that there was very little the Administration could do to quiet market fears or curb the volatility of stock prices.

headline: COURT IN BONN BARS TAX BREAK ON GIFTS TO POLITICAL PARTIES
abstract: The highest West German court has declared unconstitutional a law making corporate donations to political parties tax deductible.   The decision, by an eight-to-six vote of the Federal Constitutional Court, represents an embarrassment to the three major German political parties, which supported the enactment of the law last year amid a scandal involving illicit political donations by the giant Flick industrial concern.

headline: Dropping Income
abstract: To the Editor:   The graph showing how the middle 60 percent of income earners are faring relative to the top 20 percent raises questions that ''The Average Guy Takes a Fall'' (July 13) fails to address. If lagging productivity is a national problem, then why are the fortunes of the two groups converging rather than tracking in parallel? The top 20 percent's share of total income has risen from 40 percent to nearly 43 percent since 1968; one might ask if lagging productivity benefits the well off.  SIM GUREWITZ   Lincoln, Neb., July 17

headline: ELECTRONIC PUBLISHING ON RISE
abstract: The looming changes in Federal tax law have created a special challenge for Accountants Microsystems Inc., a Bellevue, Wash., maker of software for accountants. If Congress passes the tax revision bill, the company must revise its software packages and nearly six dozen support documents, including both graphics and text. And next year will require more product changes, according to Ole Kvern, the company's publications specialist.   Yet Mr. Kvern said he was confident the task would be completed on time and within budget - all because of electronic publishing.

headline: A MARTYR ENSHRINED: THE LEGEND OF NINOY AQUINO
abstract: At 1:05 on Thursday afternoon, President Corazon C. Aquino will dedicate a flat granite slab, in the figure of a man with arms and legs akimbo, that has been set into the tarmac at Manila International Airport.   The hour will mark the third anniversary of the assassination of her husband, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., a moment that is now understood, with the hindsight of history, to have been the beginning of the revolution that brought down Ferdinand E. Marcos.   The figure of a man in white, sprawled on the runway of the airport with a single gunshot through his head, became the symbol that unified and hardened a growing opposition to Mr. Marcos and gave rise to his unexpected challenger, Mrs. Aquino.   Now that her husband, known to Filipinos as Ninoy, has succeeded posthumously, through his widow, in ousting Mr. Marcos, his symbolism as a national martyr has been evolving.

headline: Rapp Absorbs D.D.B.'s Direct
abstract: The Direct Response Group of Dallas, acquired this year by the Doyle Dane Bernbach Group, is being merged into its much larger sister company, Rapp & Collins, to form Rapp & Collins USA, with more than $100 million in billings, $46 million of which is coming in from the Texas shop.   Stanley Rapp, 59 years old, will be chairman of the merged body and James E. Dunne 3d, 35, from D.R.G., its president and chief executive officer. After the proposed merger of   D.D.B. with Needham Harper Worldwide in late August to form DDB/Needham Worldwide, which will then come under the Omnicom Group umbrella with BBDO International, Rapp & Collins USA will be part of the holding company's Diversified Agency Services division, along with a half-dozen international offices of Rapp & Collins. Emily Soell of New York, Robert E. Mohr of Dallas and Mary Tchakirides of Los Angeles will run the three offices of R.& C.

headline: U.S. DATA SAID TO CONCLUDE SOVIET MISTOOK KOREAN PLANE
abstract: The South Korean airliner shot down by the Soviet Air Force in 1983 was not on an espionage mission, but the Russians, in a series of blunders, believed they were attacking an American reconnaissance flight, according to a magazine article.   The article, which will be published next month in The Atlantic Monthly, is based on a review of American intelligence data and on interviews with Soviet officials. It concludes that the plane penetrated Soviet airspace because of navigational errors by the Korean Air Lines crew and not, as the Soviet Union contended, because it was on an espionage mission.   The evidence gathered by American intelligence, which has not been made public, also contradicts the United States' initial contention that the Soviet Union had knowingly shot down the airliner, killing the 269 people aboard.   The article is drawn from a new book by Seymour M. Hersh, a journalist who has reported for The New York Times on corruption in Panama and on intelligence topics and who uncovered the My Lai massacre in Vietnam for an independent news agency.

headline: On Culbertson
abstract: To the Editor:   Must not the dollar balances that leave here to pay for imports return here either to pay for additional exports, creating new jobs, or for long-term capital flow, in which case new jobs may be created in plant and equipment construction? If the low-wage countries, like us, distribute most of their product to labor, most of any additional spending on imports from them would have to return here as additional export business.   Productivity is said to decline in industries hit by imports; shouldn't it then increase in exports and construction when the dollar balances come back?  MARK L. WEHLE   Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., Aug. 19

headline: 24 BLACKS ARE REPORTED SLAIN
abstract: The South African authorities today formally lifted longstanding restrictions on Winnie Mandela, the activist wife of the jailed nationalist leader Nelson Mandela.   At the same time, the Government reported that nine more blacks were slain around the nation, and mine company representatives reported that 15 black miners were killed in what the employers described as factional fighting. Thousands of miners were said by union officials to be on strike at several gold and diamond mines to protest the detention of labor leaders.   South Africa's newest state of emergency, which began on June 12, has spurred black labor unions into open protest against the authorities' actions, and some labor officials say the protest could take the form of a national stoppage a week from today.

headline: Analysts Stress Careful Buying
abstract: THE big stock market selloff last week left many investors so distressed that they are in no frame of mind to think about new equity purchases. Yet some analysts are convinced that this is the period for selective buying of stocks that have been battered recently and, now selling at attractive prices, appear to be poised for an upturn.   Of course, optimism about the market outlook has long been the prevailing mood in the financial community, where recommendations to buy are far more frequent than recommendations to sell. But some of the researchers who follow the market on a daily basis believe that the drop of almost 121 points in the Dow Jones industrial average last Thursday and Friday has created many meaningful buying opportunities.

headline: BID TO KEEP SALES TAX DEDUCTION
abstract: House conferees on the tax revision bill decided today to insist at the outset of negotiations with the Senate that the final legislation permit people to deduct their state and local sales tax payments.   The representatives also agreed to fight for a bill that would sharply restrict depreciation allowances for businesses and eliminate certain deductions for oil and gas exploration.   In one of their most significant concessions to the Senate, the representatives decided to deny deductions for charitable contributions to taxpayers who did not otherwise itemize their deductions. Such deductions are allowed under the current tax law, and the House-passed bill would permit them to the extent that contributions exceeded $100.

headline: Spain Holds 8 in Bank Theft
abstract: Eight men have been taken into custody in the theft of $5.5 million worth of treasury bills from the Bank of Spain, the police said today. They said the eight, including a bank employee and a man posing as an army general, faced charges of selling the securities in the stock market.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Home Products Corp. said its board had authorized the repurchase of an additional five million shares of its common stock. The company's shares closed at $90 a share yesterday, up $1.125.

headline: MEDIATOR NAMED TO UNTANGLE ITALY'S CABINET CRISIS
abstract: President Francesco Cossiga, acknowledging that efforts to name a new government were deadlocked, appointed a mediator today to untangle deepening political disputes over who should succeed Bettino Craxi as Prime Minister.   The mediator, Senator Amintore Fanfani, who was himself Prime Minister five times, was given an unusual ''exploratory mandate'' by the President to consult with party leaders and seek a compromise on the make-up of a future government.   The major challenge facing Mr. Fanfani, 78 years old, is to negotiate a division of power between Mr. Craxi's Socialists and the Christian Democrats, the largest of the five parties in the coalition that governed during Mr. Craxi's 34 months in office, according to politicians and analysts here.   ''It has come down to political bargaining, pure and simple,'' said an official close to the negotiations. The leaders of all major political groupings have agreed that no questions of Government policy are at issue.

headline: Fair Authority's Issue in Illinois
abstract: The Metropolitan Fair and Exposition Authority of Illinois tentatively priced $313.1 million of revenue bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.   Bonds with shorter maturities are offered, with yields ranging from 4.75 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 6.25 percent in 1991, 7.30 percent in 1996 and 7 7/8 percent in 2001.

headline: DATA BANK: September 21, 1986
Stocks Close Mixed; Dow Up 2.53
abstract: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday, as caution over the Treasury's three-part refunding helped stymie activity.   After moving in a narrow range throughout the day, the Dow Jones industrial average closed up a scant 2.53 points, at 1,779.53, as declining issues outnumbered advancing issues by 862 to 693.   Investors in equities remained cautious about the how well the Treasury's sale of 10-year notes yesterday and 30-year bonds on Thursday would be received. They also continued to assess the course of interest rates and the outlook for oil prices.

headline: EASTERN AIR WILL LAY OFF 1,534 AS PART OF A DRIVE TO STEM LOSSES
abstract: Eastern Air Lines Inc. yesterday announced plans for one of its deepest cutbacks in an effort to stem its losses.   The moves include the layoffs of 1,534 employees, which are intended to save the airline $54 million a year. Some of the jobs lost will be in New York, but many more will be in Miami. Hundreds of management workers and hundreds of the workers who maintain Eastern's planes will be laid off.

headline: Sri Lankan President Stands Firm on Elections
abstract: President J. R. Jayewardene today rejected new demands by the main opposition party for early general elections to test popular opinion on a Government plan to end Sri Lanka's ethnic conflict.   In a letter to Sirimavo Bandaranaike, a former Prime Minister and leader of the opposition Freedom Party, Mr. Jayewardene said he would not call general elections until 1989.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
Bomb in West Germany Destroys a U.S. Car
abstract: A ''small and simple'' homemade bomb destroyed a civilian car belonging to a member of the United States military, the police said Sunday.

headline: Colt Debt Ratings
abstract: Moody's Investors Service assigned speculative-grade ratings to about $856 million of Colt Industries' long-term debt, the rating firm announced yesterday.

headline: Nabisco Brands Shifts Top-Level Executives
abstract: Nabisco Brands Inc., a unit of RJR Nabisco Inc., announced yesterday that it had named a new president and chief operating officer, Charles J. Chapman, who has been president of Nabisco Brands U.S.A.   Mr. Chapman, 51, succeeds James O. Welch Jr., 55, who becomes vice chairman and remains as chief executive. Robert M. Schaeberle, 62, will continue as chairman of Nabisco Brands.

headline: Reagan Urged To Help Steel
abstract: The chairmen of five steel companies and the president of the steelworkers' union today urged President Reagan in a letter to meet with leaders of the Congressional Steel Caucus to discuss ways to help the industry. A spokesman for the White House said the President was developing his response to the group's letter.   The letter was signed by Robert E. Boni, of Armco; Walter F. Williams, of Bethlehem Steel; Frank W. Luerssen, of Inland Steel; David H. Hoag, of LTV Steel; Howard M. Love, of National Steel, and Lynn Williams, of the United Steelworkers of America.

headline: Advertising; General Foods Cuts Ted Bates
abstract: TED BATES WORLDWIDE, the most recent addition to the General Foods agency roster, was dropped from it yesterday. The three brands it has been handling have been assigned to two longtime General Foods agencies.

headline: PRESIDENT DECIDES TO LET SOVIET BUY SUBSIDIZED WHEAT
abstract: President Reagan, ending a dispute between his farm policy and foreign policy advisers, today authorized the sale of subsidized wheat to the Soviet Union.   The wheat deal was announced by Secretary of Agriculture Richard E. Lyng, who had urged the extension of the export subsidy. American farmers will receive subsidy payments that could total as much as $75 million.   ''Today's decision should boost U.S. agricultural exports,'' a White House statement said. ''This decision is designed to help make the American farmer competitive by putting him on an equal footing with his foreign counterparts.''

headline: Sudanese Guerrillas Report Battle for Main Southern City
abstract: Sudanese rebels said today that they had begun a drive on Juba, the main city in the southern Sudan, and urged residents to evacuate children.

headline: Owens-Corning Board Rejects Bid by Wickes
abstract: The board of the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation rejected today a tender offer of $74 a share, or more than $2 billion, from the Wickes Companies.   Owens-Corning called the offer ''inadequate, not fully reflecting the inherent values in the company and not in the best interests of the company and its stockholders.'' Owens-Corning's stock, which jumped above the $74 mark after the offer was announced on Aug. 12, closed today on the New York Stock Exchange at $81.75 a share, up 50 cents.

headline: People
abstract: * Norman Bierman will join Ted Bates/New York as executive vice president of client services and director of business development.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 18, 1986:

headline: Suitors Seek French Deal
abstract: A tentative agreement for a French takeover of the ITT Corporation's telecommunications operations has produced a scramble among North American and European concerns seeking to acquire the second-largest French telephone switch manufacturer.   Karlheinz Kaske, the chairman of Siemens A.G., West Germany's largest telecommunications group, said that Siemens was pursuing talks to acquire Compagnie Generale de Constructions Telephoniques, a Government-owned company. Mr. Kaske made his remarks at a weekend news conference in Rome, details of which were released Tuesday.

headline: JACKSON GETS VISA TO SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that he was given permission to attend the inauguration Sunday of Bishop Desmond M. Tutu as Anglican Archbishop of South Africa, but only under unacceptably severe restrictions.   Unless he is given more flexibility, Mr. Jackson said, such a visit ''would not be a good use of time.''

headline: NEW SETBACK FOR CLEVELAND
abstract: Steelworkers here are worried by the LTV Corporation's filing for bankruptcy protection, but city officials and economic analysts said the company's steel operations had a chance to come back.   The LTV Steel Company subsidiary was the nation's second-largest steel producer and employed 9,000 people in Cleveland.   The Plain Dealer newspaper in an article called LTV's announcement ''a psychological blow to Cleveland's economy, which has lost some 7,000 manufacturing jobs in the last year and has not fully recovered from the recession of 1981-82.''

headline: GORBACHEV HINTS ABM TREATY SHIFT, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev signaled a shift in the Soviet position on the 1972 antiballistic missile treaty in a letter to President Reagan last week, Administration officials said today.   In the letter, according to the officials, the Soviet leader moved toward a possible compromise on the period for which the two sides would adhere to the ABM treaty, thus delaying deployment of the United States' space-based missile defense program.   The American officials said Mr. Gorbachev had proposed adherence for up to 15 more years. The previous Soviet position was 15 to 20 years.

headline: Baghdad Area Struck By an Iranian Missile
abstract: An explosion rocked this city early today, apparently from an attack by an Iranian surface-to-surface missile.   The blast came several hours after Iraq said it had repulsed an Iranian ground attack on the southern front.

headline: CAPACITY USE DROPPED TO 78.3% LAST MONTH
abstract: American industry, hurt by strikes against aluminum, lumber and communications companies, operated at 78.3 percent of capacity last month, the slowest pace since November 1983, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.   The Fed said the operating rate plunged six-tenths of a percentage point in June from 78.9 percent in May for the fourth decline in five months. Since 1986 began, the operating rate at the nation's factories, mines and utilities has dropped 2.5 percentage points.

headline: Captain of Tamil Ship Defends His Actions
abstract: The captain of the Aurigae, the freighter that brought 155 Sri Lankans to the coast of Canada, says he merely took the Tamil refugees ''where they wanted to go.''   In an interview today in The Toronto Star from the Canary Islands, the captain, Wolfgang Bindel, said, ''They made the choice.''

headline: BUSINESS FORUM: BEYOND THE FAIRNESS DOCTRINE; A New War on Corporate 'Propaganda'
abstract: SINCE 1980, when the Reagan Administration all but ceased enforcing the Fairness Doctrine, advocacy advertising on television by corporations and private organizations has exploded. By my conservative estimate, these interests spent $1.8 billion in 1985 to communicate their ideas on various public policy issues. That figure is rising by 10 to 15 percent a year.  However, at the same time that it is becoming a major source of television revenue and a significant element in public debate, a substantial portion of advocacy advertising is fast degenerating into thinly disguised propaganda bordering on disinformation. And now instead of enhancing the Fairness Doctrine, the Administration is urging Congress to abolish the measure.

headline: PPG Profit Is Up 2.7%
abstract: PPG Industries today reported second-quarter earnings of $91.8 million, or $1.54 a share, up 2.7 percent from $89.4 million, or $1.28 a share, a year ago. Sales rose 9.1 percent, to $1.2 billion, from $1.1 billion. The gains were attributed to improvements in the company's glass and coatings business, increased productivity and a weaker dollar.

headline: Bethlehem Sets A 2d Price Rise
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, taking advantage of the 12-day-old strike at the USX Corporation, today announced a second round of price increases.   Bethlehem, the nation's third-largest producer, said it would increase the base price of its plate-steel products by 4 percent.

headline: CBS to Air Grace's Amended Deficit Spot
abstract: W. R. Grace & Company has been trying unsuccessfully for several months to persuade the three major television networks to air a commercial it produced warning in dramatic fashion of the dangers of the Federal budget deficit. The networks had refused to run the commercial, titled ''The Deficit Trials: 2017 A.D.,'' because they determined that it constituted advocacy advertising - taking a position on a controversial topic of public importance.

headline: THE CAPITAL SPENDING SLUMP
abstract: When the International Business Machines Corporation announced a sharp drop in second-quarter earnings last month, it blamed larger economic forces. Capital spending by all corporations is down, I.B.M. said, and that means I.B.M.'s customers are not buying as many computers as before.   As I.B.M. goes, so goes the nation. A sluggish economy has cooled the appetite of American business to invest in plants and equipment and has pushed down profits at companies that supply those goods - from the steel beams to build a new factory to the computers to make the factory work. Capital spending fell in the first half of 1986, and forecasts are that it will be equally lackluster for the rest of the year, and perhaps beyond.   For economists, this is a sign that one of the driving forces of the current economic expansion is shifting into low gear. 10 Percent of the G.N.P.

headline: RJR Vice Chairman Gets a Broader Role
abstract: RJR Nabisco Inc. said yesterday that it had increased the responsibilities of Edward A. Horrigan Jr., the food and tobacco company's vice chairman.   Mr. Horrigan, in addition to his current responsibilities of looking after tobacco and two other units, Heublein Inc. and RJR Archer Inc., will oversee corporate public relations, corporate-government relations and corporate affairs.   Mr. Horrigan, 56 years old, had been president of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company until it bought Nabisco Brands Inc. last year for $4.9 billion. He has been vice chairman since the merger.

headline: Cooking Light to Make Its Debut in March
abstract: Cooking Light, The Magazine of Food and Fitness, will be published by the Southern Progress Corporation of Birmingham, Ala., a Time Inc. subsidiary, beginning in March.

headline: The U.N. Today: Aug. 22, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Preparatory Commission for International Seabed Authority and Law of the Sea Tribunal - 10.30 A.M.   Law of the Sea, Special Commission 2 - 10.30 A.M.

headline: 2 IN ULSTER POLICE REMOVED FROM DUTY
abstract: Two senior police officers in the Royal Ulster Constabulary have been removed from operational duty as part of a continuing investigation into charges that police pursued a ''shoot to kill'' policy against unarmed Roman Catholics.   The action, the first against policmen to result from the controversial inquiry, was announced tonight by constabulary officials at the end of a day of sectarian tension marked by clashes in Portadown between policemen and Protestants.   The two officers, who were not identified, were transferred from line duty to administrative work until the inquiry can be completed. It focuses on charges that there might have been an official coverup of abuses in shooting incidents involving six Catholics in 1982.

headline: U.S. Is Investigating A High-Tech Diversion
abstract: The Reagan Administration is investigating a purported attempt to divert a shipment of militarily sensitive high-technology equipment to the Soviet bloc, officials said today.   The shipment was first reported by the Wall Street Journal, which said it involved one of the largest conspiracies to smuggle sensitive technology to Communist nations.

headline: DOW RISES BY 28.54, TO 1,811.16
abstract: Stock prices surged ahead yesterday, propelled by falling interest rates and buying programs sparked by positive index futures figures. Only a relatively low trading volume marred the strong daylong advance.   At the close of the New York Stock Exchange, the 30-share Dow Jones industrial average was up 28.54 points, at 1,811.16, the biggest gain since a 36.06-point rise on June 13. The gain followed an 18.98-point rise for all of last week.

headline: QUAKE IN GREECE KILLS AT LEAST 8
abstract: A powerful earthquake rattled through southern Greece today and a Cabinet minister said at least eight people had been killed in the port city of Kalamata.   Environment Minister Evangelos Coloumbis also said that more than 200 people were injured, 70 of them seriously, when buildings collapsed during the quake, which measured 6.2 on the open-ended Richter scale.   Another quake measuring 5.4 struck Zakinthos Island in the Ionian Sea a few hours later but there were no reports of damage or casualties, the Athens Seismological Institute said.

headline: DOLLAR LOW ENOUGH FOR VOLCKER
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the dollar had probably dropped enough in relation to the currencies of other industrial countries and that policy makers should rely on other tools to redress imbalances in the world economy.   ''In contrast to the situation 18 months ago, and assuming growing markets are open to us, my sense is that we are for now reasonably close to an appropriate adjustment'' in foreign-exchange rates, Mr. Volcker said in a statement to a House Ways and Means subcommittee. Later, in response to a question about the dollar, he said, ''I'm not sure a further adjustment is necessary.''   In today's currency trading, the dollar eased after Mr. Volcker's remarks became known.  [ Page D20. ]  An Appearance of Discord His comments, perhaps the most specific the Fed chief has made on the subject in recent years, appeared to put him at odds with the Reagan Administration as the world's finance ministers and bankers gathered here for various crucial meetings, including the annual convention of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank.

headline: DENIES LINK WITH DANILOFF AFFAIR
abstract: The United States said today that it had given Moscow a list of 25 members of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations who must leave by Oct. 1.   This is the largest number of Soviet diplomats ever expelled by the United States at one time.   The White House and the State Department denied that the action was in retaliation for the restricted status in Moscow of an American journalist, Nicholas S. Daniloff, who is awaiting a possible trial on espionage charges.   The American step, officials said, is aimed at making make sure that the Soviet Union complies with an order of six months ago to reduce the size of its United Nations missions. Move to Show U.S. Toughness    But a White House official said the decision to expel the 25 mission members and to do it in a publicized way was related to a desire to appear tough and to show that the United States was ready to put into effect retaliatory measures until Mr. Daniloff is given safe passage back home.

headline: 3 Die in Ecuador Shootout
abstract: Three Ecuadorean police officers died in a shootout with leftist guerrillas who raided a hospital to rescue a wounded comrade, a senior Government security source said today. The guerrillas, who have close links to Colombia's leftist M-19 guerrillas, successfully carried away the rebel who was guarded by three policemen. The conservative Government of President Leon Febres Cordero has charged that some rebel leaders have been trained in Libya and Colombia.

headline: Real Estate; 2 Projects Add Glitter In SoHo
abstract: THE first shops to open in the SoHo neighborhood of Manhattan tended to be unpolished avant-garde boutiques carved out of the gritty ground floors in the industrial buildings that artists were converting into studios and living spaces.   But over the years, as the area ''South of Houston Street'' has strengthened as a center of galleries, boutiques and restaurants, its shops have lost some of their rough edges. Today sleek custom-designed storefronts are the rule rather than the exception. Some prime spaces in SoHo - generally considered to be the area between Houston and Canal Streets and Sixth Avenue and Broadway -are commanding rents as high as $100 a square foot.   Two new projects on West Broadway, SoHo's main throughfare, epitomize the trend toward a refinement in retailing, which now includes newly built spaces as well as renovations. At 382 West Broadway, between Spring and Broome Streets, the Hammer Construction Corporation has built a two-level, 6,000-square-foot building. Asking rents are about $80 a square foot.

headline: EXPERTS IN VIENNA OUTLINE NEW PLAN FOR A-PLANT SAFETY
abstract: An international symposium outlined a broad program to improve safety at the world's nuclear power plants today, but some experts expressed uncertainty over whether the plan could be put into effect.   The 13-point program was described at the close of a weeklong meeting of 500 scientists from 50 countries on the causes and lessons of the disaster at the Chernobyl nuclear plant in the Soviet Ukraine on April 26. The plan includes a call for international radiation standards, detailed exchanges of safety data, and suggestions that certain safety guidelines be mandatory in all the world's nuclear plants.   Many scientists agreed that improvements were needed, especially in the Soviet Union but also in other nations, to prevent another serious accident. The Chernobyl accident, the worst in commercial nuclear power history, has killed at least 31 people, is expected to kill thousands more from cancer, and has spread radiation around the world, contaminating food and people. In the accident, serious design flaws and human errors led to explosions that ripped open the reactor.

headline: PERES DECLARES TALKS WITH KING A SUCCESS DESPITE DIFFERENCES
abstract: Prime Minister Shimon Peres continued to say today that his surprise meetings with King Hassan of Morocco were a success, although he acknowledged that there had been no breakthrough in Middle East peace efforts.   The gap between the two sides was apparent today in the joint communique issued by the two countries. It emphasized King Hassan's insistence on the terms of a 1982 Arab League meeting in Fez, Morocco, and added that Mr. Peres had ''clarified his observations on the Fez plan.''

headline: J.P. STEVENS BUYBACK
abstract: J.P. Stevens & Company said it would begin a cash tender offer for up to 2.5 million of its common shares for prices between $34 and $38 a share. The company said it would select a price to enable it to buy up to one million shares and added that it might buy as much as 2.5 million shares. The tender offer will expire Oct. 22 unless extended.

headline: VF AND BLUE BELL AGREE TO $378 MILLION MERGER
abstract: The VF Corporation, the nation's largest publicly held apparel company, yesterday acquired Blue Bell Holdings, the second-largest maker of jeans and casual wear, for about $378 million in cash and stock.   The merger of the one-time competitors dissolves the market share lead held by Levi Strauss & Company for the jeans market, and also thrusts VF into a virtual tie with Levi, its archrival, as the country's largest apparel manufacturer overall, industry analysts said.   The combination of Blue Bell, which makes Wrangler jeans, and VF, whose H. D. Lee division is the nation's third-most popular brand of jeans, gives VF at least 25 percent of the jeans market, analysts said. Levi, a closely held concern, has had market share as high as 30 percent in recent years, but analysts said that advantage has eroded and the merged companies may have surpassed Levi. Firm industry statistics were not available.

headline: Hammermill President Adjusting to Takeover
abstract: W. Craig McClelland was on the 16th tee with a business client on July 24 when he saw a golf cart heading straight for his party. He knew it was a message.   ''I decided I better hit my shot because it might be the last time I do,'' he said.

headline: Malaysia to Dissolve Assembly and Hold Vote
abstract: Malaysia's Prime Minister announced today that Parliament would be dissolved to clear the way for general elections.

headline: Coke's Struggle
abstract: To the Editor:   ''Keeping New Coke Alive'' (July 20) chronicles the dangerous miscalculations a company can make when it focuses its resources on the wrong objectives. Coca-Cola's management, in electing to battle Pepsi for incremental gains in market share rather than respond to the public's tastes, has nearly undermined Classic's strong position, damaging the company's reputation and fostering confusion in the marketplace.

headline: BOLIVIAN ASKS U.S. FOR BIG LOAN TO MAKE UP LOST COCAIN INCOME
abstract: The Bolivian Ambassador to the United States told members of a Senate subcommittee today that his country would need an immediate $100 million loan to help defray the loss of income in Bolivia because of reduced cocaine exports.   Since the United States Army, in conjunction with Bolivian antinarcotics police, began attacking cocaine processing laboratories in north-central Bolivia this month, ''we have interrupted the manufacturing flow of cocaine,'' the Ambassador, Fernando Illanes, told the Senate Appropriations Committee's defense subcommittee.   And because illegal shipments of cocaine represent Bolivia's largest source of export income - larger, the Bolivian Government estimates, than all the legitimate sources of export income combined - there is now a ''desperate need for new dollars,'' he said.   State Department officials said the cocaine raids that began almost two weeks ago appeared to have disrupted Bolivia's economy. Bolivia ''has been coming under increasing pressure in recent days,'' a State Department official said, as black market sales of dollars have increased.

headline: INVESTING; SILVER: A NOT-SO-PRECIOUS METAL
abstract: IF one had to pick an investment that has done absolutely nothing in the past four years - except, perhaps, break investors' hearts - it would be silver.  Even gold and platinum, which like silver have been out of favor for some time, have shown more life. Over the last year or so, gold is up about 23 percent, to the $350-an-ounce range, from about $285, and platinum is up 74 percent, to $435, from $250 an ounce. In the same period, silver has been fighting to stay above $5 an ounce. Silver, in fact, has not done a thing since it soared to $50 an ounce, from $11, in the great Hunt silver raids from September 1979 to January 1980, only then to collapse.

headline: CONABLE'S CAUTIOUS APPROACH
abstract: Barber B. Conable Jr., who for the last three months has headed the World Bank, faces his first annual meeting Tuesday of the bank's stockholders -151 governments representing most of mankind.   Mr. Conable will outline plans to make the institution of nearly 7,000 bureaucrats more active, flexible and creative in its role as coordinator of long-range economic programs for the poorest countries.   So far the former ranking Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee has moved cautiously in the new job, making only a few personnel and administrative changes to reinforce a more direct management style.   The 63-year-old upstate New York politician, who was trained as a lawyer and has no previous banking experience, has injected a crisp pragmatism into the hoary issues of world population, nutrition, poverty, the role of women in development - and the role of the World Bank.

headline: Pollution-Control Facilities Bonds
abstract: A $110 million issue of Florida general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 5 percent for those due in 1988 to 6.80 percent in 1996 and 7.25 percent in 2008 through underwriters led by the Bankers Trust Company.   The issue, rated double-A by Moody's and S.&P., is backed by the state's full faith and credit and will be used to finance water supply and pollution control facilities for Dade County.

headline: 6 REGIONAL BELL UNITS LIFT PROFITS
abstract: Six regional Bell companies yesterday reported improved second-quater profits, with four of them recording double-digit gains.  Their former parent, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, however, said its earnings declined 8.5 percent, largely because of a 26-day strike and continued soft sales of A.T.& T. equipment.  The strong showing by the others - U S West, which climbed 11.5 percent; Bell Atlantic, 8.6 percent; Ameritech, 5.3 percent; Pacific Telesis, 16.2 percent; Nynex, 18.4 percent, and BellSouth, 11.3 percent - was attributed to increased demand for basic phone services and stringent cost-control measures.  ''The industry continues to show earnings improvement,'' said Neil Yelsey of Salomon Brothers. Analysts, saying the earnings were right on target with their expectations, predicted a bright future for the regional companies created from the breakup of A.T.& T. on Jan. 1, 1984. A.T. & T. A.T. & T. earnings declined to $422 million, or 37 cents a share, compared with $461 million, or 41 cents a share for the comparable period last year. Revenues for the quarter were down 1.6 percent, to $8.42 billion, from $8.56 billion.

headline: South Korean Leader Shuffles His Cabinet
abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan shuffled his Cabinet today, replacing 10 of the 22 ministers, a presidential spokesman said.

headline: RIGHTS LEADERS IN SOUTH AFRICA ESTIMATE DETAINEES AT OVER 8,000
abstract: A civil rights monitoring group here said today that more than 8,000 people had been detained without trial in the first six weeks of South Africa's newest emergency decree, imposed June 12.   The estimate is higher than the 7,900 people known to have been seized in the entire seven months of the previous emergency decree, lasting from July 1985 to March 1986.   Civil rights officials who helped compile the estimate acknowledged, however, that some of it was guesswork based on previous experience of trying to calculate the number of people detained.   The latest Western effort to defuse South Africa's crisis, meanwhile, seemed to have run into fresh difficulties today when Britain's Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, who is representing the Europeaan Community, arrived in Lusaka, Zambia, to be told by President Kenneth D. Kaunda that he was not welcome.

headline: Groups Declare Boycott Of Bangladesh Elections
abstract: Two major Bangladeshi opposition groups today denounced next month's elections as a device to keep Gen. H. M. Ershad as President and said they would boycott the voting.   One opposition party had already announced it would not take part in the elections and a fourth said today it would probably also pull out.

CHAIRMEN HIT A SNAG ON TAX BILL
abstract: Senator Bob Packwood and Representative Dan Rostenkowski hit an unexpected snag late tonight in their effort to reach agreement on tax revision legislation.   New revenue estimates based on the most recent economic forecasts by the Congressional Budget Office showed they would have find ways to raise an additional $17 billion over the next five years to bring in the same amount of money as the existing tax law.   The lawmakers and President Reagan have committed themselves to producing a new tax system that raises the same amount of revenue as the current law. The lower revenue created a problem for the negotiators because their efforts to make up the shortfall could force them to undo delicate agreements reached earlier.

headline: LABOR GROUP SEEKS MEETING WITH 8 DETAINED BY PRETORIA
abstract: Visiting international labor union leaders appealed to South Africa today for an urgent answer to their request for a meeting with unionists held under the state of emergency.   The development came as the Government reported that security forces shot dead four more people in township unrest during the night. The official death toll is 162 since June 12, when the state of emergency was declared.

headline: ARREST OF TOP LABOR LEADER BY PRETORIA CONFIRMED
abstract: As an international human rights group confirmed that the leader of South Africa's largest labor federation had been taken into custody, another labor leader expressed fear yesterday that there would be more detentions of union activists.   The human rights group, Amnesty International, confirmed earlier reports that Elijah Barayi, president of the 500,000-member Congress of South African Trade Unions, was arrested in South Africa over the weekend.   Leaders of the labor federation, which is known for its militant stand in opposition to apartheid, plan to come out of hiding today to announce a strategy for pressing the South African Government to free their imprisoned colleagues. Human rights groups estimate that 900 union activists have been arrested in the crackdown against labor, church and anti-apartheid leaders that began with the emergency decree on June 12.

headline: IN JAPAN, CONCERNS GROW OVER YEN
abstract: As the yen inches closer toward the 150-to-the-dollar level, economists and business leaders are being forced to contemplate the effects of an exchange rate that only months ago was all but unthinkable here.   Last week, the yen set new record levels of strength against the dollar. Although it closed Friday in New York at 156.25 yen to the dollar, still comfortably above the 150 level, many economists are predicting it could soon hit the 150 mark and below.  [ On Monday, Reuters reported that the dollar fell to a low of 155.12 yen at the opening of trading in the foreign-exchange market here. The United States currency had been as low as 154.85 yen before the opening in international trading by Tokyo operators in Sydney, Australia, and Wellington, New Zealand, against 156.15 at the New York close and 157.45 here on Friday, dealers said. ]  The economists believe that an exchange rate of 150 yen to the dollar would considerably slow Japan's already sluggish economic growth, further slash already-declining corporate profits and accelerate several trends set in motion by this year's rapid acceleration of the yen - moving production overseas, increasing imports of manufactured goods and shifting employment from manufacturing to the service sector.

U.S. REAFFIRMS VIEW THAT QADDAFI PLANS NEW TERRORIST ACTION
abstract: The White House issued a new statement on Libya today, saying its assertions that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was planning new acts of terrorism were based on ''a realistic assessment'' by American officials.   ''The U.S. Government is dealing with realities in this situation,'' Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said. ''This is a realistic assessment.''   His statement today was the latest in a series of differing assessments of the Libyan's intentions from Administration officials in Washington and other officials there and in California, where President Reagan is vacationing.

headline: LORAL RAISES ITS OFFER TO ACQUIRE SANDERS
abstract: The Loral Corporation raised the stakes today in its bid for Sanders Associates, announcing that it would begin a tender offer for more than half of Sanders stock at $50 a share.   On Friday, New York-based Loral offered $44 a share for Sanders and was promptly rebuffed in a statement calling the offer inadequate. Wall Street, sensing a possible bidding war in the offing, sent Sanders stock shooting up $15.75 a share, to $50.50. In today's trading, Sanders rose $3.25 more, closing at $53.75.

headline: BONN, FEELING PRESSURE OF VOTERS, IS TRYING TO CURB REFUGEE INFLUX
abstract: In the face of grass-roots opposition to asylum-seekers from the third world, the West German Government has taken steps to discourage unwanted immigration.   One step is to impose a $1,000 fine on airlines that carry passengers to West Germany without a valid visa and to oblige the airlines to take the passengers back. Visa-granting practices will be tightened at consulates.   Another measure, according to Government sources, is to extend to five years, from two, the period that asylum-seekers may not seek employment. Most applicants are believed to be seeking a rosier economic future, not fleeing political persecution.

P.L.O. Plans Move To Iraq and the Sudan
abstract: The Palestine Liberation Organization has decided to move its Jordanian offices to Iraq and the Sudan if permission from those Governments could be obtained, Palestinian sources said.   The P.L.O. will also seek Arab mediation to resolve its conflict with King Hussein of Jordan, who closed the group's offices in Jordan earlier this month.   Palestinian sources here in contact with the P.L.O. said the decisions were made Sunday at the end of a weeklong meeting in Tunis of the central committee of Al Fatah, the largest group within the P.L.O.

AFTER 6 YEARS, IRAN-IRAQ WAR IS DEADLOCKED AS TACTICS SHIFT
abstract: When illumination flares begin popping and shells falling along the 733-mile border Monday morning, Iraq and Iran will have been at war for six years.   No quick or conclusive end is in sight, and the safest prediction may be a prolongation of the costly conflict.   But there are a few signs that the deadlock might end or, at least, that the Persian Gulf war might dwindle into a sort of undeclared peace, according to several military analysts and foreign experts.   Since July 23 the Iraqi Air Force, which has almost total air superiority and freedom of action, has used more aggressive tactics against Iran's oil industry, these analysts say. While in previous years efforts to block Iranian oil exports had been largely ineffective, such ''low and slow'' bombing could tighten the economic screws on Iran if it persists.

headline: SOVIET FOREIGN MINISTRY ENDORSES SPY CHARGE AGAINST U.S. REPORTER
abstract: The spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry said today that an American reporter detained since Saturday had been caught ''red-handed'' in espionage activities.   The remarks by the spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, seemingly threw the weight of the Foreign Ministry behind the detention of Nicholas Daniloff, Moscow correspondent of the news magazine U.S. News & World Report.   Mr. Daniloff was arrested by agents of the K.G.B., the internal security agency, on Saturday in a park in the Lenin Hills after a Soviet acquaintance had handed him an envelope with unspecified secret maps and papers.

headline: SAYS THEY AGREED TO CONSIDER TIES
abstract: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Prime Minister Shimon Peres met for more than an hour today, and Mr. Peres said they had agreed to consider normalizing relations between the Soviet Union and Israel.   It was the highest level at which Soviet and Israeli officials have met officially since Moscow severed relations after the Arab-Israeli war of 1967. Some Israeli diplomats said they believed it was also the first high-level Soviet contact ever with an Israeli Prime Minister.   Both sides said the atmosphere was more constructive today than at talks last month in Helsinki, Finland, between Soviet and Israeli officials. Those talks broke down when the Israelis raised questions about the emigration of Soviet Jews.
