China Project Studied
abstract: Noranda Inc. said today that it and a Chinese nonferrous metals company have begun a feasibility study, to be completed in January, for a $140 million complex in northeastern China. The Tientsin complex, using refining technology developed by Noranda, would have an annual capacity of 100,000 metric tons of processed copper.

headline: HAWAII VENTURE'S STELLAR CAST
abstract: In a marriage of spectacular expertise and connections, William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary who has become an investment Midas, has bought a stake in Hawaii's biggest savings and loan association and has hired Preston Martin to run it.   Mr. Martin was the No. 2 official of the Federal Reserve Board before resigning at the end of March and is a former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the regulatory body for the thrift industry.   Mr. Simon said in an interview after today's announcement that the deal for the Honolulu Federal Savings and Loan Association, which has $1.7 billion in deposits, marked the start of a network of banking institutions his investment group plans to acquire to ''span the Pacific'' from the United States to the Orient.   The announcement coincided with approval of Honolulu Federal's conversion to a stock association by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

headline: Making a Fuel From Old Tires
abstract: WHAT do you do with an old tire? Tire makers and recyclers are being pressed to answer that question, with more than 240 million scrap tires generated in this country each year.   The used tire - because of its size, shape and air-polluting properties when burned - has become one of the nation's most difficult disposal problems. Some of these tires are placed in landfills; others are sold as retreads. But most old tires are disposed of illegally - dumped by the side of the road or stockpiled, where they become fire hazards or harborages for rodents and mosquitoes.

headline: LOOKING ABROAD TO FILL OUR BELLIES
abstract: EVERY morning, 18-wheelers, gears grinding, back into the loading dock at the Giant Food supermarket on Rockville Pike just north of the capital. Aluminum doors clatter open, clerks scurry inside, and a dazzling array of food begins to move from the trailers to the shelves.   It is a ritual repeated at supermarkets all over America, and one that has not changed much in the last decade. What has changed, though, is the origin of the food being unloaded.   Almost unnoticed in the national anxiety over rising imports of autos, steel, textiles, and electronic appliances, is the steadily increasing amount of foreign food consumed by Americans. Pork flows in from Canada, beef from Australia, tomatoes, broccoli and cauliflower from Mexico, olives from Portugal, apples from Chile, orange juice from Brazil, mushrooms from Taiwan - a myriad of foods that, despite transportation costs and United States tariffs, still carry lower price tags than their American counterparts.

headline: Pharmacia Deal
abstract: Pharmacia A.B., one of Sweden's largest pharmaceutical companies, has acquired A.B. Leo, another Swedish pharmaceutical concern that specializes in cancer care products, for $430 million in cash and stock.

headline: Oslo May Cut Oil Royalties
abstract: The Norwegian Government said yesterday that it would propose eliminating some of the royalties required of North Sea oil companies in an effort to give the companies an incentive to maintain operations there despite the sharply lower oil prices. A Government spokesman also suggested that oil companies might no longer have to pay the same share as the state in developing new production fields.

headline: A Tool Box for On-Screen Tutorials
abstract: ONE of the most difficult questions facing any trailblazing software package is the one put to it by the potential user, namely, ''What do I do with it?'' I myself have on a number of occasions fallen into the trap of not looking at a program because I couldn't instantly figure out what it was for. The most recent occurrence of this quandary for me was with Dan Bricklin's Demo Program ($74.95 for the I.B.M. PC and compatibles from Software Garden Inc., West Newton, Mass., 02165, (617) 332-2240).   Frankly, I am not enamored of corporate slide presentations. Assuming that the equipment is functioning properly (which it was not at the last such affair I attended), gatherings of this nature offer moderately handy opportunities for a quick catnap, particularly where the producers have arranged a large and attractive repast on the groaning board as a warm-up. Outside of this rejuvenating element tendered on occasion, I find that the engagements for the most part have little of value to offer.

headline: Western Union And GTE in Deal
abstract: The GTE Corporation said it had agreed to buy Airfone Inc., which provides airline-passenger telephone service.

headline: SOME DOUBTS ON REFUGEES OFF CANADA
abstract: There were reports today that 152 Sri Lankan refugees found adrift off the coast here this week actually embarked from West Germany and not from a port in India, as they told the authorities.   Officials here said that as a result of this and other unconfirmed information, they were investigating the possibility that there had been a conspiracy to violate Canadian immigration laws.   The Sri Lankans' point of departure could have some bearing on their refugee status in Canada if it is shown that they had official residential status in a third country.   The Sri Lankans, all members of a predominantly Hindu minority group in an island nation where Buddhists are dominant, were found Monday drifting in two 28-foot lifeboats in rough seas off Newfoundland's southern coast. The refugees, almost all of them men, said they had been in the boats for five days after being put off a freighter.

headline: ADVERTISING; Account
abstract: * Charivari, a chain of high-fashion specialty stores, and Brown Group, a consumer product and specialty retailing corporation, to Keeble, Cavaco & Duka.

headline: TEXAS AIR TRANSFER OF SLOTS COMPLETED
abstract: The Texas Air Corporation said it had completed the previously announced transfer of 75 takeoff and landing slots at New York's La Guardia Airport and Washington's National Airport to the Pan Am Corporation for $60.7 million.   The company said the transaction would allow it, in turn, to complete the acquistion of Eastern Air Lines Inc. The United States Department of Transportation yesterday tentatively approved the Eastern acqusition on the condition that Texas Air sell the slots to Pan Am as it had planned.

headline: Israeli President Meets New Egyptian Envoy
abstract: Egypt's new Ambassador to Israel, Mohammed Bassiouny, who had served as charge d'affaires since the former Egyptian Ambassador was withdrawn in 1982, presented his credentials to President Chaim Herzog today.   ''I hope there will be full relations between our two countries, and a just and lasting peace that will bring prosperity and security to the entire region,'' Mr. Bassiouny said at a ceremony at the President's home in Jerusalem.

headline: Allied Stores Stock Dips $1.125 a Share
abstract: The common stock of Allied Stores dipped $1.125 a share yesterday, closing at $58.25 in heavy New York Stock Exchange trading, and analysts continued to be skeptical that the retailer would accept the $58-a-share offer announced Thursday by the Campeau Corporation, The stock had risen $10.75 a share Thursday after Campeau. a Canadian real estate developer, announced its bid. Allied owns a variety of department and specialty stores including Brooks Brothers, Bonwit Teller, Ann Taylor, Garfinckel's, Jordan Marsh and Stern's.

headline: TO ORDEALS IN GRENADA, ADD A TRIAL
abstract: In a small, bare courtroom, high on a windswept pinnacle overlooking the picture-postcard harbor dotted with sailing yachts, steamers loading bananas and cruise ships unloading tourists, 17 men and a woman are being tried here on charges of committing one of the most spectacular murders the Caribbean has ever witnessed.   It was a crime that not only took the life of the leftist Prime Minister of Grenada, Maurice Bishop, and 10 others nearly three years ago. It also brought about the death of a revolution proclaimed by the leftists, whose Government was seen by the Reagan Administration as a festering threat to the United States and its allies throughout the Western Hemisphere.   The killings grew out of a dispute over leadership of the radical Government, which was then four years old. After Mr. Bishop's death, a hard-line faction that called itself the Revolutionary Military Council took over and imposed a 24-hour curfew that made residents of the spectacularly beautiful little island prisoners in their own homes. Six days later, the United States sent in more than 5,000 marines and paratroopers in the first use of force in the Caribbean by American military units in nearly two decades.

headline: Louisville Shift To Gannett
abstract: The Gannett Company completed the purchase of the family-owned Louisville newspapers today for $306.9 million, retaining their president, George N. Gill, with the new title of president and publisher. Michael G. Gartner, Gannett general news executive, was named editor of The Louisville Times and The Courier-Journal papers, which have been owned for nearly 70 years by the Bingham family.

headline: Thai Premier Reported To Accept Offer
abstract: Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda has accepted an offer from four parties to stay in office for a third term, The Nation newspaper reported today.   The parties, which agreed after elections on July 27 to form a new coalition government, nominated General Prem as Prime Minister on Thursday.   The Nation quoted General Prem's secretary, Lieut. Gen. Chantarakupt Sirisuth, as saying the Prime Minister notified the National Assembly president Friday that he was accepting the offer.

headline: LINK IN PARIS BOMBINGS
abstract: The French police said today that they had found evidence linking bombings here to a brother of the terrorists' suspected leader.   The group taking responsibility for the bombings has demanded the release from prison of the leader, Georges Ibrahim Abdallah.

headline: Chrysler, A.M.C. In Production Pact
abstract: The American Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation signed a contract, as expected, to produce some of Chrysler's full-size models at the Kenosha A.M.C. plant.

headline: First Bank System Sees Write-Off
abstract: First Bank System Inc. said that, after a review of its investment and loan portfolio, it expects to add about $275 million to its loan-loss reserve and to charge off $275 million in loans during the third quarter.

headline: Key Rates
Delta Strategy Change Seen in Western Deal
abstract: Delta Air Lines' proposed merger with Western Airlines is being seen in the industry as a belated admission by the Atlanta-based carrier that it can no longer rely on its conservative internal growth strategy to remain competitive.   Delta has traditionally eschewed purchasing large regional carriers, the kind of acquisitions that have recently become common in the industry. Instead, its strategy has been to gradually expand from its major hub in Atlanta by adding other hubs in Dallas, Cincinnati and Memphis.

headline: OPEC DEAL: A BID TO DRAW IRAN OUT?
abstract: Hopes that the militant Islamic Government of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini might become more engaged in political and economic diplomacy were among the reasons that Saudi Arabia went along with Iran's plan to cut OPEC production and raise prices, according to State Department analysts.   ''Drawing Iran into various international networks has the potential benefit of making it more sensitive to the views of those countries that it has to deal with, and if it works it would encourage Iranians in the leadership to be more outward-looking,'' a State Department official said.   The officials said they thought this was one of the calculations made by Saudi Arabia in acceding to a compromise with an enemy that has not only attacked Saudi shipping in the Persian Gulf during its six-year war with Iraq but has blatantly threatened to overthrow the Saudi and other conservative Gulf monarchies. U.S. Goal    The principal American political objective is a truce in the Iran-Iraq war. One result of the provisional pact by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will be to raise oil prices, giving Iran more money with which to fight the war, but American officials see this as a calculated risk.

headline: AN EASY INTRODUCTION TO THE PC
abstract: WHEN one looks at the cost of a personal computer in an office environment, the most obvious expense is the hardware. It is the easiest factor to quantify, after all. One needs the computer, a monitor, a printer and perhaps a modem.   The cost of the software often comes as a nasty surprise, because the program needs are not so easy to define. A particular computer may start out almost as a dedicated word processor in its single-minded pursuit of business letters and memos. Then later scheduling software may be added to simplify the office routine, then a billing package, then a data base manager and so on. Still, it is possible to tally up the bills for the software purchased and arrive at some kind of a cost/benefit ratio.

headline: JAPANESE AGREE TO 'STAR WARS' RESEARCH
abstract: Japan gave its long-awaited approval today to the Reagan Administration's space-based antimissile program, paving the way for possible involvement by Japanese industry and Government research agencies.   But the Government stopped short of guaranteeing Japanese participation, and said that important details, including the commercial benefits Japan could expect, still had to be negotiated with Washington.   Even if a broad agreement is reached, a senior Foreign Ministry official said, individual companies and research institutions will decide whether to join the American effort, the Strategic Defense Initiative, which is informally called ''Star Wars.''   The announcement was welcomed by Japanese high-technology companies, but denounced by the political opposition and antinuclear groups. The leading opposition force, the Socialist Party, accused the Government of joining ''a strategy that expects to make the globe and space a battlefield.''

headline: Ecuador Calls Troops As Mass Strike Begins
abstract: The Ecuadorean Government called out troops today to keep order and guard public services as labor unions representing 700,000 workers went on strike for a higher minimum wage.   The job action, declared illegal by the Government on Tuesday, closed factories in the capital, but shops and banks remained open and public transportation continued to operate, although with reduced services.

headline: Advertising; Prevention Magazine's New Focus
abstract: AFTER about a decade of working in Emmaus, Pa., and living in nearby Allentown, Sanford T. Beldon will not find it easy to tear himself away from the cows and return to the hustle of Manhattan. But there are few big ad agencies or advertisers in the vicinity of Emmaus, so the new publisher of Rodale Press's Prevention magazine will make the sacrifice.   ''I'm a hands-on publisher,'' he explained over coffee one morning last week at the Algonquin. Since selling space to national advertisers is the key to the 36-year-old magazine's growth plans, the advertising capital is where his hands belong.

headline: Early Shipment For I.B.M. Model
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had shipped the first model of its most powerful new generation of mainframe computers a year ahead of the company's original schedule.

headline: New Chief Is Sought In Search by M.C.C.
abstract: The search for a new leader for the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation began today, after the announcement Thursday that Adm. Bobby R. Inman would resign at the end of the year.   A spokesman said he could not say whether directors of the research consortium in Austin, Tex., would look outside the organization's executive staff.

IRAN REPORTS RAID ON IRAQI OILFIELD
abstract: Iran said it bombed an oilfield in northern Iraq today. The report came a day after Iran fired a long-range missile into Baghdad, the Iraqi capital, and Iraqi jets retaliated by attacking an Iranian oil-export terminal at Sirri in the Persian Gulf.   The official Iranian press agency said today that Iranian jets struck oil installations two miles northeast of the Iraqi town of Kirkuk, hitting a computer control center.

headline: Planning to Supplement A Pension
abstract: THE proposed restructuring of the nation's tax system complicates retirement planning for people of all ages. ''Congress has put a lot of teeth in the current proposals,'' said Robert M. Siper, director of pension consulting services for the accounting firm of KMG Main Hurdman. The extensive changes ''will not simplify anything'' in retirement planning, he added.   While the full dimensions of the proposed changes are still being debated, experts say the basic impact of the 1986 Tax Bill is clear. The new law is expected to reduce the attractiveness of 401(k) plans and individual retirement accounts. In addition, tighter rules governing the funding of corporate pension plans would limit employees' options. One result: Individual taxpayers will have to shoulder more responsibility for organizing their own retirement plans. ''People will have to find other ways to shelter their income, and retirees will have to look to outside sources of income to supplement their retirement plan payments,'' said Richard B. Stanger, director of employee benefits services with Price Waterhouse. The best defensive stragegy is to take charge early on. ''Start planning for retirement the day you begin working, because it's anybody's guess how much you'll get from your company pension plan and Social Security,'' said Zeldy Lyman, a vice president at Kidder Peabody and Company.

headline: WAHT'S INEFFICIENT, UNFAIR AND UNSIMPLE?
abstract: AFTER the Senate passed its tax-revision bill last month, the McNeil-Lehrer Report featured a bipartisan love-in involving leading Republicans and Democrats. Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, Senator Bob Dole, Senator Bill Bradley and Representative Dan Rostenkowski fell over each other praising the bill and themselves. ''We are really doing something for the taxpayer,'' each boasted.   But I wonder whether Congress is doing something for the taxpayer or something to the taxpayer that cannot be discussed in polite company. Politicians keep crowing that America will experience the most important tax bill ever, which I think is akin to experiencing the most important flu epidemic ever. Tax overhaul, like the flu, is an annual event - some years worse than others.

headline: JAPAN BOND ROLE CALLED SIGNIFICANT
abstract: As the Government bond market prepares to absorb the $28 billion in securities the Treasury will auction this week at its quarterly refunding, the question that continues to dominate trading is how much Japanese investors will buy.   The answer, according to some officials at Japanese banks and securities firms here, is plenty. Some say investors may buy nearly as much as the estimated $2 billion to $3 billion in 10-year notes and $4 billion to $6 billion in 30-year bonds the Japanese are believed to have purchased at the last refunding in May.   ''Japanese investor attitude about the United States bond market is the same as in May, the spread between United States and Japanese interest rates is about the same, and the exchange rate looks more stable,'' said Akira Tokutomi, executive vice president for fixed income at Nikko Securities Internationl.

headline: India Arrests Suspect In Killing of General
abstract: The authorities said today that they had captured a man they suspect of assassinating Gen. Arun S. Vaidya, a former Indian army Commander in Chief.

headline: Buyback Terms Given By Anderson, Clayton
abstract: Anderson, Clayton & Company today announced the terms of its previously announced offer for its own stock, disclosing that it would buy back up to 8 million shares for $60 each. The company has 12.2 million shares outstanding.   In a letter to Bear, Stearns & Company and Gruss & Company, the board also said it had recommended that shareholders reject the offer made by the two investment firms to buy Anderson's shares for $56 a piece.

headline: SOVIET DISSIDENT REPORTS NEW K.G.B. THREAT
abstract: A Soviet dissident who was freed from a Siberian prison camp five months ago after serving three years at hard labor has told friends that the K.G.B. has threatened to send him back to prison again.   The dissident, Yuri Tarnopolsky, a chemist and a poet, told Nancy Rosenfeld of Chicago Action for Soviet Jewry in a telephone conversation last week that he did not think he would survive another prison term.   Dr. Tarnopolsky was arrested in 1983 and found guilty of anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda.

headline: SHIFT IN PRESIDENCY FOR MORGAN BANK
abstract: J. P. Morgan & Company and its subsidiary, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, announced yesterday that Robert V. Lindsay, president of both companies since 1980, intends to retire at the end of the year. Morgan said that Dennis Weatherstone, chairman of its executive committee, had been elected to succeed him.   Mr. Lindsay, who has spent his entire 37-year career with Morgan, has long wanted to leave the bank upon reaching the age of 61, a birthday he will celebrate on Jan. 1. His departure in advance of the bank's mandatory retirement age of 65 is not a surprise.

headline: FED FINES HOUSEHOLD $600,000
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board imposed a $600,000 civil penalty today against Household International Inc. - the largest one-time fine it has ever levied - for repeated lending violations at its limited-service bank subsidiary.   Limited-service banks, which the Fed has vigorously opposed, have come into being in recent years to provide commercial companies a way to enter banking. They escape the prohibition of a commercial company owning a bank by limiting their services to either making business loans or taking deposits, but not both.   Fed officials said the Household case underscored their concern that such banks were difficult to supervise and were susceptible to pressures from their commercial parents that could lead to poor loan quality.

headline: Early Oil Price Climb Cut in Record Trading
abstract: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products gyrated wildly on world oil markets yesterday as participants continued to grapple with the long-term import of OPEC's new accord.   Optimism was the watchword early in the day at the New York Mercantile Exchange, where contracts for September delivery of West Texas Intermediate crude moved as high as $16.50 a barrel, up dramatically from Monday's closing price of $13.29. But when caution set in later prices fell sharply, to a close of $15.02.

headline: EUROPEANS MAY PROP THE DOLLAR
abstract: The 12 nations of the European Community have agreed to a joint effort, starting Monday, to buttress the value of the dollar against the West German mark, the Reuters news service reported today.   The report, from Gleneagles, Scotland, where the Community's finance ministers and central bankers met this weekend, was attributed to a senior official who declined to be named. It also quoted Luxembourg's finance minister, Jacques Poos, as saying, ''We want to stop the fall of the dollar by all means possible.''   Mr. Poos added, Reuters said, that ''the general feeling was to stand up and speak with one voice toward the United States.''

headline: Jaguar Net Rises 24.9%
abstract: Jaguar P.L.C., the British luxury auto maker, said today that its net income for the first half of this year rose 24.9 percent, to $:45.1 million, or about $67.2 million at current exchange rates, from $:36.1 million a year earlier.

headline: Peat Marwick Settles Suit Brought by F.D.I.C.
abstract: Peat Marwick, Mitchell & Co., the Big Eight accounting firm, said yesterday that it had settled a $90 million lawsuit brought against it by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation after the collapse of the Penn Square Bank.   Arthur Bowman, the editor of the Public Accounting Report, an Atlanta-based industry newsletter, said the F.D.I.C. ''probably settled for less than half'' of the roughly $90 million it was seeking.   Neither Victor M. Earle, who is Peat Marwick's principal attorney in the case, nor Charles Baker, the F.D.I.C.'s lawyer, would disclose the size of the settlement. They said they did not want to prejudice coming jury trials relating to Penn Square.

headline: Pessimism On Trade Gap
abstract: A manufacturing industry group said today that it sees little improvement in the huge United States trade deficit through 1987, in part because its own members are too complacent about meeting foreign competition.   ''American manufacturers are not sufficiently aggressive given the full-scale battle the foreign producers are putting on to hold their share of the market,'' said Jerry Jasinowski, executive vice president and chief economist for the National Association of Manufacturers.

headline: HCM Reunites Winning Team
abstract: The award-winning copywriter-art director team that was knocking them dead with their Volvo advertising in the late 1970's has been reunited at the HCM agency.   John Danza, 43 years old, and Michael Drazen, 44, who turned out such good advertising at Scali, McCabe, Sloves, will now be supervising the creative output at HCM, a Franco-American joint-venture agency whose American partner is Young & Rubicam.   Mr. Drazen, the copywriter, has been executive creative director of HCM since its founding in December 1984. Mr. Danza, the art director, is joining him from the world of the film director, in which he has been involved since 1980. His previous employers have included Jack Tinker & Partners and Carl Ally Inc.

headline: 2 Abducted by Gunmen In the Philippines
abstract: A Swiss tourist and a Filipino woman were kidnapped today by men who dragged them into a boat at gunpoint on an island near this southern Philippine city, the police said.

headline: SUMMER SCANDAL UNFOLDS IN FRANCE
abstract: A summertime scandal is growing rapidly here. Among its elements are the flight to Paraguay of a former French official, tales of false receipts and espionage operations in the African country of Burundi and the purchase of a castle in the French countryside.   The scandal centers on a sordid tale, being told by a single ranking official in the Socialist Government - which lost in elections last March and now shares power - of large-scale embezzlement and misuse of funds by senior Socialist leaders, charges that have led to the indictment of four lower-ranking figures already.   The scandal has gravely touched one cabinet member in the former Socialist Government and a major daily newspaper, the rightist Le Figaro, has tried to implicate President Francois Mitterrand, claiming in a headline Monday that ''Mitterrand Knew'' of the wrongdoing.

headline: Mixed Results From Rate Cut
abstract: Bond prices were mixed in light trading yesterday, as traders chose to hang on to short-term issues and take profits on more speculative longer-term securities.   The price decline, which amounted to more than a point and a half in some issues, came a day after the Federal Reserve announced it would cut its discount rate by half a point, to 6 percent. The move had been widely anticipated, and was preceded by a rally in the credit markets that lasted the better part of two weeks.

headline: PAKISTAN AGAIN SEES SCATTERED PROTESTS
abstract: Scattered rioting and anti-Government protests continued in Karachi and rural parts of southern Pakistan for the fourth straight day today, while in Lahore 2,000 protesters held a peaceful march through the city.   Reuters reported tonight that army troops had been called out to the city of Tatta, 55 miles east of Karachi, where on Friday anti-Government protesters stormed a police station and a jail, freeing several prisoners. The report could not be confirmed.

headline: Fed Approves Underwriting
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board has approved an unusual structure that would allow a subsidiary of a commercial bank holding company to participate in a public securities underwriting.   Under the structure, the underwriter, Lazard Freres & Company, would be allowed to avoid using a retail brokerage house in the underwriting - as would usually be the case in this kind of deal - thus reducing the overall fees an investor pays.

headline: Piedmont Airlines
abstract: Piedmont Airlines said it had ordered six Boeing 767-200 extended-range wide-body aircraft and had secured an option on another six. The value of the order, with delivery expected to begin in May 1987, was not disclosed. The new Boeing is a medium- to long-range wide body that seats 220 passengers.

headline: North Carolina Sets Refunding
abstract: North Carolina, which had not issued any general obligation debt securities since April 1983, is offering $460 million of public improvement and highway refunding bonds, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

headline: SUDAN FAMINE-RELIEF FLIGHTS SET
abstract: International sponsors of a planned relief operation for hundreds of thousands of famine victims in the war-devastated southern Sudan announced today that they would begin this week to fly food and other aid to starving civilians in two Government-held towns in the region.   They refused to say, however, whether they had received assurances from rebels in the south that their plane would not be shot down.

headline: Catholics Protest To Pretoria
abstract: The United States Catholic Conference has sent the South African Government a strong protest against ''unwarranted attacks'' on ministers of the church and, in particular, the continued detention of the General Secretary of the Southern Africa Catholic Bishops Conference, church sources said this week.   In a letter dated July 25 to the South African Ambassador, Herbert Beukes, the Rev. William M. Lewers, director of the Catholic Conference's Office of International Justice and Peace, said the emergency decree in South Africa was producing ''many objectionable situations, some of which are of particular concern to church people.''

headline: IC Sells Track
abstract: IC Industries said that its Illinois Central Gulf Railroad subsidiary had agreed to sell 631 miles of track to the Chicago, Missouri & Western Railway Company for $81 million. Chicago, Missouri & Western Railway is a subsidiary of the Venango River Corporation, which owns the Chicago South Shore & South Bend Railroad. IC, a diversified consumer and commercial products company, said the rail line runs south from Joliet, Ill., to Springfield, Ill., with additional lines from St. Louis to Kansas City, Mo.

headline: 2 East German Guards Escape Over Berlin Wall
abstract: Two East German border guards escaped over the Berlin wall and then tossed their guns back into the East, the West Berlin police said today.   The escape Sunday evening was the first reported over the wall since the ceremonies on Wednesday commemorating the 25th anniversary of the concrete barrier.

headline: U.S. Sees No Sign Mexico Will Curb Agents
abstract: Administration officials said today that they saw no evidence that Mexico intended to restrict the activities of American drug agents in that country.   The officials were responding to a diplomatic note issued Wednesday by Mexico suggesting that a Drug Enforcement Administration agent who was seized in Mexico had exceeded his authority when he met with an informer.

headline: POIGNANT WELCOME IN POLAND FOR JEWISH SCHOLARS
abstract: Simply put, what happened here on Tuesday was that Moshe Altbauer, who received his doctorate from Jagiellonian University 50 years ago, came here from Israel and took part in a conference on Jewish life in medieval and Renaissance Poland.   As is often the case, the real story lay not in the basic plot, but in the nuances. Two participants in the conference in a richly paneled 14th-century chamber at the university - Marian Turski of Warsaw and Lucjan Dobroszycki of New York - have consecutive numbers tattooed on their arms, having been processed at Auschwitz together.   Moreover, Mr. Dobroszycki, editor of ''The Chronicle of the Lodz Ghetto'' and a professor at Yeshiva University, was in his native land for the first time since 1968, when he left with tens of thousands of others amid an official anti-Jewish campaign.

headline: Teen-Age Pregnancy Draws Campaign
abstract: The social problem: One of every seven babies in New York City is born to a teen-age mother. The advertising problem: How to convince teen-agers to get information, advice and help about sex without being preachy.

headline: U.S. JOURNALISTIC GROUPS SEEK TALKS ON DANILOFF
abstract: Leaders of organizations representing newspapers, magazines and broadcasting announced today that they wanted to go to Moscow to seek the release of an American journalist charged with espionage.   While the announcement was intended to show support for a colleague and outrage at his arrest, and to reassure other journalists working abroad, it was also meant to signal that the nation's journalists have a role to play in the situation independent of the Government, the organizers said.   ''The time has come to speak for ourselves, to act for ourselves,'' said Eugene L. Roberts Jr., executive editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer, who initiated the effort to assemble the diverse journalistic group.   Thus far, the arrest of Nicholas S. Daniloff, a correspondent for U.S. News & World Report, has been treated largely as a diplomatic crisis and has been handled through State Department channels.

headline: FERMENTA FOUNDER SET TO SELL TO MONTEDISON
abstract: The embattled founder of Sweden's Fermenta A. B., Refaat el-Sayed, announced today that he planned to sell his company to Montedison, the giant Italian chemical producer, in a deal worth an estimated $290 million.   Until recently, Fermenta, a pharmaceutical and biotechnology concern, was an investors' favorite and one of the fastest-growing companies in Western Europe.   The announced sale marks a fall from grace for Mr. el-Sayed, the 40-year-old Egyptian-born founder of Fermenta and the owner of about 80 percent of its voting stock. Just last year, Mr. el-Sayed was named ''Swede of the Year'' by state-owned television for breaking into the traditionally closed Swedish business fraternity and becoming the nation's most successful entrepreneur. Largely through a series of acquisitions from 1982 to 1985, Fermenta's revenues jumped twentyfold, to about $190 million, while its pretax profits leaped 65 times, to an estimated $36 million.

headline: U.S. Agency Clears Sale of Republic Air
abstract: The Transportation Department approved the largest airline deal in history today, clearing Northwest Airlines' takeover of Republic Airlines to create the nation's third-largest air carrier.   Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole, in approving the $884 million merger, acknowledged concern about the potential for reduced competition, but concluded that the two airlines would not have the market power to unfairly raise prices.

headline: BANK OF JAPAN SILENT
abstract: The Bank of Japan remained silent today on whether it would follow the Federal Reserve's lead and cut its own basic interest rate, but economists and traders think the bank may do so in a few days.   The Bank of Japan's Governor, Satoshi Sumita, has repeatedly denied that it will soon cut its rate, saying the bank has already done so three times this year and expressing concern about the possible inflationary effects of another cut.

headline: Soviet Diplomat In Bangkok for Talks
abstract: The Soviet Foreign Ministry has sent the head of its recently created Southeast Asia department to the region for discussions in advance of the annual United Nations General Assembly, according to Thai officials. Thailand is a member of the Security Council.

headline: Mack Trucks Sale
abstract: Henley Group Inc. took another step in restructuring its assets by selling its 10 percent interest in Mack Trucks Inc. to Sterling, Grace & Company and other institutional investors for $37 million. Henley contains about 35 businesses spun off from Allied-Signal Inc. in November, ranging from real estate to health-care and energy service companies. A spokesman said Henley sold the interest because it had a small investment and was offered a favorable price.

headline: MAN LINKED TO MANILA CASE QUESTIONED IN JERSEY
abstract: A former Philippine legislator who is said to be wanted for the murder of opponents of President Ferdinand E. Marcos was questioned by the police in New Jersey on Tuesday after being found on an estate owned by the Marcos family in Lawrence township.   But yesterday the local sheriff's department, after having consulted the State Department, the Secret Service and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, decided that there were no grounds for detaining the man, identified as Orlando Dulay. A State Department official declined comment on the affair.

headline: Bid Results Tallied By The Economist
abstract: The Economist Newspaper Ltd. said that it had received commitments to acquire more than 51 percent of the outstanding shares of the Business International Corporation, a closely held publishing, research and consulting firm.

headline: A Pepsi Spot On Soviet TV
abstract: Tube watchers who caught Ted Turner's Goodwill Games on either an independent television station or on cable will not be surprised to learn that Pepsi was the biggest sponsor of that coverage.   They are not aware, however, that Pepsico Inc. was the first American advertiser on Soviet television.

headline: Gulf Nations to Meet
abstract: The seventh summit conference of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council has been scheduled for Nov. 2-4, officials said today. The group includes Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, Qatar, Oman and the United Arab Emirates.

headline: Mitterrand Interceding For a Cuban Dissident
abstract: One of Cuba's most prominent dissidents has sought refuge in the French Embassy here, and Western diplomats say President Francois Mitterrand is quietly trying to persuade Fidel Castro to allow him to leave the country.   The dissident, Ricardo Bofill, a 52-year-old former philosophy professor who since 1968 has spent almost 10 years in Cuban jails, entered the embassy on Wednesday and declared that he was not going to leave.   Mr. Bofill has been refused permission by Cuban authorities to emigrate and join his wife, Maria Elena Bofill, who lives in Miami.

headline: New Creative Director At McCann-Erickson
abstract: After a five-month search McCann-Erickson/New York has chosen John Nieman as its creative director responsible for 25 clients handled by the agency.   He was formerly the group creative director responsible for accounts such as General Mills and Anheuser-Busch beers at Needham Harper Worldwide in Chicago.

headline: South Korea Is Urged To Release 2 Prisoners
abstract: Three human rights organizations asked the South Korean Government yesterday to release two opposition political leaders whom the groups call ''prisoners of conscience'' whose rights to due process have been denied.   In separate statements, the organizations - Asia Watch, Amnesty International and the International Human Rights Law Group - said they were issuing the pleas in response to a ruling on July 3 by an appeals court, which refused to overturn a conviction of a student leader, Kim Keun Tae.

headline: ARCHBISHOP RITES HONOR TUTU TODAY
abstract: The outdoor communion service Sunday that will mark Desmond M. Tutu's enthronement as the first black person to become Anglican Archbishop of Cape Town is to end with the singing of ''Nkosi Sikelele Africa,'' or ''God Bless Africa.''   The song has become the anthem of many anti-apartheid groups. As such it will be a fitting hymn for a black churchman who has become a global symbol of the quickening black struggle in South Africa against the policies of race segregation enforced by the white minority.   Church leaders and anti-apartheid activists from across South Africa and the world have gathered here for the ceremony, and members of the Afrikaner-dominated Government have accused the Archbishop-designate of ''meddling in politics.'' Even liberal whites have expressed discomfort at his calls for an end to foreign investment in South Africa and his occasional apologies for violence by blacks seeking to end apartheid.

headline: GLUM NEWS FOR U.S. APPAREL
abstract: The annual gathering of the garment and textile industry, called the Bobbin Show, brought nearly 30,000 delegates to Atlanta this week, hoping dearly for the success of American-made apparel.   But on Thursday, the American Apparel Manufacturers Association, one of several industry trade groups, will throw some cold water on that by raising a warning that the industry cannot reverse the import trend and must change its emphasis to rely more on service than manufacturing.   Rather than wail against imports, it says, American manufacturers should view themselves as middlemen between overseas producers and domestic retailers. This view has been acted on privately by segments of the industry for months now, but this is the first time it has been raised quite so publicly and officially.

headline: Banking Assignment
abstract: The Marine Midland Bank, New York, has awarded the advertising and direct-response account for its newly established corporate, institutional and international banking sector to Grey and Grey Direct. Billings are about $2 million. Benton & Bowles has been handling the bank's retail advertising.

headline: A MONEY CHASE FOR NEW YORK
abstract: New York's claim to be the world's financial center took a knock yesterday.   Even though banks operating here are trading almost twice as much currency as they did three years ago, Tokyo's foreign exchange market is growing even faster. And, it turns out, the widespread belief that New York has been closing in on London, the leader in currency trading, is unfounded.   These broad conclusions have emerged from the first coordinated attempt by central bankers in the United States, Britain and Japan to measure the size and distribution of international currency trading in leading banking centers. Such dealing has grown explosively in recent years, and the banks' surveys suggest it is larger than previously believed.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.Monday None Tuesday Industrial ProductionJune Retail SalesJune Wednesday Inventory-Sales RatioMay Capacity UtilizationJune Thursday Housing StartsJune Friday None

headline: Mediation Set For RKO Case
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission has appointed a Government mediator to try to end a 21-year tug-of-war over radio station licenses worth hundreds of millions of dollars held by Gencorp Inc.'s RKO General subsidiary.   The F.C.C. has directed the mediator, James C. McKinney, who is head of the commission's mass-media bureau, to convene within 15 days a meeting of RKO and the 69 competing applicants for licenses now held by 13 RKO stations.

headline: The Big Profits In Gold Options
abstract: WHILE many investors in gold did well during the latest surge in prices, those who made the most money with the least risk were those who bought call options on bullion when the market turned higher early last month. Since then, the price of gold bullion has risen from $345 an ounce to $387 as of yesterday's close.   The reason is that options offer investors both high leverage and limited risk. Whether gold options are based on underlying futures contracts or the physical metal, they are simply the right, without any obligation, to either buy (call) or sell (put) a fixed quantity of bullion at a set price within a certain period of time.

headline: BROADCAST CONCERN HAS PROFIT
abstract: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. reported yesterday that it earned $67 million in the second quarter, compared with the $41.2 million that Capital Cities alone earned during the 1985 period.   It forecast a somber second half because of a weak advertising environment and higher programming costs, particularly at ABC.   Earnings per share increased 31.7 percent in the quarter to $4.15, from $3.15 a year ago. Revenues rose to $1.1 billion from $267.1 million. The company said that results for the latest quarter reflect Capital Cities' merger with American Broadcasting Companies Inc. last January.

headline: Owens-Corning Outlines Changes
abstract: The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation outlined its new operational structure yesterday, the result of a reorganization plan announced last month.

headline: Hanover Rating May Be Lowered
abstract: The debt rating on about $10 billion of outstanding securities issued by the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and the Manufacturers Hanover Overseas Capital Corporation is under review for possible downgrading, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.   The review will focus on the future effects of the recent erosion in loan quality, particularly the large rise during the second quarter in energy-related nonperforming loans, such as contract drilling, service and supply.

headline: PATENTS; Flowmeter Measures All Liquids and Gases
abstract: Thomas J. Scarpa, who operates the Edinboro Computer Instruments Corporation in Edinboro, Pa., received a patent this week for a flowmeter, which he describes as having no moving parts and is suitable for measuring all types of liquids and gases, including steam.  Patent 4,604,906 describes a meter with a rod carrying an airfoil that indicates the velocity of the fluid passing through. The company is manufacturing the meter and is applying for patents on several computer inventions.

headline: INTERNATIONAL AID REACHES CAMEROON
abstract: International relief has begun flowing into the mountainous region of this small West African nation where an estimated 1,500 people died in a cloud of poisonous volcanic gas last week.   A senior Western diplomat in the Cameroon capital of Yaounde said today that once all the promised aid reached the four afflicted villages it should be sufficient to meet the immediate needs of the 1,000 to 2,000 people made homeless.   The few hundred injured when the gas descended on their villages, crops, livestock and water supplies last Thursday already appear to be well taken care of in Cameroon hospitals.   Cameroon's President, Paul Biya, today announced the formation of a national disaster committee to match up the various international offers of material and scientific aid with the needs of the survivors.

headline: AID TO ZIMBABWE SUSPENDED BY U.S.
abstract: The Reagan Administration has suspended disbursement of economic aid to Zimbabwe in response to sharp criticism leveled by a high Zimbabwean official at the United States Embassy's July 4 reception, State Department officials said today.   The criticism of the United States prompted former President Jimmy Carter and the senior American diplomat to walk out of their own embassy.   As a result of what the department described as ''the uncalled-for behavior'' by the Zimbabwean official, David Kariamazira, the Minister of Youth, Sport and Culture, the Administration decided not to turn over the remaining $13.5 million in economic aid for this fiscal year, pending an overall review of relations, officials said. Agreements on two aid projects that were to be signed today in Harare, the Zimbabwean capital, were postponed, officials said.

headline: An $85 Million Offering By County in Arizona
abstract: Maricopa County, Ariz., one of the few local governments scheduled to sell bonds this week, sold $85 million of tax-exempt general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.   The bonds, which are rated Aa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, were offered with yields ranging from 4.25 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 5.15 percent in 1990 and 6.50 percent in 1998.

headline: TALKS RESUME TO STOP SPREAD OF CHEMICAL ARMS
abstract: The United States and the Soviet Union will resume talks next week on stopping the spread of chemical weapons, Administration officials said today.   The talks are to be held Sept. 4 and 5 in Bern. Officials said the talks were part of an effort to curb the use and production of chemical weapons specifically by countries in the third world. One objective, according to the officials, is to develop an understanding about what chemicals should be subject to export controls.

headline: Offer for Associated Is Increased by May
abstract: The May Department Stores Company said last night that it had increased its offer to acquire the Associated Dry Goods Corporation to $67.68 a share in stock from an earlier offer of $66 a share.   May said the offer had been made in a letter from David C. Farrell, its chairman, to Joseph H. Johnson, Associated's chairman. Telephone calls to Associated's headquarters seeking its response to the latest offer were not answered.

headline: SOVIET PLANNING NO MORE TALKS ON ISRAELI TIES
abstract: The Soviet Union said today that it planned no further talks with Israel after a 90-minute meeting in Helsinki on Monday.   The Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, said at a briefing that the talks had produced no agreement and ''there are no plans for a continuation of this meeting.''   The comment appeared to dash expectations that the Soviet Union was prepared to move toward improved relations with Israel, broken during the Arab-Israeli war of 1967. Israel Appears More Hopeful    An Israeli spokesman painted a more hopeful picture on Monday, describing the session as ''candid and correct'' and saying that the two sides had agreed to continue contacts, probably through their interests sections in the Dutch Embassy here and the Finnish Embassy in Tel Aviv.  [ In Israel, Prime Minister Shimon Peres expressed puzzlement at Mr. Gerasimov's comment and said it was not certain that contacts would now cease. ''It is hard to interpret the Soviet nuances,'' he said. ]  Mr. Gerasimov's statement came as the Soviet authorities were reported to have issued exit visas to the family of Anatoly Shcharansky, the freed activist who now lives in Israel.  [ Page A6. ]  Arab Reaction May Be Factor On the Israeli talks, Western diplomats speculated that the Soviet Union had been thrown on the defensive because of criticism by Arab leaders and might have concluded that any potential gains would be offset by the hostile reaction in the Middle East.

headline: Della Femina Sold
abstract: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, a medium-size advertising agency that has often made a big splash with its ad campaigns, has agreed to be taken over by Wight Collins Rutherford Scott P.L.C., a major London-based advertising concern. Jerry Della Femina, chairman, did not disclose the price, but said the agency had turned down two slightly higher offers.   He said that rather than concentrating on size, the British group was concerned with creating a network of creative agencies, which was the factor that led his agency to accept the offer.

headline: Burroughs Account Is Landed by Y.&R.
abstract: The Burroughs Corporation yesterday awarded its account to Young & Rubicam. Billings were estimated at $50 million, giving Y.&R. another big win in what has been the agency's hottest year ever for new business. Y.&R. has added $535 million in billings worldwide since the beginning of 1986.

headline: Overnite's Chairman, 73, Staying On Despite Sale
abstract: Harwood Cochrane recalls that he started the Overnite Transportation Company in 1935 with two trucks -''one big one and one little one.''   Overnite is now the nation's fifth-largest trucking company and the Union Pacific Corporation announced plans last week to buy it for $1.2 billion in cash.   ''I'm delighted we sold it as well as we did and to whom we did,'' said Mr. Cochrane, who is Overnite's chairman and who will be 74 years old in November. ''I can't be here forever and I feel this is a real good answer to the problem of trying to carry on the company philosophy and tradition.''

headline: ALEXANDRIA: FABLED CITY
abstract: Alexandria, the site of the Israeli-Egyptian summit conference beginning today, is the chief port and second largest city in Egypt.   First called Racondah by the Pharoahs, then Rhacotis by the Greeks, it acquired its present name in 332 B.C., when reconstruction began under Alexander the Great.

headline: U.S. SEIZES 13 IN LOUISIANA IN PLOT TO INVADE SURINAME
abstract: Federal agents arrested 13 men in Louisiana today on charges that they were preparing to overthrow the leftist Government of Suriname, a small country on the eastern coast of South America.   All 13 were charged with violations of the Neutrality Act, which bars Americans from involvement in attempts to overthrow other governments.   Law enforcement officials said the effort was led by a former customs agent, Tommy Denley, of Grenada, Miss. Prosecutors released little information about Mr. Denley, but said he had recruited the other men with a promise of $1 million each if they succeeded in overthrowing the Surinamese Government.

headline: BANKS' NON-LOAN PROFITS EBB
abstract: Earlier this year, the nation's big banks reported booming profits from foreign-exchange commissions, securities trading and surging values of bond portfolios. But such huge windfalls in areas outside of lending were unlikely to go on forever, and they did not. As a result, many banks have reported flat or reduced earnings for the second quarter.   Some banks, notably J. P. Morgan & Company's Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the Bankers Trust Company, did continue to post healthy gains in earnings from investment banking. Analysts said they were impressed by the continued ability of such organizations to maintain and even increase earnings in a difficult banking environment.

headline: U.S.-SOVIET REGIONAL TALKS OPEN
abstract: The United States and the Soviet Union opened high-level talks today on crisis areas around the world where the two nations often have competing interests.   The delegations discussing these regional issues are headed by Michael H. Armacost, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, and Anatoly L. Adamishin, a Deputy Foreign Minister. State Department officials said the talks were expected to end Thursday.

headline: Scientific American
abstract: Robert Maxwell, chairman of Pergamon Press Ltd., said yesterday in London that he had abandoned his attempt to acquire Scientific American Inc., publisher of the scholarly monthly magazine. Scientific American rejected Pergamon's $61 million offer on Monday and reaffirmed its intent to accept a $52.6 million offer from a West German publishing concern, Verlagsgruppe Georg von Holtzbrinck of Stuttgart. Mr. Maxwell said his bid was opposed because he planned to oust management, while the West German company planned to retain management.

headline: Jersey Housing Bonds
abstract: The New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency is offering $140 million of mortgage revenue bonds throught underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.   The interest rate on bonds is set at 4 5/8 percent through Oct. 1, 1987, when the issue will be redeemed at par.

headline: MCA Inc. Seeking A Stake in Mets
abstract: Preliminary negotiations for the sale of a part interest in the New York Mets to MCA Inc., the giant entertainment company, are under way.

headline: Trump Stake In Holiday
abstract: The Holiday Corporation, operator of the Holiday Inn chain, said that Donald Trump, the New York real estate developer, had acquired between 2 percent and 5 percent of the company's stock.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JULY 14, 1986
abstract: The Economy    The impact of foreign economies on the nation's growth rate has been underestimated, economists say. About half the strength expected of the economy this year has been drained away because American consumers and businesses keep buying foreign, rather than American, goods.  [ Page D1. ]

headline: AQUINO REBUKES U.N., SAYING IT FAILED THE FILIPINOS
abstract: President Corazon C. Aquino, delivering her first speech at the United Nations on the same podium where Imelda Marcos stood a year ago, criticized the organization today for not supporting the Filipino struggle to oust Ferdinand E. Marcos.   ''We took power to implement so many of the ideals that the U.N. stands for,'' she told the 41st session of the General Assembly on its opening day of debate. ''We have restored human rights and liberated our people from the oppression and corruption of a government that had long since lost their support.   ''Yet like so many other leaders before me, I am obliged to say we did this by ourselves.

headline: Times Net Up 17.6%
abstract: The New York Times Company yesterday reported record second-quarter earnings of $36.8 million, or 91 cents a share, up 17.6 percent from $31.3 million, or 78 cents a share, in the 1985 quarter.   If not for an interest charge of $8.5 million, or 10 cents a share, profits would have climbed 31 percent, the company said.

headline: Covering The News On Cancer
abstract: THE name of the magazine is Cope and it is subtitled Living With Cancer.   Judging from the alarming estimates being released by the Government of the number of future victims of the disease, it is very much a magazine for today. It is a monthly news magazine for patients as well as for their families, the professional health care people who treat them, and the voluntary support organizations which help both.

headline: EX-INMATES COMPLAIN OF MANAGUA JAIL
abstract: Beneath a hill in the center of Managua there is an underground jail where, according to former inmates, political prisoners are often held for days or weeks under harsh and disorienting conditions.   The question of conditions at the jail was raised when Nicaraguan officials said a former official committed suicide in his cell there in June. Relatives of the man, Eduardo Trejos Silva, a former Interior Ministry offical who had been convicted of spying for the Central Intelligence Agency, have said privately that they do not believe he killed himself.   No non-Sandinista journalist or human-rights organization has been granted access to the jail, which is called El Chipote, since the Sandinista Government came to power in 1979. Senior security officials did not respond to requests for interviews to discuss conditions there.

headline: FRANCE TO REQUIRE VISAS FOR VISITORS TO COMBAT TERROR
abstract: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, speaking minutes after a fatal bomb explosion in Paris, announced measures tonight to combat a wave of terrorism, including a requirement that Americans and most other foreign visitors obtain visas.   Only citizens of the 11 other countries of the European Community and Switzerland will be exempt from the visa requirement, which Mr. Chirac said would take effect Monday. The move is part of a French effort to monitor better the movements of potential terrorists from abroad.

headline: HELP FOR CYPRUS: A FOREIGN-AID ODDITY
abstract: At the order of Congress, reluctant American foreign-aid administrators have for many years been allotting at least $15 million in annual economic assistance to Cyprus, whose standard of living is on a par with that of southern Europe.   The practice has withstood the reorientation of American help to favor ''the poorest of the poor'' in underdeveloped countries in meeting pressing needs such as food, medical care, clothing and housing.   American aid to Cyprus began in 1974, when the Turkish invasion caused large-scale destruction, the uprooting of one-third of the population of about 600,000 and extensive humanitarian needs. The program continues despite the strong economic recovery in the area controlled by the central Government, where the majority of the population who are Greek Cypriots live.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA SAID TO DETAIN 200
abstract: South African security forces detained more than 200 men and boys yesterday and evicted scores of women and children in a morning raid on two schools in a Cape Town suburb where people left homeless by recent violence had sought shelter, according to reports reaching the United States.   Monitoring groups also reported the continuing arrest of anti-apartheid activists and church workers and said whole townships had been sealed off last week by the security forces, which conducted house-to-house searches.

headline: ALLIED'S SURPRISE CHOICE, MACIOCE HAS PAID OFF
abstract: When Thomas M. Macioce was elected to head the Allied Stores Corporation in 1972, the move was generally regarded with skepticism by people within the retail industry. Mr. Macioce, who had little experience in merchandising and marketing, was one of the first chief executives of a major retail chain to have primarily a financial background. Apparently, the move paid off. ''He has steadily improved return on equity and profit margins,'' said Edmund F. Johnson, the director of Johnson Redbook Service in New York, a division of Prescott, Ball & Turben. ''People condemned him for not having a merchandising background, but he's plugged and has grown his sales nicely. He has been highly successful.''

headline: ENERGY COSTS ARE CITED
abstract: Consumer prices increased five-tenths of 1 percent in June, the steepest rise in seven months, chiefly because of a since-ended spurt in the price of gasoline, electricity and natural gas, the Labor Department reported today.   Despite the sharp rise, the Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers finished the first half of the year down two-tenths of 1 percent, the first such decline in 31 years.   But prices in the New York and northeastern New Jersey area rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in June. In the year ended June 1986, prices rose 3.1 percent locally.  [ Page D4. ]  Second Consecutive Increase Last month's rise in consumer prices marked the second consecutive monthly increase, following declines in each of the preceding three months when oil prices were tumbling. Today's report, however, did not raise concerns among economists of a resurgence of inflationary pressures in the economy.

headline: NAKASONE'S PARTY APPEARS TO REGAIN A CLEAR MAJORITY
abstract: Japan's long-ruling Liberal Democratic Party registered stunning gains today in parliamentary elections, capturing the powerful House of Representatives in a landslide victory of historic dimensions.   Returns from most districts in the voting held on Sunday showed the Liberal Democrats likely to win 300 seats in the 512-member house, a total that had been considered almost unimaginable for many years.   The last time that the Liberal Democrats, a conservative party, achieved results of such proportions was in 1960, five years after it began its unbroken three decades of rule. In that election, it captured 296 seats in a 467-member chamber.

headline: PUSH ON HIRING BIAS IN ULSTER
abstract: Encouraged by the success of the campaign to get American investors to pull out of South Africa, a coalition of Irish human rights advocates and politicians is mounting a drive to prod American companies doing business in Northern Ireland to combat discrimination against Roman Catholic workers.   The Northern Ireland campaign would place American investors and companies, once again, at the forefront of a sensitive social issue.   The effort is based on the ''MacBride Principles,'' a nine-point set of guidelines for fair employment in the predominantly Protestant British province, also known as Ulster. Drafted by four Irish activists led by Sean MacBride, a Nobel Peace Prize winner, the guidelines are patterned after the Sullivan Principles, which were presented in 1977 as an alternative to divestment in South Africa for companies doing business there. Heavily Invested    The year-old MacBride campaign is trying to convince American states and municipalities, whose pension funds are invested heavily in American companies that do business in Northern Ireland, to support the principles. In addition, the MacBride advocates are marshaling support for shareholder initiatives that criticize the employment practices of selected American companies in Northern Ireland and urge them to support the principles.

headline: ECONOMIC SCENE; U.S.-Japanese Corporate Ties
abstract: FED by a high savings rate, a huge surplus in balance of trade and strong corporate profits (until just recently), Japan has built up a huge capital base with which it could invest in foreign companies or build plants abroad. But because protectionist spirit has been rising in the United States Congress, many Japanese companies are choosing instead to form international alliances that link the biggest and strongest companies in both countries.  Such corporate affiliations - joint ventures, marketing arrangements and other cooperative efforts - are not new. American companies signed a flood of them in the 1950's and 60's. But then the participants typically were a big United States company and a small Japanese company.

headline: TIMES REPORTER BEING HELD IN PEKING
abstract: John F. Burns, chief of the Peking bureau of The New York Times, was taken into custody yesterday by Chinese security officials as he and his family were about to leave China for a three-week vacation in Hong Kong.   He was taken to a detention center in the capital.   Officials from the Peking Public Security Bureau told diplomats that Mr. Burns had been detained in connection with a recent trip that he made through the Chinese countryside.   Mr. Burns, 41 years old, was not formally charged, but Peking officials told an official from the United States Embassy that he was being investigated on suspicion of ''entering an area forbidden to foreigners, gathering intelligence information and espionage.''

headline: AMOTHER HOSTAGE SEEN IN VIDEOTAPE
abstract: David P. Jacobsen, one of the remaining American hostages in Lebanon, has said in a videotape made by his kidnappers that he felt ''like one of Custer's men,'' and added: ''You know the end of their stories. Pray that ours will have a happier ending.''   The seven-minute tape was carried by the Rev. Lawrence M. Jenco of Joliet, Ill., when he was released Saturday in Lebanon by a group that had held him captive for 19 months.

headline: PORTRAIT OF AN AGING RECOVERY
abstract: FORECASTING the economy's ups and downs is as uncertain as predicting the weather. Right now the economic outlook is decidedly cloudy, despite some bright spots. Interest rates have fallen by more than half since the early 1980's. And inflation, aided by declining oil prices, has been checked decisively.

headline: Advertising; Welch/Currier Buying Boston's Blouin & Co.
abstract: Up Boston way, Welch/Currier, founded in 1980, has begun acquiring the equity in the five-year-old Blouin & Company, from its founder-owner, Richard R. Blouin.   Each company is billing about $10 million, and Blouin is being merged into Welch/Currier, whose officers will remain. William G. Anderson, a senior vice president at Blouin, gets to be an executive vice president at his new digs.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: Assets of the nation's 362 money market mutual funds rose $1.73 billion, to $225.30 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, marking the first week all three categories have increased since May 21, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

headline: Bolivian Labor Group Plans Big Strike Today
abstract: Bolivia's labor federation says it will begin a two-day general strike to press several demands, including the immediate departure of 170 United States servicemen who are taking part in an anti-cocaine drive.   The Bolivian Labor Confederation, which includes all unionized workers, said its stoppage would begin Thursday despite Government warnings that the strike could be declared illegal.   The labor group said it was also undertaking the stoppage to back striking state-employed miners who are protesting Government plans to close several unprofitable tin mines, a measure that would put about 9,000 miners out of work.

headline: OIL PRICES EXTEND RISE, BUT OUTLOOK SEEMS DIM
abstract: Prices for crude oil and petroleum products continued their upward trek yesterday from the lows they reached Monday, even as conditions afflicting the oil market seemed to worsen.   The price of West Texas Intermediate crude oil, the major American grade, rose to the middle $12-a-barrel range on the open and futures markets, its highest level in two weeks. And Brent North Sea crude, the British blend that serves as a key international marker, traded at $10 a barrel for the first time in 10 days.

headline: Bid to Lucky Stores Challenge for Chief
abstract: John M. Lillie has been chief executive of Lucky Stores Inc. for only a little more than a year, but he is already contending with what may prove the major challenge of his tenure.   Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, has accumulated stock in the California company, which operates retail and food stores and had sales last year of $9.4 billion. Mr. Edelman has offered to buy the company for $1.79 billion. Lucky's directors will discuss the offer at a board meeting on Thursday.

headline: Thatcher Said To Back Oslo
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain wound up her official two-day visit to Norway today by tacitly approving Norway's preliminary 10 percent oil export cut for November and October, her host and colleague, Gro Harlem Brundtland, told reporters.   ''Our decision to cut export of crude by 10 percent for two months was unilateral,'' the Labor Party Prime Minister said.

headline: G.M. to Shut 3 More Plants
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would temporarily close three more plants for model changeovers beginning July 28, affecting 12,900 hourly workers.

headline: Fiat Silent on Bid
abstract: Officials of Fiat S.p.A. remained silent about details of a new takeover bid for Alfa-Romeo, which is also being sought by the Ford Motor Company. A spokesman for Italy's largest auto maker and private employer also refused to give details about talks between the Prime Minister Bettino Craxi and Fiat's chairman, Giovanni Agnelli, held in Rome on Wednesday night. Mr. Agnelli reportedly sought support from the Government for taking over the state-controlled auto maker, for which Ford has made an offer for a 20 percent stake.

headline: British Paper In Change
abstract: Eddie Shah, who led the revolution of Britain's newspaper industry with the first high-technology color national daily, has relinquished control of his troubled tabloid to its financial rescuers, sources at his newspaper said today.   The sources, who asked not to be identified, said Mr. Shah returned from vacation on Thursday to sell his controlling interest in Today to Roland (Tiny) Rowland, head of the Lonrho Group, which owns The Observer, a prestigious Sunday newspaper.

headline: Bozell, Jacobs Raises Its Stake in Multicom
abstract: At a gala cocktail party, Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt last week entertained not only some local friends but also executives from its international operation who are in town for briefings, seminars and schmooze.   It was therefore a good time to announce the agency's most recent foreign entanglements, which include an ''exclusive arrangement'' with Diamond Ads, a subsidiary of the giant Hyundai of Korea, and similar non-equity arrangements in the Netherlands, Argentina, Brazil and Venezuela.   Also, in Britain, where B.J.K.& E. had a 25 percent position in Butler Dennis Garland, it has increased its holdings to 35 percent of that agency's parent company, Multicom, no kin of Omni.

headline: Tax Bill Alters View on Gains
abstract: THE proposal to change the nation's tax laws not only would have a profound effect on the way investors buy and sell stocks, but might also dictate the kinds of companies in which they are willing to put their money, according to experts on the taxation system and the securities industry.   At the crux of the matter is the elimination of preferential treatment for long-term capital gains. Under current law, investors pay a top rate of 20 percent on the appreciation of stock if the shares are sold after being held at least six months. The gains on stock held for less time are treated as ordinary income, taxable at up to 50 percent.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
Shanghai Stock Market?
abstract: Shanghai is studying the possibility of opening a stock market for the growing number of enterprises raising funds by offering shares, the official New China News Agency said today. Since last year, 749 factories in Shanghai have issued stock, the report said.

headline: Citicorp Issue
abstract: Citicorp yesterday began offering $250 million of 10-year subordinated notes through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes, which carry a 8 1/4 percent coupon, are offered at par. Noncallable for five years, they are rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA- by S.& P.

headline: CAMPEAU RAISES BID FOR ALLIED
abstract: The Campeau Corporation yesterday raised its offer to acquire the Allied Stores Corporation by $8 a share, to $66. The amended bid, which is in cash and preferred stock, increases the proposed purchase price to $2.68 billion, from $2.47 billion.   The Canadian company previously offered $58 a share, all in cash, for 40.7 million shares of Allied common.

headline: THE PEOPLE, JOYOUS AND JOSTLING, TAKE HISTORY AND TRADITION IN THEIR STRIDE
abstract: Out among the crowds, the commoners were hardly commanded to watch, and their fascination with the royal wedding parade seemed as basic as Chaucer: the chance to witness love professed and life moving forward as a continuing tale.   Edie Skipworth was writing home as she sat on a stool in a happy mob on the parade route an hour before the marriage vows.   ''The girls are perched on the window directly opposite the gate of the Horse Guards where the huge military bands are now parading,'' she wrote of her young daughters, safely beaming on a window sill above her head as the crowd laughed and craned, pushed and waited.   ''It is really spectacular,'' she wrote, ''Fergie is no doubt having trouble with her makeup and Andrew has ducked down to the bar for a final stiff drink.''

headline: Longtime J.W.T. Man Retiring in October
abstract: J. Walter Thompson announced the news that Burton B. Petersen, 58-year-old chairman of Thompson Recruitment Advertising, will be handd ing in his retirement papers on Oct. 19, after exactly 27 years with the agency.

headline: 52 Are Reported Killed In Honduran Air Crash
abstract: The wreckage of a Honduran military transport plane that was carrying 52 people was found today in eastern Honduras, officials said. The military said there were no survivors.

headline: JWT Net Is Flat
abstract: The JWT Group, parent of J. Walter Thompson, said yesterday that its revenues in the second quarter were up 13.5 percent, to $160.6 million, from $141.5 million a year ago. Net income was $5.8 million, the same as last year's, and earnings per share were also the same, at 62 cents.

headline: UNFAMILIAR REALM FOR QUEEN: DID SHE INTRUDE INTO POLITICS?
abstract: ''God Save the Queen From Damaging the Crown.''   Implicit in that headline on the editorial in The Sunday Telegraph today was an assumption that there was a real basis to reports that Queen Elizabeth II was worried that the Commonwealth group of nations, of which she is the nominal head, might founder as a result of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's opposition to sanctions against South Africa.   The Queen, the editorial warned, was ''being sucked in'' to take a political stand on issues of race and foreign policy on which the British are deeply divided.   ''Worse,'' it went on, ''she is almost forcing herself in, apparently quite unaware that these are matters which the monarchy can only meddle with at the institution's gravest peril.''

headline: MARKET FALLS A BIT IN UNEVENTFUL DAY
abstract: The anticipation was worse than the event yesterday on Wall Street as stock prices declined, but not by a large amount, during the feared ''triple witching hour.''   When it was all over, a lot of stock had traded in the final minutes of the session, but blue-chip prices moved only a bit lower and secondary issues did not move much at all. This was quite unlike previous ''witching hours,'' when volume has soared and prices either surged or sank depending on the price relationship between regular stock indexes and stock index futures.   ''If you expected something dramatic, you didn't get it,'' said Jack Baker, head equities trader at Shearson Lehman Brothers, who conceded that tension was high throughout the session. ''You could hear a pin drop here at 4 o'clock. But nothing happened.''

headline: Oil and Baseball Don't Always Mix
abstract: Harrell Edmonds Chiles, the 76-year-old chairman and chief executive officer of the Western Company of North America, has decided that baseball and oil no longer mix.   Mr. Chiles, head of the Fort Worth oilfield services company, announced earlier this month that he had sold his majority interest in the Texas Rangers baseball team to Edward L. Gaylord and the Gaylord Broadcasting Corporation.   Mr. Chiles cited the need to direct his full attention to debt-ridden Western, which he founded. According to The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, he was paid $50 million for his interest in the team.

headline: PANEL SETS ASIDE AQUINO JUDGEMENT
abstract: A special commission today set aside the results of a trial that acquitted the former military chief, Gen. Fabian C. Ver, and 25 others in the 1983 murder of President Corazon C. Aquino's husband, Benigno.   The three-member commission declared a mistrial in the case, saying it found sufficient evidence that former President Ferdinand E. Marcos had interfered in the proceedings. The finding makes it almost certain that the accused will have to face a new trial.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, AUGUST 29, 1986
abstract: The Economy    The index of leading indicators rose 1.1 percent in July, its second-best performance this year, the Commerce Department reported. The gain was undercut, however, by a sharp downward revision for June, turning what had been reported as a rise of 0.3 percent into a 0.4 percent drop. Taken together, analysts said, the data suggest that the economy is likely to continue to grow at a lackluster pace, not much faster than in the second quarter, when the G.N.P. expanded at an annual rate of less than 1 percent.  [ Page A1. ]    The Government widened its investigation of suspected leaks of economic data, after reports that the rise in leading indicators was known in the financial markets on Wednesday. A Commerce Department spokesman refused to comment on reports of another leak involving trade deficit figures due out this morning. The credit markets chewed furiously on rumors that the deficit figures for July would show a sharp increase and that purchasing figures due Tuesday would show weaker activity.  [ D1. ]

headline: Echo Bay to Buy Tenneco Unit
