abstract: Echo Bay Mines Ltd. said it had agreed in principle to acquire Tenneco Inc.'s gold mining properties for $130 million, with closing scheduled for November.

headline: Sanyo Plans Overseas Move
abstract: The Sanyo Electric Company, one of Japan's largest electronics manufacturers, said today that it plans to move 70 percent of its computer-chip production overseas by 1990.

headline: People
abstract: * Anne Mahoney has joined Aspach Grossman Portugal, the graphics and design firm, as a principal.    * Linda A. Stern has been named to head corporate communications for Group W (Westinghouse Broadcasting Company).

headline: Broward County
abstract: A $175 million issue of Broward County, Fla., public improvement refunding bonds was tentatively priced to yield a maximum 7 7/8 percent for bonds due in 2012 through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc. Bonds with shorter maturities are offered with yields ranging from 5.80 percent in 1989 to 6.30 percent in 1991, 7.10 percent in 1996 and 7.60 percent in 2001. Rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by Standard & Poor's, the bonds are backed by the full faith and credit of the county.

headline: TERROR SUSPECT TO STAND TRIAL IN PARIS
abstract: The French Minister of Justice said today that a terrorist suspect whose release from prison was being demanded by a group responsible for recent bombings here would probably stand trial within months.   The Minister, Albin Chalandon, speaking in Dijon, said he had ordered prosecutors to demand that the suspect, Georges Ibrahim Abdallah, stand trial in Paris on charges related to the slayings of two diplomats, an Israeli and an American, here in 1982.   The release of Mr. Abdallah, a Lebanese Christian who the French police say heads the Lebanese Armed Revolutionary Faction, has been the main demand of the group that asserted responsibility for several bomb attacks in Paris from Sept. 8 to 17. Nine people died and more than 160 were wounded in the bombings.

headline: Cutting Costs Of Settling Your Estate
abstract: PLANNING your estate is much easier now than it once was, since only estates worth more than $500,000 are subject to Federal taxes. But do not be beguiled into thinking that estate planning can be avoided altogether. To be sure your heirs get what you want them to have with minimum expense and aggravation, a will is necessary. If you die without one, the state government will step in to provide for the administration of your estate - and your assets will probably not pass according to your wishes.   In addition, the Federal Government and your home state may be major beneficiaries; costly court fees, high administrative costs and avoidable taxes can quickly erode the assets your family might have gotten.

headline: The U.N. Today: July 29, 1986
abstract: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on Nicaragua at 10:30 A.M.

headline: SOUTH'S STELLAR BANK GAMBLES ON GROWTH
abstract: EVEN on weekday mornings, only a handful of people mill about the main street here, waiting for buses or idling by the granite statue of a soldier that honors the Confederate war dead. An old man walking down the street volunteers a cheery hello to a perfect stranger.   But improbable as it seems, this town is a financial center, the home of the 107-year-old Wachovia Bank and Trust Company, one of the best managed and most profitable banks in the United States. For decades, Wachovia has been to Southern banking what Morgan Guaranty has been to the establishment of the North: the most venerable and consistently profitable institution.   By almost every key measure of performance, Wachovia is outshining America's money-center banks - the giants based in New York, Chicago and California. And now Wachovia, which has prospered through a cautious, steady-as-it-goes approach to banking, is reaching for new turf. Last December it merged with the First Atlanta Corporation, one of Georgia's largest banking companies - a move that created the First Wachovia Corporation, one of the 30 largest banks in the United States, with more than $17 billion in assets.

headline: Ideal's Restructuring
abstract: Ideal Basic Industries Inc. of Denver said yesterday it had reached agreement with its preferred stockholder, the Anschutz Corporation, under which all of Anschutz's shares would be converted into common stock and Anschutz would receive 30.6 million new Ideal common shares, about 17.3 percent of the company's outstanding shares after a financial restructuring is completed.

headline: Iowa Agency Branching Out
abstract: Young & Rubicam's regional agency, Creswell, Munsell, Fultz & Zerbel of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, is making the unusual move of opening offices of its public relations division in New York and San Diego.   And it is opening here despite the fact that Burson Marsteller, a sister company under the Y.& R. umbrella, is the largest public relations firm in the world.

headline: Thousands of Poles Greet 2 Freed Activists
abstract: Thousands of Solidarity supporters gave an emotional welcome today to two leading opposition figures recently released from prison.   The two men, Adam Michnik and Bogdan Lis, spoke to a cheering crowd after appearing with Lech Walesa, the leader of the banned labor movement Solidarity, at a mass attended by more than 7,000 people.

headline: YIELDS FALL AT BANKS
abstract: The ripple effect of last week's cut in the discount rate has produced lower yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds for the week ended yesterday.   If the pattern of the previous three discount-rate cuts holds true, yields on C.D.'s will drop a third of a percentage point, and money market accounts a fourth of a percentage point.   According to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index, the average yield for six-month C.D.'s fell to 6.17 percent, from 6.32 percent, while the average yield of bank money market accounts, which compete directly with money market mutual funds, declined 8 basis points, to 5.81 percent from 5.89 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

headline: Costa Rica Cuts Pretoria Tie
abstract: Costa Rica has decided to sever all diplomatic ties with South Africa immediately to protest apartheid, President Oscar Arias Sanchez announced today. An official statement referred to ''the indifference of the Government of Prime Minister P. W. Botha in satisfying the expectations of the international community.'' Among other restrictions, the move will bar South Africans from taking part in international sports events here.

headline: China Seeking GATT Membership
abstract: China has applied for membership in GATT, the world's dominant free-trade group and will join in the major trade negotiations due to begin later this year, David Woods, a GATT spokesman said today.   China's membership would make it the biggest communist country in GATT, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which was formed in 1948 to integrate the world's free-market economies.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Oklahoma Gas and Electric Co. is offering $100 million of Aa-2/AA rated 8 1/4 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2016 at 93.50 to yield 8.87 percent, through Kidder, Peabody. The bonds are nonrefundable for five years.    * Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. is offering $200 million of A-2/AA- rated 7 7/8 percent noncallable notes due 1993 at 100.

headline: CABINET PACT GIVES LEBANON A RESPITE
abstract: An effort at reconciliation between Moslem and Christian officials appears for the moment to have rescued the Government of President Amin Gemayel from near collapse, officials and commentors here believe.   They said the effort had also given this strife-torn country a badly needed respite.   A meeting here Tuesday of the half-Moslem, half-Christian Cabinet - its first this year - in effect stopped a Syrian-backed campaign by Moslem leaders for Mr. Gemayel's resignation. The President is a Maronite Catholic who has completed four of six years of his term.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
MOSCOW OUTLINES COLLEGE OVERHAUL
abstract: The Soviet leadership has indicted the nation's system of higher education and announced a sweeping program to make it more responsive to the needs of a modern industrial economy.   The new higher education program, presented in the form of a draft decree of the ruling Communist Party, follows an overhaul last year of the system of elementary and high schools. The new plan is an attempt by the administration of Mikhail S. Gorbachev to bring universities and colleges into line with his plans for modernization and to make them a driving force for scientific and technical advances.   The aim of the program appears to be to end the traditional use of Soviet higher education as a training ground for narrow vocational and professional specialization. Instead, colleges will be expected to foster a broader-based education that would enable graduates to adapt themselves more readily to new technology and changing conditions.

headline: Son Leaving the Firm Of Rogers & Cowan
abstract: A father-son split has developed at Rogers & Cowan, a public relations firm in Los Angeles, over ''philosophical differences.''

headline: 4 GUNMEN KILL EX-COMMANDER OF INDIAN ARMY
abstract: A retired army Chief of Staff who was India's most decorated soldier was shot and killed in his car today in the western city of Pune, a few days after receiving a death threat from Sikh militants.   Four young assailants escaped on two motor scooters after the shooting of the general, Arun S. Vaidya, the Pune police said. The general's wife, who was sitting next to him, was wounded in the thigh and shoulder.   The killing of General Vaidya, who was 60 years old, stunned and dismayed Indian leaders, and threatened to aggravate tensions once again between Hindus and Sikhs throughout the country.

headline: 100 Are Feared Dead In Nigeria Ship Collision
abstract: Two passenger ships have collided in the South Atlantic off the coast of Nigeria, and about 100 people are feared killed, a Government statement said today.

headline: LEBANESE MILITIAS ARE BEING BUILT UP
abstract: Lebanese Christian and Moslem factions have begun transforming their militias into army-style units with tanks and other heavy military hardware.   The development is widely viewed here as a sign that a long struggle still lies ahead for control of this country, already divided by more than a decade of civil war.   Lebanon's three dominant militias - the Lebanese Forces, a Christian group; the Shiite movement Amal, and the Progressive Socialist Party, a Druse group - have completed plans for creating their own armies separate from the Government force.   A week ago Nabih Berri, the Minister of Justice, who heads Amal, took the salute at a military parade in Beirut's mainly Shiite southern suburbs as 800 men in khaki uniforms and leather caps marched to martial music played by a military band. Several Soviet-built T-54 tanks and many armored personnel carriers were also on display.

headline: Putting a Tag On Microbes
abstract: AMONG the most important questions worrying the public and Federal regulators about using genetically engineered microbial pesticides in the field is this one: If the bugs survive, where will they go?   Now, ways to answer the question are coming from several laboratories where scientists are discovering fast and accurate methods for spotting gene-altered microbes in the environment.   One system under development at the Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research at Cornell University tags gene-altered microbes with a natural protein that glows in the dark. Scientists at the Monsanto Company in St. Louis are working on a method that turns genetically engineered bugs a vivid blue.

headline: Debt Issue Tied to S.&P. 500
abstract: The first issue in the American market of debt securities whose value is linked to the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was offered yesterday by Salomon Brothers, on behalf of its parent, Salomon Inc.   The $100 million of four-year notes, called ''Spins'' for Standard & Poor's 500 Index Subordinated Notes, bears an interest rate of 2 percent and offers investors the prospect of an additional return depending on the performance of the stock market.

headline: U.S.'S 'FIX-IT' ANTITRUST POLICY
abstract: ON Aug. 26, the Federal Government rejected the proposed $675 million acquisition of Eastern Air Lines by the Texas Air Corporation, asserting that it would significantly reduce competition in the Northeast shuttle markets. But in rejecting a deal that would have created the nation's biggest airline, the Department of Transportation clearly signaled to the two carriers that there was a way to ''fix'' the merger to make it acceptable to the Reagan Administration.   Last Friday, two and a half weeks later, Texas Air announced that it had agreed to sell additional landing and takeoff slots at La Guardia Airport in New York to Pan American World Airways, a move that would reportedly enable Pan Am to operate a fully competitive shuttle service with Eastern's and should meet the Government's objections. Approval by the Transportation Department was expected, although it was not immediately clear if yesterday's offer by Texas Air to acquire People Express would complicate the Eastern deal.

headline: REAGAN PROMISES TO ROOT OUT SPIES, RESIST RETALIATION
abstract: President Reagan promised today that his Administration would root out and severely punish spies and would not tolerate arrests of innocent Americans ''in retaliation for protecting ourselves from espionage.''   Speaking at the headquarters of the National Security Agency, the code-breaking and electronic intelligence organization, Mr. Reagan did not specifically mention the case of Nicholas S. Daniloff, the American journalist who faces espionage charges in Moscow and has become the subject of intensive negotiations to remove a major obstacle to a summit meeting.   But his remarks were clearly intended to send a tough message about the Daniloff case and to reinforce the Administration's decision to order the expulsion of 25 Soviet officials in the United Nations mission who Washington says are intelligence officers. Briefed on Shultz Meetings   Mr. Reagan spoke after being briefed by Secretary of State George P. Shultz on his three meetings in New York with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union. Those meetings so far have failed to produce a resolution of the issue. It was unclear whether the two sides were at an impasse or whether an accord was likely soon.

headline: HANGINGS PROMPT BITTER REACTIONS
abstract: Early this morning, a prison truck took away the bodies of two young Australians who local newspapers are calling ''the first non-Asian drug pushers'' to be executed under this country's harsh narcotics laws. They had been hanged side by side at dawn, a prison official said.   Kevin Barlow, 28 years old, was cremated a few hours later in the presence of a grieving family. The body of Brian Chambers, 29, was being prepared tonight for repatriation to Australia in the company of his relatives and dozens of Australian television and newspaper journalists.

headline: Textron Will Split Bell Aerospace
abstract: Textron Inc. said it would divide its Bell Aerospace unit, its most lucrative division, into two units. B.F. Dolan, president and chief executive of Textron, said the move was an effort to ''stimulate growth within each of the divisions.''   One division, which will retain the Bell Aerospace name, will be based in Buffalo and will be responsible for military electronic equipment and engine systems.

headline: CAR SALES WERE UP 7.4% IN EARLY AUGUST
abstract: Sales of new American-made cars rose 7.4 percent in the Aug. 1-10 period, on a daily sales basis, from early August of last year, the leading manufacturers reported today. Light-truck sales were even stronger, climbing 18.4 percent from last year's period.   Including cars and light trucks, total vehicle sales were 224,874, or 28,109 daily, this year, up 10.7 percent from the total of 228,435, or 25,382 a day, in 1985. There were eight selling days in the period this year, compared with nine in 1985. Sales last year were held down by a strike by the teamsters' union workers who deliver vehicles to dealerships.

headline: Gasoline Prices Down
abstract: Gasoline prices fell slightly in the last two weeks, reversing an August increase and reflecting the end of the summer driving season, Trilby Lundberg, publisher of the Lundberg Letter, said today.

headline: Zambia Issues Threat To British on Sanctions
abstract: President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia said today that he would withdraw his country from the Commonwealth if the British Government did not agree to economic sanctions against South Africa at a meeting of seven Commonwealth members in London on Aug. 2.   ''It would be very sad to see the breakup of such an important international body and I am not happy about it,'' Mr. Kaunda said.

headline: LITTLE EFFECT IS SEEN ON BORROWING
abstract: For American consumers, who have traditionally viewed credit cards as the key to a better way of life, the new tax bill's elimination of the interest deductibility on such borrowings is expected to have little impact. Economists say studies have consistently shown that consumers are remarkably insensitive to the interest rate and tax consequences on borrowings for such items as applicances, autos and general merchandise.   ''There is no good evidence that people use credit cards more or less depending on interest rates,'' said John B. Hagens, a vice president at Chase Econometrics Inc. in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ''They seem to spend regardless of the rates charged.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, AUGUST 22, 1986
abstract: The Economy    Low-income families would have an easier tax burden, and six million households would be dropped from the tax rolls under the proposed tax legislation. Most comments on these changes have been favorable, a consensus all the more striking amid the contention on other provisions.  [ Page A1. ]    Treatment of capital gains by the tax bill is proving confusing. Because there will be five tax brackets in 1987 before the plan's two basic brackets take effect in 1988, capital gains would be treated differently for 1986, 1987 and 1988.  [ D1. ]  Vacation homes bought more for their value as shelters than as tranquil escapes would be less-attractive investments under the proposed tax legislation.  [ D3. ]

headline: THE K.G.B.'S EVIDENCE IN DEVELOPING A CASE OF ESPIONAGE AGAINST DANILOFF
abstract: Following are excerpts from an article on Nicholas S. Daniloff in the Government newspaper Izvestia on Monday, as distributed in translation by Tass, the Soviet Government press agency:    On Sept. 7, an investigator of the State Security Committee of the U.S.S.R., together with a military prosecutor, brought an indictment against Nicholas Daniloff, a United States citizen, who was detained Aug. 30 while performing a secret espionage action.   The indictment states that sufficient evidence has been obtained in connection with the case of Nicholas Daniloff giving ground to assert that, being connected with the United States secret services, on assignment from them and using the status of foreign correspondent in the Soviet Union, he engaged in espionage, gathering secret data in various ways for use to the detriment of the national interests of the Soviet Union. Change in Daniloff's Status    On familiarizing himself with the indictment, Nicholas Daniloff reluctantly put his signature, and his status changed from that of suspect to that of defendant.   The day of Aug. 30 turned out to be a hectic one for Nicholas Daniloff. He had a lot to do before his forthcoming departure from Moscow at the end of a period of work in the U.S.S.R. But nothing was so urgent as to compare with the upcoming important meeting that he had been awaiting impatiently. The day before, an old acquaintance of his had telephoned Daniloff.

headline: Leader of Armstrong Is Widening Its Base
abstract: The Armstrong Rubber Company was founded 74 years ago in Garfield, N.J., and has been a survivor in the tire industry. Frank R. O'Keefe Jr., its current chairman and chief executive, estimates that 600 tire companies have come and gone since then.   Mr. O'Keefe took over as chairman and chief executive earlier this year - ''during the eye of the storm,'' he said yesterday - and is guiding the New Haven-based company through some of its most difficult times.

headline: London Plans For Trading
abstract: The London Stock Exchange and a group of international securities dealers confirmed today that they had agreed to form a 24-hour electronic marketplace for stocks in a venture that would compete with other exchanges worldwide.   The London exchange would merge with the International Securities Regulatory Organization, the self-regulatory body for about 200 firms in the multibillion-dollar Eurobond market, both groups said. The London exchange said it would change its name to the International Stock Exchange.

headline: DATA BANK September 28, 1986
Germans Get 3 Suspects In an Ice Cream Parlor
abstract: Three of the nine suspected Red Army Faction members sought in a hunt for the killers of a nuclear physicist have been arrested by the police, who took them by surprise in an ice cream parlor in Russelsheim, about 15 miles southwest of Frankfurt, officials said today.   West German Interior Minister Friedrich Zimmermann said a tip led to the arrests of the two women and a man Saturday.

headline: ARGENTINA SEEKS I.M.F. LOAN TIED TO CROP PRICES
abstract: Argentina's treasury minister, Mario Brodersohn, said today that his Government was seeking a loan from the International Monetary Fund that would insulate Argentina from future falls in world agricultural prices.   In an interview with three reporters, he disclosed that Argentina was seeking commodity-price linkage in a new package from the I.M.F. similar to the oil-price linkage obtained by Mexico in a $1.6 billion agreement it signed with the I.M.F. in July.   The Mexican pact both provided for greater I.M.F. flexibility and demanded less austerity than in past loan agreements with the fund.

headline: Guinness Head Holds the Reins
abstract: The head of the Guinness brewing company, Ernest Saunders, has been confirmed by stockholders as executive chairman of the merged Guinness-Distillers empire, thwarting a move to overthrow him.   Some shareholders were angry that he had reneged on a promise that Sir Thomas Risk, Bank of Scotland governor, would be named chairman of the merged companies.

headline: Massachusetts Offering Bonds
abstract: A $526 million refunding by Massachusetts to reduce debt service payments on outstanding general obligation bonds was tentatively priced through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The maximum yield is 7.50 percent for 7 1/4 percent securities maturing in 2005 at a price of 97.4629.   About $414 million of the general obligation bonds with shorter maturities are offered with yields ranging from 4 percent for an issue due in 1986 to 6 percent in 1991, 7 percent in 1996 and 7.50 percent in 2001.   The bonds, backed by the full faith and credit of the state, are expected to be rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by Standard & Poor's.

headline: WHITES OWN 11 TIMES THE ASSETS BLACKS HAVE, CENSUS STUDY FINDS
abstract: White Americans, whose incomes are almost twice those of blacks, have accumulated 11 times more assets, according to a study the Census Bureau published today. It found that nearly a third of black households had no major assets at all.   While income levels have been studied frequently, the Census Bureau provided an unusual look at what it called individual wealth - the ownership of savings, housing, automobiles, stocks and the like, minus debts.   The study covered all assets except cash on hand, home furniture, jewelry, pension rights and the cash value of life insurance policies.

headline: PEKING SENTENCES AMERICAN AS SPY
abstract: An American citizen has been sentenced to 12 years' imprisonment in China on charges of spying for Taiwan, the New China News Agency said today.   It said Roland Shensu Loo, 67 years old, a naturalized American citizen, who immigrated to the United States in 1980, and three Chinese who were sentenced to shorter terms pleaded guilty to spying for a Taiwanese espionage group based in the United States.   A United States Embassy spokesman confirmed that the trial and conviction of an American citizen had taken place, but declined to name him or give details of the case.  [ Anita Stockman, a State Department spokesman, said the department would have no comment. ]  Husband and Wife Jailed Ning Nianci, 42, an engineer at the Peking Construction Engineering Institute, was jailed for 10 years, the press agency said. Her husband, Yu Defu, 48, director of the Peking Science and Education Film Studio, was sentenced to three years, and Zhu Junyi, 43, a resident of Hangzhou, capital of Zhejiang Province, got 10 years.

headline: ESTIMATES ON PROFITS SLASHED
abstract: With the Commerce Department reporting last week that second-quarter economic growth was at its lowest level in four years, the outlook for corporate profits has taken a sharp turn downward. While some sectors of the economy are showing improvements in profits, analysts have slashed their estimates for many of the country's largest companies.  After-tax corporate profits will fall 8.7 percent in 1986, according to the latest prediction by Data Resources Inc., a consulting company in Lexington, Mass.  ''Every month, as we've seen the economy not hold up to expectations, there's been a revision downward, and the sharpest revision is going on right now,'' said Werner E. Keller, the director of research at Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc. in Los Angeles.

headline: New Aircraft For President
abstract: The Air Force awarded a $249.8 million contract to the Boeing Company today for two 747 airliners to be used to fly the President. They will replace the two Boeing 707's now used by the White House.

headline: Market Place; Why Wall St. Likes Oil Rise
abstract: IF the stock market has been rising since last fall because of declining oil prices and lower interest rates, as is generally believed, why did Wall Street stage an impressive rally last week when OPEC appeared successful in its effort to raise energy prices?   That is the question puzzling some economists, who think the financial community's decision to celebrate the action by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries may have been inappropriate.   ''In a general sense, the United States is a net importer of oil,'' said Ray Fair, professor of economics at Yale University. ''When oil prices fall, it benefits. If the opposite happens - if OPEC raises prices - then things go in reverse.''

headline: Shifting Financial Gears
abstract: COLLINS SPENCER, a Hartford executive, is worried about how the expected new tax law will affect him.   ''This year it is more important to take a look at all my investments and all items outstanding to determine how best to handle my cash flow and investment requirements,'' he said. ''It just makes sense. What I'm doing is talking to my C.P.A.''   Mitchell S. Berkey, a Manhattan lawyer, is also concerned about the effects of the expected law, particularly in connection with his real estate holdings.   ''I do a net worth statement every year, and now I'll be paying more attention to the real estate part of my portfolio,'' he noted. ''Part-time investors such as myself are going to have to look long and hard for a satisfactory return on real estate.''

headline: OPEC MEETS AGAIN ON OUTPUT
abstract: OPEC delegates began gathering here today for another emergency meeting amid growing concern that failure to agree on the crucial issue of individual production quotas would further depress oil prices.   ''We have to move,'' was the laconic comment of Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the oil minister of Saudi Arabia, the organization's largest and most influential producer, as he arrived for the conference, which begins Monday.   It is the fourth time this year that the 13 ministers are reviewing their plans to limit oil output in an effort to reverse a price plunge of more than 50 percent in the last eight months. Much will depend on Mr. Yamani's ability to muster at least a majority of the ministers behind support for a binding accord on output.

headline: Bringing Order to Catalogue Chaos
abstract: LIBRARIANS and archivists, despite the similarity of their fields, have for years been at each other's throats over one issue: standardization. The librarians, who are most likely to preside over the use of the historical records contained in archives, argue for a uniform on-line cataloguing method, much like the Dewey decimal system for books. But until recently, archivists insisted that they had to be allowed to sort things in whatever way made most sense to them.

headline: S.E.C. ACTS ON 'TRIPLE WITCHING'
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today asked the New York Stock Exchange to experiment with a new procedure to reduce the volatility of stock prices on ''triple witching Fridays,'' when stock options, stock index options and stock index futures all expire.   The S.E.C. voted unanimously to send an official letter of request to the exchange in which it outlined a plan that would publicly disseminate more information about excessive buy or sell orders during the last 30 minutes of trading on these Fridays.   Triple-witching Fridays, on which the stock market averages can gyrate wildly, have caused considerable concern at the S.E.C., which fears that such fluctuations can erode investor confidence in the market. For months, the commission has been studying ways to reduce, but not necesssarily eliminate, that volatility.

headline: Taft Broadcasting Stake Acquired
abstract: The American Financial Corporation and its chairman, Carl H. Lindner, have purchased 5 percent of the Taft Broadcasting Company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, American Financial and Mr. Lindner said they had bought the Taft shares for investment purposes only but added that they intended to review their investment on a ''continuing basis and may change their plans depending on future developments.''

headline: U.S. to Sell $9.5 Billion in 1-Year Bills
abstract: Issues of Government securities this week will include the regular weekly Treasury auction of three-month and six-month bills today and $9.5 billion of one-year Treasury bills on Tuesday.   Prior to the early close of American markets last week for the long Fourth of July weekend, the outstanding one-year bill was trading at 5.91 percent on Thursday. The outstanding three-month bills were trading at 5.92 percent, and the six-month bills were trading at 5.86 percent.   The Student Loan Marketing Association plans to announce today the interest rate on $250 million of short-term floating-rate notes due Jan. 8, 1987. The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation will announce Wednesday the interest rate on $690 million of bonds due in 1989.

headline: Horn & Hardart
abstract: The California investor Theodore H. Kruttschnitt raised his stake in the Horn & Hardart Company to about 10 percent, or 1.43 million shares, from 7.6 percent. Mr. Kruttschnitt reiterated a previous statement that he might seek control of the Las Vegas-based food-service and mail-order concern. Between Aug. 7 and Sept. 16, Mr. Kruttschnitt bought 349,700 shares for $11.88 to $14.88 a share.

headline: BUSH MAY VISIT SYRIA TO SPUR PEACE TALKS
abstract: The Reagan Administration may send Vice President Bush to Syria to make a new overture to improve relations in the hope of reviving the Middle East peace process, White House officials said today.   The officials said that the State Department and the National Security Council had left open the possibility that Mr. Bush could make an unscheduled stop in Syria while on a 12-day trip to the Middle East. He is scheduled to leave July 25.   A meeting with the Syrian President, Hafez al-Assad, had been urged by King Hussein of Jordan when the Jordanian leader met with President Reagan last month. At that time, the King suggested that the United States take a more active diplomatic role in Middle East peace efforts.

headline: France Approves C.G.E.-ITT Accord
abstract: The French Government said yesterday that it had approved a plan under which the state-owned Compagnie Generale d'Electricite would acquire control of the ITT Corporation's telecommunications business.   The proposed transaction, expected to be concluded by the end of 1986, would transform ITT from a company subject to pressures from the highly competitive communications business into a service-oriented concern that is much less capital intensive.   It would also create a telecommunications company, run by C.G.E., that would be second in size only to the American Telephone an Telegraph Company. And the new C.G.E.-controlled concern, in which ITT would be a minority partner, could become the leading supplier of switching and other telecommunications equipment in 75 countries.

headline: A.B.A. PROTESTS ARRESTS TO BOTHA
abstract: The American Bar Association assailed the South African Government yesterday over the recent detention of lawyers representing clients in security cases.   The group's president, speaking on behalf of more than 310,000 member lawyers, said: ''It is fundamentally wrong to detain a lawyer for representing an unpopular client. It would be wrong here and it is equally wrong in South Africa.''

headline: Hispanic Bid For 5 TV Units
abstract: A group of Hispanic investors joined the bidding for the Spanish International Communications Corporation, offering more than $250 million for the five television stations.   The investment group, which said it would be known as the Hispanic Broadcasting Corporation of America, said that it was dedicated to maintaining Spanish language, culture and heritage through television broadcasting on the stations.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Ambassador General Partnership, which owns the hotel assets of the Tropicana Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City, is offering $175 million of 12 percent first-mortgage notes due 1996 at 99.75 to yield 12.04 percent, through Salomon Brothers Inc.    * AMR Corp. is offering $100 million of 9 percent debentures due 2016 at 96.788 to yield 9.32 percent, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.    * Chubb Corp. is issuing $200 million of 5 1/2 percent convertible Eurobonds due 1993 at par, through Morgan Stanley International. The bonds are calllable after three years if the price of the common stock exceeds the conversion price by 130 percent.

headline: Hyundai Exports Triple
abstract: The Hyundai Motor Company's car exports tripled to 138,436 vehicles in the first six months of 1986, from 46,000 in the comparable 1985 period, Hyundai officials said Saturday.

headline: STUDY URGES CANADA TO STRENGTHEN PUBLIC TV
abstract: A federal task force has recommended increasing the quantity and quality of Canadian television programs, partly by creating a new public television channel.   The recommendations, issued Monday by the Task Force on Broadcasting Policy, were aimed at reducing the large amount of American television that Canadians watch. Critics here have blamed the strength of American television for undermining Canadian national identity.

headline: Cotton Prices Plunge; Hogs Also Off Sharply
abstract: Cotton futures fell sharply today after a long rally, as the market prepared to deal with a glut of cotton. Traders said they expected the Agriculture Department to begin issuing large amounts of certificates that could be redeemed for cotton from reserves as part of their farm support payments to farmers.   The certificates originally were to be issued in August, and the delay was cited as one factor in the recent rally, which has seen cotton prices jump from about 30 cents a pound to about 45 cents before retreating today to 43.45 cents.

headline: Anne Frank House Scene of Bomb Scare
abstract: A bomb scare forced a two-hour evacuation of the Anne Frank House today as the former Soviet dissident Anatoly Shcharansky was due to visit the museum, the police said.   A Dutch army bomb disposal unit removed a vacuum cleaner bag found in a wastebasket at the museum, according to a police spokesman, Klaas Wilting, who said the bag was found to contain only refuse.   The police said they had not received any threats in connection with the Jewish activist's visit, and Mr. Shcharansky entered the museum shortly after the alert was lifted.

headline: Kodak Asks Court Review on Polaroid
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it had filed a petition with the Supreme Court seeking a review of a decision by a lower court that forced Kodak to leave the instant photography business for infringing on patents of the Polaroid Corporation. Last October Federal District Judge Rya W. Zobel in Boston found that Kodak had infringed on seven patents held by the Polaroid Corporation.

headline: SIX OUTSIDERS PLOT A FUTURE FOR FORDHAM
abstract: John C. Burton Dean, Columbia Business School    TO say that they are going to double the size of the school raises the question in my mind as to whether quality would actually have to be cut.   All business schools are seeing the demand for M.B.A.'s plateauing at best. From the viewpoint of employers, we are seeing more emphasis on the percieved quality of the school than on the degree itself.   Faculty people are in very high demand. And they come at a price. If Fordham is going to compete for senior faculty by paying salaries in the high five figures and low six figures, I can only assume that Arthur has made some arrangement that salaries in the business school are not followed by comparable salaries elsewhere in the university.

headline: Difficult Task Faces Kaiser Steel Chairman
abstract: ''We never thought Kaiser would be easy,'' said Monty H. Rial, whose group has been trying to reshape the West Coast company, the Kaiser Steel Corporation. But it has turned out to be a difficult task and Kaiser Steel announced this week that it was trying to work out a restructuring of payments to deal with a severe liquidity squeeze.   Mr. Rial was president of the Perma Resources Corporation, which bought half of Kaiser in 1984 and last year bought the remainder of the common stock for $40 million. Kaiser's steel finishing mills had already been sold off, and Kaiser's asssets today are real estate, coal operations and a fabricated products business that mostly serves the oil industry.

headline: HOW CHICAGO SHAKES WALL ST.
abstract: Come the ''triple witching hour'' Friday afternoon, financial wizards will pay as much attention to the Chicago futures trading pits as to the stock exchanges in New York.   For while the stock plunge on Wall Street last week got all the attention, the action in Chicago's futures markets was just as furious - and one of the main lessons was that the Chicago traders help shape what happens in New York.   ''If you take a look at the way the market jerks around in a day, it's hard to conclude that index futures contracts are not having a major impact on the volume and volatility in the equity marketplace,'' said B. Macon Brewer, chairman of the capital markets division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.   Stock index futures are contracts, bought and sold, that represent a bundle of underlying stocks. They go up and down with the stock market and enable investors to speculate on broad market rises and hedge against market falls. Often, futures prices swing more violently than the underlying stock prices because futures traders seek to anticipate market swings.

headline: D.D.B. Group Reports 12.1% Drop in Income
abstract: The Doyle Dane Bernbach Group yesterday reported a 12.1 percent decline in net income in the second quarter compared with the year before despite a 9.2 percent gain in revenues.   Net income was $2.9 million, or 51 cents a share, against $3.3 million, or 63 cents a share, while revenues worldwide were $60.8 million, compared with $55.7 million. In the six-month period, revenues were up 8 percent and net income was 1 percent higher.

headline: National Medical To Buy Its Stock
abstract: National Medical Enterprises, which two months ago announced a major restructuring of its businesses, said it would buy back 10 million shares, or nearly one-eighth of its stock. The stock repurchase was valued at $216.2 million based on today's closing price of $21.625, up 25 cents.

headline: US Magazine Acts To Woo Business
abstract: US magazine, owned jointly by Rolling Stone magazine and Lorimar-Telepictures, has enlisted three Hollywood stars to catch the eye of the business community.

headline: 9 in U.S. Plead Guilty In Plot on Suriname
abstract: Nine of the 14 people accused of plotting to overthrow the military Government of Suriname have pleaded guilty to lesser charges.   Five others remain charged with Neutrality Act violations and are scheduled for trial Sept. 22.

headline: JOHN CONNALLY'S TEXAS-SIZED TROUBLES
abstract: WHEN John Connally's Presidential ambitions were dashed in 1980, he decided, at age 63, that it was time to quit politics and to start making some real money.   He looked around his beloved home state of Texas, on the cusp of a fantastic boom in oil and real estate, and saw the opportunity to convert his powerful connections, tall good looks and silver tongue into a Texas-sized fortune. His friend and political protege, Ben F. Barnes, the former Lieutentant Governor of Texas, joined him. And together the men borrowed with abandon to build their empire with a rolling swagger much admired in Texas, and a conviction they couldn't lose.   The two men built shopping malls in Houston, Giddings and other oil regions of Texas. They put up a 14-story office building in Houston. They developed an upscale housing subdivision in the lovely hills to the west of Austin, the capital of Texas. They built a 120-unit beachfront condominium and shopping mall on South Padre Island, Tex., a favorate refuge of wealthy Mexicans. They invested in oil and gas wells and a gas pipeline. And they freely signed personal guarantees for loans to pals who were playing the same investment game.

headline: Manila Takes Bank Control
abstract: One of the largest banks in the Philippines was brought under state control today. The Commission on Good Government seized 95 percent of the stock of the United Coconut Planters Bank and elected new directors.

headline: Banker Pleads Guilty
abstract: The former managing director of the Overseas Trust Bank pleaded guilty Friday to charges of conspiring to defraud the bank of $66 million, court officials said. They said that Patrick Chang Chen-tsong, 35 years old, who will be sentenced Monday, had agreed to become a witness for the prosecution against four former colleagues, including the bank's one-time chairman, Huang Tiong Chan, who is in custody in the United States.

headline: School Collapse in China
abstract: Eleven children were reported killed and 35 injured when their school collapsed in the central province of Henan. Henan Daily said a Communist Party secretary and another official had been arrested in connection with the collapse on Sept. 12 in the town of Dazheng. A preliminary investigation found school officials had ignored serious structural problems in the building, the paper said.

headline: LAX SAFETY CHARGED
abstract: A South African mining company said today that 177 people, most of them black miners, died Tuesday when a fire sent palls of toxic gas through underground shafts. It was the country's worst gold-mining disaster on record.   On Tuesday the owners said 44 people died and 154 were still missing. By late afternoon today, 235 people were reported injured and 5 were missing more than 30 hours after the fire broke out.

headline: Putnam Is Suing Former Executives
abstract: The Putnam Companies, one of the largest mutual fund managers, has sued a group of former executives, contending they conspired to steal business.

headline: House Vote Fails to Overrule Trade Benefits for Rumania
abstract: The House of Representatives today defeated a move to overrule an extension of trade benefits to Rumania.

headline: Japan Growth Said to Slacken
abstract: Japan's economy is moving at a slackening pace because of a rapid slowdown in investment by export-oriented manufacturers, caused by the yen's appreciation against the dollar, the Government's Economic Planning Agency said today in its June report of leading economic indicators.

headline: SOVIET ANNOUNCES DECISION TO TRIM ITS AFGHAN FORCE
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that the Soviet Union would withdraw six regiments from Afghanistan by the end of the year, and asked that the move be matched by a reduction of Western aid to the guerrillas.   In a televised speech from the Pacific coast city of Vladivostok, he also gave a noncommittal response to President Reagan's recent letter on arms control, and called for closer relations with China.   Western diplomats said the troop withdrawal would cut Soviet forces in Afghanistan by 6 percent. The number of soviet troops in Afghanistan is estimated at 120,000, and the number of Afghan guerrillas as high as 30,000. Call for Verification    Mr. Gorbachev said the six regiments would be withdrawn in such a way as to make possible verification by ''anyone interested,'' presumably meaning American spy satellites.  [ In Washington, the Reagan Administration indicated it did not attach great importance to the announcement. In another move, the State Department proposed to a visiting Soviet official that the foreign ministers meet in mid-September to begin planning for a summit meeting. Page A7. ]  In the Vladivostok speech, Mr. Gorbachev said Mr. Reagan's reply on arms control had been delivered over the weekend. The letter ''sets one thinking'' and is being studied with ''responsibility and attention,'' Mr. Gorbachev said.

headline: HEAD FOR SUMMIT
abstract: Egyptian and Israeli negotiators agreed tonight on a formula for settling a border dispute and salvaged a meeting Thursday between President Hosni Mubarak and Prime Minister Shimon Peres.   After more than 12 hours of meetings - most of them with the American special Middle East envoy, Richard W. Murphy, taking part - the two sides agreed on the terms under which their long-running border dispute over the 700-yard Sinai beach known as Taba would be sent to arbitration. First Summit Talks Since 1981    That agreement cleared the way for the summit conference, which will be the first meeting between leaders of Egypt and Israel since 1981 and the first for Mr. Mubarak. The two-day meeting will be in Alexandria, Egypt.  [ In Jerusalem, the Likud bloc demanded that a Cabinet meeting be held Thursday so strict guidelines could be laid down for the Peres-Mubarak meeting, Israeli Government sources said. Page A8.  [ In Washington, officials reacted positively to the agreement on arbitration. But officials added that Secretary of State George P. Shultz would not be able to travel to the Middle East soon because of a full schedule. Page A9. ]  Two-Day Meeting Planned ''We have finished everything,'' said Gen. Avraham Tamir, the head of Mr. Peres's office, as he emerged from the border talks shortly before 10 P.M. ''The summit will start tomorrow and will go over into Friday.''

headline: HOUSE, 313 TO 83, AFFIRMS SANCTIONS ON SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: The House of Representatives brushed aside a new proposal by President Reagan today and voted decisively to override his veto of a bill imposing stiff economic sanctions on the South African Government.   The vote was 313 to 83, or 49 more votes than the two-thirds of those voting needed to override the veto. The President picked up six votes from the initial vote in the House, but supporters of the bill added five votes, so Mr. Reagan's appeal today had virtually no effect.   ''This bill will send a moral and diplomatic wake-up call to a President who doesn't understand the issue,'' Representative William H. Gray 3d, a Pennsylvania Democrat, said in the debate today. ''Sometimes we need to feel good about who we are and what we stand for.''

headline: NOW, JAPAN INC. WEARS A HARD HAT
abstract: UNDER the hot Arizona sun, a team of Japanese engineers watched carefully as a huge, white-and-red ''mole'' was lowered into a hole 30 feet wide and 65 feet deep. The Japanese-made machine was positioned to dig three huge drainage tunnels for the last leg of I-10, the interstate highway that will link Los Angeles with Florida.   Today, three years later, the tunneling job is about complete. The engineers, employees of Obayashi Gumi, one of Japan's biggest construction companies, are back in Tokyo. The remaining work on the tunnels is in the hands of Obayashi's American partners.   But the tunnels remain a symbol of Japan's inroads into the American construction market.

headline: American Cyanamid And Monsanto Gain
abstract: Two major chemical companies, American Cyanamid and Monsanto, yesterday reported strong earnings improvements for the recent quarter.  The American Cyanamid Company said its second-quarter profits rose 48.7 percent from the corresponding 1985 period. The Monsanto Company reported a quarterly earnings increase of 19.3 percent on a revenue increase of 14.7 percent.

headline: Washington Watch; Why Banks Really Failed
abstract: IT is not uncommon for banking regulators to identify bad real estate loans as a cause for the failure of a bank or thrift institution. But generally there is an unspoken element behind that statement implying more than just a lot of vacant office buildings. Often the root cause consists of highly inflated values for real estate carried on the bank's books.

headline: CHERNOBYL DISASTER LEAVING A LONG TRAIL OF LISTS
abstract: Here in the capital of the Ukraine, and elsewhere in administrative centers of this Soviet republic and neighboring Byelorussia, the Chernobyl nuclear disaster is leaving a legacy - of lists.   For months, the authorities have been compiling lists of evacuees. These are mainly in the custody of investigative and administrative commissions formed in Kiev. But that is just the beginning.

headline: Key Rates
DRAMA AT THE BERLIN WALL: A WILD DRIVE TO FREEDOM
abstract: A man who swerved a dump truck through East German police gunfire early today and escaped through the Berlin wall had a friend and their baby huddled on the floor under the windshield, the West Berlin police said. None of the three were hurt.

headline: A Modest Bill for Banking
abstract: With the retreat last week by Jake Garn, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, from his plans to push for comprehensive banking legislation this year, the prospects of closing the limited-service bank loophole became more distant.   Those pushing to ban these banks, which either make commecial loans or take demand deposits, but not both, seem to be losing one of the most intense banking battles in years. And a major test of their clout will come this week.

headline: Reichmann, Allied Talks
abstract: Toronto's Reichmann family and Allied Lyons P.L.C. of Britain are negotiating an end to their bitter dispute over ownership of the liquor division of Hiram Walker Resources Ltd. A series of meetings were held in London last week, and for most of this week in a Toronto hotel, but Allied said today that a deal has not been reached.

headline: Disaster in Cameroon Reported 'Under Control'
abstract: Government and American officials said today that the situation in northern Cameroon, where 1,500 people were killed by volcanic gas, now appeared to have been stabilized.

headline: THE U.N. TODAY: SEPT. 11, 1986
East German Family of 4 Swims River to West
abstract: An East German family of four climbed over border fences and swam across a river to reach West Germany early today, West German officials said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Advanced Telecommunications Corp. is offering $15 million of 8 percent subordinated debentures, due in 2006 and convertible into common at $8.25 a share, through Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette at par.    * Bank of Boston is issuing $125 million of 12-year floating-rate notes at par through Credit Suisse First Boston; interest is five-hundredths percentage point above the three-month London interbank offered rate.

headline: Soviet Commander Named
abstract: East Germany identified the new commander of the 400,000 Soviet troops in East Germany today as Gen. Valery A. Belikov, who has commanded the Carpathian Military District in the southwestern Soviet Union since 1979. General Belikov is replacing Gen. Pyotr G. Lushev.

headline: Victims Board to Get Harris Book Profits
abstract: Profits from Jean Harris's recently published book must be turned over to the Crime Victims Board, the chairman said Monday.   Mrs. Harris, convicted of killing Dr. Herman Tarnower, developer of the Scarsdale Diet, wanted royalties from ''Stranger in Two Worlds'' to be given to the Children of Bedford Hills, an organization she had set up to benefit the children of inmates at the women's prison where she is serving a 15-year-to-life sentence.

headline: GUARANTEE FOR INVESTORS IN 3D WORLD
abstract: Aiming to increase capital flow into developing countries, a part of the World Bank announced a program today that eliminates the risk of loss for foreign investors in projects that the agency originates.   The International Finance Corporation, the private-sector financing arm of the World Bank, said the arrangement should make a ''considerable'' contribution to reversing the decline in capital into the third world. The agency expects to pump $7.4 billion into more than 400 third world projects over the next five years.

headline: For Fireman's Fund, a Profit
abstract: The Fireman's Fund Corporation said yesterday that net income for the second quarter was $55 million, or 83 cents a share, against a loss of $84 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.   The insurance holding company, which is based in Novato, Calif., said second-quarter earned property-liability premiums rose 7.6 percent, to $771 million, while written net premiums increased 14 percent, to $800 million.

headline: Wells Fargo Wins Appeal
abstract: Wells Fargo Bank said today that a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit would allow the bank to continue offering mutual funds to Individual Retirement Account customers.   The June 30 ruling overturned a 1984 Federal District Court decision that such investment funds violated the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933, which prohibits commercial banks from marketing securities.

headline: FOR BRAZILIAN, U.S. TRIP MARKS SURGE IN STATUS
abstract: President Jose Sarney will visit Washington next week as the leader of a nation that has recovered its traditional self-confidence and is now seeking United States recognition of its new status as an influential third world democracy and a growing economic power.   In his talks at the White House on Wednesday and his address to a joint session of Congress on Thursday, the 56-year-old President is said to be intent on drawing the attention of the United States to the dramatic turnaround that has resulted in the emergence of a ''new Brazil'' since he assumed office in March 1985.   During this time, Brazil has returned to civilian rule after 21 years of rightist military government and, alone among Latin America's troubled economies, it has pulled out of a prolonged recession and is now growing rapidly, running up huge trade surpluses to cover the servicing of its $105 billion foreign debt, the largest in the developing world.   But the past 18 months have also been marked by tensions between the United States and Brazil. The strained relations have been provoked by a series of trade disputes which, while economic in nature, have assumed political importance in both countries. And another of Mr. Sarney's objectives, according to officials here, is to create a better climate for dealing with these conflicts without affecting broader relations.

headline: Kaiser Steel Tightens Belt
abstract: The Kaiser Steel Corporation says it has a ''severe liquidity problem,'' which includes being in default on its main bank loan, and is restructuring itself to restore its financial vigor.   The report on Kaiser was part of a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which Kaiser announced Friday along with a second-quarter loss of $13 million on sales of $56.4 million.

headline: METS A BASEBALL 'JEWEL' IN ATTENDANCE, REVENUE
abstract: The New York Mets are a glorious exception to major league baseball's prediction that its 26 teams will collectively lose $59 million this year.   Not only are the Mets so far ahead in first place in the National League East that they have been conceded its championship by their rivals, but they have dislodged the Yankees as the No. 1 draw in town and are driving toward the three million mark in home attendance, a level attained in past years only by the Los Angeles Dodgers.   In the fiscal year ended April 30 -before most of this year's attendance came into play - the Mets' gate receipts rose nearly 50 percent, to $19.8 million. Last season, the Mets played before 2.7 million people in Shea Stadium, the largest season's attendance of any sports team in New York history.

headline: Group Raises Stake in Kaiser
abstract: A group led by the investor Joseph A. Frates of Tulsa, Okla., said today that it had increased its stake in the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation to 26.5 percent, or about 11.8 million shares, from 21.6 percent. The announcement was the first move by the group since its attempt to replace Kaiser's board was defeated by shareholders on April 29.

headline: The Fading Allure of Incorporation
abstract: LAST year, James and Marnie Tynen incorporated Wet Paint Inc., their two-year-old alternative greeting card company in Pittsburgh. The Tynens found that the corporation was a better form of business for raising capital, and it forced them to be more organized - which in turn made the company more profitable. But when the board of directors meets in November, one item on the agenda will be whether to dissolve the corporation and run Wet Paint as a partnership instead.   The reason is the proposed tax bill: Under the new rules, some closely held businesses may be more profitable if they are organized as partnerships rather than as corporations. If the proposals become law, not only small-business owners but also doctors, lawyers and professionals would be well advised to re-evaluate incorporation.

headline: Ford Bank Group Head Plans a Swift Strategy
abstract: Gerald J. Ford, chairman of the Ford Bank Group, has been known to study a newly acquired bank's existing management for up to six months before making any changes.   Mr. Ford, as head of the Ford Bank Group, oversees 14 subsidiary banks throughout New Mexico, and 11 banks in Texas. Many of the banks were on the verge of insolvency at the time of acquisition. His latest complex deal calls for the Ford Bank Group to take over BankTexas Group Inc. in Dallas.

headline: WANG HAS A PROFIT IN QUARTER
abstract: Highlighting the diverse fortunes in the computer industry, four manufacturers of computer systems reported profit results today. Wang Laboratories Inc. edged back toward health and Tandem Computers Inc. was strong as expected. The Amdahl Corporation's earnings fell substantially and Prime Computer Inc. held up fairly well in comparison to an excellent quarter last year.

headline: TEAR GAS USED ON CHURCHGOERS IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: The South African police disrupted a church service in Cape Town yesterday for relatives of people who are being detained under that nation's emergency decree, and they later fired tear gas at the congregation and arrested at least three worshipers, a participant in the service said.   In a black township near Johannesburg, meanwhile, more than 100 soldiers and policemen briefly detained a high-ranking international delegation of labor leaders, including Lane Kirkland, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and the group's leader, John Vanderveken, general secretary of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.   The labor delegation also met yesterday with Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, who is scheduled to meet today with President P. W. Botha to discuss the state of emergency declared on June 12.   In Pretoria, the state Bureau for Information said security forces killed two more blacks yesterday in the violence that has claimed more than 2,000 lives since September 1984. The official death toll since the current emergency decree was imposed now stands at 164.

headline: Grey Gets Account Of Olive Garden Chain
abstract: Grey Advertising has been awarded the seven-figure Olive Garden account by the General Mills Restaurant Group. Olive Garden, an Italian restaurant chain in the Sun Belt, was previously at Young & Rubicam/Zemp in Tampa, Fla.   Grey already handles the Red Lobster and New York Steak House chains for the restaurant group.

headline: Allbritton Sets Investor Unit
abstract: The Allbritton Communications Company said yesterday that it had formed a new subsidiary that could spend up to $1 billion to acquire television stations affiliated with one of the three major networks.   A spokesman for Allbritton, which is wholly owned by Joe L. Allbritton, said that the new group, known as the Allco Corporation, was not in negotiations to acquire specific properties.

headline: Louisiana Authority Offers Farm Loan Issue
abstract: The Louisiana Agricultural Finance Authority and its underwriters, led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., yesterday introduced a taxable bond issue intended to provide lower-cost financing to farmers.   Proceeds from the new $150 million issue of 8 1/4 percent bonds due in 1996 will be used to buy the 90 percent portion of various farm loans that is insured by the Farmers Home Administration, an agency of the Department of Agriculture.

headline: KEY RATES
TRANSAMERICA AGREES TO SELL BUDGET RENT A CAR
abstract: The Transamerica Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell the Budget Rent a Car Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest car rental concern for $205 million in cash and the assumption of Budget's $296 million of debt. The buyer is a new company formed by Gibbons, Green, vanAmerongen Ltd., an investment banker specializing in leveraged buyouts.   Transamerica said its after-tax gain on the deal would be about $50 million.

headline: Panel Divided On Conrail
abstract: A House-Senate conference committee, struggling to reach agreement on a compromise measure to sell Conrail, remained divided today on some major issues. But the panel plans to continue discussing the legislation today.

headline: JORDAN TO FUNNEL U.S. AID TO WEST BANK
abstract: United States officials said today that the Reagan Administration had decided for the first time to funnel through Jordan a portion of American development aid for Palestinians living in Israeli-occupied terrorities.   While the size of the allocation, $4.5 million, is relatively small, the decision is expected to make it more difficult for the Israelis to determine how all American aid is spent in the occupied territories, as they have been able to do until now.   The United States also appeared to be seeking to provide King Hussein of Jordan with American support in his dispute with the Palestine Liberation Organization. American aides point out that since earlier this year, the King has been competing with the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, for the allegiance of Palestinians.

headline: Continental Begins Paying Off Debts
abstract: The Continental Airlines Corporation began paying the first installment of about $925 million owed to creditors, a company spokesman said in announcing that the airline had emerged from bankruptcy. Continential will pay nearly $140 million within 10 days in the first stage of a reorganization plan approved this summer by a Federal judge, the spokesman, Bruce Hicks, said.

headline: MINE KILLS 28 ON SRI LANKA BUS
abstract: Tamil rebels set off a powerful mine under a bus today, killing 28 people, as the Government and less militant Tamil leaders pursued talks to resolve the island's ethnic conflict.   A military spokesman said the bus was traveling near Vavuniya, 140 miles north of Colombo, when Tamil rebels detonated the device, killing 25 passengers at the scene.

headline: Dow Rises by 5.76 After Late Flurry
abstract: With a debate raging over whether the Federal Reserve Board would lower interest rates, the stock market was sharply lower for most of yesterday's session before a flurry of buy orders in the last hour resulted in a modest advance.   After the market closed, the rate dispute was settled when the Fed announced that it would cut its discount rate to 6 percent from 6 1/2 percent.   Hugh Johnson, a market analyst and economist with First Albany Corporation, said he believes the discount rate cut was ''going to add to the rally'' that started in Wall Street's final hour. But the positive reaction may not last long, he said, because the ''reason the discount rate was cut is that there is such a fundamental weakness in the economy.''

headline: Advertising; Magazine's Venture In China
abstract: JOHN W. PATTEN, publisher of Business Week, had an idea for a publishing adventure in China. So he went over and sold the Chinese on the idea. Just like that? Well, practically.   He made no attempt to work through Chinese diplomatic sources here in advance of the trip. Nor did he try to line up contacts through a series of letters.

headline: U.S. AND SOVIET START WASHINGTON ARMS TALKS
abstract: Soviet and American officials began two days of arms-control talks here today.   The goal of the sessions is to determine ing if there is a basis for possible compromises before the meeting of Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze scheduled for mid-September.   ''We are prepared to reach an agreement if there is readiness on the American side,'' said Viktor P. Karpov, the head of the Soviet delegation to the talks. Asked if an agreement could be achieved, Mr. Karpov said, ''Let's see.''

headline: Caterpillar Chooses First Agency in Years
abstract: Caterpillar Inc., the heavy equipment manufacturer of Peoria, Ill., wants to be known for more than just tractors. So, after an advertising hiatus of several years, it has selected Ogilvy & Mather to tackle a corporate make-over, adding up to an anticipated $3 million to $5 million a year in billings.   Also competing for the job were DFS-Dorland, Saatchi & Saatchi Compton Worldwide and Young & Rubicam, Chicago.

headline: Stocks End Day Mixed; Dow Declines Slightly
abstract: Stock prices ended narrowly mixed yesterday in the wake of the Federal Reserve Board's largely-expected discount rate cut. While blue-chip issues slipped a bit, the underlying market moved strongly ahead.   The Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.14, to 1,881.19, as volume contracted to 135.2 million shares, from 156.6 million on Wednesday.

headline: Tenneco Notes
abstract: A $250 million financing by Tenneco Inc., through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company, produced a yield of 9.06 percent. The notes, due Jan. 15, 1997, carry a 9 percent coupon and are offered at a price of 99.60. Noncallable for life, the notes are rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and BBB+ by S.&P.

headline: Senate Asks Deep Cuts In Soviet's U.N. Mission
abstract: The Senate voted today to order even deeper cuts in the personnel of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations in New York, going beyond reductions already demanded by President Reagan.   The United States has accused the Soviet Mission of harboring intelligence agents and has asked for a staff reduction to 170 over three years.

headline: Strike by Hindus Shuts Stores in New Delhi
abstract: Stores throughout the capital were closed today in a one-day strike called by Hindu leaders to protest the killing of 14 Hindus on a bus in the Punjab on Friday.   The New Delhi protest was called by the National People's Party, an offshoot of a Hindu revivalist organization.

headline: ZAMBIAN SENDS NEW PLEA TO U.S.
abstract: President Kenneth D. Kaunda said today that he would ask President Reagan to meet with the leaders of South Africa's black-governed neighbors to develop a new policy toward the region.   Mr. Kaunda met earlier today with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the American civil rights activist, who is visiting the six countries, the so-called front-line nations.   ''Zambia and other front-line states are facing severe economic problems as a result of drought, debt and a dependence on transportation routes which are vulnerable to disruption and manipulation by South Africa and its surrogates,'' Mr. Kaunda said in a statement.

headline: BUILDING A GIANT AIRLINE: THE HURDLES FOR LORENZO
abstract: In seeking Federal approval of its acquisition of People Express Inc., the Texas Air Corporation plans to argue that the Newark-based carrier is in danger of failing, sources close to Texas Air said yesterday.   The filing to the Transportation Department is expected to be made soon by the Houston-based holding company, which is eager to get quick approval of the transaction by which it will acquire People Express for about $125 million and People's subsidiary, Frontier Airlines, for $176 million.   The acquisition's approval is just one of the obstacles faced by Texas Air's chairman, Frank A. Lorenzo, as he embarks on shaping a competitive, profitable network of carriers with different structures, histories and financial states.   What make the task even more complex are the elements over which he has no control, Mr. Lorenzo said yesterday in his Houston office. In addition to the People Express acquisition, the Transportation Department must still reconsider Texas Air's purchase of Eastern Air Lines, which was rejected earlier for antitrust reasons.

headline: Philadelphia Issue Of Revenue Bonds
abstract: A $185.6 million issue of Philadelphia water and sewer revenue bonds is tentatively offered to yield a maximum 8.04 percent for a 7 1/4 percent bond due in 2014 at a price of 91.25. The underwriters are led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * American City Business Journals, Kansas City, Mo., said it and Business Journal Publications of St. Louis would merge by Nov. 15. Shareholders of Business Journal Publications will receive about $40 million, an official at American City Business said.    * American Airlines, Dallas, said it would begin its nonstop service between Dallas-Fort Worth and Tokyo in April.

headline: FOR MANY TAXPAYERS, EASIER FILING
abstract: The hundreds of provisions in the tax revision legislation might seem to suggest that the original objective of simplifying the tax system had been lost amid the political compromises of the Congressional conferees.   New income guidelines for Individual Retirement Account deductions, phase-outs of consumer interest deductions and limits on the amount homeowners can borrow against their houses if they want to deduct the interest are among the changes portending that April 15 could become an even more agonizing ritual - rather than an easier one - for millions of Americans.   But belying the thousands of pages of statutory language, explanations and Internal Revenue Service regulations that will eventually emerge, the legislation holds the promise of removing for many taxpayers some of the layers of complexity that have so frustrated them during the tax filing season and encouraged many of them to spend endless hours during the rest of the year in search of tax-saving schemes.   ''For the vast majority of taxpayers, the new system's going to be simpler,'' said Michael J. Graetz, a professor at the Yale Law School and a Treasury tax lawyer during the Nixon Administration.   Millions of taxpayers would no longer need to itemize their deductions. Record-keeping requirements would be reduced for millions more.

headline: POPE REINFORCING CLERICS IN DISPUTE WITH SANDINISTAS
abstract: A senior Vatican official said today that Pope John Paul II had given his full backing to Nicaraguan church leaders in a confrontation with the Managua Government over what critics says is harassment of the church and violations of human rights.   The Roman Catholic Church's complaints are expected to be raised at a future meeting between Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo, Archbishop of Managua, and President Daniel Ortega Saavedra.   Mr. Ortega has repeatedly sought direct contacts with the Holy See to discuss disputes. But the Vatican official said Cardinal Obando had been authorized to insist that the Government must first prove its good faith in talks with local church officials before the Vatican would consider negotiations with the Sandinistas.

headline: Israel Gets an Antiracist Law; It Permits Some Exceptions
abstract: The Israeli Knesset today approved an antiracism bill so diluted that the parties that first suggested it voted against it, and Rabbi Meir Kahane, the rightist whose activities the bill was aimed to curtail, voted in its favor.

headline: PAKISTAN LEADER WARNS FOES ON FUTURE PROTESTS
abstract: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan said today that he expected that Benazir Bhutto and other arrested opposition leaders would be released from prison soon, but that they would be arrested again if future protests were not peaceful.   General Zia asserted that Miss Bhutto had acted in an ''unpatriotic'' fashion by obtaining assistance and encouragement from the Soviet Union and India in her drive to overthrow his Government and force immediate elections this fall.   ''I have no proof, I frankly say so,'' General Zia said of his charge, but he added that Miss Bhutto had obtained ''large sums of financial support'' from outside the country, as well as ''assurances and guarantees from, and I wouldn't hesitate in naming the Soviet Union.''

headline: Eastern Lowering A First-Class Fare
abstract: Eastern Air Lines Inc. said that it would offer a new ''First-Class Super Saver'' round-trip fare for as little as $75 above its lowest weekend coach discount rate. The new fares are available to all of Eastern's United States destinations, including Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

headline: Mine Hurts 7 Sri Lankans
abstract: Seven soldiers were wounded today when a land mine laid by separatist Tamil rebels exploded under their jeep in Sri Lanka's eastern province, the military said. A spokesman for the Joint Operations Command said guerrillas set off the explosion at Pottuvil and ran away. The soldiers did not fire at the attackers as they feared civilians nearby might get caught in crossfire, he said.

headline: PRESIDENT, AT U.N., VOICES NEW 'HOPE' ON ARMS CONTROL
abstract: President Reagan said today that recent arms-control exchanges between the United States and the Soviet Union might mark ''the beginning of a serious, productive negotiation on arms reduction.''   ''All of this gives me hope,'' the President said in an address to delegates to the United Nations General Assembly.   But he said that ''a pall has been cast over our relations with the Soviet Union'' by the arrest of an American journalist, Nicholas S. Daniloff, which he called ''a particularly disturbing example of Soviet transgressions against human rights.''   ''The Soviet Union bears the responsibility for the consequences of its action,'' Mr. Reagan said. Aquino Criticizes the U.N.  In another speech today, President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines criticized the United Nations for not supporting the Filipino struggle for freedom, saying her people had to oust Ferdinand E. Marcos alone. ''We took power to implement so many of the ideals that the U.N. stands for,'' she said. ''Yet like so many other leaders before me, I am obliged to say we did this by ourselves.''  [ Page A12. ]  Mr. Reagan made no mention of a summit meeting in his 37-minute speech, which was applauded only at the end. The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who took notes as he listened to the speech, did not applaud. Mr. Reagan also said the Daniloff case was one of several troublesome areas that remained in East-West relations.

headline: PEOPLE CUTS BACK DIVIDEND
abstract: In a move to help its cash position, People Express Inc. said yesterday that it would not pay a quarterly dividend of 66 cents a share on some of its preferred stock. It had suspended payment on the common last month.   The announcement came a day after its subsidiary, Frontier Airlines, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code when a buyer for that airline could not be found.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt   * BP Canadian Holdings Ltd. is offering a 119-million-Swiss-franc, 10-year bond, with a 4 3/4 percent coupon and 99 3/4 issue price, through Union Bank of Switzerland.    * El Paso Electric Co. has filed for up to $400 million of lease obligation bonds through Paine Webber Inc.    * Mexicare Health Plans Inc. is offering $125 million of 11 3/4 percent senior subordinated notes due 1996, at 100, through Salomon Brothers Inc.    * Rochester Telephone Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $70 million medium-term note program through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: Briton Talks of Pretoria During Visit to Africa
abstract: The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, arrived here today from Zambia on a mission on behalf of the European Community to try to set up talks on the unrest in South Africa.   In Zambia, Sir Geoffrey came under criticism from President Kenneth D. Kaunda, who said the mission was ''useless.''

headline: SLOW GAIN IMPLIED BY 1.1% JULY RISE IN ECONOMIC INDEX
abstract: The Government index designed to predict what the nation's economy will do climbed 1.1 percent last month, its second-best performance this year, the Commerce Department reported today.   The gain in the index of leading indicators, however, was undercut by a sharp downward revision for June. This turned what had been originally reported as a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent into a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent.   Taken together, analysts said, today's data suggest that the economy is likely to continue to grow, but at a lackluster pace, not much faster than in the second quarter, when the gross national product expanded at an annual rate of less than 1 percent.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Advanced Systems Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $30 million of convertible subordinated debentures due 2011, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.    * Baltimore County, Md., is offering $57 million of general obligation bonds, through underwriters led by Morgan Guaranty Trust Co. of New York. Yields range from 4.50 percent in 1987 to 5.90 percent in 1991, 6.85 percent in 1996, 7.20 percent in 2001 and 7.35 percent in 2005 and 2006. They are rated triple-A by Moody's and AA+ by S.&P.

headline: Marcos Denies Urging Coup in the Philippines
abstract: Former President Ferdinand E. Marcos denied today that he had encouraged his supporters to rebel and said he was aware that events in the Philippines could jeopardize his status as a guest in the United States.
