''I am aware of that and this is why I say I categorically deny attempting to cause any rebellion, any sedition or any coup d'etat; nor am I engaged in destabilizing the Philippine Government,'' Mr. Marcos said in an interview from Honolulu on the NBC News program ''Today.''

headline: Should Ted Turner Join Actor's Equity?
abstract: THREE years ago, Ted Turner became the first executive to don an eye patch and play ''the man in the Hathaway shirt.'' John Connally, former Governor of Texas and Secretary of the Treasury, and J. W. Marriott Jr., head of the Marriott Corporation, followed. Next month, Pepsico chief Roger Enrico will take his turn.

headline: Michigan Utility In Pact With Dow
abstract: The Consumers Power Company, the financially troubled Michigan utility, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Dow Chemical Company for a joint effort to convert the idled Midland nuclear plant into a natural gas cogeneration plant. The agreement ends two years of uncertainty over the fate of the Midland plant.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Altos Computer, San Jose, Calif., said it had acquired Communications Solutions Inc., a manufacturer of I.B.M. compatible data communication software, from Control Data Corp. Terms were not disclosed.    * Circle K Corp., Phoenix, said it had bought the shares it did not already own in Circle K U.K. from Imperial Brewing and Leisure Ltd., its partner in the joint venture.

headline: COMPUTERS FOR CATCHING SCOFFLAWS
abstract: IN the 1966 movie, ''Cool Hand Luke,'' the character played by Paul Newman gets arrested for cutting meters off their posts with a pipe cutter. Within one week of the movie's opening, Baltimore lost 40 meters in the exact same manner. And in the years following, roving gangs of meter vandals plagued countless American cities.

headline: HONEYWELL HOLDS TALKS ON BUYING SPERRY UNIT
abstract: The Honeywell Corporation surprised Wall Street yesterday by announcing that it hopes to acquire more military technology operations and that it plans to sharply reduce its payroll in a companywide personnel cutback.   On Wednesday, Honeywell's stock had risen steeply on rumors that drew the opposite conclusion - management supposedly was preparing to sell its computer and military businesses, essentially dismantling the company.   The Minneapolis-based computer and controls company said yesterday that it was negotiating to purchase the much-sought-after aerospace operations of the Sperry Corporation, an acquisition that would make Honeywell a far more potent competitor in the military sector. 4,000 Jobs to Be Cut The company also said that it intended to eliminate about 4,000 jobs by year-end - an apparent response to the industrywide slump that has badly hurt Honeywell's already-ailing computer business. The reductions, affecting about 5 percent of the work force, will be accomplished through attrition, early retirements and layoffs, and will result in a charge of unspecified size against fourth-quarter earnings, the company said.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Heritage Health Plan of Southeastern Pennsylvania, Norristown, Pa., to McKinney Advertising, Philadelphia.    * U.S. Olympic Committee to Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt for public service advertising.

headline: U.S. PRESSES PLAN FOR BLACK ENVOY
abstract: The Reagan Administration pressed ahead urgently today with plans to name Robert J. Brown, a black businessman, as the next Ambassador to South Africa.   ''They are trying to compress in two days what usually takes months, because of the desire to have the nomination announced in a very short period of time,'' one Administration official said. One plan is for Mr. Reagan to announce Mr. Brown's nomination during a policy speech on South Africa next week.   In South Africa today, a court rejected an appeal by a militant labor union to have the country's newest emergency decree overturned as unlawful. But the court softened some of the restrictions so that detainees may now have access to lawyers.  [ Page A6. ]  Brown at State Dept.

headline: Greyhound Unit
abstract: The Greyhound Leasing and Financial Corporation's debt rating is under review, Moody's Investors Service Inc. announced yesterday.

headline: AN INTENT TO KILL DRUG AGENT SEEN
abstract: The Mexican policemen who American officials say tortured a Drug Enforcement Administration agent last week probably intended to kill him, officials close to the investigation of the case said today.   The Mexican Government has flatly denied that the American agent, Victor Cortez Jr., was mistreated.   Officials said Mr. Cortez had reported that while he was blindfolded and being tortured in a jail cell in Guadalajara on Wednesday, one of his captors told him: ''If you think this is bad, wait until we get you out into the country, and you'll see what Camarena went through.''   Enrique Camarena Salazar, another Drug Enforcement Administration agent, was kidnapped in Guadalajara, then tortured and killed, in February 1985.

headline: A SHIFT IN PERSPECTIVE ON RATES
abstract: After a year in which discussions of interest rates focused on how fast they would decline, the bond markets are in turmoil, as some analysts suggest that the downward trend is finished and the next move is toward higher rates.   The debate is far from settled, but last week's sharp decline in bond prices was a clear sign that the fear of higher interest rates is growing. By late Friday, the bellwether 7 1/4 percent Treasury bonds were offered at 95 3/32 to yield 7.68 percent, down from 100 21/32 to yield 7.20 percent as recently as two weeks ago.   Securities dealers agreed that in the last several days there has been increased selling by institutional investors, including some of the ''big names'' whose judgments are widely respected. If others of the 3,500 or so major institutional investors in the country decide to join the ranks of the sellers, traders said, it would be hard to imagine that bond prices could do anything but decline.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Durakon Industries, Lapeer, Mich., said its president, David W. Wright, has resigned.

headline: Squibb to Spin Off Medical Systems
abstract: The Squibb Corporation, a major producer of pharmaceuticals, said it would spin off its medical systems business to shareholders. Squibb's medical systems business had 1985 sales of $200 million.

headline: EATERIES AIM TO ENTERTAIN
abstract: Ed Debevic's is a zany 1950's diner where the cooks heap on the meat loaf, the waitresses wear saddle shoes and a brightly colored sign reads, ''Ed's Chili Dog: The Cadillac of Chili Dogs.'' A half mile south stands Shaw's Crab House, a dimly lit seafood emporium reminiscent of the haunts that gangsters frequented in the 1940's. On the north side of town, Un Grand Cafe, with its brass fixtures and festive paintings, recreates the fin de siecle gaiety of a Paris bistro.   Although very different, these colorful restaurants have two things in common: they usually have lines out the door, and they are owned by Lettuce Entertain You Enterprises, the brainchild of Richard Melman, an irreverent 44-year-old restaurant impresario.   Mr. Melman and his chief rivals on the Chicago scene, Larry and Mark Levy, are among the leaders of a small, aggressive group of young restaurateurs around the nation who are putting together empires of 10 or 20 restaurants that place as much emphasis on fun and fanfare as on food.

headline: Reliance Rebuffed
abstract: A Federal District Court judge in Manhattan yesterday ordered the Reliance Capital Group to release the shares of John Blair & Company it had collected in a tender offer.

headline: PHILIPPINE AID PLAN FACING UNCERTAINTY ON THE SENATE FLOOR
abstract: A new package of economic aid for the Philippines, which the House of Representatives approved Thursday within hours of President Corazon C. Aquino's visit, faces an uncertain future in the Senate.   Unless the problems are resolved early next week, Senate aides said today, there is little chance the $200 million in aid can receive final approval despite support from the Reagan Administration.   Timing is important, because the $200 million must be not only approved but also delivered to the Philippines by Oct. 1, when the new fiscal year begins and stringent budget ceilings become operative. The money the House approved, by a vote of 203 to 197, would be counted as a 1986 expenditure and so would escape the new limitations.

headline: Boeing Up for Contract
abstract: The Boeing Company and the General Electric Company of Britain are the only remaining contenders to build a future airborne early warning system in Britain, it was announced Friday. The two contenders have until early November to come up with final offers before a decision is made by the end of the year. The British eliminated five other contenders, including the Grumman Corporation and the Lockheed Corporation.

headline: Waterhouse Fills Key Post
abstract: Price Waterhouse, a worldwide accounting and tax consulting firm, has named Thomas L. Raleigh Jr. co-chairman of operations and deputy senior partner. Mr. Raleigh, 59 years old, succeeds John W. Zick, who has retired.   As co-chairman, Mr. Raleigh will direct planning and development of the firm's 100 American offices and will be responsible for the national finance and human resources activities.

headline: Advertising; Posey and Quest Add Genova
abstract: FOUNDED in 1979 as Posey & Parry and then going to Posey, Parry & Quest and on to Posey & Quest, the Greenwich, Conn., agency has changed its name once again. This time it reflects the modernists' antipathy to ampersands: Posey Quest Genova.   The name change also serves as a recognition of the work of Joseph Genova, the 44-year-old Sicilian-born art director who has been its executive vice president and creative director for two and a half years. It does not, however, recognize the fact that Chester L. Posey, 63, founder-chairman and importer of the ways of big city advertising to far-off Fairfield County, has retired.

headline: NOW EVEN PIEDMONT FLIES THE FAST LANE
abstract: IN his eight and a half years at Piedmont Airlines, William R. Howard has tried to rub off some of his own grandiose style on the carrier. He is a man of expensive Jamaican cigars and London-tailored suits. He avidly collects motorcycles and antique cars, and sometimes pilots his own plane to the Florida Keys, where he has a second home and a yacht.   For Piedmont, the Howard treatment has had an invigorating effect. Once a tortoise in the industry, it is now resolutely moving into the fast lane. With the best growth rate of all the major airlines, Piedmont has posted an unbroken string of yearly profits since deregulation in 1978, a rare achievement in the troubled airline industry. In the New York area, it has become the third-largest carrier, measured in the number of scheduled flights.   And in the investment world it is ''Hello Piedmont, goodbye People Express.'' The Southeastern carrier has replaced People Express as the analysts' favorite budding airline. They are flooding Wall Street with buy recommendations and Piedmont's stock is hitting new highs. Last week, bloodied People Express in a major retrenchment shut down its money-losing Frontier subsidiary and took it into bankruptcy court after failing to find a buyer.

headline: Chase Credit Card Job To McCaffrey & McCall
abstract: McCaffrey & McCall Direct Marketing has won the advertising account of the Credit Card division of Chase Manhattan Bank after a search that had included 16 agencies.

headline: 2 States Bring Bonds to Market
abstract: The State of California and the State of Washington yesterday brought a total $434 million of general obligation bonds to market through competitive bidding.   California's $250 million issue of general obligation bonds were priced through underwriters led by BankAmerica Capital Markets Group.

headline: HAIR-TRIGGER SUMMER RAISES WORRIES AND QUESTIONS IN DETROIT
abstract: Detroit, which for years has been battling the image of ''murder city,'' is struggling to stem a wave of summer shootings, and officials say they are particularly concerned about a proliferation of pistols used by and against teen-agers.   On a single weekend in August, 59 people were shot, six of them fatally, in a summer of violence that has left people questioning the reasonableness of some of the city's residents.   Reports on the weekend shooting toll have become standard fare in Detroit's daily newspapers, and city high schools have begun searching students for weapons in an effort to curb increasingly violent behavior.   Last week, just hours into the new school year, a 15-year-old boy was shot in the abdomen and critically wounded outside Pershing High School. Two teen-agers were arrested in the incident and another was being sought. And last weekend a 10-year-old boy shot and critically wounded a 10-year-old friend who did not leave when asked.

headline: LITTLE OR NO CHANGE IN PRICES
abstract: Trading in the credit markets was virtually paralyzed for much of yesterday as participants awaited today's report on the second-quarter gross national product and Congressional testimony on Wednesday by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker.   Prices moved in a narrow range and ended the day mixed, with the long bond up 1/32, to 100 30/32, to yield 7.17 percent. The price on the 10-year note was unchanged, at 101 23/ 32, to yield 7.13 percent. Prices of actively traded shorter-term issues were down 2 to 3 basis points. Rates for outstanding six-month bills were unchanged from Friday, at 5.78 percent, while the rate for outstanding three-month bills was up 2 basis points, at 5.73 percent.

headline: Chile Primate Appeals To Top Court on Youths
abstract: Chile's Roman Catholic Primate, Cardinal Juan Francisco Fresno, urged the Supreme Court today to take over the case of two youths burned in anti-Government protests, saying the explanations provided by an investigating judge were insufficient.   One of the youths, Rodrigo Rojas de Negri, 19 years old, a Chilean who had been living in exile in Washington, died.

headline: AIRLINE DEREGULATION DEBATED
abstract: Mounting distress in the airline business, illustrated this week by the shutdown and threatened bankruptcy filing of Frontier Airlines, has revived debate about the wisdom of what was once regarded as the very model of successful deregulation of a major American industry.   Although most analysts still said that the 1978 legislation abolishing 40 years of tight Federal control over fares and routes was sound public policy, even some of deregulation's most ardent supporters have begun to worry that a wave of mergers could result in cartel-like conditions, not unlike those that deregulation was intended to supplant.   There are signs, said Alfred E. Kahn, the man who was deregulation's leading architect as head of the Civil Aeronautics Board, that the industry may be headed toward ''an uncomfortably tight oligopoly.'' Antitrust Efforts    To avoid this, Mr. Kahn said that antitrust enforcement efforts must be stepped up by the Reagan Administration, which he said has been much too willing to approve airline combinations.

headline: Market Place; Streamlining Transamerica
abstract: THE Transamerica Corporation's sale of the Budget Rent a Car Corporation this week marks a major step in the once-unfocused conglomerate's effort to return to its roots in insurance and financial services. But the company may not find any immediate rewards on Wall Street.   Analysts are virtually unanimous in applauding Transamerica's sale of Budget and its plan to sell other nonfinancial businesses. They say the divestment and a return to profitability in the company's property-casualty insurance business should lead to healthy gains in earnings this year and next. But many analysts still remain lukewarm on the stock.

headline: U.S. CLAIMS SUCCESS IN BOLIVIA
abstract: American military and drug-enforcement officials said today that they believed they had stopped cocaine production in Bolivia for at least six months.   Still, a Drug Enforcement Administration official, leading reporters through the only cocaine lab that has been captured, said that ''we are disappointed'' that most of the traffickers apparently found out about the drug raids in advance and vanished into the jungle.   As a result, he said, expectations have been lowered about what the operation can accomplish. The public statement was the first the Americans have made, and it came a week after they arriving here for 60 days of operations against Bolivian drug traffickers.

headline: Relief Trucks Said to Reach War-Torn South Sudan Area
abstract: A convoy of 26 trucks carrying 700 tons of relief food arrived in the southern Sudanese town of Juba Wednesday night, the World Food Program said today.   In a telex from Rome, the United Nations agency said the shipment came from the town of Nimule on the Ugandan border and was the first to reach the south by road since the end of July.

headline: Brazil Rejects Extradition
abstract: Brazil will not agree to Haiti's request that it extradite a former police chief, Albert Pierre, if he could face the death penalty, a Government spokesman said today. Brazil will not extradite a suspect to face a sentence, such as the death penalty, that is not in its penal code, the spokesman said.

headline: Problems Seen In Eastern Bid
abstract: The takeover of Eastern Air Lines Inc. by the Texas Air Corporation has run into problems, industry sources said Friday. They said the Department of Transportation has become concerned about the ability of Pan American World Airways Inc. to mount a viable shuttle service at La Guardia Airport by Oct. 1.

headline: Children's World's Fair To Receive Assistance
abstract: The Children's World's Fair, which will be held Sept. 25-28 in Flushing Meadows Park at the site of the 1964 World's Fair, is getting some advertising assistance from Allied Outdoor and Ad Net. Allied Outdoor is donating billboard space in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx in mid-August, while Ad Net is coordinating the ad campaign, which will begin in magazines early next month.   The fair, which will celebrate the International Year of Peace, is being promoted by CARE, the international relief agency; the United Nations, and the City Parks Department.

headline: 10th Spanish Guard Dies
abstract: A civil guardsman died today of wounds received in a bomb attack on a military bus by Basque separatists, bringing to 10 the number of guards killed by the blast.

headline: G.M.A.C. Markets $400 Million Debt
abstract: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation began offering $400 million of noncallable short-term debt through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

headline: Anderson, Clayton Rejects 2d Offer
abstract: Anderson, Clayton & Company said its board had rejected a sweetened $56-a-share, $679 million buyout bid from Bear, Stearns & Company and Gruss & Company and would continue to pursue a self-tender offer and sale of stock to an employee stock ownership plan. ''The board believes this approach is in the best interests of the stockholders, and has rejected the Bear, Stearns-Gruss proposal because it would require a sale of the company and completely terminate stockholders' interest in the company,'' said W. Fenton Guinee Jr., president and chief executive.   The company also announced that it has obtained the bank commitments it needs and received approval from the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation to remove some excess assets from two retirement plans.

headline: Shasta Names Bloom
abstract: The Bloom Agency of Dallas and New York has become the agency for Shasta Beverages, a division of the National Beverage Company.

headline: PHILANTHROPISTS HONORED BY BRITAIN
abstract: John Paul Getty 2d, right, the American billionaire famed for giving money away, and Bob Geldof, the Irishman who raised $100 million for African famine relief, outside Buckingham Palace yesterday after being awarded honorary knighthoods by Queen Elizabeth II. With them were Mr. Geldof's wife, Paula, left, and Mr. Getty's sister, Donna. As foreigners, they cannot be made full knights. (Reuters)

headline: Hyundai Deal
abstract: The Hyundai Electronics Industries Company has signed a $180 million contract to supply 240,000 sixteen-bit personal computers to Blue Chip Electronics Inc., Hyundai officials said. Delivery will begin in August and continue until the end of 1987.

headline: Dollar in Record Low
abstract: The dollar dropped this morning to 152.95 yen, its lowest level ever against the Japanese currency, dealers here said. It was down sharply from 154.00 yen in New York and 154.10 at the Tokyo close on Friday. The dollar started into a swift slide today in Australia and New Zealand and opened here at 153.20 yen in light trading.

headline: BONN BALKS AT SPURRING ECONOMY
abstract: The West German Finance Minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, issued an unusually stern rebuttal today to demands that Bonn should do more to stimulate its economy, arguing that increased public borrowing would yield only ''a short-lived economic boom.''   Last week, the Economics Minister, Martin Bangemann, took the unusual step of issuing a written statement rejecting pressure, primarily from the United States, to speed economic growth.   ''The key is above all a marked and credible reduction of the United States budget deficit,'' Mr. Bangemann said.

headline: The U.N. Today: Aug. 29, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Law of the Sea, Plenary and Special Commission 3 - 10:30 A.M.

headline: A CARIBBEAN STOP ENDS POPE'S TRIP
abstract: Pope John Paul II, on his way back to Rome from Colombia tonight, paid a seven-hour visit to this Caribbean nation and told its 126,000 people, most of them Roman Catholic, ''to work for the dignity and equality of every human being.''   Earlier in the day the Pope, ending his seven-day visit to Colombia, again appealed to guerrillas to lay down their arms and called drug trafficking ''an abominable crime.''   In a dramatic departure from his prepared remarks during the final Colombian speech in the river port of Barranquilla, the Pope again pleaded with the guerrillas to abandon their armed struggle. He also urged the Government to seek reconciliation.

headline: CHILEAN EDITOR AND TWO OTHERS ARE FOUND SLAIN
abstract: An editor of an opposition magazine banned under Chile's state of siege was found shot to death, the authorities said today. The editor's family said he had been taken from his home Sunday night by armed men in civilian clothes.   Two other men were also found dead, according to human rights workers and relatives, but few details were available on those cases.   After the 38-year-old journalist, Jose Carrasco Tapia, was reported to have been dragged from bed, it was widely believed that he had been detained by Government security forces.

headline: AMERICAN EXPRESS NET IS MORE THAN DOUBLED
abstract: The American Express Company, the giant financial services organization, announced yesterday that its consolidated net income in the second quarter was a record $358.9 million, more than two and a half times its profits of $140.2 million in the corresponding quarter last year.   Net income was bolstered by an after-tax gain of $88 million from its sale of nine million shares of stock in the Fireman's Fund Corporation. Excluding the gain from the stock sale, income was up 93 percent, the company said.

headline: JAILED NICARAGUAN SAYS HE GAVE DATA TO U.S.
abstract: A Nicaraguan businessman, arrested two weeks ago and accused of espionage, said today that he had provided economic information to American officials but that none of the information was secret.   The businessman, Guillermo Quant Tai, appeared at a news conference at the Interior Ministry accompanied by Capt. Oscar Loza, chief of operations for the State Security Agency. Captain Loza asserted that Mr. Quant was working for the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: Arnell/Bickford Agency on the Move
abstract: Do not expect traditional agency behavior or output from Arnell/Bickford Associates. The address is wrong, 100 Grand Street, far from Madison Avenue, in SoHo. The experience and age of the principals are wrong - architecture is what they are out of and Peter Arnell is only 27 years old, while his partner, Ted Bickford, is 29.

headline: Soviet Journalist Vanishes
abstract: Yuri Vereshchagin, a reporter for the Soviet railroad newspaper Gudok, who was on a Mediterranean cruise, has disappeared on a tour of Rome.

headline: ITT REPORTEDLY PLANS BIG LAYOFF IN NEW YORK
abstract: The ITT Corporation, which is in the process of reducing its involvement in telecommunications, will announce within a few weeks that it is trimming its New York headquarters staff by at least half, company sources said yesterday.   The sources, who asked not to be identified, said the multinational telecommunications, insurance and hotel company was in the final stages of identifying which of its approximately 900 New York employees would be affected.   Some of the employees, who range from executives to secretaries, may be granted early retirement, but most of those affected will simply be laid off, the sources said.

headline: DATA BANK: August 24, 1986
NICARAGUA, AT VATICAN, DEFENDS BISHOP'S EXPULSION
abstract: The Nicaraguan Embassy to the Holy See issued a sharply worded statement today defending the Sandinista Government against Vatican charges that it is violating religious freedom. ''The problem is not God,'' the embassy said.   The statement defended the Government's decision to expel Bishop Pablo Antonio Vega, the second most important figure in the Nicaraguan Catholic hierarchy, saying he was punished for his political activities, not his religion.   The embassy's commentary reflected the growing concern of the Sandinistas over the increasingly fierce attacks on their Government by the Vatican and Pope John Paul II himself.

headline: Sharon Steel Reports Loss
abstract: The Sharon Steel Corporation reported on Friday a second-quarter loss of $8 million.

headline: Wanamaker Sale
abstract: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. confirmed today that it might sell its John Wanamaker division, one of the country's oldest department store chains.

headline: CORPORATE PROFITS RISE 4.1%
abstract: After-tax profits of the nation's corporations rose 4.1 percent in the second quarter, reversing a decline in the first three months of the year, the Commerce Department said today.   After-tax profits totaled $140.8 billion at an annual rate in the April-June period.

headline: CONTINUING PROBLEMS FOR COPPER
abstract: Although tentative labor agreements at some copper companies last week eased fears of a strike this summer, the nation's troubled copper companies continue to face a number of problems that analysts and experts say will keep the industry in the doldrums for some time.   A worldwide oversupply of copper persists, continuing to keep prices depressed in spite of the nation's economic recovery. The major exporting countries also continue to churn out huge amounts of copper to help pay their debts. And these major producers -Chile, Peru, the Philippines, Zaire and Zambia - have labor costs that are dramatically lower than those of United States companies and operate on land that has an ore grade that is considered better and less expensive to mine.

headline: BASQUE VOTE SET AFER SCHISM
abstract: The Basque regional government today called early elections amid political turmoil that officials in Madrid said had complicated the fight against Basque separatist terrorists.   The elections, called for Nov. 30, have been caused by a schism in the governing Basque Nationalist Party that the head of the regional government, Jose Antonio Ardanza, said in an address on Basque radio and television had made the region ungovernable.

headline: Reitman Group Names Two New Executives
abstract: Jerry I. Reitman, chairman and chief executive of the two-month-old Reitman Group, a direct response ad agency, has just brought in a president, Steven Stark, who will also be chief operating officer, and Bruce Lee, who will be senior vice president, executive creative director.   Mr. Stark, 45, one-time vice president, marketing, of the Publishers Clearing House, was most recently president of his own company, Resultant Marketing. Mr. Lee, 37, is coming in from Scali, McCabe, Sloves Direct, which he helped to found. Before that he worked for McCann-Erickson Direct and Ogilvy & Mather Direct.

headline: JUSTICE DEPT. BACKS LEGALITY OF FED'S POLICY BODY
abstract: The Justice Department, resolving an evident dilemma, has sided with the Federal Reserve in a dispute over the constitutional legitimacy of the central bank's principal body for making monetary policy.   In a brief filed in Federal District Court late Thursday night, the Department said that the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee is legally constituted, even though five of its 12 members have not been appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate.   ''The F.O.M.C. is not engaged in regulation, but rather implements a public/private mechanism that Congress and the President established to carry out monetary policy,'' the department said. The courts, therefore, should not impose a ''structure that was specifically considered and rejected by Congress'' when the committee was established in its current form half a century ago, the brief said.

headline: Sri Lankan Soldiers Battle the Guerrillas
abstract: Heavy fighting broke out today between soldiers and separatist guerrillas on a northwestern island after the rebels destroyed a bridge to the mainland, military sources and residents said.

headline: Analog Values In Computing
abstract: THERE are analog watches (the ones with the hands) and digital watches, analog phonograph records and digital compact disks. Computers also were once analog and digital. But digital computers won out so overwhelmingly that people no longer bother to say ''digital computer.'' It is simply assumed that a computer is digital. But life may be stirring on the analog side. Scientists are starting to work on futuristic computers that might again make use of analog computing techniques. No one expects analog computing to recapture the mainstream of the computer world, but some think that analog techniques might be better suited for some tasks, such as recognition of objects in computer vision systems, that have so far defied solution by digital techniques.   ''I suspect the computers used in the future will be hybrid designs, incorporating analog and digital,'' said Terrence J. Sejnowski, professor of biophysics at Johns Hopkins University, who notes that the brain also uses a combination of digital and analog processing.

headline: I.B.M. WINS PATENT SETTLEMENT
abstract: Settling a major Silicon Valley patent infringement suit, five former employees of the International Business Machines Corporation agreed yesterday to stop marketing a disk drive system based on key I.B.M. technology.   At the same time, the former employees, founders of the Cybernex Corporation, announced that they were selling Cybernex's disk drive technology operations - virtually all of the company - to the Read-Rite Corporation, a competitor based in Milpitas, Calif. But rather than abandoning its business, Cybernex said it was acquiring a troubled Xerox subsidiary that was also in the disk drive business, marking the third computer-peripheral business unit that Xerox has sold in the past year.

headline: Coseka Oil Write-Down
abstract: Coseka Resources Ltd. said Friday that it would write down the value of oil and gas assets by about $195 million, after tax, to reflect current energy price levels and an accounting change. A company spokesman said the charge would be taken in the third quarter ended Sept. 30. Coseka calculated the write-down under new oil and gas accounting guidelines from the Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants, it said.

headline: BUSH CONSIDERING STOP IN MOROCCO
abstract: The Reagan Administration, seeking to nurture the recent Israeli-Moroccan initiative, tentatively decided today to have Vice President Bush stop in Morocco during a visit to the Middle East.   Aides to Mr. Bush, who left tonight on a 12-day tour of the Middle East, said he was considering adding such a stop, which will likely come at the end of the trip. Mr. Bush is also expected to visit Israel, Jordan and Egypt.   A trip to Morocco would be likely to involve a meeting with King Hassan II and would come only days after the Moroccan leader held talks there with Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel.

headline: Ex-Republic Air Chief To Head Flying Tiger
abstract: Stephen M. Wolf, who took Republic Airlines from the brink of bankruptcy to profitability, has been appointed chairman, chief executive officer and president of Flying Tiger Line in Los Angeles and a director of its parent company.   After yesterday's announcement, Mr. Wolf was at the company's mid-morning executive briefings.

headline: Western Federal Sale
abstract: The New York-based financial services firm Oppenheimer & Company said it planned to try to sell the Western Federal Savings and Loan Association of Marina Del Ray, Calif. Oppenheimer holds a 9.8 percent stake in Western Federal. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Oppenheimer said negotiations to sell the savings and loan had ended.

headline: Greek Quake Toll at 20
abstract: Officials said today that a 65-year-old woman had died of injuries suffered in an earthquake three days ago, bringing the toll to 20. Rescue workers continued to clear rubble and inspect buildings. Authorities said 117 quake victims remained hospitalized.

headline: Norwest Bank Official Will Become Its Chief
abstract: James R. Campbell, president of Norwest Bank Minneapolis, the lead bank of the Norwest Corporation, a holding company, will assume the additional title of chief executive.   Mr. Campbell, a native of Byron, Minn., succeeds W. James Armstrong, 56, who will resign as the bank's chairman and chief executive after completing a restructuring that, Mr. Armstrong said, ''frankly, leaves me in a lesser role as chairman.'' Mr. Armstrong said he would pursue senior management opportunities in banking or financial services.   Under Mr. Armstrong's two years as chairman, Norwest Bank has been hurt by disappointing performances in its commercial banking segment. It has also lost market share in corporate lending to its crosstown rival, First Bank System, analysts said. Norwest is also without a central location after a fire destroyed its headquarters in 1982. Within the last year, Norwest has reorganized its management, consolidating its national, financial institutions and middle market departments under Mr. Campbell.

headline: Iran and Iraq Report Intense Border Fighting
abstract: Iran and Iraq reported today that heavy fighting raged around Mehran, an Iranian border town seized by Iraqi forces six weeks ago.   Iraq said in a statement that an Iranian attempt to retake the town had failed, but that fighting continued.   Iranian communiques later spoke of ''remarkable victories'' by their forces, with hundreds of Iraqi casualties and the destruction of two Iraqi brigade headquarters.

headline: Associated's Merger Terms
abstract: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, saying that the only impediment to a merger with the May Department Stores Company was the price of May stock in an exchange, said yesterday that its board had recommended an exchange ratio of 0.882 share of May for each share of Associated common. That would mean that Associated shareholders would get $69.35 a share in May stock, based on yesterday's New York Stock Exchange closing price for May of $78.625.

headline: Boy George Is Arrested
abstract: The pop singer Boy George was arrested today and charged with heroin possession, the police said. He was later released by Scotland Yard and ordered to appear before a London magistrate on July 29. The 25-year-old singer was said to be undergoing treatment for heroin addiction.

headline: Treasury Sets $28 Billion Sale
abstract: The Treasury Department announced yesterday that it will auction a record $28 billion of 3-year, 10-year and 30-year securities Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday next week at its quarterly refunding, an amount slightly smaller than the credit markets had expected.   The Treasury said that the 3-year notes would be new issues, but that it would reopen - that is, issue more of - the outstanding 7 3/8 percent 10-year notes due May 1996 and 7.25 percent 30-year bonds due May 2016 auctioned at its May refunding, rather than offering new issues of these maturities.   Some dealers said that while this decision might make Japanese investors, who are large holders of the 10-year and 30-year securities, less interested in the auction, it was also likely to mean somewhat greater price stability in what has lately been a very volatile market.   Raymond Stone, chief financial economist for Merrill Lynch Captial Markets, said the composition of the offering - $9.5 billion each for the 3- and 10-year notes and only $9 billion for the 30-year bond - appeared to reflect some concern on the Treasury's part that investor appetite at the long end of the Government bond market might be lacking.

headline: Moscow Sees No Gains At Nuclear Test Talks
abstract: The Soviet delegate at the nuclear test talks here said today that the two sides had been unable to narrow differences.   But the declaration by Andronik M. Petrosyants, chairman of the Soviet State Committee on the Utilization of Atomic Energy, was followed by a statement from the United States delegation calling the talks ''useful.''

headline: Fairchild, Hitachi
abstract: The Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation, a unit of Schlumberger Ltd., said that Hitachi Ltd. of Tokyo had agreed to become the first alternate-source supplier of a new line of Fairchild digital logic circuits. Fairchild, based in Cupertino, Calif., said Hitachi's semiconductor and integrated circuit division would make Fairchild advanced complementary metal oxide semiconductor devices, a type of circuit used where low-power consumption is required. Kirk Pond, executive vice president of Fairchild's digital unit, said that the alliance with Hitachi is expected to give Fairchild an edge in Japan, the largest market for CMOS devices.

headline: Iran Is Reported to Free Soviet Ship After Search
abstract: Iran released a Soviet freighter today after forcing it to an Iranian port and searching it for goods that might aid Iraq's war effort, shipping executives said.   Iranian warships also briefly stopped a second Soviet freighter, the Tutov, but allowed it to continue its trip to an undisclosed Persian Gulf port Wednesday, the executives said.

headline: Mortgage Rates Higher
abstract: Mortgage rates rose between early May and early June, the first increase since September, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said yesterday. The rise reflected generally higher interest rates in the period.

headline: REAGAN REJECTS ZAMBIAN REQUEST
abstract: President Reagan has rejected an invitation from President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia to meet with leaders of black-governed nations near South Africa to discuss the Administration's policy in the region, White House officials said today.   Mr. Kaunda made a public request for such a meeting in late August, saying that talks were needed to discuss a ''humane U.S. policy'' toward southern Africa and ''promote the restoration and development of the countries being strangled by the tentacles of apartheid.''   The Zambian leader also said the African leaders of the so-called front-line nations would be willing to come to Washington to meet with Mr. Reagan if he would not travel to Africa.

headline: 2 Killed in Pakistan In Curfew Attacks
abstract: Security forces opened fire today on curfew violators attacking religious buildings here, killing 2 people and raising the death toll to 12 in two days of clashes between Moslem sects, the Government said.

headline: Grey Gives Mitsubishi 'Associative Visuals'
abstract: Mitsubishi, another of the second-tier Japanese auto imports, also has a new campaign breaking this fall. The campaign, from Grey Advertising, is built around the theme, ''Perfecting the Experience.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JULY 17, 1986
abstract: Companies BankAmerica lost $640 million in the second quarter, hurt by plummeting oil prices. The nation's second-largest bank increased reserves to cover greater-than-expected losses on loans to energy and real estate companies. The loss is the second largest ever for a U.S. bank, after the $1.16 billion deficit at Continental Illinois in the second quarter of 1984. Bank officials and analysts do not see any imminent danger of BankAmerica's failure.  [ Page A1. ]  The Pentagon suspended Litton Industries from bidding for military contracts a day after a subsidiary agreed to plead guilty to 325 counts of fraud involving $6.3 million in overbilling. Litton is the military's 19th-largest contractor.  [ D1. ]  Rates for TV advertising time are being cut, or else raised just moderately, by ABC, CBS and NBC as demand weakens. In the past, the networks were able to command double-digit price increases, so the turnaround comes as a relief to advertisers.  [ D1. ]  May will acquire Associated Dry Goods in a stock exchange valued near $2.7 billion. The new company, with 303 department stores, is expected to have sales of about $9.4 billion.  [ D1. ]  Apple's revenues rose for the first time in five quarters, helped by sales of its Macintosh personal computer, and the company reported a profit. At Burroughs, profits increased 41 percent.  [ D1. ]  Savings executives are attacking rules proposed by the Financial Accounting Standards Board for the accounting for upfront loan charges, including application and origination fees.  [ D2. ]  First Oklahoma is uncertain about its net worth, after being stripped of the First National Bank and Trust.

headline: REAGAN WEIGHING GRAIN-SALE ISSUE
abstract: The White House said today that President Reagan, after a contentious meeting on Monday, was undecided whether to support a Republican-backed Senate bill to allow the sale of subsidized grain to the Soviet Union.   An official said the issue was difficult to resolve in this election year because it pitted the Senate majority leader, Robert Dole of Kansas, who says the subsidies are needed by farmers, against Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who has opposed subsidized exports to the Soviet Union.   The issue has become a major problem because of conflicting domestic political and foreign policy considerations. Neither choice, a White House official said, is ''particularly appealing.''

headline: June Deficit Below May
abstract: The Federal budget posted a $1.01 billion deficit in June, sharply less than the May imbalance because of a large increase in month-to-month tax collections, the Treasury Department said today.

headline: Top Brazilian Official On Environment Resigns
abstract: The head of Brazil's Environmental Protection Agency has resigned after 12 years in his post, citing what he called attempts to curtail the agency's independence.   The former agency chief, Paulo Nogueira Neto, said: ''Resigning was the strongest measure I could take to call attention to a disastrous problem.

headline: Gangster Killed in Naples
abstract: A suspected boss of the Naples Mafia was shot dead today in a crowded fish market, the police said. The man, Matteo Vezzi, 41 years old, died instantly when an unidentified man on a motor scooter fired a pistol at him from close range.

headline: Advertising; 2 Health Aid Accounts Won
abstract: Both Lowe Marschalk Inc., and Saatchi & Saatchi Compton have got assignments that will fit nicely in their medicine cabinets.   For Lowe Marschalk, a joint venture of the Interpublic Group of Companies and Lowe Howard-Spink & Bell of London, the job is coming from Chesebrough-Pond's, which was already on its client list.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Tri-State Honda Dealers Advertising Association to the Earle Palmer Brown Companies, Philadelphia.    * Citizen Watch Company's Consumer Electronics Group to Paul Kaufman Associates for advertising and public relations.

headline: British Aerospace Net
abstract: British Aerospace P.L.C. said today that its first-half profit after an extraordinary charge fell 80 percent, to $:12.5 million, or $18.8 million at current exchange rates, from $:62.1 million a year earlier.   The company, which makes aircraft, satellites and other aerospace equipment for commercial and military customers, said the figures include a one-time after-tax charge of $:44.1 million, representing the estimated costs of the termination of manufacturing at the company's plant in Weybridge, England.

headline: Bear Stearns Net Off 38.7%
abstract: The Bear Stearns Companies reported yesterday that it had net income of $19 million in the first quarter that ended July 25, a 38.7 percent decline from $31 million in the 1985 period.   The securities firm said that earnings per share fell to 23 cents, from 37 cents, and that revenues slipped to $499.7 million, from $565.2 million.

headline: Ashton-Tate 'Mac' System
abstract: Ashton-Tate, the leading vendor of data management programs for personal computers, will introduce on Monday its first product for Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh computer.   The product, known as dBase Mac, will be a database management system priced at $495 and available in the fourth quarter of the year.

headline: Advertising; The Fourth Generates Big Plans
abstract: IF there is an event around at which it is possible to entertain, you can bet you'll find media people with advertising prospects in tow. And since this Fourth of July weekend is turning out to be the granddaddy of such events, it has generated some big thoughts among wine buyers.   ''It would be easier telling you who isn't entertaining than who is,'' said Joseph W. Ostrow, the executive vice president of Young & Rubicam, overstating the case out of boyish enthusiasm.   The most popular entertainment medium certainly seems to be the Independence Day boat ride. Its particular asset is that a single boat chartered for the day can be used twice, once for a luncheon and viewing tall ships and the other for dinner and fireworks oohing.

headline: Seoul Charges 154 Students; Leftists Facing Crackdown
abstract: Prosecutors said today that 154 students had been charged with trying to topple the Government of President Chun Doo Hwan.   The Government has been cracking down on radicals before the Asian Games that are scheduled to open in Seoul on Sept. 20.

headline: Market Place; Honeywell's Prospects
abstract: WHEN the Burroughs Corporation was pursuing the rival Sperry Corporation last spring, one rumor came up time and again on Wall Street. A deal was brewing between Sperry and Honeywell Inc., the gossip said.   In the months since, Burroughs has succeeded in winning over Sperry and nothing more was heard about Honeywell's involvement. That is, until last Friday, when it was disclosed that Sperry had offered to buy Honeywell at a price in the neighborhood of $5 billion. That amounted to $105 a share for a stock that was then selling at about $76 a share and which yesterday was down $1.25, to $71.75.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Chemical New York Corporation has named George V. Grune, chairman and chief executive of the Reader's Digest Association, to its board, as well to the board of its principal subsidiary, Chemical Bank.    * Equimark Corp., Pittsburgh, a bank holding company, announced that Mark A. Mendelson had submitted his resignation as director of the corporation, as well as from the board of the proposed new subsidiary of Equimark, Equibank (Delaware), to devote time to other business matters.    * Harvard Industries, a designer and manufacturer of engineered products and systems, has announced the following new directors: Harold S. Geneen, chairman emeritus of ITT Corporation; John W. Culligan, chairman and chief executive of American Home Products, and John B. Curcio, chairman and chief executive of Mack Trucks.

headline: SANDINISTA HEADS WEST AFTER A 6-DAY WOOING OF NEW YORK
abstract: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua left New York City yesterday, bound for Denver and an appearance at the convention of the National Bar Association, after six days of intensive diplomacy that found him pressing the Sandinista case and cause in settings as diverse as the United Nations and the Brooklyn waterfront.   Officially, Mr. Ortega was in New York to urge the United Nations to support a decision by the International Court of Justice calling on the United States to stop ''arming and training'' anti-Sandinista rebels, known as contras. But he spent as much time here appealing directly to the court of American public opinion, bypassing an Administration in Washington that has dismissed him as ''a dictator in designer glasses.''   Those extraofficial efforts included such unconventional forays as a Sunday stroll along the promenade in Brooklyn Heights. There, after attending services at a Methodist church in Park Slope, he posed for photographers with the Statue of Liberty in the background as passing joggers looked on in astonishment.

headline: Hafts Agree to End Bid for Safeway
abstract: The Haft family of Washington agreed yesterday to drop its hostile takeover bid for Safeway Stores, but Wall Street sources said that the family's Dart Group Corporation had won the right to buy as many as 500 Safeway stores in the Washington and Los Angeles areas.   If the Hafts decide to buy the stores, the cost could run as high as $1 billion, sources said. The deal would give the family control of a fourth of Safeway's supermarkets in the country, including all the Safeway stores east of the Mississippi.

headline: POWER FAILURE BRINGS JITTERS AT RITES FOR BENIGNO AQUINO
abstract: A vast power blackout on the anniversary of the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. sent a tremor of apprehension through Manila tonight.   In an unusual response to a power failure, which is not uncommon here, the armed forces announced over the radio that troops had been put on alert and that there was no cause for alarm. Officials said police checkpoints had been set up around Manila.   Much of the island of Luzon, including the capital of Manila, was blacked out for up to five hours, with power returning in stages to different areas.

headline: ATOMIC TEST PLAN HAS NEW ELEMENTS
abstract: President Reagan's address to the United Nations today marks a significant shift in the United States position on nuclear testing, American officials said.   For the first time, Mr. Reagan said that an arms control pact could include new limits on nuclear testing. But, the officials noted, he set two conditions.

headline: West German Paper Predicts Sakharov-Mandela Exchange
abstract: The West German newspaper Bild said today that Andrei D. Sakharov, the banished Soviet physicist, and Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned South African black leader, would be freed as part of an East-West prisoner exchange.   Bild said President Francois Mitterrand, who arrived in Moscow today, would go over the details of the arrangement.   The newspaper, which in February was the first to announce the release of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Soviet dissident, has been speculating about a Sakharov-Mandela exchange for several months.

headline: G.M. Plans to End Chevette in 1987
abstract: The General Motors Corporation will stop building its subcompact Chevrolet Chevette next year and will shift production of the full-size Chevrolet Caprice from Detroit to the Chevette plant in Lakewood, Ga.

headline: INVESTING; AFTER WALL STREET'S LATEST JOLT
abstract: DESPITE a torrid East Coast heat wave early last week, a sudden, scary chill hit Wall Street. After watching the market set record highs the previous week, traders knocked almost 62 points off the Dow Jones industrial average last Monday. The slide continued on Tuesday, as the Dow lost another 18 points.  While the market recovered somewhat in the latter part of the week, investors were stunned. When one money manager was asked what he thought the market might do next, he said meekly, ''I don't have a clue.'' And some began asking whether the declines Monday and Tuesday signaled the close of this unprecedented bull market.

headline: U.S. WHEAT HELP FAILS TO SPEED SOVIET BUYING
abstract: Two weeks after President Reagan authorized the sale of subsidized wheat to the Soviet Union, Moscow has not yet purchased a single bushel of grain from American traders, the Department of Agriculture said today.   Traders had hoped for quicker results.   Administration officials said today that they expected the Soviet Union to take weeks to decide whether to complete a deal. The sale was a way the White House answered critics who said the Administration was ignoring farmers, even though President Reagan would prefer not to sell subsidized wheat to the Russians.

headline: Chris-Craft Discloses Stock Plan
abstract: Chris-Craft Industries announced a recapitalization plan yesterday that would allow it to issue additional common stock with minimal effect on voting control of the company.   Chris-Craft, which is mainly involved in television broadcasting, authorized a new class B common stock and the distribution of two class B common shares for each outstanding common share.

headline: PRODUCER PRICE INDEX UP SLIGHT 0.3%
abstract: A key Government price gauge rose a moderate three-tenths of 1 percent in August, a smaller-than-expected increase that reassured many economists about prospects for avoiding a surge in inflation.   A fear of accelerating inflation contributed importantly to this week's turmoil in the financial markets.   The rise in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, only the second advance so far this year, was a result of continued sharp increases for food that were not entirely offset by declines in the price of heating oil and gasoline. Economists Express Relief    The Labor Department's report brought expressions of relief from economists, most of whom had expected the index to show a considerably higher increase. Moreover, because of widely circulated rumors that the rise would be five-tenths of 1 percent, the report dispelled Government concern that there had been premature disclosure of official data.

headline: Sperry Sought Honeywell
abstract: During its fight earlier this year to remain independent, the Sperry Corporation offered to acquire its rival, the Honeywell Corporation, one of the nation's largest computer makers, for $105 a share, or nearly $5 billion.

headline: Ryan Sought By NVHomes
abstract: NVHomes L.P., a Virginia-based partnership that builds and sells family homes and condominiums, said today that it plans a $45-a-share tender offer for Ryan Homes Inc.   NVHomes, which is looking to increase its market share in the Middle Atlantic States and Washington, D.C., area, said that it already owns a 6.7 percent stake, or 465,900 shares, in Ryan, which it purchased in August, making today's offer for the remaining shares worth about $292 million.

headline: Investors Extend Conrail Offer
abstract: A group of 42 investors, whose $1.4 billion offer for the Government-owned Conrail freight railroad was to expire today, said it was extending its bid and that Congress should act to accept it while market conditions were ripe. Morgan Stanley & Company, the syndicate's organizer, said Conrail's success and the solid stock market performance made this the right time for Congress to finally unload the railroad.

headline: New Electronic Data Service
abstract: The New York Times Syndication Sales Corporation, a subsidiary of The New York Times Company, and Covidea, a partnership of several financial, communications and media companies, yesterday introduced an electronic information service intended for use by consumers in the New York area.   The service, called New York Pulse, was developed by the Times Company over the last two years, according to Jeffrey L. Eisberg, the president and general manager of New York Pulse.

headline: Your Money; Fixed-Income Stock Play
abstract: NEW stock market-linked debt securities that give individual investors the assurance of a fixed income, along with the potential for capital appreciation, have made an appearance in the American financial markets.   The securities, traded on the New York Stock Exchange, have the ponderous name of Salomon Inc. 2 Percent Standard & Poor's 500 Index Subordinated Notes Due 1990. But they are generally known on Wall Street by the acronym SPIN's. The joint underwriters last month were Salomon and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

headline: ZULUS, TORN TWO WAYS, SEEK MIDDLE GROUND
abstract: Felix Nzama relaxed on the covered porch of his home above the curls of the Tugela River and mused a little on the nation's miseries and confrontations.   Sometimes, he said earlier this year, youthful militants from the cities would come to the hills and valleys of his home at Jameson's Drift, in a land populated by people of Zulu ethnic descent. And sometimes, he said, they would try to inflame the passions of rural scholars in the same way the emotions of young black people in the cities have ignited protest.   But then, he said, with a small smile, ''Soon they find that the wind, in Zululand, blows too strongly for them.''   In other words, he and people like him did not approve of such disruption and, with stern discipline, would seek to quell it.

headline: NO END IN SIGHT FOR BASQUE TERRORISM
abstract: A recent surge in terrorism by the Basque separatist group E.T.A. has underlined how the 18-year-old group remains one of the most effective and elusive terrorist organizations in Europe and a thorn for Spain's young democracy.   An army colonel was shot and killed near here this month. Since mid-July, 12 members of the paramilitary Civil Guard were killed by a car bomb in Madrid, an E.T.A. squad staged a grenade attack against the Defense Ministry and two guardsmen were killed by a booby-trap bomb near this Basque industrial city.   According to the police, 32 people have died in E.T.A. attacks since the beginning of the year.   Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, vowing to wipe out E.T.A., has counterattacked with increased police force, offers of limited amnesty and heightened cooperation from France in handing back terrorist suspects and closing an E.T.A. sanctuary there.

headline: Northern Trust
abstract: The Northern Trust Corporation, the fourth-largestbank holding company in Illinois, said that it had acquired the First Lake Forest Corporation, the holding company of three suburban banks, for $61.9 million in cash. The acquisition gives Northern Trust a strong position in the lucrative Lake County area, north of Chicago along Lake Michigan. The Lake Forest Corporation, which has $419 million in assets, owns the First National Bank of Lake Forest, the Lake Forest National Bank and the First National Bank of Lake Bluff.

headline: Church of England Delays Vote on Women
abstract: The Church of England, faced with a report warning that the 450-year-old church could be split if women are ordained as priests, decided today to postpone action on the issue for at least six months.   The General Synod, the church's 574-member policy-making body, voted by what appeared to be a unanimous show of hands to have the college of bishops study the report and reach a conclusion before the next synod meeting, set for February.

headline: BOLIVIA SAYS ITS DRIVE ON COCAINE WILL GO ON UNTIL TRADE IS ENDED
abstract: The Bolivian Interior Minister announced today that drug raids about to begin here with assistance from the United States military would continue until the drug trade was wiped out in Bolivia.   The official, Fernando Barthelemy, said American troops would provide support for the raids for as long as necessary.   About 100 American troops in combat gear and carrying weapons, including M-16 rifles, arrived today in Trinidad, Bolivia, airlifted from American bases in Panama. Trinidad, in the Beni region of north central Bolivia, is the heart of the nation's cocaine-producing region.

headline: Short-Order Planning for the Masses
abstract: AS part of their push to become one-stop financial ''supermarkets,'' New York's largest banks and savings and loan associations have been offering customers a wide variety of nonbank products such as mutual funds, discount brokerage and insurance. Now many banks are going one step further by providing financial planning advice to help customers reconcile these investment opportunities with their financial needs.   Such financial counseling has long been available to the banks' wealthiest customers, albeit at a hefty price. Irving Trust, for instance, provides planning help to customers with more than $1 million in assets - for a fee of $3,000 to $5,000. The new services, however, are tailored to a different market: middle-income New Yorkers who need basic assistance in budgeting, minimizing taxes, purchasing insurance and investing for retirement. ''Traditionally, financial planning has been something for the wealthy,'' explained Chemical Bank spokesman Kenneth B. Herz. ''Now it's available to the masses.''

headline: Likely Fairview Buyers Include the Reichmanns
abstract: The wealthy Reichmann family is widely considered here to be the most likely buyer of the Cadillac Fairview Corporation, a move that would create an enormously powerful force in North American real estate.   The Reichmanns already own 26 percent of Cadillac Fairview. Cemp Investments Ltd., a family trust of the heirs to the Seagram liquor fortune of Samuel Bronfman, said Wednesday it had decided to sell its 50 percent interest in Cadillac Fairview.

headline: Newmont Mining
abstract: The Newmont Mining Corporation said yesterday that it has adopted a plan to recapitalize its Magma Copper Company unit.

headline: HELMUT SCHMIDT'S VALEDICTORY: AS BITING AS EVER
abstract: Former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt gave his last speech today to the West German Parliament, a chamber he has graced with his oratorical power and acerbic wit for 33 years.   Someone figured out that Mr. Schmidt had spoken to Parliament more than 500 times; his first salvo as a young Social Democratic legislator from Hamburg was aimed at the Postal Minister on Jan. 21, 1954.   Mr. Schmidt's discourse today was a national event, a spoken testament by a man who even out of power remains the country's most popular politician.   It was, formally, just another speech in a windy budget debate, a partisan event that elicits flashes of rhetoric meant for the television cameras and the evening news programs. But for Mr. Schmidt, who will not be running for Parliament in elections that will be held Jan. 25, it was farewell.

headline: AMERADA, TENNECO OFF
abstract: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, said yesterday that its net income for the second quarter, helped partly by improved margins for petroleum products and chemicals, rose 50.3 percent.   However, excluding a special $545 million write-down in the 1985 quarter, Exxon's earnings would have fallen 11 percent.   Two other oil companies -Amerada Hess and Tenneco Inc. -posted sharp declines in quarterly earnings, reflecting the effect of the steep collapse in oil prices.

headline: Quaker Deal Final
abstract: The Quaker Oats Company has completed the previously announced $275 million purchase of the Golden Grain Macaroni Company, whose brands include Rice-A-Roni, Noodle-Roni, Golden Grain and Mission pasta, Ghirardelli chocolate and Vernell candy.

headline: Allied-Signal Deal
abstract: Allied-Signal Inc. said it had agreed to buy Endevco, a unit of Becton Dickinson & Company, for an undisclosed price.

headline: COSTA RICA GETS TOUGHER ON CONTRAS
abstract: President Oscar Arias says that despite the likelihood of increased fighting between the Nicaraguan Government and United States-backed rebels in the region he is determined to prevent this country from being used as a base for foreign military operations.   Mr. Arias, who took office in May, vowed to do all he could to insure that anti-Sandinista rebels do not operate from Costa Rican territory. He said he had already dismissed some officials suspected of tolerating activity by the rebels, who are known as contras.   Costa Rica shares a long border with Nicaragua, and bands of contras have in the past set up bases on both sides. The main anti-Sandinista force is based along Nicaragua's northern border with Honduras.

headline: At Least Two Investors Report Stakes in Viacom
abstract: Several investors reported large stakes in Viacom International yesterday, a development that may impede a $2.7 billion buyout bid from a group led by the senior management of the diversified entertainment and communications concern.   Coniston Partners, a New Jersey-based investment group led by Keith Gollust, Paul Tierney and Augustus Oliver, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it owned 12.4 percent of Viacom International. At the same time National Amusements, one of the nation's largest movie theater owners, filed an amended 13-D form with the S.E.C. that said it had raised its own stake in the company to 9.9 percent from 8.7 percent.

headline: U.N. Reports Accord On Sudan Relief Flights
abstract: The United Nations has reached a tentative agreement with Sudanese rebels that could allow resumption of food aid flights into the beseiged city of Wau in the southern Sudan by the end of this week, United Nations officials said today.   Under the agreement, a chartered Hercules 130 transport will be able to fly grain and other supplies into the city, which has been cut off from any relief efforts since August.

headline: 'Liars' Get Attention For Isuzu
abstract: JERRY DELLA FEMINA cannot stand most automobile commercials.   ''Today's automobile advertising might be the worst type of advertising I've seen in years,'' the chairman of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners said. 'It's just one big cliche after another.''   Surprising words coming from a man whose agency handles a $30 million automotive account, American Isuzu. But he can afford to lambaste the hackneyed techniques of most car commercials because his shop has come up with a campaign for Isuzu that turns the cliches on their heads.

headline: DOLLAR HITS LOW LEVEL VS. YEN
abstract: With the dollar falling to the lowest level against the Japanese yen since the late 1940's, gold bullion prices soared to a two-year high in active trading yesterday.   At the close of New York's Commodity Exchange, the world's biggest gold futures market, bullion for delivery in August jumped $10.70 an ounce, to $362.70, the highest level since July 3, 1984.   The dollar's decline was touched off by remarks made Wednesday night by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who suggested that the currency was overvalued. With the dollar so weak, investors sought greater stability in gold.

headline: Water Utility's Sharp Growth
abstract: IT is no secret that electric and telephone utilities have fared handsomely in a stock market environment partial to companies with rising dividends. But another regulated industry - the water utilities - has turned in a stellar performance amid little fanfare.   Yesterday, shares of the American Water Works Company traded at a record price of 44 1/2, before closing at 43 1/2, down 1/4, on the Big Board. Adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in early 1985, its shares -and dividends - have been climbing steadily for a number of years. The stock sold as low as 13 1/2 in 1984 and earlier changed hands at 6 1/4 in 1982. It has outdistanced many blue chips over the course of the bull market.

headline: CHRISTIAN MILITIA FOILS BEIRUT RAID
abstract: Christian militiamen, reportedly backed by units of the Lebanese Army, have foiled an attempt by pro-Syrian militiamen to seize control of the predominantly Christian sector of Beirut.   The police said 52 people were killed and 200 wounded in the fighting on Saturday, when rival militiamen fought pitched street battles for 13 hours.   Artillery duels were reported today across the Green Line dividing the predominantly Christian eastern sector of the capital from the mostly Moslem west. Shells and rockets fell in residential quarters close to the line, but it was not clear which forces were involved.

headline: BUSH ABANDONS PLANS TO VISIT MOROCCO DURING MIDEAST TRIP
abstract: Vice President Bush abandoned plans today to visit Morocco after receiving no encouragement from King Hassan II for the trip, Bush aides said.   Mr. Bush's decision came despite urging by Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel that he make the trip. Mr. Bush's aides had expected a Morocco visit to be a major event in his trip to the Middle East.   Mr. Bush spent today sightseeing in the old walled city and also met with Anatoly Shcharansky, the human rights activist.

headline: CBS Trading Examined
abstract: The investigative staff of the Chicago Board Options Exchange has examined on four occasions during the past year unusual activity in the trading of options in CBS Inc. stock, a spokesman for the exchange said today.   Warren Moulds, the spokesman, said that, beginning last February, the exchange noticed unusually high levels of trading in CBS options and asked its investigative staff to look into the matter.

headline: TEAMS FORMING TO SEEK LARGE U.S. JET CONTRACT
abstract: Two teams of aerospace industry giants are forming to seek an Air Force contract for the next generation of fighter aircraft, the companies said today.   The Boeing Company, the General Dynamics Corporation and the Lockheed Corporation announced today that they would cooperate in an effort to obtain the project known as the Advanced Tactical Fighter.   The Northrop Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation are in ''serious discussions'' to form a competing team, officials of the companies said.

headline: Reliance Capital
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission rejected a request from the Reliance Capital Group to establish a voting trust to simplify its acquisition of John Blair & Company, a diversified media concern based in New York. If the trust had been approved, Reliance would have been able to operate Blair while the F.C.C. formally reviewed the transfer of Blair's broadcasting licenses. The F.C.C. also ruled that Reliance did not violate any commission statutes by accepting about 10.5 million Blair common shares.

headline: Nicaragua Lifts Its Ban On Political Gatherings
abstract: Nicaragua's Government temporarily lifted a ban today on unauthorized political rallies and partly suspended press censorship in response to calls from the opposition for a more democratic debate on the country's new constitution.

headline: Chile Holds 3 Suspects In Assassination Attempt
abstract: Security agents have arrested three people for questioning in the attempted assassination of President Augusto Pinochet this month in which five of his bodyguards were killed, a prosecutor announced today.

headline: U.S. SAYS IT WARNED MARCOS ABOUT INSTIGATING TROUBLE IN MANILA
abstract: The Reagan Administration said today that former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines had been warned that his efforts to undermine the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino were ''inconsistent with his status as a guest in the United States.''   It said Mr. Marcos, who is in exile in Hawaii, should realize that he ''is part of the past of Philippine politics'' and should stop trying to instigate trouble.   But officials said there were no plans to deport Mr. Marcos because no government was willing to take him.

headline: MERRILL LYNCH'S LONDON BLITZ
abstract: For the American brokerage giant Merrill Lynch & Company, the Big Bang has meant recruiting a large team for the assault on the British stock and government-bond markets.   Merrill Lynch considered but quickly rejected acquiring a sizable British brokerage house. Instead, Merrill set about buying people rather than firms. By now, it has assembled a team 200-strong, making Merrill the biggest player in the London domestic markets among the American brokers and investment banks.

headline: Tax Simplicity: Design vs. Use
abstract: DRIVING a car with an automatic transmission is simpler than driving with a standard transmission, though in design the standard transmission is the simpler of the two. It is in use that the automatic transmission is simpler.   This observation is relevant to tax revision because recent discussions about the overhaul of the system have confused simplicity of design with simplicity of use. Tax reformers should be concerned with fairness and simplicity of use. And they might find that complexity of design is often the best way to achieve those goals.

headline: 8 Tamil Rebels Killed in Boat
abstract: At least eight Tamil rebels were killed Friday when a navy vessel fired at a guerrilla boat off Sri Lanka's east coast, the Government said today.

headline: Chinese Goods Ordered
abstract: Chinese beer and toys are most in demand by American buyers attending this week's China trade exposition here. ''Quite a number of deals have been made,'' said the show's director, Pasteur Lai of Lein Tai Hong Ltd., based in Hong Kong.

headline: U.S. AND BOLIVIANS MOUNT JOINT RAID ON A COCAINE LAB
abstract: United States and Bolivian forces today undertook the first of several planned drug raids.   The purpose of the raids, American and Bolivian officials said, is to disrupt the cocaine trade by putting cocaine processors out of business. That, they said, would make it less profitable for Bolivian farmers to grow coca, from which cocaine is produced.

headline: SPANIARDS FEAR AN INFLUX OF ARAB TERRORISTS
abstract: The crackdown in France on Arab-related terrorism has raised fears in Spain that many suspected Arab terrorists are shifting their bases here, Spanish officials said.   Spanish officials have tightened border controls and even begun to impose curbs on the many thousands of North Africans who go through Spain to France each year.   To avoid having any of the North Africans turned back at the French border and remain in Spain, Spanish officials are enforcing French visa requirements at the Strait of Gibraltar and other ferry points.   At the same time, the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez has publicly pledged full intelligence cooperation with the conservative French Government of Prime Minister Jacques Chirac. A Spanish Deputy Interior Minister was in Paris this week seeking to cement the relationship.

headline: PRETORIA EXPELS LUTHERAN PASTOR
abstract: A Lutheran minister, ordered expelled by the South African Government, left Johannesburg yesterday after being detained at the airport by the police, who apparently wanted to insure that he got on his plane to New York, sources in South Africa said.   The minister, the Rev. Brian Burchfield, had been served with a deportation order on Saturday. No reason was given for his expulsion.

headline: Reader's Digest Officer
abstract: The Reader's Digest Association, the magazine publisher, said yesterday that Richard F. McLoughlin, 57 years old, would become president and chief operating officer at year-end. Now vice chairman, he will replace William J. Cross, who is retiring but will remain on the board.

headline: Encore Contract
abstract: The Encore Computer Corporation said it had been awarded a contract to develop a powerful parallel-processing computer architecture for the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency. It said the contract is worth $10.7 million over three years and calls for a prototype computer system that can execute one billion instructions a second.

headline: Dealing a One-Two Punch to Growth
abstract: THE euphoria on Capitol Hill about the benefits of tax reform is a rare bipartisan phenomenon that should make an economist reluctant to play the traditional role of wet blanket. But, alas, that is the destiny of our profession. Stepping back from the details of the 1986 tax reform bill and focusing on the big picture, it is evident that the impending changes in the Internal Revenue Code will depress the economy.   True, most individual and family taxpayers will pay less in Federal taxes. But, simultaneously, the ''revenue neutral'' tax bill will shift $120 billion of Federal taxes to business over the next five years. Politically, that is a neat switch. Our political representatives can first crow about cutting our taxes and then sympathize when prices rise more rapidly or when wages rise more slowly as companies adjust to the higher tax burden. The economic problem is that taxes are being raised on savings and investment, key ingredients for economic growth and job creation.

headline: THE DAILY NEW'S LATEST BIND
abstract: James Hoge, the publisher of The Daily News, describes his newspaper's predicament in stark tabloid style. ''Survival is at stake,'' he declared in a letter to employees last month, ''and there is no time to lose.''   Mr. Hoge does have his problems. Faced with a persistent erosion in circulation, an ever tougher competition in covering the news, and now the loss of $11 million in department store advertising - the kind that pays the rent - he is trying to keep The News alive in a saturated market where true prosperity can likely come only by knocking out a competitor.   Part of Mr. Hoge's strategy is a renewed effort to bring in additional advertising. But he has also warned employees that costs must be cut, and jobs will go. As some union leaders see it, the publisher is accentuating the paper's difficulties to soften them up for coming contract negotiations, in which The News is certain to seek concessions from unionized workers.

headline: MODERN JAPAN, LAND OF SUPERSTITION
abstract: It all looks easy for Japan's governing party now that it has won a smashing victory at the polls. But when party leaders scheduled national elections for last Sunday they were testing the fates as well as the political waters.   Any of them could have looked at a calendar and realized right off that it was the worst possible day for such a significant undertaking.   Millions of Japanese, politicians included, put full faith in a lunar-year system borrowed long ago from China, a six-day cycle of lucky days, unlucky days and so-so days, when good fortune may come in the morning only to disappear in the afternoon.

headline: A Travelers Account
abstract: Another account in almost the same billings area is Travelers Mortgage Services of Cherry Hill, N.J., a subsidiary of the Travelers, which has dropped its account at Grey Advertising. The former agency as Morgan, Cohen & Naish of Philadelphia.

headline: Advertising; Ex-Revlon Associates' Venture
abstract: SANFORD BUCHSBAUM, a leading citizen of adland, and Martin Stevens, his longtime associate at Revlon and a frequently lauded creative man, will be doing something they have been talking about for some time now, opening an agency of their own.   Stevens & Buchsbaum is its name. Aug. 1 is its opening date. The location, however, is still up in the air. But that doesn't matter so much since there are already a couple of clients, and that's what keeps the cogs greased.

headline: Economic Calendar
