abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

headline: RUSH ON '86 DEDUCTIONS, DELAYS ON INCOME SEEN
abstract: The proposed tax bill is likely to touch off both a rush by individuals in the coming months to qualify for more tax deductions than usual this year and a search for ways they can defer income until 1987.   Nearly all of the bill's provisions affecting individuals take effect Jan. 1.   ''People typically tend to accelerate deductions and postpone income,'' said Ira H. Shapiro, the director of tax policy at Coopers & Lybrand, an accounting firm. ''But in this environment it becomes even more important, because the tax rate is higher this year than it will be next year for most people and also because there are a lot of deductions that will either be repealed or limited next year.''   For the most part, the compromise bill agreed to by Congressional tax conferees Saturday night did not surprise financial consultants, who have spent months constructing possible scenarios for their clients. But after months of uncertainty, the legislation has reached final form, and taxpayers can now begin to take substantive action.

headline: NAKASONE'S FATE RESTS ON VOTE TODAY
abstract: Cruising campaign sound trucks ended their relentless blare tonight as Japan prepared for unusual simultaneous elections on Sunday for both houses of Parliament.   Attention was focused mainly on the decision-making lower chamber, where every major poll suggested that the governing Liberal Democratic Party would strengthen its hold on power and could even manage a landslide victory.   To a large degree, the dimension of that presumed victory has become the dominant issue. The lineup in the new House of Representatives will decide power relationships within the governing party and determine whether Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone can survive in office or must give way to one of three so-called ''new leaders'' waiting to take charge.

headline: Market Place; Seeking Curbs On Volatility
abstract: STILL stunned by the stock market debacle of Sept. 11 and 12 that was caused in part by program trading of stock index futures and options, traders in New York and Chicago, where most futures and options contracts are traded, are divided about what can or should be done to avoid a repeat of the impact.   The topic continued to be aired this week as discussion centered both on the effect on last Friday's ''triple witching hour'' of the Securities and Exchange Commission's voluntary experiment to curb volatility and a report in The New York Times yesterday that the commission was considering a number of new approaches. These include limiting the number of index options an investor can hold at any one time and raising margin requirements.   None of those interviewed yesterday said that the issue, which has been under scrutiny by the S.E.C. for some months, should be abandoned.

headline: Storage Proposes Reorganization
abstract: The Storage Technology Corporation has filed a reorganization plan in Bankruptcy Court that would repay about $800 million in debt to 8,500 creditors. Under the plan, the maker of computer memory storage devices would repay the debts with $140 million in cash, $285 million in 10-year notes and 196 million shares of newly issued stock valued at $375 million.

headline: DOLLAR CLIMBS AGAIN; BONN REPORTS ARE CITED
abstract: The dollar moved higher against the West German mark again yesterday in brisk, nervous trading on the foreign exchange markets.   By late in the day, the dollar, which rose by about 2 percent against the mark to open the week, had appreciated by another 1 percent, to 2.0535.   Gold prices fell sharply as traders chose to take profits. In New York gold was at $431 an ounce, down $9 from Monday.

headline: Oklahoma Bank Fails
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said Friday that the Citizens National Bank and Trust Company of Oklahoma City had failed, the 90th bank to fail this year. The bank's deposits of $157.5 million have been transferred to the Liberty National Bank and Trust Company of Oklahoma City.

headline: Market Place; How the Funds Did in Quarter
abstract: THE nation's two top-performing mutual funds in the second quarter had one thing in common: They rode to stardom chiefly on the soaring price of Home Shopping Network Inc., the ''hottest'' new issue of this year. Home Shopping, a cable television retailer, went public on May 13 at $18 a share and closed on June 30 at $95.375 on the American Stock Exchange.   ''Home Shopping was the dramatic event for us,'' acknowledged G. Kenneth Heebner, portfolio manager of Zenith Fund-Capital Growth, a Boston-based fund that posted a total return of 38.28 percent for the latest three months. ''That stock is 20 percent of our portfolio.''

headline: In Europe, Their Reception Is Bleak
abstract: Some 50,000 Tamil refugees have made their way from Sri Lanka to Western Europe in the last five years by elaborate air routes that sometimes include covert passage in trains or in cars that slip across frontiers at night.   These mostly Hindu refugees, fleeing a separatist insurgency and shrinking economic horizons in Sri Lanka, are but one group of refugees to leave troubled third-world nations for Western Europe.   But the Tamils have the unhappy distinction of being perhaps the least welcome. A culturally alien group that has swiftly appeared in Europe in great numbers, the Tamils are generally regarded as a problem best dealt with by the police and border authorities. They linger in a debilitating legal limbo, usually without work and uncertain of their future.

headline: WOMAN CHOSEN TO HEAD JAPAN SOCIALIST PARTY
abstract: In this country where politics is virtually an all-male preserve, a woman was chosen today for the first time to head a major party.   Takako Doi, a Member of Parliament since 1969, was overwhelmingly elected chairman of the main opposition force, the Socialist Party. The position will give her great prominence but perhaps just as much frustration.   The Socialists, a declining influence in recent years, have been rudderless since early July, when they suffered their worst defeat ever in a national election. In Parliament's decision-making lower house, they won a record low total of 86 seats, while the long-governing Liberal Democratic Party surged to a record high of 304.

headline: VATICAN REPORT THREATENS PRO-CHOICE NUNS
abstract: The Vatican today formally threatened to take disciplinary action against two American nuns who signed an advertisement during the 1984 presidential campaign supporting the right of Roman Catholics to dissent from the church's opposition to abortion.   In a statement, the Vatican office that deals with religious orders also said it had cleared an additional 25 American nuns, priests and brothers who also signed the advertisement but have since made ''public declarations of adherence to Catholic doctrine on abortion.''   The two nuns under threat, Sisters Barbara Ferraro and Patricia Hussey, who work in a shelter for the homeless in Charleston, W. Va., have refused to make such a declaration.   In the announcement today, the Vatican's first formal comment since the case began, Jerome Cardinal Hamer, the prefect of the Congregation for Religious and Secular Institutes, appeared to be issuing a direct challenge to the Sisters of Notre Dame de Namur, the order to which the two nuns belong.

headline: Japan Posts Trade Surplus
abstract: Japan posted a record trade surplus in July, when unemployment also set a record, according to Government figures released today.

headline: OPTIMISM ON TAX-EXEMPTS
abstract: Despite the dearth of new financings in the tax-exempt bond market, the market is far from moribund. Investment bankers are confident that investor demand will not be badly damaged under the proposed Federal tax bill and that new financings will be readily absorbed when activity rebounds later this year.   Because yields of tax-exempt issues rose earlier this year, relative to taxable bond yields, many analysts agree with Aaron Gurwitz, an economist at Salomon Brothers Inc., who said the reduced supply of new tax-exempt issues and the elimination of other tax shelters and income deductions ''should translate into an improvement in the relative value of long-term municipals.''   The municipal market will still be vulnerable to fluctuations in the demand for tax-exempt bond interest from casualty insurance companies, but on balance ''it is apparent that tax-exempt securities remain attractive investments for individuals and for property-casualty insurers,'' the Salomon analyst concluded. Impact of A.M.T.  According to a recent study by Kidder, Peabody & Company, the proposed alternative minimum income tax for individuals, which would tax interest on some kinds of nonessential function local government bonds issued after Aug. 7, ''may not be as negative as was initially thought.'' Bonds defined as nonessential in the tax bill include those for housing, industrial development and student loans.

headline: GORBACHEV PRODS U.S. ON ARMS OFFER
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev accused the United States today of ignoring Soviet peace overtures and of coercing the Western European allies to spurn Soviet arms control proposals.   Mr. Gorbachev's speech, at a Polish party congress, contained some of the strongest criticism of the United States since the Soviet Union began issuing arms control initiatives early this year.   ''The cause of disarmament has not been advanced by a single millimeter because of the American Administration's open obstruction,'' he said.   ''Worse, Washington is destroying the remaining constraints containing the arms race - the SALT II treaty and other Soviet-American agreements. American officials are not short on eloquent statements about their desire for peace and disarmament, but they are doing just the opposite.''

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Bank of New York Co. has elected Harold E. Sells as a director of the company and of its subsidiary, the Bank of New York, Mr. Sells is president and chief operating officer of F. W. Woolworth Co.    * Imperial Schrade Corp., a maker of pocket knives, hunting knives, kitchen cutlery and gadgets, has elected Walter A. Gardiner president and chief executive.

headline: The U.N. Today; July 1, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Commission on International Trade Law - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: G.M.A.C. Obligations Offer Monthly Payment
abstract: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is offering $400 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through First Boston Corporation with several unusual features, including monthly payments of principal and interest.   In the past, publicly offered issues of collateralized mortgage obligations have paid interest and principal quarterly or semiannually. Although the delay between the time when mortgage payments are received and the time when they are issued to investors was costly and inconvenient, it was recommended by tax attorneys as a way of showing that the issuer retained an interest in the collateral for the financing.

headline: Twistee Treat
abstract: The Twistee Treat Corporation said it had agreed with Metro Treat Inc. to develop up to 400 new Twistee Treat stores in the New York metropolitan area. Twistee Treat said it would receive $1 million as a nonrefundable performance deposit and 30 stores must be opened in the first year, followed by 50 a year for the next seven years in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Twistee Treat is an operator and franchiser of ice cream stores in Florida.

headline: DOREMUS ADDS RICHARD WEINER
abstract: Doremus & Company, the corporate and financial advertising and public relations subsidiary of BBDO International Inc., said yesterday that it had acquired Richard Weiner Inc., another public relations concern. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: MOROCCO AND ISRAEL DIFFER IN ASSESSING PROGRESS AT MEETING
abstract: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel ended a 48-hour visit to Morocco tonight and said he and King Hassan II had agreed in principle to have further contacts to advance the cause of peace.   But King Hassan, in a speech to Moroccans tonight, emphasized that his talks with Mr. Peres had produced no agreements and that neither side had changed its positions.   Israeli and Moroccan officials said an official communique would be issued simultaneously in Morocco and Israel on Thursday. The one-page communique will be the first joint statement by Arab and Israeli leaders since Egypt and Israel signed a peace treaty in 1979.

headline: VIDEO GAMES, ONCE ZAPPED, IN COMEBACK
abstract: Don't look now, but here comes Pac-Man. Again. Video games, the entertainment craze blamed for everything from sore thumbs to the decline of the nation's youth, are making a comeback.   Three companies will be selling home video game machines this Christmas. Retailers that have not sold machines for two years are stocking up again. And television will soon reverberate once more to the zapping and beeping sounds of commercials about invading aliens and missile warfare. ''The fun is back,'' Atari says in the first television commercials it has made in two years.   ''It's like back to the future,'' said James H. Levy, president of Activision, a video game cartridge company that went from rags to riches to rags.

headline: THE TAX BILL OF 1986; The Impact on Compensation
abstract: If the tax bill becomes law, Robert J. Carpenter would pocket about $250,000 less from the portfolio of stock benefits he has accumulated as chairman and chief executive of a genetic engineering company.  Mr. Carpenter's portfolio is part of an incentive stock option program set up by his company, Integrated Genetics, to reward executives with benefits that would not be taxed as heavily as regular income. But under the new bill, the proceeds from selling the stock would be taxed at 28 percent rather than the 20 percent capital gains rate of the present law.  An incentive stock option program is but one type of executive compensation that would be significantly affected by the proposed tax changes. Pension plans, company savings programs, deferred compensation - all of the various ways executives are rewarded - are likely to change under the new bill.
